HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Of Ballistic Outerwear And Other Protections

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
Several months ago, an executive of a New York commercial bank began receiving telephone threats -- at home and at work -- from a disgruntled former employee. He called in Stephen D'Andrilli, president of the Guardian Group International in New York, a security company, which tapped the executive's phone and hired a bodyguard. Soon, the threats subsided.
"This is getting to be a more and more serious problem," said Mr. D'Andrilli, who would not identify the executive. "You have people who feel they have given a lot to a company and they become extremely angry when they are let go." 
 William McCarthy, a former head of the New York City Police Department's bomb squad, agrees. "If you lay people off, they may resort to violence to gain revenge," said Mr. McCarthy, now president of Threat Research Inc., a New York security management company. And former employees have the advantage of familiarity with a building's entrances, exits and general layout -- and staff routines, too.
In fact, spurred by such recent events as the Persian Gulf War and the growth of business opportunities in an unstable Eastern Europe -- as well as the American recession -- executives are increasingly looking for the expertise of the security industry.
The Security Industry Association, a Washington-based group representing companies that sell and service security equipment, reports total 1990 revenues of its members at $9.7 billion, up from $8.8 billion in 1989.
In addition to buying hardware -- ranging from computerized locks to electronic surveillance systems -- executives are rethinking their daily office routines and preparing for emergencies.
"Companies are focusing more on protecting their people, instead of their property," said Bill Zalud, editor of Security magazine, based in Des Plaines, Ill. "There's been an explosion of conferences," no pun intended, added Mr. Zalud, who estimates that the number of conferences natiowide has doubled since 1986, to nearly 500.
Indeed, Mr. McCarthy took to the podium at New York City's Javits Center recently to discuss "Bombs: A Growing Risk to Corporate America" at the annual International Security Conference and Exposition. His audience was composed primarily of executives responsible for their companies' safekeeping. Formerly known as security managers or facilities managers, they now bear loftier titles to reflect their enhanced status. "Corporate vice president for asset protection" is a current favorite.
While most bomb threats are false alarms -- for every contraption that actually explodes, the Federal Bureau of Investigation counts 50 phony alarms -- the number of real incidents is on the rise. In 1990, there were 1,300 bombings in the United States, up from 870 in 1983. A steady 20 percent or so of the targets are commercial buildings, according to statistics from Threat Research.
Among other things, Mr. McCarthy told his audience to analyze packages carefully -- grease stains can indicate a leak from explosives; a mass of stamps instead of metered postage can mean the sender didn't want the package weighed and checked at a post office. "If you think somebody has sent you a bomb, there are four rules to follow," he said: "Don't touch it, don't move it, don't wet it, don't open it." Call security people at the company or the police.
Bombs aside, there are the risks of kidnapping and extortion, rare in this country, but not so rare overseas. "When a top executive travels, you have to make sure everything is protected -- the planes, the cars, the hotels," said Mr. D'Andrilli of the Guardian Group. "Ideally, you go through his itinerary, and check each destination out."
Eastern Europe, while hardly as threatening an environment as, say, the Middle East, is not at all like London or Paris. "There isn't an effective internal response system yet for Westerners who encounter security difficulties," said John Horn, a managing director at Kroll Associates, a New York security consulting firm.
Some executives seem to be taking extreme measures. Hugh Downe Jr., president of American Body Armor and Equipment, a Fernandina Beach, Fla., maker of bulletproof clothing, reports brisk sales of a $500 "executive vest," which can be custom-produced in various fabrics. The company also sells ballistic outerwear, such as the $1,000 London Fog raincoat lined with Kevlar -- a bulletproof fiber developed by DuPont -- that Mayor David Dinkins bought last year.
While most executives don't require such gear, there are instances where it may come in handy. In 1985, the chairman of Deak Perera, the New York foreign exchange firm, was fatally shot at his desk by an irate customer. In 1990, the head of Germany's Deutschebank was assassinated near his office. This summer, two gunmen from an ultranationalist Japanese organization took a Nomura manager hostage in Tokyo.
"Shootings aren't common in offices, but they do happen," Mr. Downe said. He won't reveal the names of any customers who purchased the "executive vest" -- for security reasons, of course -- but describes them as "high-profile" types: "They're the kind of people whose fear of violence is heightened when the international situation is unstable."
Back home, there is also the growing market for supplying countermeasures when community activists, outraged by a company's social or environmental policies, start in with bomb threats. "These people aren't really going to blow up your offices," Mr. McCarthy said. "But they are going to wreak havoc, by making hundreds of people evacuate the premises. By the time they get back to their desks, they're ready to pack it in and call it a day."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
'Insider' -- an International Positive

BYLINE: By JUDITH N. SHAPIRO; Judith N. Shapiro is manager of government issues at the General Electric Company.

 BODY:
The stock market scandals in the United States and Japan have given a bad name to insiders, but in most countries being an insider is still the only way to do business. Companies that fail to establish themselves as "home players" in the foreign markets they want to penetrate never succeed there.
Now, the unprecedented movement toward open markets in Europe -- both East and West -- as well as in Asia and Latin America, is creating a rare opportunity for American companies to become insiders in countries where they once were disadvantaged. As nations from Mexico to Hungary, Germany to Japan, try to remove trade barriers and create more equal conditions for competition, smart American companies -- big and small, in any number of industries -- can finally challenge long-entrenched domestic companies in their own markets. 
 To do so, Americans should first make sure they know the foreign market from the inside out, positioning themselves to take immediate advantage of any political changes that could affect trade or the way business is conducted. It will not do you any good if trade barriers are removed and a competitor beats you into the market with a better product. The longer the foreign market has been closed, the more likely it is that companies are working with dated, incomplete or incorrect information. Insist on good information, preferably from in-country experts.
With this in hand, work to influence change from the inside out, aligning yourself with those in the country who seek economic and political freedom. The process of change is always messy and never risk-free. But the aternative -- alignment with a crumbling status quo -- is ruinous.
By aligning yourself with the forces of change, you stand the best chance to reap the benefits of that change. Companies outside the establishment in their home markets have a shared interest with you in changing the rules of the game. It may seem counterintuitive to build insider status by aligning with outsiders. But such unconventional business alliances make good sense when the status quo is under attack and the influence of established competitors is being challenged by economic and political reforms aimed at making markets more competitive. You can position yourself to become part of the new insider networks as internal lines of power and influence are redrawn.
Influencing change from the inside out is best done in tandem with efforts to lobby Washington -- directly, or through trade associations or industry advisory groups -- to remove barriers to trade.
Your company should also participate as a "home player" in policy debates in the countries where you want to do business. American-style lobbying is usually inappropriate, but foreign governments are increasingly in need of technical advice to execute economic reforms and have begun to establish private-sector advisory groups for that purpose.
Building insider status takes time and effort. Savvy companies used to work within the status quo overseas, arranging special deals and using trade barriers to their own advantage. No more. Savvy companies are the ones aligned with the forces of reform -- the ones turning themselves into the new insiders.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
* Joseph E. Seagram & Sons., New York, is offering $200 million in debentures due in 2011 at 99.212 to yield 8.96 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co.. The noncallable debentures have an 8 7/8 percent coupon and are rated A-2 by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and A by Moody's Investors Service Inc.
* Viacom Inc., New York, priced $200 million in 10-year senior subordinated debentures through Goldman, Sachs & Co. to yield 10.25 percent. Noncallable, the issue received a Ba-3 rating from Moody's and a B+ from S.& P.
 

Common Stock
* Horace Mann Educators Corp., Springfield, Ill., an insurance holding company, has filed for 13 million common shares in an initial public offering. The proceeds will be used to reduce debt. The First Boston Corp. and Lehman Brothers are the managing underwriters.
 
Ratings
* Connecticut's general-obligation bonds were downgraded by S.& P. from AA to AA-, and the rating agency also assigned an AA- rating to the state's approaching issue of $690.7 million in economic recovery notes.
* First Interstate Bancorp, Los Angeles, and its affiliates were put on credit watch by S.& P. after the company announced that it expected a third-quarter loss. The company currently has a BBB+ rating for its senior debt.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is limited to offerings of three- and six-month bills totaling $21.2 billion today, and $12.5 billion of one-year bills on Thursday.
By late in the day Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 5.16 percent, and the six-month bill at 5.20 percent. For the outstanding one-year bill, the bid was 5.23 percent.

HEADLINE: Egypt Wants Powerful Central Bank

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Egyptian Government, confronting the second big scandal in the nation's financial industry in less than three years, is planning to give its central bank sweeping new powers to regulate the industry for the first time in two decades.
Egyptian officials described the new regulations, which will be put before Parliament in a few weeks, as an effort to build up the capital base of the country's banks and monitor their activities. 
 The move to tighten Government control comes in the wake of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal. The Egyptian branch of the bank, Bank of Credit and Commerce Egypt, has about $400 million invested in B.C.C.I. It is unclear how many other Egyptian banks invested money in B.C.C.I. or how much.
Many bankers say regulation has been long overdue in Eqypt.
"The Goverment had to do something to restore the trust in the banking sector," said Hamed al-Sayeh, a former Minister of Economy.
 
Deep-Seated Banking Problems
 The country's banking sector was teetering on the edge of ruin until earlier this year when half of the country's foreign debt, about $25 billion, was canceled and the remaining payments rescheduled by international lending agencies. The move was made to reward Egypt for its support during the Persian Gulf war. The United States also forgave $7 billion in Egypt's military debts.
But the causes of the problems are deep seated. State banks have often been unable to retrieve loans made to the public sector. Meanwhile, private banks, whose cash flow has often depended on remittances from Egyptians working in gulf nations, are frequently manned by poorly trained personnel who at times engage in questionable financial practices, according to bankers here.
The Government had to inject $600 million into four state-owned banks earlier this year to shore them up and is now trying to cope with the collapse of several investment houses in the last three years. The investment houses, little more than pyramid schemes, wiped out more than $500 million in savings by thousands of Egyptians, many of them of modest means.
 
'Egypt's Last Chance'
 Medhat Bakri, an economist, said of the current predicament, "There is no doubt now that this is Egypt's last chance, and if we let it slip through our hands it will wreak economic ruin for generations to come."
The new regulations, part of the financial reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund, would allow the central bank to veto the appointment of banking executives or official auditors. The central bank would be authorized to force banks that appear to be short of cash to increase their capital base or face liquidation or merger. All banks would have to meet a capital-to-assets ratio for the first time.
 
A Run on the B.C.C.I. Branch
 The law would prohibit banks from lending more than a quarter of their assets to any one client or to own more than a quarter of the shares of any company.
The industry will have five years to meet these stipulations.
The central bank would also act as a general shareholder of the four leading state-run banks, the National Bank of Egypt, Banque du Caire, the Bank of Alexandria and Banque Misr, which together account for about 60 percent of the country's banking activity.
The latest jolt to the banking industry came in July, when Egyptian investors made a run on the B.C.C.I. branch after the scandal enveloped the parent company. The investors withdrew dollars and Eqyptian pounds worth a combined total of $29.4 million.
Subsequently, withdrawals were limited to $1,000 and 3,000 Egyptian pounds (about $900) for each depositor.
The Egyptian branch, 49 percent of which is controlled by B.C.C.I. and the remainder by individual Egyptian investors, has been taken over by a Government administrator and will change its name.
The country's remaining banks, all state-owned or jointly run enterprises, will place five-tenths of 1 percent of their dollar and Egyptian pound holdings with the B.C.C.I. branch to stave off collapse.
 
Prelude to Deposit Insurance
 The stop-gap measure to save the B.C.C.I. branch bank is the prelude, Egyptian officials say, to the country's first deposit-insurance program.
Banks will be required under the law to contribute one-quarter of 1 percent of their holdings to a fund, managed by the central bank, to bail out any other banks that go under in the future.
"One of the positive effects of the B.C.C.I. affair in Egypt is the introduction of, hopefully, a deposit insurance," said Keith Holt, the chief executive of the joint-venture Hong Kong Egyptian Bank. "The other effect, hopefully, will be a strengthening of the monitoring and regulatory role by the authorities."

HEADLINE: Auditing The Auditors -- A special Report.;
How B.C.C.I.'s Accounts Won Stamp of Approval

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
In the spring of 1990, relations between the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and its auditor were badly strained. In a confidential report to the directors of the troubled bank on April 18, 1990, Price Waterhouse expressed its mounting concern about several matters of the "utmost urgency." They included a pile of troubled loans to customers, suspect lending to shareholders and transactions that Price Waterhouse said were "either false or deceitful."
Price Waterhouse told the directors that it had tried to identify all the fraudulent transactions. But, the auditor added, "It is impossible, without an exhaustive inquiry, to know whether this has been achieved." 
 Yet less than two weeks later, on April 30, 1990, Price Waterhouse signed B.C.C.I.'s annual report for 1989, attesting that the accounts gave a "fair and true view of the financial position of the group." The annual report made no mention of false or deceitful transactions or the auditor's other worries.
 
New Light on Role
 Public records, some previously undisclosed documents and interviews with key figures and experts in international banking shed critical new light on the role of Price Waterhouse in the B.C.C.I. case. The accounting firm was eventally instructed by the Bank of England to investigate the shady bank, and its report in June prompted the decision by regulators on July 5 to seize B.C.C.I.
The regulators assert the bank had conducted fraud on a multibillion-dollar scale, using phony loans, phantom deposits and false accounting, starting more than a decade ago. In the United States, based on investigations by Government prosecutors and the Federal Reserve, the bank has been charged with laundering the illicit funds of international drug barons and accused of secretly purchasing American banks.
The documents and interviews show that in its years as B.C.C.I.'s auditor, Price Waterhouse among other things failed to check on the absence of payments on loans that were part of the fraud and missed an opportunity in 1986 to uncover huge losses on trading in financial futures and options that the bank was hiding. When Price Waterhouse became the bank's sole auditor in 1987, it received an unusual warning about the weakness in the bank's management and financial controls from another accounting firm.
The decision by Price Waterhouse to give unqualified approval to the bank's last public annual report -- despite the clear signs of trouble -- has come under scrutiny by Government investigators, lawyers representing depositors and accounting experts.
Price Waterhouse insists that it acted properly and points out that the British Government has praised the firm for the work it did.
But Robin Munro-Davies, managing director of IBCA Ltd., a bank-rating agency based in London, commented: "At the outset, I figured that Price Waterhouse was grossly misled and was not derelict itself. But I'm less and less convinced of that now."
Ian Brindle, senior partner of Price Waterhouse in London, declined to be interviewed for this article. But on the matter of declaring the annual report "fair and true," he told The Financial Times in July, "You simply can't go around qualifying the accounts of a bank without creating all sorts of problems, without the whole thing collapsing." In accounting terms, "qualifying" the bank's accounts would have meant spelling out the auditor's findings and its concerns. Better, Price Waterhouse figured, to work quietly with the regulators to try to repair the damage and avoid the risk of scaring depositors into pulling their money out.
Price Waterhouse in the United States, for its part, says its London office did most of the work on the B.C.C.I. audit and signed its financial statements. Price Waterhouse worldwide, it explains, is a network of 26 separate but related firms. Shaun F. O'Malley, the senior partner in the United States, said in a statement that the firm's London office "has assured us that the work of Price Waterhouse professionals was in accordance with applicable professional standards."
 
Suits Against Waterhouse
 Lawsuits by depositors' charging Price Waterhouse with gross negligence have been filed in Britain, and more are expected. A Senate subcommittee plans to call Price Waterhouse to testify at hearings to explain its role.
"It's obvious that people who relied on Price Waterhouse-approved audits were misled," said Jonathan Winer, an investigator for the Senate subcommittee on terrorism, narcotics and international operations.
Though Price Waterhouse defends its stance, accounting experts contend that the auditor's decision to approve B.C.C.I.'s financial statements while it was uncertain about the magnitude of the fraud was a serious and damaging error in judgment.
"An auditor should not approve the accounts without knowing the extent of the fraud," said Lee J. Seidler, an accounting expert and a special associate director of Bear, Stearns & Company. "But Price Waterhouse appears to have signed a set of accounts without knowing how deep the hole was."
 
The Task
Accounting Firm Faces a Challenge
 The task of trying to audit B.C.C.I. was a formidable challenge. The sprawling private bank had assets of $20 billion and offices in 69 countries. It was chartered in one tax-and-regulatory haven, Luxembourg, and had vital operations in another, the Cayman Islands. Moreover, clues to much of the fraud were in 6,000 secret files kept by the former chief executive, Swaleh Naqvi, who has been indicted in the United States on fraud and money-laundering charges and is being held in Abu Dhabi.
According to standard auditing doctrine, the main responsibility for detecting fraud rests with the management of a company or bank. The auditor's responsibility is to conduct its work so that it has a "reasonable expectation" of detecting sizable misstatements in a company's financial accounts.
In March, Price Waterhouse was told by the Bank of England to plumb the depths of the B.C.C.I. fraud. Under English law, the British central bank, which has supervisors but no American-style examiners, can delegate a bank's reporting accountant to conduct investigations, though it rarely does so.
 
Report Prompted Closing
 The resulting Price Waterhouse report on June 22, 1991, describing "an enormous and complex web of fictitious transactions" prompted the closing of B.C.C.I. less than two weeks later. Robin Leigh-Pemberton, the governor of the Bank of England, told a parliamentary committee that Price Waterhouse worked "promptly and effectively throughout the whole of this matter."
Still, the auditor's critics say that over the years it too readily accepted the assurances of the B.C.C.I. management and moved too slowly in addressing problems within the bank.
Some critics suggest Price Waterhouse was reluctant to antagonize a lucrative client that one former bank executive said paid audit fees of more than $3 million a year. But accounting experts reply that a $3 million fee would not have been high for a bank with the sprawl and complexity of B.C.C.I. The real issue, these experts say, may have been whether the fees were enough for Price Waterhouse to make a profit without cutting corners on such a difficult audit.
 
A Warning
Large Losses Are Discovered

When Price Waterhouse became the sole auditor in 1987, it was aware of the difficulties of handling B.C.C.I. For more than a decade, it had audited B.C.C.I. Overseas in the Caymans, where confidential customer accounts with scant record-keeping were the norm. The Price Waterhouse office in the Caymans was the auditor for an even more secretive affiliate, the International Credit and Investment Company Overseas, which a Federal Reserve report termed the alter ego of the bank. Before 1987, Ernst & Whinney had audited BCCI Holdings S.A., the Luxembourg parent company for the group.
In 1986, Ernst & Whinney formally expressed its concern to the management of B.C.C.I. after it was discovered that the bank's London treasury operation had incurred large losses in trading financial futures and options. The treasury was run from London but most transactions were recorded in the Caymans, where Price Waterhouse handled the audit work.
In a letter dated May 29, 1986, Ernst & Whinney wrote to the bank's founder and president, Aga Hassan Abedi, stressing the need for "marked improvement" in management controls and expressing its concern that because the auditing duties were split between two firms Ernst & Whinney was kept at a distance from crucial documents, according to a former B.C.C.I. executive who has a copy of the letter.
 
Asked for Sole Role
 Ernst & Whinney said it would be inappropriate to withdraw for 1986 but declared that it would not be an auditor for 1987 unless B.C.C.I. agreed to make it the sole auditor and to strengthen its management.
By the following spring, little had changed. On April 13, 1987, Ernst & Whinney, as it was finishing its review of the bank's 1986 financial statements, wrote to Mr. Naqvi, the bank's chief executive. It reiterated the need for a stronger management team, improved financial controls and the oversight of a single auditor.
"The problem will not be eased by further delay," the letter stated, according to the former bank official. About a week later, the B.C.C.I. board met and appointed Price Waterhouse as its sole auditor. Shortly afterward Ernst & Whinney passed the two letters to Price Waterhouse.
Another former bank executive, Masihur Rahman, who has cooperated with American investigators, says Price Waterhouse was selected because Mr. Abedi and Mr. Naqvi did not want Ernst & Whinney prying into the files in the Caymans. "Price Waterhouse took a soft and gentle approach, and they did not want to upset that," Mr. Rahman said.
Price Waterhouse says it cannot give a detailed account of its handling of the B.C.C.I. audit, citing client confidentiality. Sue Hurley, the firm's spokeswoman in London, vigorously denied Mr. Rahman's view that Price Waterhouse was lax in reviewing the bank's Cayman accounts. "He has misrepresented the facts," Ms. Hurley said.
 
An Inquiry
A Closer Look By Luxembourg

When the losses from the London treasury operations became apparent in late 1985, the Luxembourg regulators demanded a review of the problem. B.C.C.I. management asked Price Waterhouse in the Caymans to handle the review, which in turn requested assistance from the firm's London office. The inquiry found that significant losses had gone unrecorded and said this was a result of incompetence, not fraud.
But in its June 1991 report to the Bank of England that led to the closing of B.C.C.I., Price Waterhouse stated, "With the benefit of hindsight, it appears more sinister in that it now seems to have been a deliberate way to fictitiously inflate income." The firm did not examine the accounting for previous years because losses were not apparent from the accounts. "Again, with hindsight," the June report added, "we now know that such losses were being concealed." From 1977 through 1985, the total of losses and fictitious profits from the treasury operations was estimated at nearly $1 billion.
"Price Waterhouse seems to have accepted at face value the numbers from the previous years even though they found improper accounting for 1985," said Clive Russell, deputy senior partner of Halpern & Woolf, a London accountant representing depositors.
By early 1990, it was apparent to the auditors and regulators that B.C.C.I. had severe financial problems. A task force of four bank executives, headed by Mr. Rahman, was to review B.C.C.I.'s problem loans. It worked with Price Waterhouse on the inquiry, which graphically portrayed how scant was the reporting and documentation on large loans and how little checking had been done by the management or auditors.
 
Loan Is an Example
 A $150 million loan to Abdul Raouf Khalil, a wealthy Saudi Arabian businessman, is a striking example. Mr. Khalil was one of the front men used by B.C.C.I. to buy control secretly of First American Bankshares in Washington and the National Bank of Georgia, in violation of American banking laws. The task force report states, "The review of this loan makes really sorry reading, and the task force feels that P. W. should have sought better clarification and documentary proofs in earlier years."
A briefing paper for the task force, supplied by Price Waterhouse on March 14, 1990, stated that nothing had been paid on five years of interest and principal, an amount totaling at least $45 million, and that the bank had had no contact with Mr. Khalil during that period. Investigators charge that front men like Mr. Khalil were given money, disguised as loans, to buy First American on behalf of B.C.C.I.
Asked about the Khalil loan, Price Waterhouse officials declined to comment specifically, but noted that most international banks have "hold mail" accounts, in which statements are not mailed to an account holder with a penchant for privacy, and auditors rely on the assurances of management.
Yet a banking expert at a leading American accounting firm says that hold-mail accounts tend to be treated with skepticism by auditors and that efforts should be made to push for some evidence of periodic contact with the account holder, like having him sign statements when he comes into the bank in person to handle a transaction. Besides, the accountant added, hold-mail accounts are typically deposit accounts, not huge loan customers like Mr. Khalil.
 
The Questions
An Increasing Number of Critics

Price Waterhouse has two explanations for its decision to approve B.C.C.I.'s yearly financial statements as "true and fair" in April 1990. First, the firm points to a note to the 1989 annual report saying that the Government of Abu Dhabi took a 77 percent stake in the bank and pledged to "maintain the group's capital base while the reorganization and restructuring necessary for its continuing development is undertaken." That note, Price Waterhouse says, was a warning that the bank had serious problems.
The second explanation is that Price Waterhouse did not want to spell out the bank's problems and the auditor's worries in the annual report because it feared that might provoke a run by depositors.
"They knew they were dealing with a can of worms, and they fudged the issue," said Hugh Aldous, senior partner of Robson Rhodes, a London accounting firm. "By defining their responsibilities narrowly, Price Waterhouse let the whole problem go on longer and probably with greater damage than would have been the case otherwise."
The Government of Abu Dhabi and its ruler, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, apparently came to share that view. On Dec. 24, 1990, an internal committee was formed to pursue the bank's troubles. Abu Dhabi's Government insisted that a second accounting firm be added, and it hired Ernst & Young (formed in 1989, when Ernst & Whinney merged with Arthur Young). "By then, the Abu Dhabi shareholders clearly wanted an independent perspective," said Caffey Norman, a partner of Patton, Boggs & Blow, a Washington law firm representing the Abu Dhabi interests.
 
Loss of Life Savings
 Mohammed Khasruzzaman, an Omani businessman, deposited $300,000 with B.C.C.I. in London on Aug. 7, 1990, just after Iraq invaded Kuwait, and another $300,000 on Jan. 17, 1991, after the start of the gulf war. Mr. Khasruzzaman said he was concerned about keeping his life savings in Oman at a time of great turmoil in the gulf, and B.C.C.I. had branches in both Oman and London.
Before depositing his funds with B.C.C.I., he says he asked to see a copy of the bank's most recent annual report, for 1989, and took comfort from the unqualified opinion from Price Waterhouse. Last month, the 36-year-old Omani and his wife sued Price Waterhouse for negligence in London. "It's clear that the auditors knew about the fraud when they signed the B.C.C.I. accounts," Mr. Khasruzzaman said. "And that was not clearly spelled out in the annual report. I lost my life's savings."

HEADLINE: Compaq to Show Computers

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation plans to introduce four computers on Monday with several parts that can be replaced when more advanced versions of those parts are produced.
Three new machines that use Intel's more powerful 80486 computer chip are priced from $3,199 to $7,199, offering a wide range of speed and memory. Three versions of the fourth machine, which has an 80386 chip, are priced below $4,000. 
 The company will also announce price reductions of $1,000 on three models using the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor, bringing the retail price on Compaq's basic 386 machine below $3,000 for the first time.
The moves are Compaq's response to inroads made earlier this year by Dell Computer, AST Research and other lower-priced rivals whose machine designs permit customers to plug in more powerful microprocessors when faster versions are produced.
At a news conference scheduled for Monday in New York, Compaq will display replaceable design features for video; memory; input-output, or how information enters and leaves the machne; the internal data links of the computer, known as bus wiring, and for the Intel microprocessors.
The four new machines are in production and their sales have been booked for the third quarter, which ends in two weeks. Lorie Strong, Compaq's vice president for product marketing, said the company had demonstrated the machines to about 70 large buyers, including companies that had bought other brands.
"We went to accounts where the new machines might cannibalize somebody else's sales," she said. "That was part of the criteria."
 
Scrambling for Momentum
 Compaq is scrambling to generate sales momentum. Revenues at the Houston-based company have been virtually flat this year, a casualty of stiff competition, recession and troubles in its distribution channels. On May 15, its stock price fell 27 percent, to $36, on gloomy profit news. The stock closed Friday at $33.875, off 50 cents.
Ms. Strong said the new machines would make Compaq more competitive in the $2,500 to $3,500 price range, where sales for desktop machines have been strongest this year.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Is Surging Again After a Period of Difficulties

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS

 BODY:
After a hiccup caused by low oil prices and a shift to free-market policies, Venezuela has reclaimed its position as the nation in the Americas with the highest economic growth rates.
The gross national product, which grew 5 percent in 1990, expanded by an annualized rate of 10 percent during the first half of this year, according to figures released here in late August. 
 Memories are now fading of 1989, the rough first year of President Carlos Andres Perez. That year, the economy shrank by 8 percent and a reduction of food and gas subsidies set off riots that killed 300 people.
"We are back to the fastest-growing economy in the region," said Andres Sosa Pietri, president of Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A., the national oil company. "We lagged in the '80s, but now we are back on our feet."
Michael Skol, the United States Ambassador here, predicted, "Venezuela is likely to have a sustained economic boom in the 1990's, with growth rates higher than Chile's."
Although annual inflation continues to hover around 37 percent, optimism is growing. American, European and Venezuelan companies are embarking on multibillion-dollar "megaprojects" involving Venezuela's highly profitable oil and minerals.
And President Perez's determined commitment to free-market policies appears to be bearing fruit, as trade tariffs drop, investment rules ease and the Government starts to sell money-losing state companies to investors.
In early August, the Government accepted a $145 million bid by a consortium led by Iberia, the Spanish airline, to buy a 60 percent stake in the state-owned international airline, Viasa. In October, private companies are to bid for the state telephone company, whose inefficiency has long hampered the economy.
During a visit to New York and Washington scheduled for late September, Mr. Perez plans to discuss with United States officials a timetable for establishing a free-trade agreement. Since taking office in February 1989, Mr. Perez has reduced import tariffs to 10 percent, on average, from 34 percent. In April, Venezuela signed a framework agreement with the United States for trade and investment liberalization.
Leading a Congressional delegation to Caracas in late August, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, said Mr. Perez had shown "great leadership in opening markets and in helping to develop trade between our two great countries."
 
A 'Safe Source' of Oil
 Accounting for about half the growth forecast through 1996 is a five-year, $48 billion expansion program by the national oil company.
Venezuela ships two-thirds of its daily exports of 1.9 million barrels to the United States. With oil production plummeting in the Soviet Union and political uncertainty gripping the Middle East, Venezuela likes to portray itself as a "safe source." To meet growing demand from the United States, the oil company plans to increase production capacity by 20 percent, to 3.5 million barrels a day, by 1996.
Foreign companies are entering new areas of the petroelum industry. In November, about 20 American and foreign companies are expected to submit bids to reactivate marginal fields that have been abandoned in eastern Venezuela. Total predicted production of these fields is expected to be 150,000 barrels a day.
 
Natural Gas Project
 In another project, Government approval is expected later this year for a $3 billion natural gas processing plant to be built with multinational control. Called Cristobal Colon, the project involves Mitsubishi, Shell Oil and Exxon.
"It will be the first time since the nationalization of the oil industry in 1975 that foreigners will have majority equities," said Mr. Skol, the American Ambassador.
The national oil company is also negotiating with American and European companies on multibillion-dollar joint ventures to exploit Venezuela's vast coal and bitumen reserves.
After the privatization of only three banks in two and a half years, efforts to sell state companies appear to have accelerated with the sale of Viasa in August. Fondo de Inversiones de Venezuela, a state agency charged with privatization, is accepting bids for a number of state companies -- a shipyard, a cement company, four hotels and several sugar mills.
But the most keenly awaited sale is that of the telephone company.
With half of Venezuela's demand for three million lines going unmet, it takes eight years to get a telephone installed. Some offices employ secretaries simply to dial and redial numbers. One United States company, Procter & Gamble, gave up and installed a $150,000 private microwave system after moving here in 1987, and other companies have shied away from Venezuela because of weak telecommunications.
"There are a lot of projects in tourism, trade and industry asking for services we can't offer," said Fernando Martinez Mottola, president of the phone company, Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela.
 
Winning a $98 Million Bid
 In a first step to privatize telephone service, a consortium led by BellSouth Enterprises and Racal Telecom submitted a winning $98 million bid in May to provide 20 years of cellular telephone service.
In October, eight international consortiums are to bid on buying the phone company, which has 20,000 employees, a $600 million debt and enormous growth prospects.
According to the tender, the buyer will have to install an average of 300,000 lines a year over the next five years, and by the end of the 1990's, the wait for a new phone must be no more than a week.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The nation's large life insurers have quietly begun exploring the establishment of a giant emergency fund that could provide short-term assistance to cash-strapped companies. The fund, which would be financed by the insurers, would probably be modeled after the Fed's lending program for distressed banks. [Page D1.] 
 Retailers, bankers and other executives say they are hopeful that lower interest rates will stimulate spending by making borrowing more affordable. But many other executives said they thought consumers would not begin spending more until layoffs subside and Americans feel more secure. [D1.]
The space agency is reluctantly shelving plans for large spacecraft in favor of ones that are relatively small and simple. [A1.]
Supervisors of some of the largest public forests say they have come under intense political pressure to cut more timber than the land can afford to give up. [A1.]
 
Companies
Price Waterhouse's decision to give unqualified approval to B.C.C.I.'s last public annual report -- despite clear signs of trouble -- has come under scrutiny by investigators, lawyers representing depositors and accounting experts. Documents and interviews show that in its years as B.C.C.I.'s auditor, the firm failed to check on the absence of payments on loans and missed an opportunity to uncover huge trading losses the bank was hiding. [A1.] India's Finance Minister said he would ask intelligence agencies to investigate charges that B.C.C.I. laundered money from India and maintained close contacts with drug barons. [D8.]
S. G. Warburg disclosed details of its relationship with Salomon, portraying itself as a victim in the Treasury scandal. [D7.]
Compaq introduces four computers today with parts that can be replaced when more advanced versions are produced. [D4.]
 
International
The dominant themes at Frankfurt's international auto show, where car makers usually flaunt speed, styling and technical wizardry, have been environmental consciousness and safety. [D1.]
Honda's American subsidiary says it received "verbal approval" to ship U.S.-made Accord station wagons to France. The Japanese may also have won an important symbolic victory to the extent that U.S. officials were willing to argue Honda's case. [D1.]
Venezuela has reclaimed its position as the nation in the Americas with the highest economic growth rate. [D1.]
Egypt plans to give its central bank sweeping new powers to regulate the financial industry. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
The new television season has begun, but the annual ratings race is less intense than usual. That is because ABC, one of the three main competitors, says it does not matter who wins. [D1.]
Gannett's purchase of five daily papers in the Washington suburbs has prompted a challenge to the company's license to operate WUSA-TV, a CBS affiliate based in Washington. [D11.]
Resurrection is evidently in the air these days for financial magazines, and new publications are even in the works. [D11.]
The fall fashion magazines are still fat, alluring and revealing, even in these lean advertising times. Ad Scene. [10.]
Redbook's new trade campaign is redefining the audience of the women's magazine. Instead of "jugglers," Redbook readers are now seen as "squeezers." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Israeli Loan Dispute Turns Ugly; Rightist Calls Bush 'Anti-Semite'

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Israel's bitter confrontation with the White House over United States loan guarantees turned nastier today when a Cabinet minister called President Bush an anti-Semite and a liar and the Government vowed that there would be no retreat on its request for American aid.
The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, later repudiated the attack on Mr. Bush by his fellow Cabinet member, Rehavam Zeevi, a minister without portfolio from a far-right party. Mr. Arens said that Mr. Zeevi's remarks did not reflect the Government's view or Israeli public opinion. 
 Nonetheless, the vehemence of the language underlined the multilayered passions that have been set loose here by the dispute over the loan guarantees. Valued at $10 billion, the guarantees would be used by Israel to help resettle hundreds of thousands of new immigrants from the Soviet Union.
 
Baker's Visit Begins Monday
 It seems inevitable that the issue will be one of the first to be dealt with on Monday, when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrives here to try to kick-start the faltering American initiative to arrange a Middle East peace conference for next month.
The main obstacle to peace talks has been the seemingly irreconcilable differences between Israel and Palestinian leaders over which Palestinians will be allowed to attend. But before he tries to bridge that gap, Mr. Baker must deal with a sudden rupture in United States-Israeli relations over the loan guarantees, a split that Abba Eban, one of Israel's elder statesmen, said today was the worst that he could remember in 40 years.
Senior officials said they hoped that Mr. Baker would offer a face-saving compromise that could accommodate Israel's desire for immediate aid and Mr. Bush's adamant position that allowing a debate on the guarantees now would undermine the peace process.
 
Israelis Reluctant to Wait
 Mr. Bush has insisted that Congress delay action on the Israeli request by 120 days, and has warned that he would use his veto to block any early decision on the matter. For their part, the Israelis say there is no point in waiting because Mr. Bush has given no sign that he would support the requested aid even after the 120 days.
Their fear is that the President would continue to use the guarantees as "a cudgel," in the words of one official, to keep pressing them on the subject that lies at the heart of the fight: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's insistence on, and Mr. Bush's strong opposition to, expanded Israeli settlement in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
But Mr. Shamir's advisers also fear a head-on collision with the United States, Israel's main ally and the source of $3 billion a year in regular economic and military aid. "The last thing we wanted was a confrontation with the Administration and, God forbid, with the President himself," one said.
 
U.S. Groups Urge Compromise
 Leaders of Jewish organizations in the United States are understood to have advised Mr. Shamir to accept a compromise, and a senior official here said that the Government was willing to do so. But the Prime Minister made it clear that the initiative would have to come from the Americans.
"We will not retreat -- we will stick by our position," officials quoted him as saying at a Cabinet meeting today.
But he also urged his ministers to "calm the atmosphere and watch our words" after Mr. Zeevi asserted at the meeting that Mr. Bush was an anti-Semite and a liar for supposedly misrepresenting Israel's stand on loan guarantees.
Mr. Zeevi is one of two members of Parliament from Moledet, a right-wing party that wants Palestinians out of the territories that Israel has occupied since 1967. His appointment this year as a minister without portfolio caused a political storm, with even some members of Mr. Shamir's Likud Party complaining about letting a person with such views join the Government.
Mr. Zeevi's attack on Mr. Bush was reported outside the closed session by one of his own aides, who said that the minister also accused the President of "cheap demagoguery." But, perhaps chastised by Mr. Shamir's appeal for milder language, Mr. Zeevi emerged from the meeting speaking in softer tones.
 
Raising Doubts on Bush's Role
 "I said he is very close to it, to being an anti-Semite and anti-Israel," he said. His remarks at the meeting were also reported on Israel state radio.
Mr. Arens, the Defense Minister, then appeared on the ABC News program "This Week," during which he repudiated Mr. Zeevi's remarks and said they did not "reflect major opinion within the Israeli Government, or for that matter within Israel itself."
Although Mr. Zeevi's opinions may be extreme, he is not alone here in raising doubts about Mr. Bush's commitment to Israel's welfare and his ability to serve as a fair mediator at peace talks. "A lot of insecurities come to the surface here when they feel cornered," said Harry Wall, the representative in Israel of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
Mr. Shamir insists that Israel is still ready to go to the conference. But he also has warned repeatedly that by raising the issue of loan guarantees when Arab nations themselves had not done so in agreeing to peace talks, Mr. Bush has made it likely that the Arabs will toughen their demands.
A political analyst close to the Government said the Israelis might simply decide to abandon their aid request for now rather than have it "held hostage" by the Bush Administration.
 
Leftists Fault Government
 Beyond the immediate friction between Washington and Jerusalem, the dispute has unleashed other emotions.
On the political right, Parliament members who have been opposed to peace talks all along say the confrontation would justify a decision by Israel to pull out of the process entirely. On the left, politicians and press commentators say that Mr. Shamir and his Housing Minister, Ariel Sharon, brought about the crisis through a deliberately provocative policy of settlement-building.
"The friendship of the United States was one of our greatest assets during the 43 years of Israel's existence," a dozen left-leaning members of Parliament said in an open letter to Mr. Shamir that is to appear in newspapers on Monday. "Through your militant fanaticism, you may negate this asset and turn the friendly attitude of the United States to one of hostility."
"It is certainly clear," they said, "that the peace process and settlement process are opposites."
To some extent, the feelings that have been stirred also touch on Jewish consciousness.
 
Blaming American Lobbyists
 Yossi Sarid, a member of Parliament from the leftist Citizens Rights Movement, attacked American Jewish groups the other day for their campaign on behalf of the loan guarantees, an effort that Mr. Bush caustically criticized when he threatened to veto Congressional action. The lobbying effort, Mr. Sarid said, was a "vulgar mistake" that could increase anti-Israel and anti-Jewish feelings in the United States.
But Mr. Shamir sees American Jews in a different light, and has invoked memories of Nazi horrors in pressing for a strong pro-Israel campaign in Washington. American Jews "did nothing" to save European Jews from mass murder during World War II, he was quoted as telling a group of supporters in Paris on Friday.
"This hangs very heavily on their consciences," he said. "Because of this, they are now very active."

HEADLINE: The U.S.-Soviet Agenda;
Moscow's Economic Struggle Is Paramount, As Baker's Week of Talks Makes Evident

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMA-ATA, U.S.S.R., Sept. 15

 BODY:
When he was meeting in Moscow with the new K.G.B. chief, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d asked for a small favor.
Would the K.G.B., Mr. Baker asked, please help the leaders of the new Soviet economic council locate and total up all Soviet gold reserves so they could prepare an economic reform plan that the West could seriously respond to? 
 The fact that Mr. Baker was meeting with the K.G.B. boss in his office was a bizarre enough symbol of the way in which the August revolution has transformed the American-Soviet agenda. But that one of his priorities was to enlist the K.G.B. in the economic reform was even more telling.
The old agenda of American-Soviet relations was dominated by arms control and regional conflicts. Mr. Baker has spent a week here working on establishing the new agenda. He has talked with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the change-minded Mayors of St. Petersburg and Moscow, prominent intellectuals, and the leaders of all the republics, including President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan here in the Kazakh capital. And the talks have made it clear that the new agenda reads like this: Economics, economics and then more economics.
 
Quick Successes Needed
 It is not simply because the arms control slate was pretty well swept clean last year with the conventional and strategic arms treaties or because Mr. Gorbachev has been ready to throw overboard any regional conflict -- Afghanistan, Cuba, the Baltic republics and the Kurile Islands -- that might block Western economic aid.
Rather, it is because American officials are convinced that unless the Soviet economy can be improved soon all the positive changes of the past month will not be sustainable and the Soviet Union could easily revert to a boiling pot of ethnic violence, nationalist competition and reactionary lapses.
Baker aides said the overwhelming impression after the week of talks in the Soviet Union was not how radically things had changed but how much needed to be done to make those changes permanent. American officials concluded that Soviet leaders need time to prove that reform pays, but to buy time, they need some quick, concrete successes.
As a result, while the Bush Administration always felt it had a certain stake in Mr. Gorbachev's continued hold on power, American officials feel that much more intensely about the hard-core supporters of change who have moved to the top since the failed coup last month.
"The key thing that has to inform what we do is the fact that we have an enormous stake in these guys succeeding," a senior Baker aide said. "While everything we saw was striking and builds a tremendous sense of hope, it is also true that these people are talking their need to deliver and there is a danger if they don't deliver. Our policy is going to have to be shaped in a way that is designed to help them deliver."
The official added that whether it was Mr. Nazarbayev or Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak of St. Petersburg, "they have to be able to show that things can improve and that will build their authority and give them more time."
"They are consumed with a sense of urgency," he said.
Baker aides said that since the coup republic leaders they had spoken with seemed to express pragmatism about the need to maintain a degree of economic cohesion, not to mention centralized nuclear controls, even if they asserted more individual independence and identities.
Bush Administration officials have been obsessive in avoiding public statements on what they prefer for the Soviet Union in that regard.
But privately they made clear that they want at a minimum a loose confederation with a single economic space, common currency, and central bank and central fiscal and monetary policies constituting sustainable economic reform. Mr. Baker has also said no economic help is going to be feasible if the republics do not work out a coherent economic arrangement with a central decision-making body that can enforce business contracts and laws.
 
A Degree of Integration
 "When Baker talked to them about the importance of them making their own decisions, but recognizing the benefits of economic integration, it fell on fertile ground," a State Department official said. Among the intellectual architects of reform Mr. Baker heard "a desire to rein in separatist tendencies," the official said.
"Whereas before they wanted the pluralism to develop and for the center to become less weighty, now as they look at some of the outpouring of emotion and some of the impulses, many of them say, 'Let's not lose sight of the value of the center,' " the official said, using the word center to refer to the central Government.
This brings the policy makers to the challenge of the day. For some kind of center to hold, the change-minded leaders in each republic have to establish bases of support and respect, besides those based on nationalist passions.
For American policy toward the Soviet Union that means several things, Administration officials said. Their first priority, they said, will be to make sure that the Soviets get through the winter without serious food shortages and an agricultural team is already drawing up plans for that. But this must be done delicately to insure that the goods get to where they are needed and that handouts do not damage Soviet agriculture.
Also, officials said, they need to organize some projects that will demonstrate early successes while Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a leader of the Soviet transition economic team, and the republics get their economic treaty and reform package together.
"Instead of trying to green the world, we need to plant half a dozen pots," an American diplomat said.
In St. Petersburg, for instance, the official suggested establishment of a shopping street, with Soviet-owned and Western-owned stores, or maybe a new road-building project that could supply jobs and improve traffic.
Another American official said, "We need to take a reform city government, in a major city, and work with it to build a demonstration project that everyone could see."
Second, American officials said, "technical assistance" is going to have to be much more broadly defined, from simply providing economic or agricultural advice to sending American teams to do managerial and entrepreneurial training and help in the development of political institutions.
 
The Army Wants Help
 For instance, the new Defense Minister, Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, asked American officials about helping to develop a justice system for the Soviet Army so that Soviet citizens would be convinced that the laws that apply to them would also apply to the military.
But without broader free-market economic reform, technical aid can take the Soviet Union only so far. All week long, American officials stressed to their Soviet counterparts the need to agree speedily on an economic treaty and reform program approved by the International Monetary Fund that would include at a minimum contract and property rights, a macro-economic stabilization plan, price decontrols and a convertible currency.
The Americans said that the Soviets promised that the plan would come "soon," but there is still no sign of the final product.
Mr. Baker strongly hinted that as soon as the Soviets produce that plan, the United States and its allies would come up with some serious cash and credit for a stabilization fund, but he always declined to be more specific.
Mr. Baker and his aides could probably best be described as more hopeful about a Soviet transformation than before the coup, but still highly dubious.
"In the end we can't do it for them," a State Department official said. "It is trite but it is true. They have to get their act together. They have to translate the theory of what they want into reality. It all starts with them."

HEADLINE: Forest Supervisors Say Politicians Are Asking Them to Cut Too Much

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KALISPELL, Mont. Sept. 11

 BODY:
Supervisors of some of the nation's largest public forests say they have come under intense political pressure to cut more timber than the land can handle.
Already, grizzly bears and 20-pound bull trout are in trouble from excessive logging in the forests of the northern Rocky Mountains, biologists say. Now, managers of these forests say they are slowing down the Government's logging program to protect fish and wildlife. But they say they are doing so at the risk of their own jobs. 
 The timber industry, some Bush Administration officials and other politicians argue that trees on the public lands of the Northern Rockies must be logged at a certain level to keep the regional economy afloat. But the Forest Service supervisors say Western senators and Administration officials are trying to force them into unsound land stewardship to benefit the industry.
"The pressure is there, and it is intense," said Orville Daniels, supervisor of the 2.5-million-acre Lolo National Forest in Montana.
Mr. Daniels and other foresters and biologists across the nation say they are caught in a squeeze between science and politics. This week, a Congressional subcommittee began issuing subpoenas to top Forest Service officials, who are to appear at a Sept. 24 hearing, before the House Subcommittee on Civil Service, to determine whether professional land managers are being harassed.
A Federal district judge in Seattle, in issuing an injunction against logging in parts of the Northwest, spoke of "executive branch" meddling in the agencies governing the nation's public forests. The judge, William L. Dwyer, wrote on May 23 that there was "a deliberate and systematic refusal by the Forest Service and the Fish and Wildlife Serviice to comply with laws protecting wildlife."
"This is not the doing of scientists, foresters, rangers and others at working levels of these agencies," continued Judge Dwyer, who was appointed by President Reagan in 1987. "It reflects decisions made by higher authorities in the executive branch of government."
At the center of the Montana dispute is John W. Mumma, a 32-year Forest Service employee, who was forced into retirement at the age of 51 this month after Western Republican senators and timber industry executives complained that he was not allowing trees to be logged fast enough from the Rocky Mountains.
Mr. Mumma oversaw 25 million acres of public land in 13 National Forests in Montana, Idaho and the Dakotas. The first biologist to hold the job of regional forester in the Northern Rockies, he was widely regarded as a reformer, and his ouster two weeks ago is seen by some in the service as a signal that the Bush Administration is caving in to political pressure from the timber industry.
"If they get away with this, the budding reform movement in the Forest Service could be squashed," said Jeff DeBonis, founder of the Association of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics, which he said has 2,000 past and present service workers among its membership.
 
Meeting With Agriculture
 Top timber industry executives met recently with Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan, who oversees the Forest Service, and complained that Mr. Mumma was not putting enough trees up for sale. Nationwide, only 60 percent of this year's Government timber target has been met, which the Forest Service attributes to environmental appeals. It was Mr. Madigan who ordered Mr. Mumma to take a desk job in Washington this month. He refused the reassignment, and announced his retirement instead. Neither Mr. Mumma nor Mr. Madigan would comment on the move.
Susan Hess, director of public affairs for the Forest Service, said the inability of Mr. Mumma to meet the timber cut was only part of the reason for his ouster. She said his removal as regional forester was not an attempt to stifle dissident voices in the Forest Service, but rather "was due to the general job performance of Mr. Mumma."
Under a typical timber sale, the Forest Service builds the roads and then sells the timber to private logging companies. Most of the trees are clearcut, a method in which all the trees are removed from a given site.
The land that Mr. Mumma oversaw is bigger than most American states, and is perhaps the most sparsely populated area in the contiguous United States. But it supports huge trout, badgers, wolves, mountain goats, mountain lions, large herds of elk and deer, and the only sizable population of grizzly bears outside of Alaska.
It is also an area with large tracts of corporate timberland, primarily that of the Plum Creek Timber Company, whose managers acknowledged several years ago that were cutting far more trees than could grow back to replace them. They said they were not practicing sustained yield, the long-held industry concept of cutting an even amount of trees every year, and then replanting in place of the clearcuts.
Plum Creek owns about 800,000 acres of forest in Montana. The company's leaders now say they are curbing the excesses of the 1980's and are practicing what they call "environmental foresty," -- less clearcutting and more trees left as buffer zones around creeks and streams.
In recent years, Federal and private studies have documented how excessive logging, on public and private land, has affected elk, grizzly bears and trout in the Rockies. For example, heavy tree cutting was found to be a cause of mudslides and sediment buildup in Swan River, just south of here, which flows into Flathead Lake.
The sediment, and the algae that come with it, are so high in some places that it is driving out of the river the oxygen that trout need to survive, according to a study released this summer.
"The Swan is one of the last premier bull trout basins left in the world, and if nothing is done, it will continue to choke on sediment," said Dr. Richard Hauer, a University of Montana biologist, who was a co-author of the study.
 
Effect on Wildlife
 Near Kalispell, in a 459-square-mile corner of the Kootenai National Forest where as much as 70 percent of the land has been clearcut, Federal biologists warned in 1989 that continued high logging could affect grizzly bears, which are a threatened species. The bears have been forced to scatter to isolated high country. Yet logging in that section, the Yaak region, was increased by 30 percent last year, rather than reduced as the Forest Service favored, after staff members of Senator James A. McClure, a Republican of Idaho who retired from the Senate in 1990, met with the Forest Service staff.
Mr. McClure and foresters with Plum Creek said a higher level of logging was needed in the Yaak region and nearby areas because the trees are infested with pine beetles. They argued that it was better to salvage the trees while they have commercial value, a view disputed by other foresters.
In an effort to try to repair some of the land after more than a decade of heavy cutting, forest supervisors throughout the region have been reducing the volume of timber, going below the targets set by Congress.
"We have a good thing going for the future, and I do not intend for us to screw it up for short-term reasons that are not sound," wrote Tom Kovalicky, supervisor of the Nez Perce National Forest in Idaho, in a memo sent to other Government foresters last fall.
Commenting on Mr. Mumma in that memo, Mr. Kovalicky wrote, "John is the only regional forester in recent times who is fighting for resource balance."
But the refusal by Federal land managers to cut as much timber as desired by industry has angered Republican senators like Larry E. Craig of Idaho and Conrad Burns of Montana.
Last May, Senator Craig wrote a letter to F. Dale Robertson, the Chief of the Forest Service, in which he castigated the chief for not cutting trees fast enough in the Rocky Mountain region. "You have serious management problems that must be addressed," Senator Craig wrote in the May 23 letter. "It is my hope that you will move to assure targets are met and line officers are held accountable."
 
Request for Reports
 He told Mr. Robertson to send him summaries each month of what the service was doing to keep sales flowing. "I intend to take increased oversight of the operation of the Forest Service," he said in closing.
In an interview, Mr. Craig said he did not intend the letter to be a direct threat to Mr. Mumma's job. He said the region was in "crisis and paralysis," and that slowing timber sales could eventually threaten jobs.
As for the contention that forest managers cannot cut the amount of timber desired by industry and Congress without harming wildlife, Senator Craig said, "I'm frustrated by that because I don't know if it's just an excuse."
Yet even other private logging companies say excessive cutting by Plum Creek and others caused officials to restrict logging on public land. "It's very much a part of the problem," said Doug Mood of the Pyramid Mountain Lumber Company, a small concern near Missoula.
But Mr. Mood also faulted the Forest Service. "From the leadership, right on down, they don't know what they want anymore in the Forest Service," he said.

HEADLINE: A Bernhardt Biography From a 40-Year Piano Duo

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
She grew up in the demimonde of mid-19th-century Paris, the illegitimate daughter of a Jewish courtesan from Amsterdam. Trained to follow in her mother's footsteps, she instead became an actress, which in those days wasn't much different. She was known for sleeping in a coffin, as well as with hundreds of men.
Her friends and admirers included Victor Hugo, Gustave Flaubert, Gustave Dore, Alexandre Dumas (father and son) and the Prince of Wales. Decades before movies and television, long before the age of huge publicity machines, she achieved international fame on a scale previously unknown. 
 "And she was the greatest actress who ever lived," says Robert Fizdale, the author with Arthur Gold of "The Divine Sarah: A Life of Sarah Bernhardt," which Alfred A. Knopf is publishing this month. "Her acting was extremely stylized, in a way we don't find natural today, but it was very beautiful. Acting reflects the behavior of the time. She wept and fainted onstage, but in her day women often wept and fainted. If she were living now, she would act the way people act now. She would be a great actress today."
Mr. Fizdale, who is 71 years old, and Mr. Gold, who died of lung cancer last year at age 72 shortly after finishing the first draft of the biography, met as students at the Juilliard School in the late 1930's. They became a well-known couple around New York, partners in life as well as in work. They shared an apartment in Manhattan and a home in Water Mill, L.I., and they performed together as an internationally renowned piano duo for nearly 40 years before retiring from the stage in 1982 because Mr. Fizdale was suffering from arthritis.
 
The Start of Writing
 "I felt somehow responsible for ending Arthur's career," Mr. Fizdale says in a gentle and refined voice that seems full of the music he created for so many years. "So I hesitated to break the bad news. But finally I had to. I said I didn't think I could go on much longer because it was painful to hit the keys. And he said: 'Don't worry about it. I'm so sick of flying. I'm sorry about your fingers but I'm not at all sorry about stopping.' "
Even before their career as musicians ended, they had begun to write. Their first book, "Misia," a biography of the Parisian pianist and arts patron Misia Sert, was published in 1980. And after they stopped performing, they published "The Gold and Fizdale Cookbook" in 1984, wrote articles about food for Vogue and were contributing editors of Architectural Digest.
They chose Bernhardt as their second biographical subject, Mr. Fizdale says, "because we liked the idea of writing about performers."
"That's what we were," he says, sitting in the offices of his publisher, "and we thought it was about time for another book about her, because the last ones were some time ago. It never occurred to us to write about musicians. I think it's much more difficult to write about music. You can describe an actor's performance, the gestures they make, but it's very hard to describe music. You run out of adjectives and you still don't give a picture of what it really is. And in any case, I think we liked the idea of getting away from music."
 
Work Apart, Argue Together
 They would work on separate sections in separate rooms, he says, "as far apart as possible," taking a break every hour or so to see what the other had done. "Often we had terrible fights," he says. "But we did that when we gave concerts, too. We were so used to that that we knew they weren't serious." Finishing "The Divine Sarah," he says, was in many ways a race against time for Mr. Gold. "But I didn't know that," he says, as what seems to be the beginning of a tear forms in his eye. "I didn't know he wasn't well. He looked well and worked very hard and we went out a lot. But of course he also smoked so much."
He and Mr. Gold were able to draw on unpublished letters, Mr. Fizdale says, including Bernhardt's correspondence with friends, lovers and her son, Maurice.
First they looked into Bernhardt's difficult childhood, one spent with a mother who didn't like her and in a house constantly visited by wealthy men who after a while were interested not only in the mother but in the young Sarah as well.
 
Making Thin Beautiful
 "An unhappy childhood often makes for a very interesting grown-up," Mr. Fizdale says. "At least it did in Sarah's case. She was obsessed with trying to get her mother to show some affection, and she never succeeded. She might very well not have been a great actress if she had been the favorite child."
But Mr. Fizdale says that he and Mr. Gold did not want to dwell on psychological interpretations. "I think that's for the psychologists," he says. "We just wanted to provide enough information to give an idea that there were psychological problems."
The many men in her life were attracted by the magnetism of her personality, Mr. Fizdale says, as well as by her physical beauty. But it was a beauty that was the complete opposite of the style of the times. Her face was indeed stunning, but in an era when voluptuousness was the fashionable female look and a handsome man was what we today would call a couch potato, Sarah Bernhardt, just over five feet tall, was thin, incredibly thin.
"Audiences at first thought she was ridiculous because she was so skinny," Mr. Fizdale says. "When she raised her arms, people would boo because her arms weren't fleshy enough. The perception of beauty in those days had economic roots. If you were thin, it meant you didn't get enough to eat. And if you weren't thin, it meant you had money. But in the end, Bernhardt made thinness beautiful. It was almost as if she was a model for today's world."
Bernhardt, Mr. Fizdale says, was much more than an actress. She was a sculptor and a painter whose works were exhibited in Paris for more than 20 years. She wrote plays and books. She was an expert at publicity. It was she who arranged the taking and distribution of photographs of her asleep in a coffin and who reveled in the notoriety they created. And unlike most actresses of the time, she was intensely interested in politics.
"When she went to Vienna to perform, she would always be asked by interviewers what the ladies were wearing," Mr. Fizdale says. "And she would say: 'I don't want to discuss that; I want to discuss anti-Semitism in Austria.' Which was a very courageous thing to say at the time, because nobody in Austria wanted to discuss it. And Bernhardt, who worshiped her son and couldn't live without him, didn't speak to him for a year during the Dreyfus affair because he opposed Dreyfus. She was instrumental in getting people involved in the case." Dreyfus, who had been convicted of treason and imprisoned, was exonerated when it turned out that he had been the victim of anti-Semitism and a conspiracy.
 
A Lopsided Judgment
 When Bernhardt died in 1923, at age 79, a crowd estimated at 600,000 to one million people filled the streets of Paris to get a glimpse of her funeral cortege. They were paying homage to a woman who had thrilled audiences with her acting, with her performances in Dumas fils's "Dame aux Camelias" and Oscar Wilde's "Salome"; as both Hamlet and Ophelia; as Phedre and Lady Macbeth, and in countless other parts. Playwrights had created roles especially for her: before there was a "Tosca" by Puccini, there was "La Tosca," written for Bernhardt by Victorien Sardou. Even Marcel Proust was inspired by her; in "Remembrance of Things Past," she was the model for the actress Berma.
Not everyone admired her. George Bernard Shaw considered her acting "childishly egotistical." But D. H. Lawrence called her "the incarnation of wild emotion which we share with all live things."
Her talent, Mr. Fizdale says, cannot be judged by the films and recordings that exist today, because they are played at the speeded-up rate common to her era and seem grotesque.
"In most of the recordings people have heard, she sounds like Minnie Mouse, very squeaky and very fast," he says. "Her golden voice makes no impression at all. But when they are played at the right speed, things are completely different. There's a lot of static, but you get a distinct impression of a beautiful voice. Some of it is so moving that when it's over you want to jump to your feet and cheer. You begin to understand what it was like for audiences to watch her on the stage. The rapture, the excitement they must have felt."
