HEADLINE: PRO HOCKEY;
Disarray on Ice With N.H.L. At Crossroads

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Brett Hull remembers his college days, in the mid-1980's, when he could watch big-league hockey on cable television. "It was great," he said. "Every week, on ESPN and USA."
With or without TV this season, Hull wants to see Eric Lindros, the 18-year-old amateur sensation, in the National Hockey League. "We need Eric Lindros," Hull said, "and we need people to get off his case." 
 Like many of his fellow players, Hull is also concerned about terms of the expiring collective bargaining agreement, which restricts free agency and sometimes punishes players who are awarded as compensation. "Scott Stevens," Hull said, citing a recent case, "was treated most unfairly."
Finally, Hull wonders about the N.H.L.'s expansion plans. At least one proposed franchise is having serious financial problems and none of the three have new arenas yet.
"In most other sports, you've got to get a barn first," Hull said, referring to arenas. "If expansion doesn't work, someone has to be to blame."
Hull, as even casual sports fans probably know, is the son of one of hockey's greatest players, Bobby Hull. The younger Hull is a sharpshooter for the St. Louis Blues and is the current goal-scoring champion of the N.H.L., with 86 goals last season. He is also a booster of his sport, which he calls "the best in the world."
Although his league has enjoyed relative stability and modest prosperity for more than a decade, it is at a crossroads -- perhaps a major intersection -- as it prepares for its 75th season, the 25th since its expansion from six teams and into the modern era.
Even as the best players from Canada and the United States conclude the championship round of the Canada Cup this week, the problems facing the league -- the collective bargaining agreement, the expansion difficulties, the lack of a television contract in the United States and the Lindros affair -- cast significant shadows over hockey's ambitious plans for a bright decade in the 1990's.
Despite all the questions, however, there is little sense that the professional hockey business is in peril. Over all, it is profitable. Although they want reform of free agency, few players speak in militant tones about strike possibilities.
"As a union, we're as close as we've ever been," said Brent Sutter, the captain of the Islanders and a member of Team Canada. "This is a very important collective bargaining agreement. There certainly have to be some changes."
The five-year agreement was scheduled to expire tonight at midnight. Negotiators met through the weekend in a hotel in downtown Montreal. The season begins in two weeks.
"The old agreement is so old-fashioned and so out-of-date that it is tough to live by," said Joe Mullen, a veteran of the Pittsburgh Penguins. "They call it 'free agency.' There is none. I found out the hard way."
So did Stevens. When he moved from Washington to St. Louis last season, the Blues had to give the Capitals five first-round draft choices as compensation. When Brendan Shanahan moved this summer
from New Jersey to St. Louis, an arbitrator awarded Stevens to the Devils as compensation.. Others feel slighted in other ways.
"I didn't get a single offer," said Mike Richter of the Rangers, a free agent who is the first-string goalie for Team USA "The compensation would be five first-rounders. A team like Washington has them.
"The players don't want to go overboard. But we wonder: are we missing out? The consensus is we're underpaid. But we're not sure."
 
Average Salary Was $254,000
 According to the N.H.L.P.A., last season's average salary was $254,000, considerably less than that paid to players in other major sports who have more free-agent mobility. Those sports also earn revenue from national television contracts, which hockey lacks in the United States.
For the last three seasons, the N.H.L. appeared on SportsChannel America, a cable network. When SportsChannel failed to expand beyond the limited number of markets it's available in, the league became invisible in many areas of the country.
Even if new nationwide cable contracts are signed, they are expected to yield far less money than the $51 million that SportsChannel paid for the last three seasons. The league president, John Ziegler, says he isn't concerned.
"Our broadcast position is very sound," said Ziegler. "We'll have some kind of contract with somebody."
In the United States, in the late 1960's and early 1970's, the N.H.L. appeared on major, over-the-air networks, CBS and NBC. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, it was one of the first sports to embrace cable, but its exposure has declined while cable has grown.
"Come on," Wayne Gretzky said recently. "You can't tell me our game isn't more exciting than bowling on a Sunday afternoon or women's golf. We can't get on TV? Somewhere, somebody is doing something wrong and they've got to make changes."
Ziegler said the widespread cable exposure of the mid-1980's wasn't especially profitable.
"Broadcasting is not a critical item to our business," Ziegler said, adding that most of hockey's TV money comes from local TV packages and that about two-thirds of hockey's revenue comes from gate receipts.
Other substantial revenue was to come from expansion, with up to seven new franchises paying $50 million to join the league during the decade. San Jose begins this season, with Tampa Bay and Ottawa scheduled for the 1992-93 season.
But after putting up the $5 million deposit, the Tampa, Fla., team failed to make its $22.5 million payment on June 15 and still hasn't done so. Ziegler said over the weekend that "we hit a real hiccup" in the Tampa situation because of the economic recession.
 
The Lindros Factor
 Many promoters, fans and players are excited about Lindros, a 6-foot-5-inch, 235-pound center who is making a major impression this month as a star of Team Canada. Lindros plays with a rare combination of size, skill and aggression, which prompts comparisons to Gordie Howe, Jean Beliveau, Mark Messier and Mario Lemieux. He is, however, reluctant to play for the Quebec Nordiques, the team that made him the first pick in last summer's amateur draft.
"Why should I play for a club that's spent the last 1,000 days in last place?" Lindros said recently. His negotiating stance, bold by hockey standards, has angered some segments of the hockey establishment and has come to be viewed by the Canadian public as an English-versus-French issue.
"It is very important for the Nordiques to either sign him or get some players for him in trade," Gretzky said last week. "But it looks like that is not going to happen."
Ziegler says the Lindros matter is none of his business.
"It would be absolutely inappropriate for me to get involved unless both the player and the club asked me," Ziegler said. "I certainly would like to see Eric Lindros play in the N.H.L. But you have to put one hockey player in perspective. It is a team game. This league has succeeded for 75 years without any particular player."
According to figures provided by the league, attendance last season for regular season and playoff games was 13,786,100, down from 13,935,244 the year before.
 
Absorbed W.H.L. IN '79
 Ziegler has held his job since 1977, back when Jimmy Carter was just getting comfortable in the White House. Ziegler's major achievement came in 1979, when he steered an "expansion" that eventually blended the N.H.L. with the remnants of the now-defunct World Hockey Association. It ended a decade of warring leagues, bankrupt franchises, uneven quality and general chaos.
The N.H.L. says its gross revenue was about $400 million last season from ticket sales and broadcast fees, including Canada and local packages. Profits last season were $15 million, down from $40 million the previous year. But the figures provided don't include revenue from concessions, parking and luxury boxes, which are considerable in some cities.
"My guess," Ziegler said, "is that three or four teams lost money last season and 12 were right on the cusp."'
What, then, is the real problem? With the N.H.L., it may be image, particularly the common misperception that hockey is mostly fist-fighting on ice skates.
To improve its image, the league has hired a specialist, Bill Wilkerson, who is consolidating in Toronto the public-relations operations that used to be scattered across offices in Toronto, Montreal and New York.
Despite all the difficulties, most N.H.L. people see no reason why the league can't thrive for another 75 years.
"The league is upside-down right now," said John Davidson, the former Ranger goalie who is regarded as one of the best television reporters in hockey. "But it will survive. Because the fans are so good. Because the players are so good. And because the sport is so good."

HEADLINE: Senator Harkin Joins Race for President

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINTERSET, Iowa, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa roared into the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, scoffing at President Bush as a uncaring plutocrat with political "feet of clay" and casting the election as a stark choice between a government for the privileged and a government for the people at large.
With a fiery address delivered at a rally just south of Des Moines, Mr. Harkin promised a hard and unyielding attack on Mr. Bush, brushing aside all the months of poll data and expert analysis holding that the President will be very tough to beat. "I know there are those who say it's a long shot," said the 51-year-old Mr. Harkin, "that we might as well just call the election off." 
 He paused, then shouted with the anger that has roused many of the party faithful in recent months, "I'm here today to tell you that George Herbert Walker Bush has got feet of clay and I intend to take a hammer to them."
 
Tsongas, Wilder, Now Harkin
 Mr. Harkin, a fourth-generation Iowan, a former Navy jet pilot and a second-term Senator, becomes the third major candidate to declare formally for the Democratic nomination, joining Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts.
Mr. Harkin has positioned himself as the unabashed voice of traditional Democratic values, a candidate who relishes the prospect of going mano a mano with the President -- not a small selling point in a party where many believe that Michael S. Dukakis lost in 1988 by failing to fight back.
Mr. Harkin's address today was populism with a razor's edge, attacking Mr. Bush -- whom Mr. Harkin almost invariably refers to by his full four names -- as a tribune of privilege devoted to policies that help the rich, insensitive to the hopes and dreams of ordinary Americans. Mr. Harkin described the "supply side" economics of the Reagan and Bush years as a "failed economic experiment" that should be consigned to "the trash heap of history" alongside Communism.
In its place, Mr. Harkin asserted, should come a "percolate up" economics that would emphasize "investment" in people and the nation's infrastructure. And he said the money would be readily available now that the cold war was over.
"If you believe like I do that Europe is rich enough and strong enough and powerful enough to defend itself if it wants to, and we can take some of your wealth and invest it in America -- and build better roads, and better highways, better energy systems, educate our kids, have better health care -- then you take your ballot and you put it in the Harkin box," he said.
 
Made-for-Television Moment
 Mr. Harkin declared his candidacy on the farm of a friend, on a gentle hilltop surrounded by rolling cornfields, a perfect, made-for-television backdrop for his defense of the "the hard-working men and women of America, our farmers, our small-business people, the people who pull the load and pay the taxes."
His audience, about 2,000 strong, was arrayed before him on bales of straw. Many of the Iowans wore T-shirts that declared, "Give 'em hell, Harkin"; other shirts declared, "Tom Harkin -- George Bush's worst nightmare." Everywhere there were flags, and the program began with the Pledge of Allegiance, reflecting the determination of many Democrats never again to let the Republicans seize control of the symbols of patriotism, as they often seemed to do in 1988.
His sleeves rolled up, Mr. Harkin reveled in the chants and cheers of the hometown crowd, and he quickly found his cadence on the makeshift stage. He began with a paean to his hometown of Cumming, Iowa, to the values of small-town America, to the strength of communities. "For the last four years, we've had a different vision of America coming out of the White House," Mr. Harkin said. The Republicans' message, he went on, pits "race against race," and "class against class," and holds that "the few at the top are privileged and deserve special treatment and favors from the government."
The Iowa Democrat said it was time for his party to "turn the tables" on the Republicans with their own once-devastating question: "Are you better off today than you were four years ago?" And the political terrain on which he intends to fight was clear: repeatedly, he said it was time to turn American resources toward American problems, in the schools, the streets, the infrastructure.
 
Redirecting the Vision
 "We're not going to get to that new America," he said, "if we have a President in the White House like George Bush, who thinks that the real threats to our national security are halfway around the world, when they're really halfway down our streets."
The remark reflected a common Democratic theme in the 1992 campaign, a relentless emphasis on domestic issues and a growing demand to redirect spending from overseas to the home front. Governor Wilder has cast the issue as "putting America first."
The Democratic field is still forming, with Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska both expected to make their intentions official in a few weeks.
At least initially, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Harkin are considered intriguing rivals, because Mr. Harkin preaches traditional Democratic values and argues that there is nothing inherently wrong with the party's message, while Mr. Clinton argues that the party must refashion its appeal to regain the middle class. For example, Mr. Clinton argues that the Democrats must try to make government work better and must put more emphasis on personal responsibility in social welfare programs.
But Mr. Harkin's most immediate concern could be Mr. Kerrey, from neighboring Nebraska. If Mr. Kerrey enters the race, as is expected, he could make the Iowa caucuses difficult for Mr. Harkin, who already faces the problem of controlling expectations about how well he should perform in his home state. Some Iowa Democrats say Mr. Kerrey could run well in western Iowa.
Mr. Harkin faces a broader problem: the perception that he is simply another liberal Democrat who is ideologically out of sync with the times. To that suggestion, Tim Raftis, Mr. Harkin's campaign manager, replied, "That charge comes right out of the Republican White House."
Bullishness was in the air around the Harkin camp today, which, by serendipity, launched its pugnacious drive for the nomination in the birthplace of John Wayne.

HEADLINE: Report Urges Science Funds Be Used for Education

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept.15

 BODY:
A report made public today recommends that the Federal Government designate a portion of the $68 billion now spent annually on Federal science research and development for improving math and science education in public schools.
"We're trying to position the Federal Government to be a leader rather than a cheerleader for science and mathematics education reform," said Dr. Rollin Johnson, project director for the Carnegie Commission on Science, Technology, and Government, which issued the report. The commission was established in 1988 by the Carnegie Corporation to study ways to incorporate scientific and technological knowledge in Government policy-making. 
 While the report did not recommend what percentage of the science research budget should be diverted, Dr. Johnson said, "Even 1 percent of the R and D funding would more than double the current Federal spending that is specifically targeted to math and science education."
The report, "In the National Interest: The Federal Government in the Reform of K-12 Math and Science Education," also recommends greater coordination of Government efforts to meet national goals in science education. One of the six education goals that the nation's governors and President Bush agreed to in 1989 was to position American students to rank first in the world in math and science.
"There is no shortage of motivated Americans with good ideas about how to serve our children better," said Dr. Lewis M. Branscomb, chairman of the study group that prepared the report. "But the Federal Government is not yet organized to bring to every classroom in America the best of the ideas."
Interest in mathematics and science education is receiving heightened attention after various reports this year that indicate that American students are performing poorly in those subjects. Business leaders, in particular, are alarmed by the poor mathematics performance because the skill is critical to future jobs if the United States is to compete economically.
Indeed, the role of science and mathematics education is the focus of a workshop at an education conference being sponsored by Fortune Magazine here Monday.
"We realize that there is a crisis in math and science in K-12," said Samuel H. Fuller, vice president of corporate research for the Digital Equipment Corporation, one of the panelists. He said that his company had expanded its educational efforts by providing education and support for people who want to switch to teaching in mid-career.
Thirty percent of the nation's elementary and secondary pupils are concentrated in 250 of the nation's 16,000 school districts, Dr. Johnson said, districts that are often in inner cities where poverty and social problems abound.
The report notes that 60 percent of the mathematics teachers and 40 percent of science teachers do not have college degrees in the subject they teach. The report called for colleges and universities to educate undergraduates for professional careers in math and science, either as teachers or researchers.
The report also encouraged better dissemination of new ideas as well as better distribution of Federal education money.
For example, the report suggests that the Eisenhower State Mathematics and Science Program, a Federal program that provides states with $200 million a year for science and mathematics education, award its money on the basis of competition. Currently 75 percent of the money, which is meant to improve science and math teaching, is distributed by economic and population formulas. Some critics maintain that the money for the program is often spent on building maintenance instead of for improvements.
The report recommends the creation of a joint office through which the Department of Education and the National Science Foundation can coordinate improvements in math and science education.

HEADLINE: Between 2 Worlds: Dominicans in New York -- A Special Report;
Between 2 Worlds: Dominicans in New York

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
Martin Gomez starts all his mornings in America in the same place, at the foot of the George Washington Bridge, waiting for his ride and his future.
As the commuters from New Jersey begin to flow across the bridge to their jobs in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Gomez and hundreds of other Dominican immigrants are heading the other way, in an alternative rush hour imported from the streets of Santo Domingo. 
 In a caravan of livery cabs, broken-down cars, vans and school buses painted bright blue, they are going to sew dresses in factories, make beds in hotels and scrub office floors in central and northern New Jersey.
Those Dominicans, the largest group of recent immigrants, stand for a new wave of immigration that is transforming the New York metropolitan region. Their economically ravaged homeland, where the average salary is $40 a month, sent more people to New York in the 1980's than any other country.
By an inexact official count, the Dominicans in the city are now 400,000 strong. Their entrepreneurial zeal has apparently bought them most of the city's bodegas and many of its livery cabs, and, to an exuberant merengue beat, they have revived a decaying Washington Heights.
The Dominicans have crowded into tenements that once were home to German Jews and the Irish. But while new arrivals are from somewhere else now, their story is in many ways the same. Their lives are still defined by money: earning it, saving it, and sending it back to their families.
Worker by worker by worker, they send so much home, an estimated $300 million to $600 million a year, that their remittances are the Dominican Republic's second-largest industry. Entire Dominican towns are dependent on money from New York.
All immigrants live suspended between two worlds, the old country and the new. The Dominicans just do so more than most. They may complain incessantly about how bad things are at home -- the incompetent bureaucracy, the daily blackouts, the steep price of everything from plantains to sugar, but they talk just as much of returning. Home is a three-hour flight and a $489 round-trip ticket away.
"The Dominicans are like sojourners, or permanent immigrants," said Luis Guarnizo, a doctoral candidate in sociology at the Johns Hopkins University who has extensively studied and written about Dominican immigrants. "They have two lives, one back home and one here. It adds up to almost no life.
"They come here thinking, 'I'm going to save money, buy a house back home, and go back and start a business.' But life here is more difficult than they think. Time goes by, and their stay lengthens. Because of the bureaucracy and corruption in the Dominican Republic, going back is harder than they expected."
In the strict accounting of Mr. Gomez's existence, there are no meals out, no movies, not even television. Back in the Dominican Republic, he made about $10 a week as a cook. In America, depending on how much overtime he can find, he makes from $1,000 to $3,200 a month cleaning offices and factories. This is where it goes:
*$212 a month for his share of a two-room apartment without a kitchen in Washington Heights.
*$175 a month for meals cooked by a neighborhood woman, including the rice and beans he takes to work for lunch.
*$300 a month to his savings account.
*$300 a month for his wife and three children back in Santiago.
 
'Everyone Is Depending on Me'
 By force of thought, if not fact, he said, "My wife and my children get me up every morning at 5." The pressure is enormous.
"Everyone is depending on me," he said. "Sometimes I don't want to work on weekends, but I have to do it. I have to feed my family, I have to feed myself. I have to pay the rent here -- and there. I have to pay the light bill here -- and there. I don't want to let anyone down."
He budgets $489 in air fare for his yearly trip home. When he has saved enough money, he says, he will build a house and stay in the land of beautiful beaches.
To judge from their rising economic profile, more and more Dominicans, like Mr. Gomez, are wistfully planting both feet on their new land, doing, in their own way, what generations of immigrants have done before them. The Dominicans, redefining the nature of "Hispanic" in a city where the word has long been synonymous with "Puerto Rican," have gone from driving livery cabs to operating fleets of them, from owning bodegas to buying supermarkets. Some have moved from the tenements of Washington Heights to houses in the suburbs.
And after cutting their political teeth on the local school board, the Dominicans last week all but won their own district on the City Council, which is about to expand, to 51 from 35 members, in an effort to give greater political power to the minority groups that now constitute a majority of the city's population.
The primary vote gave the Democratic nomination to Guillermo Linares, a teacher and public-school advocate, who prevailed over two other Dominicans. In November, he is virtually assured of becoming the first Dominican elected to the Council.
"Now we are beginning to put down roots in this country," said Dr. Rafael Lantigua, an internist at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center who was a leader in the drive for a Dominican Council district. "We know the only way to get services in a country like ours, and I say ours because this is our country, is through political empowerment."
 
The Drug Dealers
'It's an Injustice' To Generalize
 Talk to the Dominicans, from Washington Heights to newer communities in the western Bronx; Corona, Queens, and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the conversation invariably comes around to the same rankling point: the way they have come to be defined as drug dealers in the popular imagination.
"We're not all drug dealers," said Maria Miguelena Barbuena, the main Maria behind Las Tres Marias, a restaurant at 170th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which is widely popular with Dominican cabdrivers, lawyers and community leaders. "Look at my hands. These are hard-working hands. We are hard-working people."
As the commander of the Manhattan North Tactical Narcotics Team, Capt. Robert Curley is an expert on the young Dominicans who sell cocaine in Washington Heights. He knows that the customers are mostly from the suburbs -- many come across the same bridge that Mr. Gomez and the other workers cross daily -- and that Washington Heights has the heaviest drug traffic in Manhattan.
He also knows that the local precinct, the 34th, had 103 slayings last year, the second highest toll in the city, after the 77th in the East New York section of Brooklyn. The 34th is also more than twice the geographic size of many other precincts.
 
'That Look of Fatigue'
 But, Captain Curley said, "it's an injustice to just equate Dominicans with drug-dealing." He said he had learned the real story of the community by studying the faces of the workers who return across the bridge at the end of the day.
"You see someone in work clothes, with a thermos," Captain Curley said. "You see that look of fatigue. It's something you're familiar with. They get out and wave. In your mind you can just hear the conversation, 'See you tomorrow.' You can tell it's someone coming home from work."
Luis Guarnizo has interviewed nearly 100 Dominican executives in the city, including a handful of drug dealers. He said the pressure to support families back home and the lack of good jobs in New York drove some immigrants into the trade.
To go to New York, Mr. Guarnizo said, many Dominicans borrow $2,000 to $10,000 to finance illegal passages. Mr. Gomez borrowed $5,000 for air fare and to pay off officials for the necessary documents. He spent the first few years in this country paying off the debt.
"They mortgage their family house and borrow money at 10 percent interest a month," Mr. Guarnizo said. "Once they're here, you can't imagine the pressure on them. If they don't keep up with payments, their family will be thrown out of their house back home.
"And back home, everyone has an image of easy money to be made in New York. You want to go back with money. Otherwise your community thinks you're a loser."
One drug dealer had been a laid-off construction worker. "He had spent all his savings," Mr. Guarnizo recalled. "Meanwhile, the offers kept coming in: 'C'mon, forget your moral principles, let's make money.' Finally, he started driving a car for the dealers. He was making $300 a week. Then he moved up to dealing."
After 18 months in the drug trade, the man had enough money to return home and open a legitimate business.
 
The Entrepreneurs
Restaurant Born Of Plantain Stew
 Where better to study Dominican enterprise than Las Tres Marias?
Maria Miguelena Barbuena arrived in New York at the age of 12 and went to work sewing dresses in a factory.
"I had to do it," she said. "My mother was sick, and we were five in the house. My mother was very proud. She didn't want to go on welfare."
Twenty years ago, her mother started cooking a Dominican stew called sancocho for neighborhood customers. The stew, made with plantains, peas and meat, became a Washington Heights staple. Eventually, Mrs. Barbuena borrowed money and started the restaurant.
 
A Dream Met
 "I dream of this, and I get it," she said. "There's nothing more for me to dream."
She has done well enough to be able to move out of Washington Heights, away from the drug dealers, to a house on a quiet block in New Milford, N.J. But, she said, Las Tres Marias could not exist outside Washington Heights.
"I want to be where my people are, where they know me," she said. "Maybe someplace else I fail."
There are actually five Marias behind Las Tres Marias. Working alongside Maria Miguelena are her sisters, Maria Amarilis, Maria Librado and Maria Teresa, and the woman who started it all, their mother, Maria Dulce.
 
Saving $13,000 in a Year
 So why isn't the restaurant Las Cincas Marias? "I don't think it sounds commercial," Mrs. Barbuena said. "Las Tres Marias sounds better."
Twenty years ago, Puerto Ricans owned most of the bodegas in the city. Today Dominicans do.
To acquire his, Julio Trejo, from Puerto Plata, held four jobs at once. He worked days in a lamp factory in Paterson, N.J., and nights cleaning offices. Weekends he drove a livery cab and played drums in a merengue band.
"I didn't stop for anything," Mr. Trejo said. "I saved $13,000 in one year. I had no time to spend it."
He arrived 12 years ago. Two years later, he paid $50,000 for his bodega, El Paraiso on West 175th Street in the Bronx. Today, it costs $150,000 to $200,000 to buy a bodega, said Agostin Garcia, president of the Dominican Chamber of Commerce.
 
'Competition Among the Powerless'
 El Paraiso is no paradise. "You got to work 15 hours a day," Mr. Trejo said. This life leaves him no time for playing in his old band, Los Principes. But he can afford to send his children to parochial school. And he recently opened El Paraiso II nearby, on West 181st Street.
Some people talk of scattered tensions between the Dominicans and the Puerto Ricans, not unlike any other "competition among the powerless," in the words of Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, who grew up in Brooklyn. He related a recent encounter in a bodega. The owner, who is Dominican, was displaying the flag of his country.
"This Puerto Rican walked in and said, 'Why don't you have a Puerto Rican flag?' " Mr. Falcon recounted. "The owner said, 'You're not a real country. At least we're a real country, an independent country.' "
 
The New New Yorkers
'Here Is the Land Of Opportunity'
 Francisca Rodriguez likes to show visitors the view of the George Washington Bridge from her apartment window, and the snapshot of the house she is building in her hometown of Dajabon.
Mrs. Rodriguez arrived four years ago and went to work in the housekeeping department of a midtown hotel. She has never been over the bridge she admires from her window. The boundaries of her New York are defined by her two stops on the No. 1 train, in Washington Heights and midtown.
At night, she watches news of the Dominican Republic on cable television. At the newsstand at 181st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, she has her choice of 10 newspapers published in the Dominican Republic and flown daily to New York.
Mrs. Rodriguez says she is in New York only until she saves enough money to go home and open a bodega.
She and her 17-year-old son, Elvis, are close. But like many young Dominicans -- and with an median age of 22, they are the youngest of the new immigrants -- Elvis will not be going back with his mother.
"I love New York," he said. Elvis, who is a senior at George Washington High School, said he believes this is the place he can fulfill his dream to be a computer programmer.
 
'I Want to Be Buried Here'
 Maria Miguelena Barbuena is not going back, either. "Even if I die in Santo Domingo, I want to be buried here," she said.
Yesenia Herarte, 19, works six days a week as a cashier at the Key Food store in Washington Heights and moonlights as a youth counselor. Ms. Herarte, who wants to be an engineer, studies English at night.
But on Sundays, she climbs a steep staircase above a warehouse on Webster Avenue in the Bronx and enters a large room filled with people from her hometown, Esperanza, which means "hope" in Spanish. There, the members of the Esperanza Social Club dance, exchange tips on jobs and apartments and raise money to send home.
All over Washington Heights and the Bronx, Dominicans meet in similar social clubs, organized around hometowns. The Dominicans are singularly passionate about baseball, and each club has its own team.
"Here is the land of opportunity -- money and success," Mr. Guarnizo said. "But social life is also important to Dominicans. They talk a lot, sharing, hanging out with friends. Here they work so hard they have to give a lot of that up. They have to strengthen their culture here to keep going in a society that appears hostile. They love their country. They recreate Dominicanness here."
The longer they stay, though, the more important they become as New Yorkers. In an affirmation of that ascent, an estimated quarter-million people gathered along Madison Avenue on a Sunday last month for the annual merengue celebration that is the Dominican Day Parade.
 
Making a New Home
 A deputy city human rights commissioner is a Dominican, Rolando T. Acosta.
Emmanuel Gautreau, from Santo Domingo, was the valedictorian at City College this year. Mr. Gautreau, 33, a former handyman, majored in English and wants to be a teacher.
And year after year, the best high school baseball players in the city are Dominicans. Last year's star, Manny Ramirez of George Washington, was the top pick of the Cleveland Indians in the professional draft.
Dr. Lantigua arrived from Santo Domingo in 1972. "In 1975 I was quoted in The New York Times saying, 'We Dominicans should come here, get expertise and go back to the Dominican Republic to use that expertise,' " he recalled.
Instead, Dr. Lantigua applied his skills and training to the poor Dominicans of Washington Heights. They are his patients at Columbia-Presbyterian. Ten years ago, he founded Alianza Dominicana, a community-service agency. He worked on Mayor David N. Dinkins's campaign and fought for the new Council district.
"We have to make New York New York again," he said. "It was immigrants who did it before, European immigrants. Now, it's going to be a mix of Afro-Americans and Latino immigrants.
"We feel that the American dream is still alive. There is more hope here for all Dominicans."

LENGTH: 1462 words

HEADLINE: Unions Court Old Allies: Immigrants and Unorganized

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
"Welcome to the Williamsburg workers' center," a handwritten sign on the wall says in Spanish.
The place is unprepossessing. Inexpensive wood paneling lines the walls of the three plain rooms. An unmarked red metal door faces out on a quiet industrial street in Brooklyn. But to anyone willing to sign up and pay a $12 fee, the center offers a chance to take an English-language course or find out how to obtain unemployment insurance. 
 For many labor leaders, the modest new center represents an innovative community-based approach to organizing, a model that they hope will enable the labor movement to reverse its precipitous slide in recent decades.
In the last 10 years alone, the proportion of workers in the state belonging to unions dropped, to 25 percent from 39 percent. Nationally, the unionized proportion of the work force fell, to 16 percent from 25 percent, in the same period. Comparable statistics are not kept by New Jersey or Connecticut, but several Labor Department officials said those states had experienced similar declines.
 
Rethinking Organizing Strategies
 Labor experts and union leaders attribute the falloff to a host of factors, from the decline of the manufacturing industries,where unions were often strongest, to what union officials view as the lax enforcement of Federal labor laws.
The changed environment has challenged unions to rethink organizing strategies, to become more creative in trying to stanch and, perhaps, reversing their declining fortunes. Although unions once concentrated primarily on organizing individual work sites, many now take a broader approach, sometimes aiming recruitment at entire communities.
"You can't get out of this mess shop by shop," said Nick Unger, the New York political director of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union. "A shop closes, you organize a shop. Three shops close, you organize one or two. You don't build an institutional memory or a union that way."
The center on Whipple Street in the Williamsburg neighborhood is an example of a union's trying to organize workers by appealing to a broad community. Created last year by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, the center is open to adults in Williamsburg and the neighboring Bushwick. Participants can take classes in Spanish literacy, English as a Second Language and other subjects, from sewing to drama.
They also receive associate membership in the union, which helps them obtain discounts on prescription drugs, among other features. The participants can receive counseling on subjects like problems with immigration or social-service agencies or collecting overtime from a reluctant employer.
The point, of course, is to burnish the union's image in a neighborhood of immigrants from Latin America who provide much of the labor for the remaining apparel manufacturers in the city. There is a long-term goal, as well: to build support for the union campaign to become the official representative of more than 3,000 workers in dozens of garment factories in Williamsburg and vicinity.
Although the center opened early last year, it began to solicit members formally and establish class rosters last month. The organizers, using tactics more typically associated with community organizers than labor leaders, went to churches to describe their plans and leafleted at subway stations and outside factories.
Hilda Sepulveda was among nearly 300 people who have enrolled at the center, in a sliver of a building wedged between a McDonald's restaurant and a church just south of Broadway, the main artery in Williamsburg. She signed up for an English class, Ms. Sepulveda said as she registered, because she thinks it will help her "get a better future, a better job."
"I would like to get ahead," she said, speaking in Spanish through an interpreter.
 
'Encouraged Them to Stick With Us'
 Ms. Sepulveda works at a nearby sweater factory, one of 68 plants that belong to a trade association that is the prime target of the union organizing campaign. She said she might be interested some day in joining the union. For the moment, though, she said she is more concerned about learning English.
Ms. Sepulveda's priorities did not displease the director of the center, Ken Thorbourne. "We're trying to build up the good name of the union," Mr. Thorbourne said. "I'd be happy if we accomplished that. But it's also to gain access to people, to train them, to help them fight for their rights.
"We knew we had to try to become part of the community. We needed to offer people something that encouraged them to stick with us."
The union has little choice but to think long-term. All 68 factories in the Williamsburg association have a union, an independent local called the United Production Workers of America. Some workers in the plants, along with the I.L.G.W.U., contend that the local was created by the manufacturers' association and does not adequately represent employees' interests. Trying to unseat an existing union is a politically challenging and legally complex task.
 
Historical Focus of I.L.G.W.U.
 The I.L.G.W.U. is also seeking to organize employees in other nonunion factories in Brooklyn, many of them quite small. The campaign began two years ago and will likely take another two years, Mr. Thorbourne said. The workers' first vote on affiliating with the union will probably be next year, he said.
The workers' center and the factory campaign is one of the responses to the sharp decline of manufacturing in the New York metropolitan region in the last 20 years, a shift that has hurt many industrial unions and forced them to reconsider their recruiting. Despite the falloff in many industrial unions, an estimated 35 to 40 percent of the workers in the city are unionized, primarily because membership in government workers' unions surged in the 80's.
The I.L.G.W.U. union has set up workers' centers in Los Angeles and San Francisco, its president, Jay Mazur, said. In one sense, the strategy reflects the union's historical focus on immigrant workers and their communities, he said. But it also represents a new thrust in the labor movement, adapting tactics from community organizers and the civil rights movement to produce broader recruitment campaigns.
In many cities the Service Employees International Union has been campaigning to unionize custodians, calling the effort "justice for janitors." It has enlisted churches and civil rights leaders in the effort, which it presents more as a social movement than a conventional union campaign.
 
Rallies for Union Linen
 In New York, among other places, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, which represents workers in men's apparel factories, has been trying to "think social," in the words of Mr. Unger. Sometimes that takes the form of trying to put economic pressure on companies that use products made by nonunion workers. The clothing workers' union, for example, represents employees in commercial laundries that supply linens to New York restaurants. When the union identifies restaurants using linens from nonunion laundries, it sometimes holds rallies in front of those restaurants.
"We can discuss with their patrons just what they are putting on their face," Mr. Unger said. "We remind them that they are putting dirt to their face and that it's a bad thing to do."
Organized labor's decline has tested unions' resourcefulness. Many unions representing public employees, including those in the city, have long railed without much success against city and state governments that contract public services to businesses.
The Communication Workers of America, which represents more than 40,000 state workers in New Jersey, is taking a new tack. It is trying to organize the workers in private social-service agencies. The union is concentrating its initial campaign on agencies that care, at state expense, for handicapped and retarded people in group homes and community centers. The people who work for the agencies are paid 30 to 50 percent less than comparable state workers, said the organizer leading the effort, Marilyn W. Haith. Among other facets, organizing those workers would shrink the disparity between union and nonunion wages.
The effort began a year ago, and the first affiliation vote is to be held today at an association for retarded people in Atlantic County. Ms. Haith said she expected a vote would also be held soon at a similar center in Union County.
The union hopes to organize an estimated 10,000 workers in private agencies that work for the state, she said.
The campaign, like many ventures by other unions, is in its early stages. "We haven't been successful yet," Mr. Thorbourne said. "We'll see if creativity is the answer."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bush at the U.N.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The moment has come for the President of the United States to step up to his obligation to form and articulate American foreign policy in the wake of the death of Communism and the breakup of the Soviet Union. The forum is the U.N. session opening this week in New York.
The need for a substantive speech, now scheduled for Monday Sept. 23, is all the more pressing because his last attempt -- his dismaying "Chicken Kiev" speech in Ukraine on Aug. 1 -- betrayed a misconceptual framework. That was the first address by a U.S. President that had to be followed by an op-ed article by his national security adviser to explain that what he said was not what he meant. 
 It came with ill grace for Mr. Bush to implicitly derogate his Presidential predecessors from Truman to Reagan, who waged and won the cold war, for having engaged Soviet leaders "in duels of eloquent bluff and bravado."
Worse was his dire warning to the peoples of Ukraine, the Baltics and other republics seeking independence from central Moscow rule that "Americans will not support those who seek independence in order to replace a far-off tyranny with a localdespotism. They will not aid those who promote a suicidal nationalism based upon ethnic hatred."
That was to shore up the Gorbachev Communist centralizers against the likes of the Yeltsin separatists. Though Brent Scowcroft later insisted no pro-union purpose was intended, the plain truth was emphasized in another line: "America's first system of government -- the Continental Congress -- failed because the states were too suspicious of one another and the central government too weak to protect commerce and individual rights."
Came the putsch and its counter-coup, and the restive republics scrapped the centralism to create just the sort of loose articles of confederation Mr. Bush had instructed them were such a failure in our experience.
Small wonder Secretary of State Baker received such a lukewarm reception in the Baltic republics the other day. (The U.S., shamefully, was 39th to recognize their freedom, just after Mongolia.) The people knew their independence came despite the Bush Administration's historically wrongheaded support of Moscow central.
O.K., so the Bush foreign policy zigged while the world zagged, and the U.S. found itself sadly mispositioned on the central issue of our time. That was last month. This is now; time to abandon the old New World Order based on a Gemini hegemony and to set forward the new New World Order based on a high-flying eagle and a multipolar bear.
Can President Bush come up with a conceptual framework in the short time remaining? Yes, if he stops his frenetic travel and lectern-pounding to focus on his U.N. speech.
For openers, quote President Benjamin Harrison, who said in 1888: "We have no commission from God to police the world." Propose to intervene only to protect vital interests, as when an aggressor builds or buys nuclear weaponry. Invite world participation in our space shield to safeguard everyone from nuclear blackmail or accidental missile launch.
State our intent to increase the momentum for freedom around the world, helping those who root out the Communists still lying in the weeds, creating financial magnets and laws to attract free-enterprise investments. Promise to use our economic retaliatory power to break tariff barriers and crush cartels.
Show how we will provide humanitarian aid in the spirit of our past generosity, expecting our prosperous trading partners to do the same, remembering that help toward self-help is the best help -- no Marshall Plans or grandiose designs, especially when assets are wasted on standing armies and legions of spies.
A week is plenty of time to create the "Bush Doctrine." No State Department Pablum; no 15-minute package claiming leadership without being leaderly; no historic mistakes that call for op-ed clarification.
Take yellow pad in hand, Mr. President, and show how America intends to participate in, rather than continue to observe, the sweep of history in the run-up to the millennium. By rising to this intellectual challenge, you will earn the world's attention at your next great forum, in Hawaii three months from now: aboard the battleship Missouri on the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Judging Robert Gates: Dialogue - Farewell to the Old C.I.A.;
Just the Man For the Job?

BYLINE: By David L. Boren; David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The confirmation hearings on the nomination of Robert Gates as Director of Central Intelligence give us an opportunity to look into the future as well as the past. I am not among those who have rushed to a negative judgment about Mr. Gates. He would clearly bring valuable experience to the position, having been both a producer of intelligence after serving in several different positions at the C.I.A. and a consumer of intelligence as a member of the National Security Council staff in the Carter and Bush Administrations.
At the same time, serious questions have been raised about his purported knowledge of the Iran-contra affair that demand thorough examination. I will not reach any conclusions about Mr. Gates's nomination until I have obtained answers to these questions in the hearings, which begin today. 
 It is critical that these hearings also mark the beginning of a valuable debate about the future of American intelligence.
I have no quarrel with those who want to overhaul our current system. An intelligence organization designed to meet the challenges of the cold war can no longer do the job -- and would not be worth what we have been paying for it in the past. While spending on intelligence gathering and analysis will remain considerable, it can and should be substantially reduced.
Some people have called for a rearrangement of the intelligence bureaucracy; others have even urged the dismantling of the C.I.A.
While issues may change, policy makers will always need to make informed decisions based on timely and accurate intelligence. We will always need an institution devoted to the collection and analysis of intelligence.
The broad outlines of the new intelligence mission are already taking shape. There must be more emphasis on gathering intelligence from agents and informants rather than relying so much on technological wizardry. We must have better information providing earlier warning of risks to our national security.
The greatest intelligence failure of the gulf war was our inability to detect more quickly the threat that Saddam Hussein posed to his neighbors. With better forecasts about Iraq's intentions, President Bush could have taken early steps like beefing up U.S. presence in the region to deter Iraq's aggression, perhaps avoiding war.
Too much of our intelligence gathering and analysis are still focused on the Soviet Union. While we should not ignore it or Eastern Europe, we must improve our capabilities in the third world and the Middle East and also devote more attention to terrorism and narcotics trafficking. Money no longer needed for Soviet-related intelligence work, which currently takes up half of the intelligence budget, should be more than adequate to finance these new priorities.
In addition, we need to transfer more resources to and build up economic intelligence. The aggressive acts of industrial espionage by foreign governments -- at times in collaboration with their intelligence services -- are a clear indication of this threat. We have yet to determine how to deter these activities and to set appropriate American countermeasures.
Furthermore, as the line between civilian and military threats to our national security becomes blurred, we can no longer afford to support the separate intelligence empires of the C.I.A. and Defense Department that do not talk to each other. Without cooperation, policy makers receive fragmented intelligence.
Finally, we must place less value on bureaucratic consensus in intelligence analysis, and more on clear predictions that leave room for dissenting views. Current intelligence, as Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf observed, is often "caveated, footnoted, and watered down to the point of being irrelevant."
The next Director of Central Intelligence will preside over the first sweeping redesign of American intelligence since the National Security Act was enacted 44 years ago. As Lincoln said, "We must think and act anew." It is critical that our top intelligence official have the vision and determination to do exactly that.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Humble Sludge Holds Wealth of Soil Nutrients;
Cleaning L.I. Sound

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A critical point not included in your otherwise excellent survey of the sewage treatment plants for metropolitan New York (The Week in Review, Aug. 18) is that all the plants perform only secondary treatment of sewage. They lack the facilities for tertiary treatment to remove the dissolved chemicals in our sewage, which are devastating the ecology of Long Island Sound. Nitrates in particular cause blooms of microscopic organisms, which use up most of the oxygen in the marine waters. 
 Fish and shellfish cannot survive under these conditions, and Long Island Sound is dying biologically from its western end in New York City on toward the east. Heavy metals from industrial sewage accumulates in lobsters and other marine life, making them unsafe for human consumption. Fin rot and cancers afflict some bottom-feeding fish.
The scientists who have been working on plans to save the Sound's ecology want more sewage plants and more control of land runoff of rain to reduce contamination of the Sound; but of special import for the city, they want sewage plants upgraded to tertiary capability. The cost for doing this for city plants that feed their output into the Sound would be far more than the city can afford in its present financial embarrassment.
The only hope for saving Long Island Sound is Federal aid, amounting over the period needed to expand and upgrade pollution control all along the New York and Connecticut shores to about $10 billion, as estimated by Representative George J. Hochbrueckner of Suffolk County.
As Tom Wicker states (column, Aug. 18), such infrastructure projects should be financed by the Federal Government to prime the pump of real recovery. They would offer a way to reduce unemployment and, with some retraining, provide new jobs for engineers, technicians and managers who will become unemployed as defense contracts are reduced.
 
FREDERICK S. LIGHTFOOT
Greenport, L.I., Aug. 26, 1991

HEADLINE: Newark's Housing Stock Can Match That of Most Other Cities;
Blame the Tunnel

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your special report "The Two Newarks: Boom Amid Bust" (front page, Aug. 13) questions whether or not Newark can become "livable" again to match its downtown business zone and regain the population it has lost since World War II. 
 Actually, the death knell of Newark's population, which had grown to about 450,000 at its peak, was sounded long before the war.
When I moved from New York to one of Newark's suburbs in 1920, Newark was a residential as well as a business and industrial city. Its school system was rated one of the best in the country. Newark Academy was an outstanding preparatory school dating back to Colonial times. There were three legitimate theaters and several excellent restaurants. These catered to Newark citizens and to suburbanites.
And then came the Holland Tunnel and the growth of automobile ownership. Suddenly, New York City became too close. The Hudson River was no longer a barrier. Broad Street, Newark, surrendered to Broadway, New York. Newark's downward slide in population started then and has continued ever since. Almost all of the people who work in downtown offices commute from out of town.
Despite optimistic soothsayers, I fear that geography has sealed Newark's fate. Only a 21st century miracle may change it.
 
JOHN D. CLARK
Lakehurst, N.J., Aug. 24, 1991

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Lower As Gold Posts Modest Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday as traders, discouraged by the continuing weakness in the economy, soured on the currency. Gold prices advanced modestly.
Analysts said that nothing new had developed to influence trading, so investors sold the dollar on expectations that the weakened economy would push interest rates lower. 
 On Friday, the Federal Reserve dropped its discount rate, the interest it charges commercial banks, half a percentage point, to 5 percent, after reports indicated that the economic recovery was stumbling.
The pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7385 in New York, from $1.7295 late on Friday. In earlier trading in London, sterling rose to $1.7400, from $1.7320 late on Friday.
The dollar lost ground to the Japanese yen, falling to 133.55 yen, from 134.15 on Friday. Markets in Tokyo were closed for a national holiday yesterday, but in London the dollar was quoted at 134.05 Japanese yen, down from Friday's close of 134.45 in Tokyo.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Friday, included: 1.6730 German marks, down from 1.6900; 1.4610 Swiss francs, down from 1.4800; 5.6970 French francs, down from 5.7555; 1,252.00 Italian lire, down from 1,266.00, and 1.13615 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13575.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday, gold edged higher, picking up 10 cents, to close at $344.50 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $344.30, also up 10 cents.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $345.40 an ounce, up from $344.25 late on Friday, while in Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $345.50, up from $344.00. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 to close at a bid $345.52.
Also on the Comex, silver gained eight-tenths of a cent to close at $3.998. In London, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.07, up from $3.98 late on Friday.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Lax Bank Regulation

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A report released today by Congressional auditors criticizes Federal regulators for what it calls their lax supervision of the Bank of New England before it failed.
The report, issued by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, raises new questions for Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency and the bank's chief regulator, who faces confirmation hearings on a second term later this month. 
 The Boston-based bank, part of the Bank of New England Corporation, a $32 billion banking empire in Massachusetts, Maine and Connecticut, failed earlier this year at an estimated cost of $2.5 billion, making it one of the most costly bank failures in history.
 
Actions 'Too Late'
 The G.A.O. asserted that the comptroller's office had repeatedly played down any criticism of the bank, limited the scope of its examinations, raised no questions about the payment of $400 million by subsidiary banks to their holding company between 1987 and 1989, and took no enforcement actions until 1989, by which time "it was too late."
In a statement, Mr. Clarke did not contest the report's accuracy, but called attention to previous testimony in which representatives of the comptroller's office "acknowledged shortcomings in the agency's supervision of Bank of New England during the 1980's."
Mr. Clarke's statement went on to point out policy and organizational changes carried out by his office "to prevent similar problems from occurring again."
 
A Tougher Hearing
 Mr. Clarke, a former Houston lawyer for banks, has been comptroller for almost six years, a period that has seen a record number of bank failures. His next confirmation hearing is expected to be much tougher than his first in 1985.
There has been criticism from both lawmakers and banking experts that Mr. Clarke softened examination and regulatory policies early in his tenure, helping fuel excessive real estate lending by banks. There have also been complaints that much more recently, his examiners have become too restrictive, helping to create a credit crunch. The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs has been waiting for today's report before it goes ahead with the confirmation hearing, which is scheduled for next week.
The comptroller's office regulates nationally chartered banks, which include most of the nation's biggest banks. Mr. Clarke is also a director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the financially troubled agency that inherits the bad loans of a failed bank in its role as insurer.
In some ways, today's report tells the story of a long-simmering financial fire neglected until the fire was out of control.
It was not until 1989, after deterioration of the New England economy, that the comptroller's office significantly increased the level of staffing at the Bank of New England Corporation's banks, from 50 full-time examiners to 125, the report said.
One year earlier, when the comptroller's northeast district office, based in New York, asked for additional resources, the national office refused, citing problems in Texas banks, the G.A.O. said.
Shortly after the bank failed, Mr. Clarke, after being asked at a Senate hearing if more supervisors had been requested or were needed, said, "I really do not think that the problem was not having enough supervisors" but stemmed from the failure to follow up and be more aggressive.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Clarke, Leonora S. Cross, said Mr. Clarke still held to that view and was probably not aware of the request for additional staffing when he testified earlier this year, since "it would have been handled at a lower level."
Between 1985 and 1988, as the Bank of New England grew rapidly and made large real estate loans, Mr. Clarke's examiners found problems. "However, these problems were not characterized in O.C.C. examination reports as seriously affecting bank operations until 1988, " the report said.
In one of its central complaints, the G.A.O. said it was "concerned that O.C.C. did not expand its scope of examinations when these problems were identified."
 
Lagging Enforcement Action
 Despite the failure of the bank to correct its problems and temper its risky growth strategy, "O.C.C. took no enforcement action to compel corrective measures until 1989," but "by that time the New England economy was declining and it was too late," the report concluded.
Today's report was critical of the comptroller's office for not raising questions when more than $400 million was transferred between 1987 and 1989 to the Bank of New England's holding company from the subsidiary banks. Most of these payments were dividends, which, the G.A.O. found, increased by 131 percent between 1988 and 1989.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hanson to Buy Beazer In $609 Million Deal

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Hanson P.L.C., the largest industrial conglomerate in Britain, said yesterday that it would buy Beazer P.L.C., the British construction group with vast holdings in the United States, for $2.14 a share, or $609 million.
Beazer said it had recommended that shareholders accept the bid, which requires shareholder and regulatory approvals. 
 Under the deal, Hanson will acquire a building-materials concern that includes the Koppers Company in Pittsburgh and home-building operations in Tennessee, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina. In the United States, Koppers is the biggest producer of sand and gravel and the second-biggest producer of aggregates, the concrete component used in construction projects and roads.
"Our long-term faith in the construction industry is bolstered by our belief that we have reached the bottom of its current cycle of recession," Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson, said. "And we look forward to developing Beazer's well-established businesses alongside our own."
The announcement raised a number of questions among industry analysts about how the acquisition of Beazer would affect Hanson's relationship with Imperial Chemical Industries, the British chemicals company in which Hanson holds a 2.8 percent stake. The purchase of that stake in June created rumors that Hanson would soon seek control of Imperial.
But James M. Brier, director of investor relations for Hanson Industries, the United States arm of Hanson, said the company's holdings in Imperial Chemical Industries were "for investment purposes only," adding that the latest transaction "does not change the situation in any way."
Carol Neves, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said Hanson had "enough financial power that this acquisition won't be a big deal in terms of interfering with its plans with I.C.I."
Shares of Beazer soared $2.25, to $8.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. It was the most active issue on the Big Board, with 13.5 million shares changing hands. Hanson shares rose 37.5 cents on the Big Board on news of the acquisition, closing at $19.
Last week, Beazer issued a prospectus announcing plans to spin off European operations by selling shares in a new company. Beazer has said it intends to base itself in the United States, where the company has operations in 30 states that supply cement, asphalt and other materials.
Hanson owns Hanson Brick, the largest brick maker in Europe. In Britain, the company is also the largest producer of batteries and the second-largest tobacco company. In the United States, Hanson owns the Peabody Coal Company in Kentucky, the country's biggest coal producer.

HEADLINE: Big Airlines Join T.W.A. in Cutting Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Big Three airlines -- American, United and Delta -- wasted little time yesterday matching T.W.A.'s $198 round-trip coast-to-coast air fare, which was announced in newspaper advertisements in the morning. By afternoon, the three carriers announced similar fares, although each added a wrinkle or two of its own.
While subject to a number of restrictions, including availability, T.W.A.'s fare is much lower than anything currently available. It is, for example, $140 less than American's current lowest-priced New York-to-San Francisco round trip, and far below American's $756, unrestricted, fully refundable one-way fare between those two points. 
 Industry analysts said that in lowering its fare, T.W.A., which is facing a financial squeeze, was trying to raise cash when airline traffic is entering into its slack post-vacation season. "I'd be surprised if it's anything but a cash-flow move," said Christopher Tunnar, an analyst with Arthur D. Little, a research firm in Cambridge, Mass.
 
Enticement to Fliers
 But Jim Faulkner, T.W.A.'s director of public relations, denied that. "Traffic always falls off this time of year," he said, "so this was our way to entice people to keep flying." He added that it was too early to know how many people took advantage of the new fare yesterday.
No airline can make money on a $198 round trip coast-to-coast fare, Mr. Tunnar said, but airlines occasionally use such prices to lure passengers into their planes. While the first carrier to cut fares is likely to have no more than a one-day advantage, because competitors feel compelled to follow suit to avoid losing market share, that is usually enough time to bring a publicity advantage -- and, if necessary, provide immediate cash, even if at the risk of long-term financial health.
To qualify for the $198 rates, passengers must purchase tickets no later than this Thursday. Tickets are nonrefundable. Purchases must be made at least seven days in advance of a flight, or within 24 hours after booking, whichever comes first. Travel must be completed on or before Dec. 15 and must include a Saturday stay-over. The $198 fare does not apply to flights on Nov. 26 and 27, and Dec. 1, 2 and 3.
T.W.A.'s discount fare is good on flights from New York, Newark, Baltimore and Washington on the East Coast, and from Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Jose, Orange County and Ontario, Calif., on the West Coast.
 
Others Add Cities
 American has added Islip, L.I., and Newburgh, N.Y., on the East Coast and Burbank and Long Beach in California. It is also offering a $218 round trip between its East Coast cities and San Jose and Oakland, Calif.
United's plan includes White Plains and New Haven, as well as many of the other cities also served by T.W.A. and American, while Delta's fares are also valid between the major cities, as well as Newburgh.
The carriers were unwilling yesterday to predict the likelihood of future fare cuts, but Mr. Tunnar said he would not rule them out.
"The Fed thinks they have to reduce the prime rate another half-point to stimulate the economy, and the travel industry is much the same," he said. "The No. 1 reason for people not traveling is still the recession -- the amount of money they have left over at the end of the day. Somehow the airlines have to do something to fill up the back of their planes."

HEADLINE: Unusual Labor Pact For Nynex

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Nynex Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an unusual mid-contract accord with its unions in an effort to avoid another strike like one in 1989, the industry's longest and most bitter since the breakup of A.T.& T.
In the new labor accord, the first of its kind in the telecommunications industry, Nynex is giving pay increases of 13 percent over the next three years. That compares with a 9.2 percent wage rise in the 1989 three-year contract and 10.3 percent in a 1986 agreement. 
 Negotiated 11 months before the old Nynex contract was to expire, the new pact could provide a model for the "Baby Bell" companies and their unions as those contracts expire next year.
 
7 Previous Strikes
 All of the Baby Bells are heavily unionized. There have been seven strikes at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Baby Bells since the 1984 breakup. Six lasted less than a month, but the seventh, the 1989 Nynex strike, lasted more than four months.
Nynex's revenue growth has slowed as the recession hurt white-collar employment, and that decline has reduced the number of business conversations and data transmissions. Meanwhile, the phone unions have had trouble recruiting members and the recession has meant widescale anxiety about layoffs, discouraging union militancy.
Nynex, the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone, also raised the possibility of layoffs of nonunion, white-collar employees. Nynex said that it planned to reduce by 5 percent its 32,000 management workers through "voluntary transfers, retirements or separations and then, if necessary, involuntary separations."
 
First Manager Layoffs
 Kenneth M. Leon, an analyst at Bear, Stearns who follows Nynex, noted that the reductions represented the first time Nynex had sought to lay off managers, a sign that the Northeastern recession was still battering New York Telephone and New England Telephone.
"Normally, I would regard the Nynex labor agreement as positive," Mr. Leon said. "But this is far from conclusive. It's not at all clear whether these moves will generate profits, and the recession may dim any luster of this accord."
Nynex estimates the cost of the new contract at $240 million, compared with $180 million for the old one.
The Nynex agreement is likely be sent in early October to members of the Communications Workers of America, Nynex's principal union, and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
Contracts for nearly a half-million workers at A.T.&T., GTE and the six other Baby Bells expire next year. News of the Nynex accord was announced on Friday, but no details were given then. The preliminary reaction from other unions over the weekend has been positive, a Communications Workers spokesman said.
In Englewood, Colo., U S West, another Baby Bell company, reacted favorably to the early conclusion of labor talks, but said it was not familiar with the details of the talks. "Over all, it's a positive development," said Debra L. Thomas, a spokeswoman for U S West. That company had a seven-day strike in 1986.
 
Cost of Living Provision
 In the new Nynex accord, union members may also get a modest cost-of-living adjustment in 1994 if inflation cumulatively exceeds 9 percent for two years, as well as preserving the health benefits that were the central dispute in 1989. Nynex is also giving pension enhancements, which would provide the early retirement for thousands of workers that some union employees had sought, while helping to trim the ranks of older workers, whose pay and benefits are more expensive.
The Baby Bells have been hit by slow growth in recent years in the majority of their business -- telephone conversations. Last year, Nynex, the second-largest Baby Bell, after BellSouth, posted revenue of $13.6 billion, up about 20 percent since 1986, or less than 4 percent annually for the last five years.
Profits last year totaled $949 million, down 22 percent from 1986, or an annual decline of about 4 percent. Nynex has said the main reason for the profit drop is high costs, including labor.
 
Covers 57,000 Workers
 The agreement announced yesterday extends until August 1995 a three-and-a-half-year accord that would have expired in August 1992. It covers 57,000 telephone technicians, installers, operators, repair workers and others.
About 60,000 workers walked off the job in the 1989 labor dispute, but Nynex has since accepted the early retirement or not filled the jobs of 3,000 workers for a shrinage of the labor force of about 5 percent.

HEADLINE: World Bank Management Shift Is Seen

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The new president of the World Bank, Lewis T. Preston, is beginning to assert his control over the organization by imposing a new system of senior management used in American corporations, World Bank officials and economic-development experts said today.
Mr. Preston is said to be replacing the bank's three senior vice presidents with a three-member office of the president. The bank's vice presidents -- currently 14, soon to be 17 -- will report directly to the president's office. Under the current system, each vice president reports to one of the senior vice presidents. The World Bank declined to comment. 
 The bank, which has 155 member nations, lends money for development projects in poor countries.
The new management structure may enable the highly bureaucratic organization to respond more swiftly to events in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The Bush Administration is counting on the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to provide large-scale technical assistance to the Soviet Union for such tasks as designing a new customs service and making the ruble convertible into other currencies.
 
'Reform, or a Power Grab'
 The change may improve the bank's efficiency and seems likely to increase Mr. Preston's influence over its bureaucracy in the process, said Richard E. Feinberg, the executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council, an economic- development research center in Washington. "This is an efficiency reform, or a power grab," he said.
A World Bank official who insisted on anonymity said that instead of "each senior vice president running his own little empire, each vice president would report to a committee." He called the change "a fairly dramatic move."
 
May Speed Up Decisions
 Mr. Preston, the former chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company, replaced Barber B. Conable Jr., who retired at the beginning the month.
The new lines of authority may help Mr. Preston tackle the voluminous paperwork and slow decision making that has increasingly mired the World Bank, Mr. Feinberg said.
The senior vice president for finance, Ernest Stern, will be joined in the office of the president by Attila Karaosmanoglu, currently vice president of the Asia regional office, and Sven Sandstrom. Mr. Sandstrom is the current director of a less influential office of the president than the one Mr. Preston is said to be planning.
 
Impact on Two Senior Officials
 The role of the current senior vice president for policy, research and public affairs, Wilfried P. Thalwitz, 59, is unclear, though Mr. Thalwitz will be staying with the bank, his assistant said.
The shake-up includes the retirement of Moeen A. Qureshi, 62, who is the senior vice president of operations and who had previously expressed a desire to retire. Mr. Qureshi did not return telephone calls for comment.
Mr. Qureshi, a Pakistani, has been the most senior World Bank official from a developing country. His departure "might dilute the developing-country executive role," even if a developing-country official is named to the new office of the president, said the World Bank official, adding that he had not yet heard anybody complain about the prospect of the developing world's losing a representative.
