HEADLINE: Opponents Seek to Curb Banking Changes

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The leading Congressional opponents to legislation that would sweep away the Depresssion-era regulations that govern the nation's banking industry had their chance today to try to preserve the status quo.
The opposition is centered in the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and one of its subcommittees today approved amendments that would retain prohibitions against industrial concerns acquiring banks and would severely restrict the ability of banks to enter the securities business. 
 The amendments are intended to thwart the several measures currently wending their way through Congress, which would dismantle the current banking regulations and give banks broad powers to compete in new lines of business. The changes are being sought by the Bush Adminstration and for the most part have been incorporated in bills already approved by the House and Senate banking committees.
Opposition to the changes is being led by Representative John D. Dingell, the powerful Michigan Democrat who heads the Energy and Commerce Committee, and by Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who heads the subcommittee that passed the amendments.
The amendments will be brought before the Rules Committee, which will decide whether to attach them to the main House banking bill or send them directly to the floor for consideration later this year.
The subcommittee's actions today struck at the heart of the proposed changes. If ultimately enacted, the amendments would bar industrial and commercial concerns, such as I.B.M. or General Electric, from acquiring banks and would place limits on the ability of banks that underwrite securities to make loans to their underwriting clients.
The Adminstration and the banking industry is seeking these changes as a way to bring new capital to a beleaguered industry and to enable American banks to become more competitive globally with international banks that are permitted to both underwrite securities and make loans to corporate customers.
Mr. Dingell, who fears that loosening existing regulations could lead to the kinds of speculative excesses that caused the Great Depresession and other financial panics, is seen as the remaining obstacle to the changes.
 
A Fear of 'Larcenous Scoundrels'
 In an impassioned opening statement, Mr. Dingell walked subcommittee members through a history of banking crises and concluded that the "banks have matured, but the people haven't."
"There are still the same larcenous scoundrels as there always will be," he said.
At today's hearing, the subcommittee voted to accept an amendment that favors the longstanding prohibitions against corporate ownership of banks. The move came after defeat of a proposal from Representative Matthew Rinaldo, a New Jersey Republican, that would have permitted such acquistions if the banks were failing or had already failed.
The Rinaldo measure was defeated by a 15-to-11 vote along partisan lines, with the Democrats opposed and the Republicans supporting. It would have permitted industrial concerns to buy troubled banks and infuse them with sufficient capital to bring them up to the capital requirements of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The Adminstration, which is seeking the infusion of private capital into the banking industry on the belief it would reduce the burden of bank failures on the taxpayer, had indicated it could have accepted the Rinaldo proposal as a compromise.
The other major issue taken up by the subcommittee was a provision that would not dismantle the Housing banking committee's repeal of restrictions that separate commercial banking and investment banking and that prevent banks from underwriting securities.
But, while going along with the House banking committee's change, the subcommittee approved an amendment that effectively undercut it. The amendment would prevent banks from making loans to corporate underwriting clients for three months after underwriting securities for that client.

HEADLINE: The General Gets an 'Incomplete'

 BODY:
Explaining his premature resignation as head of the New York City School Construction Authority, Gen. Charles Williams says he has "accomplished everything that is needed to get the authority up to speed." That may be true. But he had a full year left on a three-year contract and his agency is only halfway through a five-year plan, amid citywide economic uncertainty. So: Why did he leave, and what's to become of the authority?
The School Construction Authority was created in 1988 as an independent agency to build new schools and renovate existing ones without the rigid Civil Service, contracting and land use procedures that had delayed projects supervised by the Board of Education by as long as 10 years. 
 The authority is responsible for a $4.3 billion capital plan to build 50 new schools and 30 annexes and to renovate 70 other schools over five years. In the interest of efficiency, the State Legislature has exempted the authority from the Wicks law, which prohibits use of a single general contractor for most public construction projects.
Under General Williams, who spent 29 years in the Army Corps of Engineers, the authority has won praise for prompt payment and fair play. It has awarded $1.5 billion in construction contracts and completed 20 new facilities, five athletic fields and two modernizations.
The reasons for the general's departure aren't clear. He was criticized for paying high salaries to top managers and for a bloated administrative staff; the Board of Trustees, which oversees the authority, recently proposed a watchdog committee. General Williams, however, insists he has a better offer from the private sector.
Still, his decision is disappointing, especially since his accomplishments outweighed his shortcomings. Now it's up to Mayor David Dinkins and the trustees to insure a smooth transition so that the critical work of the agency will continue.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Warmer Globe, Greener Pastures?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
LOOKING forward to a winter beach vacation on balmy Cape Cod? There may not be scheduled flights from La Guardia Airport -- the runways are so often flooded at high tide. But the highways are reliable, now that the Rhode Island dikes have been reinforced and bridges all raised by five feet.
This vision of the future may seem unthinkable. While it is widely understood that the accumulation of "greenhouse" gases in the atmosphere could dramatically change weather patterns over the next century and raise the level of the oceans, it is also widely assumed that governments can and must check global warming. 
 But a new report from the National Academy of Sciences dares to challenge this environmentally correct view, examining the prospects for adapting to a warmer, drier climate rather than preventing weather changes. And though the authors draw no conclusions, this provocative study suggests that the warm, new world might not be unpalatable.
In April a separate National Academy panel on global warming plumped what has been dubbed the "no regrets" greenhouse policy. Until the timing and consequences of warming were better understood, the panel concluded, it made sense to cut greenhouse emissions only where the cutting would be free or relatively cheap.
The contemplated reductions, totaling one-third of current emissions, were less than most environmental lobbies wanted and more than the Bush Administration was ready to accept -- and thus represented a pleasing political middle. But it left open the question of how much farther to go if, as expected, the climate continues to warm in spite of low-cost remedial action. The answer, economists say, ought to depend in part on how costly it would be to adapt to climate change.
The new National Academy report, from another panel headed by Paul Waggoner at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, focuses on the adaptation option. While its conclusions are couched in the language of science, the overall impression is sunny: Most societies would probably be able to cope with the 2 to 9 degree Fahrenheit warming now expected by the mid-21st century.
Human health, the panelists concluded, would not be significantly affected. People adapt well to warmer climates -- indeed, migration southward since the invention of air-conditioning suggests that many prefer their world without winter.
Nor is there reason to believe that economic productivity would change much. Manufacturing and most services are relatively insensitive to weather: it is as easy to build tractors in Florida as in Minnesota. Moreover, the life of most capital equipment and structures is short relative to the time frame of global warming, making it relatively cheap for business to change technology or location to accommodate the weather.
Farming and fishing would be more dramatically affected by a warmer and drier climate. But together, these industries contribute a scant 3 percent to America's G.N.P. And in any case, agriculture is far more adaptable than is generally understood; conceivably, higher crop yields from a carbon-rich atmosphere would fully offset the added costs of irrigation and genetic adaptation.
The big-ticket adjustments, the panelists believe, would be protection of coastal areas from flooding and building the capacity to move and store more fresh water. But according to an independent study by the panel's economist, William Nordhaus of Yale, these costs would be spread over decades and need not amount to more than a quarter of 1 percent of G.N.P.
If you sense something is missing here, you are not alone. The perspective of the study is that of economists and engineers: Nature is an economic tool and a playground for humans. Therefore, rapid, irrevocable changes in the global ecology are a liability only to the degree that they reduce productivity or upset the users of the playground.
This position has its appeal if one believes that the value of, say, wilderness or species diversity exists only in the eyes and minds of the beholders. But there is no simple way for the beholders to put a price tag on such intangibles. And many environmentalists are not even prepared to try, as long as the option of preservation is available.
The implicit optimism of the National Academy's adaptation panel suggests that policy makers are going to have a tough time ducking this core issue of environmental values. If the costs of adaptation are indeed modest, it would probably pay to roll with the greenhouse punch. Unless, of course, the intangible losses from rapid ecological change are given great weight -- and societies are ready to spend tens or even hundreds of billions of dollars to avoid them.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Rises $2.10 in a Rally Of Precious Metals Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices rallied yesterday amid expectations for lower interest rates and signs that the tide of Soviet metal sales was ebbing.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for delivery in October rose $2.10, to $347.30 a troy ounce; December silver rose 6 cents, to $4.11 a troy ounce. 
 October platinum rose $3.70, to $353.50 a troy ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The markets finished below their highs but the upward move has not necessarily stalled, said Randolph Donney, chief of commodities research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
"There is a good feel to the metals now; they've been able to hold up under pressure," he said.
Mr. Donney predicted that December silver would make a stab at $4.19 an ounce today after peaking at $4.145 yesterday.
 
Expect Another Rate Cut
 Mr. Donney and Fred Demler, a metals economist with Paine Webber Inc., said metal traders expected the Federal Reserve to make another cut in its discount rate to stimulate an economic recovery. The Fed cut the rate, which it charges on loans to financial institutions, by half a percentage point, to 5 percent, on Friday
Crude oil futures slipped on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of a weekly American Petroleum Institute report that showed an unexpectedly large drop of six million barrels in United States crude oil stocks last week. The report may support crude futures today..
Crude oil for October delivery fell 20 cents, to $21.62 a barrel. Heating oil for October delivery dropped 0.95 cent, to 61.11 cents a gallon. October unleaded gasoline fell 0.70 cent, to 61.06 cents a gallon, and natural gas rose 0.3 cent, to $1.598 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Soybean futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending Monday's gains amid rising fears of a damaging freeze later this week in the northwestern corner of the Midwest.
 
Wheat Futures Higher
 Wheat futures rose on signs of stronger export demand but corn and oat futures retreated slightly.
Wheat for September delivery settled 2 1/4 cents higher at $3.31 a bushel. September corn fell 3/4 cent, to $2.51 a bushel. September oats dropped 1 cent, to $1.19 1/4 a bushel. The September soybean contract, which expires tomorrow, fell 1 1/2 cents, to $6.00 1/2 a bushel. The November soybean contract finished 2 1/2 cents higher at $6.11 1/2 a bushel.
Most pork belly futures plunged the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on weakening chart signals and expectations for lower fresh belly prices. The selling pressure spilled over to the hog pit.
Cattle advanced in line with higher cash cattle prices.
Live cattle for October delivery rose 0.18 cent, to 71.70 cents a pound. September feeder cattle rose 0.23 cent, to 85.25 cents a pound. October live hogs fell 0.45 cent, to 45.35 cents a pound, and February frozen pork bellies ended 2 cents lower at 49.07 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Grew 0.3% In August

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The industrial sector, one of the economy's few strong spots, grew for the fifth month in a row in August, the Federal Reserve said today.
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month from July. The rise was modest by comparison with a revised six-tenths of 1 percent rise in July and an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in June. 
 The August rise was led by higher output of consumer goods and business equipment but pulled down by a sharp decline in auto production. Among manufacturing industries alone, output also rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
The Strongest Sector
 Although the overall August rise was the smallest since March, when production fell, economists said the gains in the output of goods other than cars showed that manufacturing was still the strongest sector of the economy as it emerges from recession.
"The manufacturing sector is the only area where we're seeing much strength, and we're seeing that continue," said David Wyss, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill, a research concern in Lexington, Mass.
At a White House news conference, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, hailed the growth in output as new evidence that the recovery from the recession that began in July 1990 was under way.
 
General Improvement
 He said the new figures "augment other closely watched data on the economy that also have been improving in general in recent months." Such data, he said, include housing starts, consumer spending, personal income, durable goods and increases in the index of leading indicators.
Over all, the manufacturing sector operated at 80 percent of its total production capacity last month, its highest level since January, the Fed said. Capacity utilization was a revised 79.9 percent in July.
August auto production -- which plunged 9.3 percent after five straight monthly increases -- dragged down the total output figure. Excluding cars, industrial output rose five-tenths of 1 percent. Economists, however, dismissed the decline as a seasonal aberration that often occurs at the end of a model year.
Economists said they were encouraged by a sharp 1 percent gain in consumer-goods production other than cars, which included higher clothing and food output, and with a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in output of business equipment other than cars.
"That should be encouraging," said Mohsen Bonakdarpour, an economist with the WEFA Group, a forecasting concern in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "That's a sign of a recovery period."
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, added, "While the August growth rate of industrial production is slower than in preceding months, these figures are favorable in one critical respect: They indicate that the rise in industrial activity is now spreading throughout the economy."
 
Spotty Recovery
 Although economists believe the recession is over, the recovery has been spotty. Job- and income-growth have been slow, consumer spending has been less than robust and retail sales have been erratic, while manufacturing and home building have been strong.
To stimulate business activity, the Fed last Friday cut the interest rate it charges banks and eased other credit to encourage more borrowing and spending.
The lean level of business inventories, which were at a two-year low in July, should also prompt manufacturers to increase production as they begin to run low on merchandise, economists said.
 
Slow to Snap Back
 While applauding the production report today, Mr. Boskin also acknowledged that the economy was slow to snap back.
"We obviously have only been into a recovery for a short period. It is going at a modest pace," he told reporters.
He added that the White House was still worried about a variety of factors that could hamper growth.
"While there is some upside potential for the economy to do even better than we've been looking at, there also are some concerns about the availability of credit, money growth, foreign demand for our exports, should foreign countries slow down even more than they have recently, and so on." he said.
He said that the White House appreciated the Fed's recent interest rate cuts, but that there was concern that the Fed's action might not be sufficient.
 
Annual Car Output Rate
 The output report today showed that car production fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.3 million units in August from 6 million in July.
Production of construction materials rose six-tenths of 1 percent in August after a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in July, the Fed said.
Mining output fell 1.1 percent last month after rising 1 percent in July. Declines in oil and coal production outweighed a rise in mining for metal ores.
Utility output rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, mostly because of a jump in electricity production to meet air-conditioning demand. In July, utility output fell nine-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Edge Upward

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Comments by Federal Reserve Board officials were the focal points of trading in the Treasury securities market yesterday, where prices of notes and bonds managed to eke out small gains at the close of a generally sluggish session.
Remarks by Wayne Angell, Fed governor, helped to depress prices early in the session. 
 In a television interview, Mr. Angell said that for all intents and purposes the recession was over and that an economic recovery was under way.
With Mr. Angell's comments apparently in mind, traders used a report from the Fed that showed that factory output rose by three-tenths of a percent last month, the fifth consecutive monthly advance, as another excuse to sell securities.
That was the end of the selling, however.
And prices began to rally early in the afternoon after the substance of a Market News Service interview with Robert Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, flashed across trading screens.
In the interview, Mr. Forrestal said that it was too soon to tell whether additional cuts in interest rates by the Fed were necessary to spur the economy.
But Mr. Forrestal added the central bank was "poised to do whatever is necessary" to spur the economy out of recession. He added that favorable inflation figures have given the Fed more latitude to ease monetary policy.
"Shortly after Forrestal's comments came out, the market started to improve," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets.
 
Housing Report Awaited
 Some analysts said that some of the price improvement resulted from the expectation that a report due this morning on new housing starts will show that activity in this key sector of the economy remained lethargic in August.
"I would be surprised if housing showed any strength," Mr. Stone said. "The decline in mortgage rates could help a bit, but demographics are working against housing. And at the moment it is hard for builders to get financing, particularly for the construction of multifamily dwellings."
Analysts at MMS International noted in their daily market commentary that "weak housing data should effectively revive the underlying bullish tone" in the credit markets.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 14/32, up 5/32, to yield 7.91 percent, compared with 7.92 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 29/32 in late trading, up 5/32, to yield 7.59 percent. The 7 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 23/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.07 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 13/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 6.15 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were basically unchanged.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.17 percent, unchanged from late Monday. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point, at 5.21 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, M. A. Hanna priced a total of $250 million worth of securities in a two-part offering through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The first part of the offering consists of $100 million worth of seven-year notes due Sept. 15, 1998.
The 9 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, 1.58 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/4 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $150 million were offered as 12-year notes maturing Sept. 15, 2003.
These 9 3/8 percent securities were also priced at $100, or par, 1.75 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
All of the securities are noncallable for life. Both parts of the issue are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager on an offering of $100 million worth of 15-year notes by KFW International Finance.
The 8.20 percent notes were priced at $100, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were little changed in quiet trading.
Heavy issuance of new tax-exempt municipal bonds had little adverse impact on prices in the secondary market for municipal bonds.
Market participants said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Money Market Accounts And C.D.'s Decline Again

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts dropped further in the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a North Palm Beach, Fla., publication that focuses on interest rates.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, like many in the credit markets, had expected the Federal Reserve to lower the discount rate, as it did last week, to 5 from 5 1/2 percent, leading to a cut also in the prime rate by banks around the country. The prime rate is used as a benchmark for setting rates on many consumer and business loans. 
 The new rates quoted by commercial and savings banks have begun to reflect the Federal Reserve move, which is aimed at stimulating the economy.
 
Rates Go Lower
 At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday the three-month bill was sold at an average discount rate of 5.19 percent, compared with 5.29 percent the previous week, while the six-month bill averaged 5.22, compared with 5.30 percent.
According to The Monitor, the largest change in rates wase made by Astoria Federal Savings, which lowered its money-market account by 31 basis points, to 5.33 percent from 5.64 percent, and its three-month certificate of deposit by 32 basis points, to 5.43 percent from 5.75 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Another large change was made by the Midlantic Bank in New Jersey, which lowered its six-month certificate of deposit by 35 basis points, to 5.40 percent from 5.75 percent.
Among the commercial banks in New York, the average yield has been cut 4 basis points, to 4.83 percent for money-market accounts, and the three-month certificates have fallen 11 basis points, to 5.07 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut an average of 6 basis points, to 5.35 percent for money-market accounts, and 8 points, to 5.47 percent for three-month certificates.
Nationwide, according to The Monitor, the average yields of 20 major banks outside the New York area have been cut by 6 basis points, to 5.06 percent for their money market accounts, and 7 points to 5.29 percent for six-month certificates.

HEADLINE: Official Says Real Cost Of Bailout Isn't Shown

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Government's senior auditor, Charles A. Bowsher, said today that a new prediction that the savings and loan bailout could be costlier and longer than officially recognized suggested that the Administration may be putting off its true costs until after the Presidential election next year.
"What the Administration is asking for is enough working capital and loss funds to get through the election and into 1993," Mr. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, said in an interview during a break in an appearance before the House Banking Committee's Financial Institutions Supervision, Regulation and Insurance Subcommittee. "It's not at all clear that it will be enough." 
 Mr. Bowsher's comment came after Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the lawmakers the bailout costs would total $191 billion, in terms of actual annual losses, from 1989 to 1996, or $31 billion more than the Administration had said would be needed.
 
$80 Billion Is Sought
 Treasury officials have steadfastly denied that they are playing politics with the financing by underestimating the costs until after the election. They have said in recent weeks that they expected a new $80 billion appropriation this fall would be sufficient -- perhaps even be more than necessary -- to complete the job.
At a hearing last week, Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, noting that the Administration had been criticized for past estimates, said it had taken special care to assure an accurate estimate.
"While C.B.O. does not have enough information about the Administration's latest estimates to make a precise comparison," Mr. Reischauer said, "our analysis suggests that the final costs of resolution will be higher, more institutions will be closed and the cleanup job will take longer than the Administration anticipates." His forecasts are considered objective enough to provide the basis for both Democratic- and Republican-sponsored legislation.
Mr. Reischauer said that the Resolution Trust Corporation would probably be resolving the plight of failed institutions through early 1995, three years beyond the period initially contemplated by Congress and the Administration.
He estimated that 1,500 of the nation's savings associations would ultimately have to be closed or merged, which was lower than his previous estimate of up to 1,700, but still substantially above the Administration's projection of 1,000 institutions. Since August 1989, Resolution Trust has seized 651 institutions and sold, merged or liquidated 536 of them.
Measuring the entire expense in terms of 1990 dollars and unadjusted for inflation, Mr. Reischauer estimated that the bailout would cost $155 billion, not including the $60 billion that will be charged to the Government for the rescue of savings associations before 1989.
Since 1989, when a new agency was created to handle the bailout, Congress has authorized $80 billion that officials say will be spent by the end of 1991.
The hearing today was called to create a record and consider the Treasury's new $80 billion request.
Mr. Bowsher was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1981 and is widely cited in Congress, although some conservative Republicans have accused him in recent months of making the Comptroller General's office more partisan.
 
40-Year Estimate
 Mr. Bowsher has estimated that when the costs of borrowing money to finance the bailout are also included, the rescue costs could approach $500 billion over the next 40 years. He suggested that Congress consider providing funds only until next August in order to supervise the bailout more tightly, but did not express a preference between that approach and the Administration's request.
Mr. Bowsher also said today that the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress that he heads, would be unable to certify the finances of Resolution Trust. He said that the accounting office would have to issue a disclaimer on the corporation's financial statements and balance sheet because of the inability to verify accurately the value of its assets.

HEADLINE: Rate-Cut Tonic: Good, Not Great

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Lower interest rates are supposed to revive the recovery, but many people wonder whether they will. The Federal Reserve Board's tonic, they fret, cannot fill up empty office towers, clean up bank loan portfolios or alter the need for America's service sector to ax costs and jobs. Besides, if three earlier rate cuts have not done the trick, why should this one?
But business economists say that interest rates have come down substantially and that business stands to be the biggest beneficiary. In fact, the past interest-rate cuts account in part for the recovery in sales and output since last spring. 
 "A significant cut in the discount rate was exactly what you'd hope for to correct our economic problems," said Walter K. Joelson, chief economist at the General Electric Company. Bernard Lashinksy, chief economist at the Inland Steel Corporation, added, "It will help a lot, a real lot."
One reason for economists' confidence that the Fed can get business and consumers to spend more: It already has. The Fed started to cut rates last summer. The result was more or less consecutive monthly gains since last winter or spring in housing, retail sales, industrial production and orders for long-lived consumers goods and capital equipment. Housing starts, for example, are up 23 percent since January.
"There was clearly a turning point." said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. The recovery cannot be traced to lower rates alone, of course. A rebound in consumer confidence was crucial. So were plunging oil prices, weak raw-material prices and easing wage pressures.
To be sure, lower rates will not magically crank up stalled car sales. Consumers have made it plain that they will not buy cars unless they are offered bargains -- and Detroit has lately been handing them price increases. Nor can lower rates ignite the kind of boom that followed the recession in 1981 and 1982. The Fed is "unlikely to give us a recovery like in 1983," Mr. Joelson said, "but it's a far cry from getting nothing."
Mr. Joelson is counting on the same so-so growth -- about 2.5 percent a year in the nation's gross national product, or the total cost of goods and services sold -- that most forecasters expect for the year ahead.
 
Discount Rate Cut
 The Fed's latest round of cuts, announced last Friday, sliced to 5 percent from 5 1/2 percent the discount rate it charges when it lends money to banks. And, for the second time in recent months, it cut the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point. That rate is the one banks are charged on overnight loans.
As a result, short-term rates are the lowest they have been since the late 70's and long-term rates -- corporate bonds and mortgage rates -- are the lowest they have been since the late 80's. The last two cuts in the Federal funds rate represent one-fourth of the distance that the Fed has moved since last winter.
Lower rates should make life easier for corporations and banks as well as debt-burdened consumers and home buyers. "The drop in interest rates, along with the decline in inflation, is like a tax cut," Mr. Kudlow said.
For starters, companies with floating-rate debt will see their interest payments shrink. David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, estimates that businesses will have reaped savings from lower interest payments that are equivalent to a 15 percent jump in after-tax profits. "That's obviously a powerful stimulant," he said.
As long as interest payments are half again as large as after-tax profits, "you have to be very, very tight with inventories," Mr. Joelson said. And inventories have continued to shrink after the recession ended in the spring.
 
Inventories Are Helped
 "The more rates come down, the more possibility there is of keeping normal inventories," Mr. Joelson said. "You can't sell from an empty wagon." Even if businesses merely replaced existing stocks, instead of letting them fall further, factory production would get a big lift.
More important, freeing up company cash should encourage the gradual resumption of corporate hiring that began this summer. That would put money in consumers' pockets at a time when consumers have been pulling in their horns. Since consumers are spend 96 percent of after-tax pay these days, a rise in income virtually guarantees more spending.
Lower rates should help shore up capital spending, which typically weakens even as the economy recovers. Buying, say, a $2 million I.B.M. minicomputer would be a lot cheaper. With a two percentage point drop in the prime rate since last winter, Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill said, the buyer would save roughly $40,000 a year on interest charges. "They could afford to hire a new programmer, too," he quipped.
That is critical to makers of capital equipment like General Electric and the Digital Equipment Corporation. "As long rates come down, G.E. crosses its fingers because it's a little shot in the arm for construction," Mr. Joelson said.
Brad Allen, a spokesman for Digital, said: "We're very dependent on capital spending. Lower interest rates will help ease the capital-spending environment."
 
Loosening Up Credit
 Lower rates could also help loosen the credit squeeze, since lower rates typically involve the creation of more bank reserves. Money would become more available for business even if banks are reluctant to extend loans, said James E. Annable Jr., chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. That is because "cash earns no returns," so banks will at least invest their cash in T-bills," he said. "The seller of those securities has more money to lend or spend."
No one can say whether the latest rate cut will or will not be enough to clear the way for a sustainable recovery. "Every time rates come down, there's a group that says they have to come down some more," Mr. Joelson said. That group includes Michael Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, who said yesterday that the Fed might have to lower rates again. The fact is that there is only one way to find out: wait and see.
"The Fed is feeling its way along," Mr. Annable said. "If there's more weakness, they'll do it again."
The economy, most forecasters estimate, expanded this summer, probably at an annual rate of 2.5 to 3.5 percent. Those results, based on preliminary data, are virtually baked into the cake since consumer spending rose smartly in June and July and business has not been cutting inventories as fast as in the spring. But, worries have been focused on the fall. "The great risk was always a collapse in the fourth quarter," Mr. Annable said.
 
Higher Spending by Christmas?
 The effect of the latest round of cuts should start to show up around Christmas. It takes three or four months, on average, Mr. Annable said, for interest payments to adjust and business and consumers to react with higher spending.
Consumers, who have even more debt outstanding than American corporations, reap benefits, too. Their debt, three-quarters of which is home mortgages, currently equals about 93 percent of after-tax income. The average American consumer spends 9 percent of take-home pay on interest payments. Mr. Wyss estimates that half of those are variable payments. "The rate decline since last year has added about one percentage point to Americans' incomes, not a trivial amount," Mr. Wyss said.
The net effect on households is harder to pin down, compared with other parts of the economy. Economists contend that the effect is still positive in the aggregate. For one thing, Mr. Kudlow said, lower rates are instantly capitalized in higher asset values, including bonds, stocks and, most important, housing. "That makes consumers feel more secure," he said.
Further, Mr. Wyss said, a decline in rates redistributes income from the frugal elderly to freer-spending younger families.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Slide; Mark Dominates Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its slide against many currencies yesterday, losing ground to currencies backed by higher interest rates.
Analysts said the German mark dominated foreign exchange trading. Ronald Holzer, a vice president with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said demand for the mark increased as investors poured money into German investments that pay higher yields. 
 The dollar closed at 1.6720 marks in New York, down from 1.6730 late Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6705 marks from 1.6725.
The dollar has lost favor with traders since it became clear United States rates were falling, even before the Federal Reserve lowered its discount rate half a percentage point, to 5 percent, on Friday.
For the dollar, "the trend is clearly down right now, based on interest rate differentials," Mr. Holzer said.
Economic statistics released yesterday painted a picture of a stagnant economy and helped undermine the dollar further as traders feared the Fed might have to cut rates even more to stimulate activity.
The British pound rose against the dollar, closing at $1.7425 in New York, up from $1.7385 late Monday. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.7425, from $1.7400 late Monday.
The dollar gained against the Japanese yen, rising to 133.85 yen in New York, from 133.55 on Monday. In Tokyo, following a holiday on Monday in Japan, the dollar fell 0.69 yen, to a closing 133.63 yen, from Friday's close, and in London it was quoted at 133.75 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4590 Swiss francs, down from 1.4610; 5.6935 French francs, down from 5.6970; 1,250.00 Italian lire, down from 1252.00, and 1.13615 Canadian dollars, unchanged.

HEADLINE: U.S. TIES ISRAELI AID REQUEST TO FREEZE ON SETTLEMENTS AFTER TALKS END IN IMPASSE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Israel and the United States failed today to reach a compromise on the explosive loan guarantee issue. Within hours after the talks ended the Bush Administration signaled that it would refuse to provide the requested help unless Israel agreed to a freeze on future settlements in the occupied territories.
After Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d finished his second day of meetings in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, reporters on Mr. Baker's flight to Cairo were summoned for an unusually blunt briefing. They were told explicitly for the first time what has been implicit in the Administration's position all along: that it will not give the Israelis the $10 billion five-year loan guarantee for housing for Soviet immigrants without an Israeli agreement to halt future settlements in the occupied West Bank, Golan Heights and Gaza strip. 
 The United States has opposed the settlements on legal and political grounds. The Bush Administration has joined the issue now because it is being pressed by Israel and its supporters to come through with a huge loan program to aid Soviet immigrants. If granted without an agreement on freezing further expansion, the loan program might lead to large-scale settlements, making it much more difficult to work out an Arab-Israeli peace accord.
 
Plans for Soviet Influx
 Reporters traveling with Mr. Baker were told that it was his recommendation that the President go to the American people with a nationwide campaign, including a possible televised address from the Oval Office, "if that is what it takes, because it is their tax dollars that would be supporting settlement activity, which we used to characterize as illegal and which we now moderately characterize as an obstacle to peace."
The sharp words aboard the plane, coming a week after President Bush's tough remarks in Washington, seemed calculated to put pressure on Mr. Shamir to agree to put off Israel's request for the loan guarantees until next January.
The issue of settlements will undoubtedly arise if the loan guarantees are again sought in January, but by then enough progress may have been made in peace talks that the issue would not be as acute as it is now, American officials said.
Washington has been urging Israel and its supporters to agree to a four-month delay in raising the loan-guarantee issue to allow a peace conference to take place this fall without the contentious issue of settlements.
If the Bush Administration sticks to its position, it would mark the first time that any American Government has attempted to use its economic leverage over Israel to get it to halt the building of settlements in the occupied territories.
Successive American Administrations have opposed settlement building since Israel, in the aftermath of the June 1967 war, took control of the West Bank of the Jordan, including the eastern part of Jerusalem from Jordan, the Golan Heights from Syria, and the Gaza strip from Egypt. But not one has ever gone as far to explicitly tie economic assistance to a formal freeze.
Israel has made it clear that it needs the loans to build housing and roads in coming years to care for the huge influx of Soviet Jews. Some 300,000 have entered in the last few years, and a million more are expected in coming years.
 
U.S. Money and Settlements
 Technically, no American aid to Israel can be used in the occupied lands. But the Israelis have been accused of using the American aid to free up other funds for the occupied lands and then asserting that American money was being spent in Israel proper.
The Bush Administration has now concluded, reporters were told, that the only way to make sure that no American money ends up building new Jewish settlements is by insisting on a total freeze on settlements.
That move is bound to generate an explosive debate in the United States between the Administration and Israel's Congressional backers. And that, reporters were told, is precisely why the Bush Administration wants to delay the Israeli loan requests until after the start of a proposed peace conference in October.
Since either Israel will be upset or the Arabs will be upset with the outcome of the coming debate, the Administration wants it to take place after the Arabs and Israelis have been enticed to the peace conference and will have much more to lose if they walk out or scuttle it.
 
Extensive Immigrant Flow
 The issue of Jewish settlements and housing projects in lands that have been predominantly occupied by Arabs is one of the most emotional in Israel, and has been a thorn in United States-Israeli relations for the last 14 years. With the rise to power in Israel in 1977 of the conservative Likud party, which has held that the land taken from Jordan was historically part of Israel, settlement activity has risen significantly.
There are about 225,000 Jews living in the occupied territories, the State Department says, including 90,000 in the West Bank; 12,000 in the Golan Heights, which Israel in effect annexed in 1981; 3,000 in the Gaza strip, and 120,000 in East Jerusalem, which was annexed by Israel in 1967, and the surrounding suburb.
The United States has taken the position that the Fourth Geneva Convention signed at the end of World War II bars an occupying power from settling the land with its citizens. On that basis, the United States has regarded the Israeli settlements as illegal.
The issue has been complicated by the extensive flow of Soviet immigrants in the last few years, and the temptation of Israeli officials to open up the West Bank for settlement even further.
At a news conference last week, Mr. Bush startled supporters of Israel by sharply criticized Israeli lobbying on the loan-guarantee issue. One reason for the briefing today appeared to be to try to dispel any notion that there might be differences between the Secretary of State and the President on how tough to be with the Israelis.
The Administration's assessment, reporters were told, was that if the United States were to let the Israelis have the $10 billion loan guarantees without any prior commitment by Israel to halt new settlements, the Arab countries and Palestinians would not come to the proposed peace conference -- and that is something the Bush Administration could understand. The loan guarantees are a form of insurance to banks and other lending institutions that loans to Israel will be repaid. That allows Israel to get favorable terms.
Reporters were told that if the United States gave the loan guarantees to Israel now, without linking them to a settlement halt, Mr. Baker was confident that the Arabs would not show up.
Paradoxically, no Arab Government has stated that in public. When Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, was asked today whether Egypt felt that way he avoided answering explicitly.
The Israelis told Mr. Baker they would agree to the delay provided that the Administration would promise now that Israel would get the full $10 billion in loan guarantees in four months without any links to a settlement halt.
When asked for the Administration's reaction to the Israeli offer, reporters were told "that is just something we are not going to agree to if we only get one vote" in Congress.
Mr. Baker said he offered the Israelis a six-point compromise proposal of his own that included an Administration commitment to address the loan-guarantee issue in principle after the four-month delay, to press its allies to help with loan guarantees and to compensate Israel for any costs in the delay. But it explicitly did not include a promise of the full $10 billion in guarantees or a way to avoid any link to a halt on settlements.
 
Arab Calls for a Halt
 Reporters traveling with Mr. Baker were told that he does not want "to indicate one inch of flexibility beyond the six points that we have proposed, which are damn forthcoming and you can use the word damn."
"It is a case frankly of not being able to justify in our own minds or to the other parties to the peace process an unconditional $10 billion infusion that does not have any restriction other than the usual boiler plate, which doesn't have any effect on the question of settlements," he continued.
According to American officials, "every Arab Government" that Mr. Baker spoke with during his attempts to organize a peace conference over the last seven months asked him to make a halt on Israeli settlement building in the West Bank and Gaza strip a precondition for their attending the peace conference.
Mr. Baker was said to have told the Arabs that the question of settlements was a matter for negotiations between them and Israel. Moreover, he reportedly did not believe he could get the Israelis to agree to a freeze on settlements in advance of the talks.
Reporters traveling with Mr. Baker were told the Administration thought that, having gotten the Arabs to drop their demand for a halt on settlements as a condition for attending the peace talks, it could not now suddenly turn around and give Israel the guarantees without insuring first that the money would not go into new settlements.
It is precisely because there has to be a debate on the terms of the loan guarantees -- a debate that is bound to alienate either Israel or the Arabs and lead one of the parties not to attend the peace conference -- that Mr. Bush wants the issue postponed until the conference is under way.
American officials said that Mr. Baker still had not received a Palestinian commitment to attend the peace conference or to send representatives who would be acceptable to Israel. The Israelis insist that they not be from East Jerusalem, that they not have any ties to the P.L.O. and that they be only from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, not from the Palestinian diaspora.
American officials are hoping some decision from the Palestinians will emerge from the Palestine National Council meeting in Algiers, the P.L.O.'s parliament in exile, which is tentatively scheduled for Sept. 23.
Mr. Baker, in an attempt to win more support in the United States for the Administration's position, disclosed the elements of the Administration's six-point compromise proposal, which has been circulating on Capitol Hill for more than a week.
He said, "If the Government of Israel would agree to the 120-day delay we are seeking in order that the issue not be the subject of a big divisive debate, with attendant adverse consequences for the peace process, the Administration would agree as follows."
"First that we would work with the supporters of absorption assistance in the Congress in January to find a suitable legislative vehicle."
He continued, "We would agree that we would not ask for a further delay come January. Third, we would be willing to restate our support for the principle of absorption aid."
Fourth, he said, the Administration would try to limit the amount of money that it has to set aside by law in case the Israelis do not repay any of the loans.
Fifth, the United States would compensate Israel for any "out of pocket" expenses that it would incur by delaying its loan requests for 120 days.
Sixth, said Mr. Baker, the United States would press its allies to help Israel with similar housing-loan guarantees of their own.
