HEADLINE: The Gates Hearings;
Excerpts From Senate Hearing on Nominee to Head the C.I.A.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from today's hearings by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, with questions by Senators Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio; John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri; Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, and Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire. The transcript was provided by the Federal News Service.
 
QUESTIONS
By SENATOR METZENBAUM
 Q. I think I'd like to summarize where I think we stand so far. My questions last night were probing inconsistencies between what you said to Congressional committees at various times regarding Iran-contra and what was actually happening in your shop. . . . Frankly, Mr. Gates, one of the most difficult challenges that I'm finding in connection with your confirmation relates to the fact that so much was happening at the C.I.A. and around the C.I.A., and you have pretty much indicated that you didn't know. . . . I was also concerned by your answer as to how you would have handled a direct question in 1986 regarding whether there were undisclosed covert action findings. 
 You said that in such a situation you would have given a slightly deceptive answer: namely, that you lacked all the facts in order to get time to warn [the Director of Central Intelligence, William J.] Casey that you were on the spot. Politically, I can understand why you would want to do that. But you also said that you would not view this answer as misleading, which I found hard to accept. To slightly deceive Congress is to mislead Congress.
You went on to say that you would have gotten back to us quickly with the full truth or you would resign, and that, unquestionably, was a good answer.
But this seems to miss the point. If you were hiding things from us, even for a short time, then how can we ever trust you truthfully to answer a question when it is posed? . . .
Let's go back to the first time that you say you heard about the Iran arms sale. On Dec. 5, 1985, you attended a meeting at the C.I.A., where you learned that the agency had been involved the previous month in supporting an Israeli transfer of U.S. arms to Iran without a Presidential finding [authorization for covert action, required by law]. . . .
Why didn't you immediately voice your objections to your superiors? Why did you not immediately insist on proper reporting procedure with respect to any future covert activity?
A. . . . These were all matters completely outside my area of responsibility, Senator. I make no bones about the fact that I was not knowledgeable about the specifics of the law with respect to the Arms Export Control Act. And so, again, these matters were outside of my area. And I would say to you when it became my responsibility, again as I indicated last night, I promulgated new rules, as Acting Director, forbidding a proprietary to undertake any action on behalf of the Government without presumption that a finding would be required.
Q. Do you have any doubt in your mind that what was being talked about at that meeting was illegal, was improper and that it shouldn't take place? Didn't you have any feeling about that at all?
A. No, sir. And I may say that the Deputy Director at the time, Mr. McMahon, was a man of enormous probity, and I was completely comfortable with the circumstances that were going on at that time.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. You gave written testimony to this committee that you saw a scenario paper from the National Security Council in February 1986 which laid out a schedule for the exchange of arms for hostages. You have described the scenario which predicted the Ayatollah Khomeini would be dead by May of that year as laughable. That was the quality of the intelligence operation that had been taken out of your agency's control. Yet you allowed it to go forward.
At the same time, you, in your words, quote, "lost touch with the project," end of quote, as you became involved with the confirmation process to become Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.
Now the foreign policy implications of an arms for hostages swap with Iran was staggering. The plan being implemented was doomed to be a fiasco. The question is, how could you put your personal agenda over your obvious obligations as a professional to put a halt to this violation of U.S. policy? . . .
A. Senator Metzenbaum, the President of the United States made the decision to sell arms for hostages. He may have made that decision in the context of larger objectives and an opening to Iran and so on and so forth, but that was his decision. It was a policy decision. . . .
It seems to me that it is not the role of C.I.A. to question the policy decision. We should have questioned how our part of that operation was carried out and the fact that it was in violation of all of the procedures and approaches that we normally would take in one of these covert actions. In that area, I think we were negligent as an agency.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. As you mention again your statement yesterday, I do have to reflect upon the fact that nothing is more useful in many instances than to say, "I was wrong, my fault, I'm sorry, I shouldn't have, I'd do it differently."

 	 	 		. . .	 	A. I think that beginning the very day that I became Acting Director -- not today, not yesterday, not when I was nominated for this position now, not even when I was nominated in February 1987, did I suddenly come to these things or learn these lessons. But the record is clear that I learned them immediately, and that beginning when I became Acting Director in the middle of December 1986 I began to put into place the kind of procedures that would insure this kind of thing wouldn't happen again.
And I took actions on receiving information, the illustration that I used yesterday, to insure that the Congress was fully informed when we received information that even suggested the possibility of an impropriety. And that happened, Senator, within a matter of days after I became Acting Director, not in connection with any nomination procedure.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Admiral Poindexter [the White House national security adviser] has twice testified that he approached you in July 1986 with the proposal that the C.I.A. purchase a supply network that had been set up for the contras, and consisted of airplanes, boats, warehouses and weapons. In his deposition he said your response was, "Let me check into it," or something like that. The network was worth over $4 million.
An exchange of communication through the White House computer between North and Poindexter verifies Poindexter's testimony that he had at least one conversation with you about the possibility of the C.I.A. taking over the resupply network when legal restrictions were lifted by Congress. A private network set up or run by officials of the U.S. Government was, of course, in violation of the Boland Amendments [Congressional prohibitions on involvement with the Nicaraguan rebels]. . . . shouldn't it have bothered you that the national security adviser to the President was acting as their broker. . . .
A. Senator, at that time I had no idea that they were anything more than a private group of people who had gotten together to support the contras. I had no indication that there was a violation of law. . . .
I had no idea that there was anything improper or inappropriate going on. I had the view of Admiral Poindexter that he was a completely straight arrow and completely straight shooter.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. I'm afraid, Mr. Gates, as we sit here looking at you as the should-have-been, would-have-been, could-have-been nominee, rather than the man who is, concerns me.
You testified before this committee on Dec. 4, 1986, regarding Charlie Allen's Oct. 1, 1986, approach to you about his concerns regarding possible diversion of monies to the contras [Charles Allen, national intelligence officer]. You told us consonant with the way we -- this is a quote -- "Consonant with the way we had responded to such stories in the past, my first reaction was to tell Mr. Allen I didn't want to hear any more about it. That I didn't want to know anything about funding for the contras." . . .
A. Two points, Senator. First of all, it was agency policy to keep as great a distance as possible between ourselves and the private benefactors. There were clear prohibitions in the Boland Amendment in terms of our relationship with the private benefactors. My initial reaction was in reaction to that policy that we weren't supposed to know, we weren't supposed to have any contacts, it was basically none of our business who was giving money to the contras or how much it was.
Now the second point is that although that was my immediate reaction to Mr. Allen, one of reaction of surprise perhaps to what he said, the fact is that the actions I took are quite different. I told him to see the Director as soon as possible. . . . My actions bespeak a very different approach and a very different attitude.
Let me make one final point on this question, Senator Metzenbaum. As I have thought about my 1987 confirmation hearings, one of the few things that I said in that hearing that I regretted was the statement that we didn't want to know and we shunned information. Unfortunately, I chose in those hearings to speak from an institutional standpoint. I chose to repeat what I had been told by others in the agency had been their approach, when people had come to them or when they thought they might have the opportunity to learn more, that they had shunned the information, they had turned it away, they didn't want to know.
But I don't think there's any example in the record -- and of all the interviews that this committee has done -- of somebody coming to me from the agency and reporting wrong-doing or an impropriety during that period. And the first time I have any recollection of tht happening on October the 1st, 1986, I took an action. And I think that is more important.
Q. Mr. Gates, you don't seem to understand that it isn't enough to just wait for somebody to come and report an impropriety. You are an intelligence officer, you are skilled in this business. . . . What bothers me is that this very intelligent man, this high-ranking official in the C.I.A. and the N.S.C. doesn't say, "Wait a minute. Tell me some more. What did you say? . . . "There is a violation -- possible violation of the Boland Amendment here. I believe we have a responsibility." It was as if you said, "I'm fading into the shadows. I don't want to hear another word about it. See no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil." . . .
What would you do about it now?
A. Well, if something like that came to my attention now, Senator, I would first see the naTional security adviser and tell him there was a problem. And if he did not immediately follow up either with the White House counsel or the Attorney General, I would. And if he did not -- or did not want me to do that, I would go to the President.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS
By SENATOR DANFORTH
 Q. Mr. Gates, I listened very carefully to Senator Metzenbaum's statement that in his view your position at the C.I.A. was like the three monkeys: "Hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil." Is it a fair statement ----
A. Absolutely not, Senator Danforth. As I indicated yesterday, within a day or two after becoming Acting Director, information came to me suggesting the possibility that some U.S. Government officials and perhaps a couple of C.I.A. officers had been engaged in arms sales to the contras. That information was characterized to me by people as hearsay, perhaps disinformation and so on. It was my judgment that it warranted greater attention than that, and I directed the individual -- the head of the other intelligence agency -- not only to brief the Attorney General but the Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, the acting national security adviser and the chairmen of the two intelligence oversight committees. I believe that that is characteristic of a very aggressive approach toward looking into wrongdoing that characterizes my performance, certainly as Acting Director and also as Deputy Director under Director Webster. . . .
When information first came to me that one of our officers had not -- had violated agency policy in terms of the private benefactors, I notified the chairman of this committee in January 1987. And when it came to my attention a couple of weeks later that that officer may not have told the truth, I was on the phone to Chairman Boren and to the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee within an hour of having learned that information myself.
. . . Frankly, I think that my whole career speaks to a willingness to speak my mind and say what I think. When I was a relatively new analyst, in 1973, I wrote an article for Studies in Intelligence that basically said that the entire way we went about doing Soviet analysis had deep flaws and that we weren't doing it very well.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. It's very interesting to me that some people attack you because they say that your views might have been too strongly stated, particularly with respect to the U.S.S.R., and other people say, oh, you have politicized your views. I don't think you can have it both ways. You have been, haven't you, at odds with various people in various administrations with respect to how your analysis squares with their policy?
A. Yes, sir. That began when I was working with Dr. Brzezinski on the N.S.C. staff in the Carter Administration. It continued in the Reagan Administration and even to an extent in this one.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. I think, Mr. Gates, from your record it's clear that you're a person who is independent and that you call them as you see them. . . .
Let me ask you a question about how intelligence analysis fits in with policy making. I'll just give you one example that to me is an interesting example. Last winter we were facing a vote in the Senate on the question of whether to authorize the use of force against Iraq. A very good debate, very hotly contested on both sides. . . . After a lot of pressure that was directed at the agency, finally the view was expressed, "Well, sanctions are not likely to get Iraq out of Kuwait. I mean, maybe they'll hurt the economy, hurt the civilian population, hurt the Air Force, but not likely to extract these embedded ground troops out of Iraq." That was a kind of bottom line getting all of the murkiness out of the analysis. . . .
As soon as that bottom line was expressed, immediately the rejoinder of those who had, in my opinion, made up their minds that they were against the use of force, their immediate rejoinder was, "Well, the C.I.A. has become politicized." . . .
How can you as Director give us information which is clear in the basis of decision making and at the same time which isn't going to be immediately discounted as being simply a statement of Administration policy?
A. Senator, I think that the provision of briefings and documents, intelligence assesments to the Congress on a continuing basis, so that the people in the oversight committees and in the other committees that receive this material have access to that on a continuing basis, as I've indicated previously, is one sure way of providing a safeguard on the integrity and objectivity of analysis. . . .
But I think that there should be no question about their basic integrity. But I think that provision of this material to the Congress is one safeguard. I think the other safeguard, frankly, is certainly referring to the President who has nominated me, President Bush, is that this President wants the material with the bark off. He wants to know clearly the situation he's getting himself into. And I've never heard him complain if the intelligence is in a different direction than the policy is headed.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. You were very close to President Bush. You've worked in the White House now for some time. He is a person who has served in the job for which you have been nominated. He is a person who is very knowledgable about foreign affairs. . . . Do you believe that as Director of Central Intelligence you would be in any way coopted by virtue of your past relationship with the President?
A. No, sir, I don't. . . . I think that having a Director who has a close personal relationship with the President offers a unique opportunity for the intelligence community to provide relevant intelligence and sharper intelligence to the policy process, and frankly, also to the Congress.
Q. If I could just ask one more question, Mr. Gates, it's the reverse of the prior one. . . . Is the C.I.A. going to be -- under your directorship, is it simply going to be a rationalization for Bob Gates' basic view of the world? How do you guard yourself against maybe not being open to what the thoughts and what the advice and the analysis is of people who are working in the agency?
A. Well, Senator, I would concede that I am probably not the easiest person in the world to work for. I am fairly demanding, and I'm probably, at times, more direct than I -- than I might be in terms of people's egos.
But fundamental to my approach to analysis -- and it begins with the article that I wrote in 1973 -- is my belief that the policy maker must be exposed to alternative points of view, that all points of view have to be heard and they have to be presented. . . .
I have always believed in alternative analysis. I believe that if you look at the record of intelligence failures over the last 20 years, in virtually every instance, it is because there was a single outcome forecast -- it is going to be X or Y or Z instead of telling the policy: Look, we really don't know how this is going to come out. Here are the possibilities, and here is our best estimate. . . .
So I -- the way I would characterize myself is as a person who has strong views, but I am open to different interpretations, and I also recognize and am willing to acknowledge when I've been wrong.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS
By SENATOR BRADLEY
 Q. Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. Mr. Gates, yesterday you were rather disarming in admitting error when you said that you should have taken more seriously the possibility of impropriety or even wrongdoing when you said that you should have been more skeptical, when you said you should have pressed harder, and I'm just curious now, five years later, as you reflect on those failures. Tell me what -- why do you think they occurred? In other words, what part of you didn't assert itself?
A. I think that I was too cautious in approaching the clandestine service, Senator, and also in deferring to Mr. Casey's special relationship with the clandestine service. Having grown up in a different culture, in the analytical culture, knowing that there were some strains and perhaps even a measure of mistrust of me in the clandestine service, I paid attention to other aspects of the work and did not press these issues.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. If we could, I'd like to go back to what was basically the strategic rationale for the Iran-contra operation. . . . This was really initiated by the national intelligence officer for the Near East and Southeast Asia, but you were the manager of the memorandum, and this was a memorandum that basically stated that Soviet's inroads were being made in Iran. And excluded from the final memorandum was both the Soviet section of the C.I.A. and the Iranian section of the State Department. . . .
About a month later, in June of 1985, the Soviets removed the remaining 1,000 technicians. They ceased all deliveries. . . . Yet, this estimate really wasn't changed until February 1986. How do you explain that?
And in the interim, of course, Iran-contra was born.
A. . . . This estimate had two fundamental points. One was that the internal situation in Iran was worse than people had anticipated and raised the possibility of significant tumult before Ayatollah Khomeini died.
The other was that these conditions created the circumstances in which the Soviets might make significant inroads at the expense of the west and the United States, in particular. The first of those points was a direct outgrowth of an estimate or of an assessment done by a directorate of intelligence analyst in late March of 1985. . . .
There was a disagreement, I later learned, in C.I.A. with the estimate's views on the Soviet -- the potential for Soviet achievement. But the analysts weren't excluded from involvement in the estimate. They simply did not have their views accepted.
And for reasons that are not clear to me, those analysts not only did not come to me, they did not go to their immediate supervisor, the director of Soviet analysis, to protest that their views were not being taken fully into account by the national intelligence officer. So I was unaware of this -- of this dispute and the fact that the C.I.A. Soviet analysts felt their views hadn't been fully taken into account.
Q. And that's why there was no alternative view presented?
A. On the Soviet issues, yes, sir.
Q. And why on the Iranian issue was there no alternative view?
A. There was a long discussion at the board meeting about that. Some changes were proposed in the language to try and satisfy the I.N.R. representative. I spoke about it. Mr. McMahon spoke. General Odom of N.S.A. spoke. I think the Director spoke. All trying to say: Doesn't the -- don't the changes that we've made accommodate the -- the view that you all have? The I.N.R. representative said no, and Mr. Casey said, "Fine, take your footnote."
I think at some point after that, I'm -- my own memory is vague on it. But I apparently called Ambassador Abramowitz and talked him out of the footnote. My view was that the footnote, that the change that had been made in the estimate was sufficient, that the footnote was kind of pointless.
Q. But you did call and urged him not to put the footnote in?
A. Apparently so, and I was successful in persuading him that it did not add to the policy makers' knowledge on this matter.
Q. So that there was no alternative view presented?
A. That is correct because I felt that the view that they had, as they had written their footnote, really didn't representative an alternative view.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. I'd like to turn to Iraq, if I could. Could you give me -- what was the intelligence basis for the Administration's response to the gassing of the Kurds? Do you recall August '88? . . . What was -- what was the basis for the kind of lukewarm response? I mean, you know, opposing it, but at the same time not opposing it strongly. Was there a basis in intelligence for that? Was there something about Iraq that -- --
A. Not that I'm aware of, Senator. . . . I'm not quite sure what you're asking me.
Q. Well, let's go down. Let's do another one, and you'll get the drift. We passed an amendment here in the Congress in, I think, '88 that applied unilateral sanctions to Iraq. This is, I think, after the gassing. And the Administration fought to delete those unilateral sanctions in the conference and succeeded in doing so. Was there an intelligence basis for the effort to delete unilateral sanctions against Saddam Hussein?
A. No, sir, I don't think so.
Q. So that the effort to delete them was not based upon any information about his intentions?
A. I think it was based on policy considerations.
Q. Uh-huh. Now, could you tell me, in 1988, Iraq routed Iran, if you recall, and you were the Deputy D.C.I. [Director of Central Intelligence] at that time. Is that not correct?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. Isn't it true that you refocused collection and analytical resources away from Iraq toward other issues in areas of concern after that routing? . . .
A. Our concentration on the Iran-Iraq war had imposed some limitations on our satellite capabilities in terms of some longstanding problems in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, and so once the war was over, we tried to address some of those issues and problems.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. What I'm getting at is here was the end of the war. Iraq was still a problem; at this point, admittedly the most powerful country in the region. And we moved our intelligence resources elsewhere. . . . Was that a wise thing to have done?
A. I believe the intelligence assessment that was done in 1989, Senator Bradley, stated the view that Saddam Hussein and Iraq would be spending the next several years, more likely than not, engaged in rebuilding. Iraq had taken a fairly heavy pounding in the war, even though they won it and had the kind of capabilities that you're -- you're describing. . . .
Q. Uh-huh. Were you responsible for directing this? [the assessment]
A. No, sir, I don't think so.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Another area of real importance in the world, of course, in the new world, is China. And I recall an exchange we had back in 1986 in the committee. . . . What would you do differently to catch that kind of change in China that you did not do to catch that kind of change in the Soviet Union?
A. Part of the problem is being able to measure broad popular sentiment and overall conditions in a country that is fundamentally a difficult place in which to travel or to gather information or to talk to people.
Now I know lots of travelers go to China, lots of travelers went to the Soviet Union. But it certainly is an environment in which people are afraid to talk and often afraid to be candid. I think more can be done through expanded human intelligence collection.
I think part of what can be done is simply to ensure that people are thinking about these problems, that they are sitting down and trying to identify, here are what the different alternative paths may be historically for this country, and here are the indications of what we might see if the country were moving in one or another of those paths, and those indications would then perhaps provide a guide for collection.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS
By SENATOR RUDMAN
 Q. There are a few areas that I think do need some emphasis here to keep this record straight.
Senator Metzenbaum referred during a long series of questions, both last evening and this morning, to a November-December -- I don't know the exact date -- appearance of yours before the Senate Intelligence Committee, in which you made known your strong feelings about notification.
Then in the questions following that narrative, there was the suggestion that somehow you were disingenuous to the committee, that you fact misrepresented to the Congress your point of view because at the time you were doing that you were aware of an unreported finding. . . . I want to, for the record, refer to Iran-contra exhibit JMP-28, which is on the White House stationary of Jan. 17, 1986. I might say parenthetically that I hope that some day I will never have to talk about this subject again, but I guess it just keeps coming up. It's almost like a typhus epidemic in that anybody within five miles of the germ either died, is infected, or is barely able to survive. . . .
The Jan. 17 White House exhibit I have in front of me was a memorandum for the President of the United States, then Ronald Reagan, from his national security adviser, John Poindexter. It's very instructive, in reading that, to read the last paragraph. . . . It said the following, and I would point out this time you were the Deputy Director for Intelligence. Am I correct?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. That is a very esteemed position but it is hardly the final policy leadership of the C.I.A., is that correct?
A. Yes, sir.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. In the finding itself, in the operative clause, it says the following: "I hereby find" -- this is the President of the United States speaking -- " hereby find that the following operation in a foreign country, including all support necessary to such operation, is important to the national security of the United States, and due to its extreme sensitivity and security risks, I determine it is essential to limit prior notice and direct the Director of Central Intelligence to refrain from reporting this finding to the Congress as provided in Section 501 of the National Security Act of 1947 as amended, until I otherwise direct." . . . Do you feel that as a Deputy Director of Intelligence or as the Deputy Director of Intelligence that you at that point were free to violate that restriction laid on the agency by the President of the United States?
A. No, sir.
Q. Now to carry it a step further, what you have said to us in testimony is that were you to find yourself in that position, you would -- and I'd like you to finish the sentence.
A. I characterize that if I had found myself asked the specific question in April 1986 confronted with the directive from the President I would in effect seek time to go back and say that I had been confronted with this situation, that I had to respond to the committee, and that the only possibilities were either to tell them about the finding or to go back and tell them that I had been directed by the President not to answer the question.
But I would have sought guidance in that way and I would have come back to the committee immediately. I am assuming it would have been the very next day.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. I want to talk about the famous Allen meeting of Oct. 1, 1986 and the memo that was executed pursuant to that. I'm not very anxious to air soiled laundry of the C.I.A. at this hearing, but there is something that really ought to be said here, and I am aware of it. I have been made aware of it, and I want to discuss it with you in as diplomatic terms as I can. You, Mr. Gates, are a product of the intelligence directorate. Am I correct?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. And at the time, Clair George was the director of operations. Am I correct?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. Am I correct that there was -- you characterize it as mistrust, but would I be accurate in saying that the relationship between you and Mr. George was somewhat strained at times?
A. We cooperated in some areas, and we had some strong disagreements in others, yes, sir.
Q. Would it also be fair to say that, although neither of you knew what the outcome be, that you were looked at as people who were upward-bound in the agency and there might have been some thought on someone's part that you were competitors for advancement within the agency? Is that a fair statement?
A. I suppose some may have thought that, yes.
Q. Well, many people thought that, Mr. Gates.
Now, when Mr. Allen came to you with this complaint, he was essentially talking about something that was within the realm of the operations directorate. Am I correct?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. And you were in the intelligence directorate.
A. By that time, sir, I was the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.
Q. But your background, I should have said ----
A. Yes.
Q. ---- was in the Intelligence Directorate.
A. Yes.
Q. Let me ask you this flat-out question, Mr. Gates. It's -- I've never asked it to you in our private meetings. I saved it for today. During that time when you were dealing with Mr. Casey, who you knew had a rather direct pipeline down to the D.O. [operations directorate] and, in fact, would even bypass the D.O. and go to some of his subordinates, Mr. George's subordinates, such as Mr. Fiers, was it not a fact that you -- one of the reasons you proceeded with extreme caution was that you did not want to get yourself into a situation of antagonizing the operations directorate without adequate and substantial cause to go forward?
A. I certainly was concerned that they not view me as having some sort of a inherent suspicion of them or mistrust of them in terms of their activities and their integrity. I did worry about that, yes. . . .
And I think also it was part of the reason why I moved slowly in involving myself in the activities of the clandestine services. I indicated yesterday only moving to get these briefings on a couple of these operations at the end of July, several months after I became deputy.
Q. Well, I thank you for that answer. It confirms what I have been told by others and what I have thought. And one of the problems of these hearings is they take place in a rather sterile atmosphere, and to try to get the real-life feelings of people who are on-line in the position facing the crisis is a very difficult thing to convey. . . .

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS: New-Era Espionage;
More Spies and Less Costly Hardware Are at Heart of Gates's Plan for C.I.A.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates this week committed himself to refashion American espionage for a new era, including some changes, like a steep increase in human, as opposed to electronic, spying, that would reverse decades-old trends.
But he stopped well short of endorsing the kind of wholesale overhaul and cuts in the $30 billion-a-year spy bureaucracy that growing numbers of critics are demanding now that the Soviet military threat has eased. 
 If Mr. Gates is confirmed, as seemed increasingly likely today, his public statements suggest that he will try to streamline and refocus the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister organizations along lines advocated by many critical, but moderate experts. Some of his proposals, like expanding the number of agents gathering intelligence while reducing the reliance on satellites and other electronic systems, have been debated for years.
The Gates blueprint reflects the views of his boss, President Bush, and most members of the Senate Intelligence Committee who are debating whether to support his confirmation as Director of Central Intelligence.
Mr. Gates's proposal of limited changes comes at a time when the C.I.A. and its sister intelligence agencies are under sharper and more sustained attack than at almost any time in their history.
On one hand, Congressional budget-cutters are proposing sharp reductions in spending, arguing that the need for espionage has fallen with the military threat from Moscow. On the other, the agency is being widely accused of misreading the most important sea of changes in recent history, from the end of Soviet-style Communism to the corrupting effect of narcotics on global politics to the rise of Islamic fundamentalism and the military adventures of Iraq. The debate was crystallized on a recent cover of Time Magazine that posed the question, in bold type: "Is the C.I.A. obsolete?"
Mr. Gates is not oblivious to the criticism, and in his testimony this week, he has acknowledged its validity. "At a time of revolutionary change abroad and government-wide fiscal constraints at home, U.S. intelligence cannot remain fundamentally unaffected," he told the intelligence panel on Monday. "C.I.A. and U.S. intelligence must change and be seen to change, or confront irrelevance and growing sentiment for their dismantlement."
Mr. Gates's own proposals for changes implicitly criticize American espionage for pursuing secrets that are no longer important, writing too much about topics that the Government does not care about, and failing to mesh properly with the Pentagon bureaucracy in times of military crisis, like the Persian Gulf war.
But his proposal, given to the panel on Monday and enlarged on today, calls more for reorganizing the system than scrapping it. He also warned in his testimony today that the C.I.A. would be unable to make some wholesale changes, like shifting spies or analysts to environmental problems, because it would lack the money.
Mr. Gates's plan calls for the White House to immediately compile a master list of information deemed vital to national security in the next 10 to 15 years. That list would become a map for budgetary and bureaucratic changes in the espionage agencies in this decade.
Mr. Gates's plan calls for "dramatically" increasing the use of human spies and limiting covert operations, like C.I.A.-backed guerrilla wars undertaken in Central America and Afghanistan. He also proposes to better integrate the duties of the civilian C.I.A. and the warren of intelligence agencies at the Pentagon, so that bureaucratic disputes and communications glitches do not cripple the military in times of crisis.
Some Government officials, including General H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf war, sharply criticized the intelligence bureaucracy this summer for failing to adequately integrate support for troops and aircraft in the battlefield.
Mr. Gates would push to free much of the intelligence agencies' spending from direct control by the Pentagon. That would effectively give him more freedom to spend money where he believes it is needed, because spending for espionage would no longer fluctuate in lock step with each spike or dip in the military's increasingly volatile budget.
 
More Open to the Public
 Finally, in a move that is surely controversial within the C.I.A., he pledges to enlarge on efforts by the last C.I.A. director, William H. Webster, to make the agency more open to the public and Congress. Mr. Gates argued this week that rampant public mistrust of the C.I.A. can only be allayed by making the agency's activities less mysterious and open to distortion.
By and large, Mr. Gates's proposals are not surprising. They are in large part an endorsement of Mr. Webster, who began remaking the agency's public image and sought to expand the number and versatility of its spies and place new curbs on covert activities during his four years as Director of Central Intelligence.
Others are ideas touted by private experts such as Roy Godson, an intelligence expert at the Washington-based National Strategy Information Center, or mentors like Mr. Gates's chief private supporter, Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, retired, a former top C.I.A. official.
They also reflect the reality of 1990's espionage, a profession in which technology no longer reigns supreme and old-fashioned, George Smiley tradecraft is again in ascendance.
 
Spies Versus Satellites
 Satellites, once praised as the miracle workers of intelligence, proved unable to divine the military intentions of a Saddam Hussein or photograph the economic collapse of a Soviet empire. In a time of fiscal austerity, they also have proven too costly for widespread, everyday use; the C.I.A. can hire literally thousands of spies for the cost of one moderately expensive reconnaissance spacecraft.
Mr. Gates's proposals dovetail with recommendations from the intelligence committee, including its chairman, Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, something that cannot help but advance Mr. Gates's confirmation prospects.
Because they almost surely carry President Bush's personal endorsement as well, they stand a good chance of being enacted should Mr. Gates be given the top C.I.A. job.
Two former White House intelligence officials said today that Mr. Gates's ideas have merit.
"I think he gave a realistic appraisal," said Vincent M. Cannistraro, a former C.I.A. officer and intelligence director under President Reagan. "He said about as much as he can say in public testimony without making people jump out of the seventh floor," a reference to the C.I.A.'s executive offices.
Mr. Cannistraro has criticized the agency's response to global changes, even suggesting recently that the C.I.A. could be dismantled and its functions spun off elsewhere.
His former boss in the White House, Kenneth R. deGraffenreid, said today that Mr. Gates's real test would come not in proposing reforms, but in steering them through the bureaucracy.
As director, Mr. Gates would oversee a vast network of espionage agencies that includes the C.I.A., the Defense Intelligence Agency, which performs military analysis; the National Security Agency, which conducts electronic eavesdropping; the National Reconnaissance Office, which launches and controls satellites, and intelligence divisions at the State Department, Treasury Department, Justice Department and elsewhere.
"Given that Gates is a reformer, I don't think those are platitudes. He knows where he's going," said Mr. deGraffenreid, now a private consultant on national security matters.
Mr. Webster was sometimes criticized for failing to push his reforms hard enough, he said. Few believe that the aggressive Mr. Gates will suffer that flaw should he win the top C.I.A. job.

HEADLINE: The Night Guns 'n' Roses' 'Illusions' Became Real

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Monday was a good night to be a teen-age heavy-metal fan in New York City.
At midnight 1,500 people, most of them young, white and male, were lined up outside Tower Records in Greenwich Village. That was the bewitching hour when the two long-awaited new albums by Guns 'n' Roses, "Use Your Illusions I" and "Use Your Illusions II," went on sale across the country. 
 But those who showed up at the downtown Tower and three other record stores in Manhattan witnessed a second special event. In what might be described as a mild publicity coup, Epic Records cashed in on the presale hoopla that Geffen Records had created for Guns 'n' Roses by sending Ozzy Osbourne, its own heavy-metal heavyweight, to the two HMV and two Tower stores to promote his new album, "Don't Blame Me."
"We're here to see Ozzy and shake his hand and buy the Guns 'n' Roses albums," said 19-year-old Russ Porcino of Staten Island. "You're getting two things for one."
Anyone imagining that the demand was a product of a publicity agent's hyperactive mind, however, had only to stand in the line outside the downtown Tower store. For John Gainfort, 27, of Manhattan, who was there with a friend, Mike Torres, Guns 'n' Roses "is the greatest."
"Just about everybody I know is waiting to get the record," he said. "It may be a bit hyped, in that the band took so long to release the record, but it's worth the wait."
Inside the store, fans attacked boxes of the albums, grabbing both volumes. As soon as a photographer or television camera came close, buyers would jump up and shout, holding the albums up in the air, creating perfect photo opportunities and showing their tribal colors.
By 2 A.M., 621 copies of the "Use Your Illusions" compact disk and 224 cassettes had been sold in the downtown Tower store. (The store had no LP's available.) "I didn't think Guns 'n' Roses would do so well," said Mathew Koenig, a regional manager for Tower. "It's the Village, and the Village isn't Guns 'n' Roses territory."
Mr. Osbourne, publicity coup or not, didn't break 100, CD's and tapes combined, at the store.
 
2 hours, 500,000 Sales
 The "Use Your Illusions" CD's sold 500,000 copies nationwide in the first two hours it was on sale, said a Geffen spokesman. Because these sales are coming from the core Guns 'n' Roses audience, it is hard to predict the albums' eventual total sales. But most industry figures interviewed said the CD's have a chance to hit the level of sales achieved by blockbuster albums like Michael Jackson's "Thriller" and Bruce Springsteen's "Born in the U.S.A." And importantly, they, along with a slew of other big records soon to be released, should help the industry recover frpm its current recession.
"It's just amazing; it's just incredible," said Ed Rosenblatt, president of Geffen. "We're sitting on top of the world.
The Camelot chain, based in Canton, Ohio, which had ordered a quarter of a million copies, sold 10,000 copies in the early hours Tuesday at the seven stores it opened at midnight. A spokesman for the chain predicted it would sell 100,000 copies of "Use Your Illusions" in the first week.
Dick Odette, vice president for purchasing for the Minneapolis-based Musicland chain, said: "We opened around 70 stores on Monday night. We had ordered a little shy of a half-million copies, and this is the biggest single release we've ever had. The demand is real. It feels real good."
 
Too Wild for K Mart
 Two of the largest sales outlets for rock records, K Mart and Wal-Mart, refused to carry the Guns 'n' Roses albums. Both chains are known for not selling any records that might be considered controversial or offensive. Guns 'n' Roses, in turn, parodies the language of warning stickers placed on records by the Recording Industry Association of America. The "Use Your Illusions" albums carry stickers that say, "This album contains language which some listeners may find objectionable," followed by an expletive.
Eddie Gilreath, the head of sales at Geffen, was quoted in Billboard this week as saying the company could have shipped a million more copies had the two chains decided to sell the album.
"I think the demand is so high for the record that kids walking into a K Mart looking for the record will just go somewhere else," Mr. Rosenblatt said. "At some point it will hurt, in that parents looking for a birthday or Christmas present may not buy it. But the stores have a great deal more to lose than we do as a record company. It's the image of the band that gets them, and they're frightened."

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
House Votes Bill to Extend Jobless Pay by Margin That Would Defeat Veto

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The House passed legislation today to provide extra unemployment benefits for three million people who have been out of work at least half a year. The bill, which is similar to one President Bush killed in August, was passed by an apparently veto-proof vote of 283 to 125.
The President was able to block the August bill without vetoing it. The measure passed today was written in a way that would force him to cast a veto if he wants to stop it. 
 The vote on the $6.3 billion measure, which would provide up to 20 extra weeks of benefits for the unemployed in states hit hard by the recession, was 11 votes more than the two-thirds majority required to override a Presidential veto, which the Office of Management and Budget threatened today. Forty-eight Republicans joined 234 Democrats and one independent in support; 107 Republicans and 18 Democrats were opposed.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said he would try to bring up similar legislation in the Senate on Thursday.
The measure that died in August attracted much greater Republican support, 70 more than today's, after Republicans were assured that Mr. Bush would be able to kill it easily. The Aug. 2 vote was 375 to 45, with 118 Republicans in favor.
Under the August version, the extended benefits could not go to the jobless unless Mr. Bush both signed the bill and declared an emergency under the terms of last year's budget act to limit the deficit. He signed the bill, saying he wanted to show his sympathy for the unemployed, but refused to declare an emergency, saying, "I won't bust the budget."
Today's legislation would waive the budget act requirements. If Mr. Bush signed it, the benefits would flow, and the deficit would increase. If he vetoed it, Congress would have a chance to muster the two-thirds votes needed to override.
But it is not clear just what kind of bill will be sent to Mr. Bush. Mr. Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, plans to bring up the same bill that was passed in August. That bill would stir less opposition in the Senate, where the rules, or the absence of rules, make it easy for a determined minority to delay action.
Differences in the two bills would be settled in a House-Senate conference. The Senate might give in on the emergency issue. In exchange, it might expect the House to drop its proposal that would make the changes in the unemployment insurance law permanent, not temporary, as in Mr. Bentsen's bill.
 
Bill Echoes Democrats' Theme
 The bill passed today re-emphasized the Democratic theme that President Bush was more concerned with the problems of foreign countries than with those of unemployed Americans. Democrats have complained for weeks that he was quick to endorse emergency status for spending abroad, but not at home.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who has been the chief sponsor of the House bill, urged passage. "We've spent billions to bail out the S.& L.'s," he said. "We've helped Kurds in Turkey. We've helped the Bangladeshis. It's time to help Americans."
Speaker Thomas S. Foley, talking to reporters as the House voted, said he hoped President Bush would sign the legislation because high unemployment continued even after a recovery began and hundreds of thousands of people each month exhausted their state benefits, which are usually limited to 26 weeks.
"Around the country I don't see anything that could go for any sort of a certainly robust recovery, an energetic recovery or a sharp recovery or vigorous recovery," he said.
Richard A. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, disagreed, telling reporters after a lunch with Senate Republicans that "the economy has turned" and the Administration felt that legislation to extend benefits was unnecessary.
 
Dole Substitute Backed
 But he said the Administration could support a substitute that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, plans to offer. It would cost about half as much and provide a maximum of 10 weeks of additional benefits. The Dole bill includes provisions to auction unused radio frequencies, which he said would raise enough money to pay for the additional benefits.
Under the House bill, the new payments would come from a Federal trust fund created to pay extended benefits. The fund, which pays half the current unemployment benefits while a state pays half, now stands at $8 billion.
Benefits can now be extended for 13 weeks beyond the regular 26 weeks in a state when joblessness among its workers who are covered by unemployment isnurance reaches 6 percent. The benefits can also be extended for the same period when the rate reaches 5 percent if the level of the insured jobless exceeds by one-fifth the average level in that state over the last two years.
The unemployment rate among those covered by insurance, about half the work force, is much lower than the total unemployment rate, which was 6.8 percent in August. So under the law as it now stands, those extended benefits are going only to unemployed workers in Rhode Island and Puerto Rico.
 
A Total Unemployment Measure
 Under the bill passed today, the measuring standard used would be total unemployment, not insured unemployment, averaged over the previous six months. In states with 8 percent unemployment, an additional 20 weeks of benefits could be paid to jobless workers. According to the most recent data available, through July, that would add Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan and West Virginia to Puerto Rico and Rhode Island.
In states with 7 percent unemploymengt, an extra 15 weeks of benefits would be paid. Workers in the nation's two most-populous states, California and New York, would qualify, as would those in five other states and the District of Columbia.
In states with 6 percent unemployment, an additional 10 weeks of benefits would be paid, and in all others, five extra weeks would be paid.
All the additional benefits would be paid entirely from Federal money.
Another provision would make people who leave the armed services eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, rather than the 13 weeks that is their limit now. They would also be able to start collecting after one week instead of the current four. Both changes would treat them as civilians are now treated.

HEADLINE: Spiraling Welfare Roll Dominates Dinkins's Report Card

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Issuing the first full-year report card on his administration yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins painted a dark picture of New York City's growing social problems and service burdens, dominated by a welfare roll that is climbing to nearly 1 million people for the first time in 15 years.
The Mayor's Management Report, an annual survey that has been issued since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, found dirtier streets, more homeless families in temporary housing and more children in foster care, spiraling demand for social services for AIDS cases, a drop in the portion of the city's garbage that is recycled and a swelling jail population.
 
No 'Cooking' of Indicators
 But that is not the worst of it. The report covered only the fiscal year that ended June 30 and does not reflect the latest round of service cuts in the $28.5 billion budget adopted in July. For example, those cuts are projected to leave half the city's 59 sanitation districts rated less than 50 percent clean, up from 12 districts now. 
 "It is what it is," said Harvey Robins, the Mayor's director of operations, who compiled the report. When reporters teased him about the tendency of such summaries to "cook" the hundreds of pages of statistical indicators in the most favorable way, he said: "Not only didn't we cook them. This year, we didn't even put them on the stove."
The depth of the city's managerial problems was underlined at another gathering in another room at City Hall yesterday, as administration officials acknowledged that their program to stem the flow of families entering shelters for the homeless had failed to do so. They predicted that by next June, 6,000 families would be living in the shelters, breaking the 1987 record set during the Koch administration. [Page B3.]
The growing welfare roll, amounting to about one-eighth of the city's population, was not unexpected, and accelerates a trend that began in 1990, reversing several years of declines since the early 80's. On June 30, the city had about 937,000 people on the rolls, up from 860,000 the year before. City officials attributed the rise primarily to the recession and expressed concern that it was a harbinger of socioeconomic problems that they would be confronting for years to come.
"You have an explosion in the demand for social services, partly because there are more and more people who are in need," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "And we don't have resources to support it as much as we would like. It's going to become increasingly difficult, or if we do respond, it's going to have to come from other areas of government. On a global basis, more and more of our resources are going to have to go to solve these problems, unless we can get the Federal Government back into it."
Mary Nakashian, First Deputy Commissioner in the Human Resources Administration's family support administration, said the welfare roll tended to be a lagging indicator of economic trends, because, to qualify for benefits, recipients must first show they have exhausted other options. The city shares the cost of the various public assistance programs with the state and Federal Government, but in the current year the city's share alone is projected to be nearly $700 million.
While the welfare figures show the depth of the city's problems, officials said, they also demonstrate its commitment to confronting them.
 
Some Good News
 "In some ways, this is an indication of the city's capacity to meet needs," Ms. Nakashian said. "We're trying to make sure that people who deserve and are entitled to get on these programs do so."
The report was not without nuggets of good news. More streets were resurfaced, reports of child abuse and neglect fell, more vacant lots were cleaned and there were fewer civilian complaints against police officers.
The city also managed to produce a record 4,173 new or renovated apartments for the homeless, slightly more than the year before, despite cuts in its capital spending. But even this was a sign of the burdens the city faces, since it embarked on building such housing in the 80's only after the Federal Government cut its own efforts.
Mr. Dinkins, who has made efforts to organize other big-city mayors to lobby Washington for more Federal aid, likened Washington's treatment of cities to banks' refusals to make home loans in poor or minority neighborhoods, saying, "The redlining of America's cities by its Federal Government must cease."
The report covered so many fields that few clear themes emerged. In introducing it, Mr. Dinkins said that his administration was committed, amid fiscal troubles, to delivering "the same or greater service for less cost." But when asked to cite two or three examples of that, he groped in vain for an answer, eventually citing a decline in crime, a decline in reports of child abuse and the serving of more meals for the elderly.
"I've got to hasten to say I don't mean I'm satisfied," he said.
The Mayor took pains in his remarks to point up that overall reports of crime fell 4 percent, though murders and manslaughters rose almost 5 percent. Mr. Dinkins said it was not clear whether the city's policing strategies had much effect one way or the other.
Despite the hiring of 1,488 new police officers under the Mayor's ambitious anti-crime plan, the average number of officers scheduled to go on patrol each day stayed basically flat, at just over 10,000, because the new recruits were still in training.
Because of delays and reductions in the city's recycling program, the portion of the city's waste that was recycled totaled just 4.9 percent, down from 6.7 percent the year before.

LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: A City's Determination To Rewrite History Puts Its Classrooms in Chaos

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17

 BODY:
The easy part for the city of Oakland was saying "No" to the social studies textbooks and the vision of multicultural education ordained by the state of California.
Now comes the harrowing task: To rewrite history and do it quickly so that the district's 40,000 elementary and junior high school students do not fall behind while their elders bicker. 
 California, the nation's most populous state and an education maverick, last year sanctioned a new set of social studies textbooks for the primary and junior high grades. But the Oakland school board, overriding the city's teachers and siding with its ethnic advocacy groups, rejected the texts last spring on the ground that the state was bullying them into accepting books that did not reflect a district where 9 of 10 children are non-white.
Since then, amid good intentions but misguided plans, this East Bay city's schools have been thrown into chaos. Two weeks into the academic year, students and teachers face the disorderly reality of learning with no books, old books or books widely considered inferior to the ones that were jettisoned. Meanwhile, district officials and community representatives continue to argue over the new materials -- what they will say, who will write them, and how much they will cost.
 
Students Lost in the Battle
 "The war did not stop with the vote, and the kids may get sacrificed in the battle," said Toni Cook, a member of the Oakland Board of Education, who voted against the books, as did all four black members of the seven-member board. "That, in fact, is the tragedy."
Multicultural education, and a narrower movement in certain urban school districts known as Afrocentrism, is being debated from one end of America to the other. There is little dispute that students should be taught more about the contributions and viewpoints of ethnic and cultural groups other than white Europeans. But there is rancorous debate about how to do that without distorting history or stirring racial discord.
California was the first state to tackle the issue in a sweeping way, with a curriculum overhaul in 1987 that has since been translated, subject by subject, into textbooks. This spring, New York started the same process.
The district-by-district battle over whether to approve the textbooks was bitter here in California, the nation's largest and most ethnically diverse state. But only a small number of districts, Oakland primary among them, rejected the Houghton Mifflin books, which are generally agreed to be flawed but better than the aging texts now in the schools.
 
Copier Machine in Overdrive
 In their place, the Oakland Board of Education selected different texts for certain grades and received state waivers to buy them, even though the alternatives are widely considered, even in Oakland, to be inferior to the Houghton Mifflin series.
But in grades four, five and seven they found no books that matched the new statewide curriculum. In the fourth and fifth grades, where that framework still stresses California and America history, old textbooks have been dusted off, books that date to 1985 and reflect virtually no multicultural perspectives.
In seventh grade, things are even worse because of major changes in the curriculum. There, a hodgepodge of history and geography has been replaced by the study of history from A.D. 500 to 1789, with a focus on non-Western civilizations. The old books make no sense with the new curriculum. And the teachers have no lesson plans, dittos or other materials from years past, and little knowledge of Islamic, Ming Chinese or Aztec history, which they now must teach.
The result is that the rejected text has sneaked into the classrooms. At the Claremont Middle School, for instance, where the Houghton Mifflin books were tested last year, seventh-grade teachers are lining up at the copier machine to duplicate chapters from "Across the Centuries."
"We're in better shape than other schools because we have one set of the books here," said Steven Weinberg, the chairman of the social studies department, who voted for the books when the teachers sent their favorable recommendation to the school board.
But teachers at the Claremont School say they have already used a semester's worth of copier paper in the first two weeks of school.
Teachers with experience in multicultural education are having the easiest time improvising. Take Cheryl R. Washington, a special education teacher at Whittier Elementary School, who also teaches African-American history to youngsters in her neighborhood each Saturday morning. Last week, with no textbooks and using homemade materials, Ms. Washington taught her fourth and fifth graders a different lesson about continents than the one they learned last year.
"We've always said that this is a continent," she said, pointing to Europe on a map. She showed them that it is not a land mass surrounded by water -- the standard definition -- but rather is attached to Asia. "Instead of calling it Europe, some people call it Eurasia. That is another point of view. No view is right, no view is wrong and you might want to talk it over with your parents."
 
Controlling the Curriculum
 At the school district headquarters, far from the realities of Ms. Washington's or Mr. Weinberg's classrooms, the bickering goes on, as it has since last spring when the board split along racial lines and rejected the textbooks.
At that crucial meeting, outnumbered supporters of the textbooks were heckled and called names and some were so intimidated they left without speaking. "Democracy in action," Sheila Jordan, the only white member of the board, said later.
Now the fight is about power more than principle, about whether the insiders from the school district or the outsiders from the community will control the new curriculum. At last week's board meeting, the two sides argued about who would select the supplementary reading lists and who would appoint the review committees. Decisions were delayed, study groups formed and more meetings scheduled.
So far, there is not much to review. The district has issued each teacher a generic geography lesson, appropriate for the grade, which is not very useful and covers only six weeks. The district also plans to use lessons prepared by a county consortium of educators. And the community committee that led rejection of the books is at work on alternative materials.
 
A Worksheet Rejected
 That committee, which has about 100 members, spent the summer writing its own six-week lesson plans for grades four, five and seven. It was a "hairy" process, said Fred Ellis, a professor of education at California State University at Hayward and a leader of the group. Many ethnic organizations participated, each wanting its own group's heritage told in its own way, and decisions were made by consensus.
The district is willing to use the committee's lessons for the fourth and fifth grades, although they are sketchy. But the seventh-grade material has been deemed unacceptable by the district's curriculum department and by some board members.
One section of the seventh-grade material, criticized in many news accounts here, has been withdrawn, Mr. Ellis said. It was a worksheet, headlined "Crimes of a Racist Society," which included pictures of the non-white victims of an accused mass murderer in Milwaukee and an editorial cartoon of Judge Clarence Thomas, the Supreme Court nominee.
Another section, unchanged, asks students a series of questions such as: "Why do such enormous inequities of wealth and power exist in the world and within the United States? What might be the economic/political interests of some people for keeping some communities more wealthy than others?"
 
Squeezing in Medieval History
 Other worksheets include articles about toxic dumps in minority communities and polls showing many white people consider blacks lazy.
"These issues of racism are very important and they need to be addressed by students," said Shelly Weintraub, who runs the social studies division of the curriculum department. "But somewhere along the line, we have to teach medieval world history."
The creators of the new materials argue that they are imperfect but pointed in the right direction.
"It's a curriculum in creation," said Kitty Kelly Epstein, an associate professor of education at Holy Names College here and a leader of the committee. "It reflects the struggles and debates of this community. We can go into the classroom with this and evoke the big questions and then modify it based on criticism."
The board shows no signs of endorsing that approach, despite having few alternatives. At each meeting, the combatants seem farther apart; the community reverberates with charges and countercharges.
Ms. Epstein said the state is to blame for the current mess because it tried to force its choice of textbooks on a city that did not want them. The state Superintendent of Public Education, Bill Honig, accused Oakland of "making political points" at the expense of its children.
Board members who opposed the textbooks said the district should not have counted on a rubber stamp vote and should have prepared an alternative to the textbooks. And dissenting members said that the board was unduly influenced by a small but noisy clique.
Ms. Cook noted that there is more than enough blame to go around. "It's been a combination of errors, faux pas and power plays," she said. "And nobody among us should be casting a stone."

Washington, a special education teacher at Whittier Elementary School, had to use homemade materials and no textbooks to teach her students a lesson about continents. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
One Red Cent

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Senator Sam Nunn's Armed Services Committee and the Senate cut perhaps $100 million from the Administration's military budget request of $290.8 billion.
Representative Les Aspin's Armed Services Committee and the House did about as much to protect that budget the fiscal year beginning next month. 
 With accounting adjustments and the like, the reductions effectively equal about one red cent. The cuts rank among the very smallest since 1945. Most tellingly, they come at that very moment in history when the Soviet threat has collapsed, when the U.S. deficit soars toward $2 trillion and when America is falling apart.
Why can't Democratic leaders find more than one red military cent to nip from the 1992 budget nearing final passage? Why, when even President Bush -- rebuffing Defense Secretary Dick Cheney -- speaks of "an opportunity for a vastly restructured national security posture," do so many Democrats still speak with such caution about future defense budgets?
Try politics and politics. Democrats still seem to wilt under charges of being soft on defense and tremble from the memory of their wrong-headed opposition to the Persian Gulf war. And they wilt and tremble just when world events should make them bold and visionary, and when Americans are ready to reorder defense and domestic priorities.
The Democrats have another political reason for being timid on the Pentagon's 1992 budget. They made a complicated budget deal with the White House last year that destroyed their political incentive to cut defense. The agreement effectively barred Democrats from shifting money torn from arms to unemployment benefits and highways. A Pentagon dollar saved could be applied only to deficit reduction. And for all the Democrats' yammering about the importance of slicing the deficit, they saw little political payoff in transferring money to a Treasury bank account. In this way the Pentagon budget ceiling worked out with the White House became a floor as well.
George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, says he is willing now to reopen the deal and hit defense, but House Speaker Tom Foley thinks it is too late and too hard to beat a Presidential veto. Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin agree with Mr. Foley and have another reason for holding the line: They helped Mr. Cheney set the Pentagon ceiling for 1992 and feel queasy about further U.S. force reductions.
The two chairmen say they are satisfied for now with the Cheney plan to draw down U.S. forces by 25 percent over six years. But those levels were decided upon before the failed coup in Moscow and before the virtual implosion of the Soviet Government and military establishment.
Mr. Nunn promises to look at the Soviet threat again, but not before the 1993 budget. Mr. Aspin agrees and went further yesterday by outlining standards for making larger than planned cuts.
He says he will propose new cuts for next year only if there are further "irreversible" changes in the Soviet Union, specifically only if Moscow dismantles its still mighty military-industrial complex. That sounds good, but it doesn't work.
The Soviets should junk most of this complex (but how much?), and we should not give them economic aid until they do. But if they can't do what's right for them, that does not mean we can't do what makes sense for us. Why tie our interests to their bureaucratic inertia?
Does Mr. Aspin fear that unless virtually dismantled, Soviet factories will crank up and Soviet armies will invade Europe? No, he says, because the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Europe and the collapse of the Warsaw Pact are irreversible. Well, if these are irreversible what is he worried about, a Soviet attack on China?
He clearly does worry about the 30,000 Soviet nuclear weapons. Well, that number will soon be halved, and we still have our matching power. Besides, what are the Soviets going to do, threaten nuclear war to get more Western corn? The demise of the Soviet Union does not suspend the laws of mutual deterrence; it opens the gates to further cuts in nuclear arms to go along with the massive cuts in Soviet conventional forces already under way.
Arise, Congress! Arise, moderates and liberals! You have your country to save and nothing to lose but your seats.

HEADLINE: White House Should Stay With Lead Cleanup

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The failure of the Bush Administration to invest in our children's health is brought home by withdrawal of support for a Federal leadership role in preventing lead poisoning (news article, Aug. 24). This reversal of Federal support for lead poisoning prevention came after pressure from the National Association of Realtors, who predict that lead clean-up would raise housing prices $5,000 to $10,000. 
 Lead poisoning is the most common and socially devastating disease of young American children, resulting in lifelong stupidity for at least 3 million to 4 million future citizens. This invisible epidemic costs the country more than $28 billion. A recent study by the Centers for Disease Control shows that a $32 billion investment in lead poisoning prevention over 20 years would save $60 billion in health-care and special-educations costs, a figure that also takes account of increased income associated with increased IQ.
Lead abatement of an average housing unit of five to six rooms costs less then $3,000. How much more productive it is to spend half as much money on hazardous lead abatements than on the mandatory lifetime costs for children disabled by a preventable, but incurable disease.
The loss of Federal public health leadership will inevitably cost all of us in higher taxes, as we bear the double burden of increased medical and educational costs for the children affected, and the loss of their productive potential.
Yet a concerted societywide effort could virtually eliminate this disease in 20 years.
The Bush Administration should not back away from its own strategic plan. Rather it should create a lead-cleanup superfund to reimburse homeowners for the cost of hazard abatement. This active health policy would both reassure realtors that the housing market recovery will not be jeopardized and prevent the lifelong agony of millions of children and their families.
 
MARIANNE C. FAHS
Assoc. Prof., Health Economics
Mount Sinai Medical Center
New York, Sept. 7, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: On the Runway: Democrats

 BODY:
For weeks now, the best word to describe Democratic Presidential candidates for 1992 was "former." One dropout followed another: Nunn, McGovern, Gephardt, Gore, Rockefeller. And the absence of a campaign impelled this page to try provoking discussion of issues with a series of editorials, "Pinch-Hitting for the Democrats." Suddenly, the field of eager candidates looks like the flight line at La Guardia at rush hour.
Former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts was for four months the sole candidate. Then Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia launched his campaign last Friday; Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa took off Sunday; and revving their engines on the taxiway are Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and former Gov. Jerry Brown of California, among others. 
 To citizens dispirited by the endless 1988 campaign, that may sound like the Seven Dwarfs all over again. But this campaign can't help but be much shorter. The New Hampshire primary is only five months away. More important, these candidates can provide what both their party and the public now need most: an argument.
The Democrats, who have occupied the White House for only four years since 1968, need to argue out what they stand for. And the public needs to argue out what America stands for. The collapse of Communism creates a reverberating need to redefine America's enemies, and goals.
There have not in recent years been many illuminating arguments over compelling priorities -- certainly not in the 1988 campaign when Michael Dukakis won the Democratic nomination with a pledge of "good jobs for good wages" and George Bush won election with a campaign chiefly memorable for images of a paroled rapist and the flag.
Public concerns, however, are piling up. Among them are the widely felt disgust with politics . . . the need to recast Federal spending toward the future . . . the crippled health care system . . . the pressures on families, especially poor families . . . racial tension, and justice.
Taken together, the Democrats on, and just off, the runway address all these concerns. Paul Tsongas stands against divisive racial politics and for realistic economics, though in terms that imply perfumed protectionism. Governor Wilder, while standing up for civil rights, reaches out for general support. Senator Harkin starts his campaign full of flags and fight on behalf of traditional working-class liberalism.
Governor Clinton offers a record of achievement in dealing with the problems of children and sets out a creative anti-poverty position. And former Governor Brown sounds like the Outsider Incarnate, speaking for people who feel disconnected from politics.
None of these candidates so far offer much of an international vision, implicitly acknowledging the strength of President Bush's performance in handling the Communist world and the Middle East. None so far have been forced to face up to the need to pay for domestic reforms. All must be regarded as long, long shots.
Yet winning is not the only thing. Democrats may wish they had a better-known, more powerful challenger. Republicans may not like any of these messengers or their messages. But the arrival of all these candidates with something serious to say is a development citizens of all political persuasions can only welcome, for America has a lot to talk about.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Overdue Loans Rise 2.73%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The percentage of consumer loans at least 30 days past due rose to 2.73 percent in the April-June quarter, the highest level in nearly two years and a sign that the recession is pinching borrowers, the American Bankers Association said today.
The seasonally adjusted delinquency rate for the second quarter, compiled by the trade association from seven types of closed-end installment loans, was up from 2.67 percent in the first quarter and 2.55 percent a year earlier. The rate was the highest since it was 2.88 percent in the third quarter of 1989. 
 But while delinquencies rose for closed-end loans, they fell for bank credit cards and home equity credit lines.
The rate for home equity lines edged down from 0.98 percent in the first quarter to 0.90 percent in the April-June period. Still, it was substantially higher than the 0.75 percent rate a year earlier.
The association said 3.23 percent of credit-card borrowers were behind on their payments, down from 3.34 percent in the first three months of the year but up from 2.36 percent in the second quarter of 1990.
Included in the closed-end rate are two types of auto loans, personal loans, recreational vehicle loans, mobile home loans, property improvement loans and closed-end home equity loans. The delinquency rate is derived from a survey of 800 banks in the 50 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);
