HEADLINE: Slanting of Intelligence Becomes Issue for Nominee

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The possible shaping of intelligence to fit the foreign policy goals of an administration has emerged as an important issue in the confirmation hearings of Robert M. Gates, raising questions about the integrity of the intelligence process.
Mr. Gates, nominated to be the Director of Central Intelligence, was accused this week by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, of bending intelligence assessments while serving in senior positions at the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1980's, either to fit his pessimistic view of the Kremlin or to please his bosses. 
 Mr. Gates, currently the deputy national security adviser, has defended his conduct, but acknowledged that in at least one case involving Iran he had acted to suppress dissent so that the C.I.A. and the other intelligence arms of the Reagan Administration could present a unified interagency view to the White House.
On Friday, as the Senate Intelligence Committee continues its examination of Mr. Gates's fitness for the top intelligence post, it will hear in a closed session from former and current C.I.A. officials who will argue both sides of the issue.
Two former analysts, Melvin Goodman and Jennifer Glaudemans, are expected to testify that Mr. Gates, as a senior intelligence official working under the stewardship of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence from 1981 to 1986, actively suppressed dissent and contributed to an atmosphere of intimidation among the agency's analysts.
Despite the assertions, the prospects of Mr. Gates's confirmation appear promising, unless there are startling new revelations in an open session on Thursday and the closed meetings scheduled for Friday and Tuesday.
But the committee hearings have spotlighted a particularly sensitive intersection between intelligence agencies and policy makers. The shaping of intelligence into a convenient rationale for policy goals is considered a serious breach of an analyst's obligation to provide dispassionate conclusions and predictions, regardless of what the policy makers want.
While these standards of neutrality have not always been honored in the face of White House pressure, President Bush, a former Director of Central Intelligence himself, has instructed the intelligence services to reach independent judgments and to stay out of the policy-making arena.
"Casey and Gates changed procedures and rewrote key judgments," said one former intelligence analyst who insisted on anonymity. "Analysts who didn't pursue the policy agenda were basically ordered to get on board. It was a corruption of the process."
Such tailoring, known at the C.I.A. as "cooking the books," is extraordinarily difficult to prove. What one analyst considers slanting another analyst may simply believe is an honest difference of opinion.
"The other word for tailoring is editing," said Herbert Meyer, a former special assistant to Mr. Casey and a former senior agency analyst, who shared Mr. Gates's hardline views on the Soviet Union. "That's what Bob got paid to do. He didn't just sign things that landed on his desk. People who accused Casey or Gates or me of cooking the books have never come to grips with the fact that in each instance where an accusation was made our conclusions turned out to be correct."
 
Report on Pope to Be Scrutinized
 The committee will hear assertions on Friday that Mr. Gates, as a senior C.I.A. official, skewed an agency assessment in April 1985 that concluded that the Soviet Union's intelligence agency masterminded the 1981 assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II.
Critics of the report have said that Mr. Gates was so intent on presenting the report as the unanimous view of the agency that he deleted dissenting opinions written by other analysts and ignored data that stated that the assassination attempt was inconsistent with K.G.B. operations, instead basing the conclusions on flimsy evidence.
Mr. Gates sought to deflate the accusation in advance on Tuesday, when he told the committee that after the report on the assassination attempt was issued he ordered one of his officers to write an "attack" on it and asked the C.I.A.'s Project Evaluation staff to review the entire record. But former agency officials familiar with the post-mortems said the investigation, even though it was watered down, indicated that Mr. Gates had misrepresented the report's conclusions.
 
On Arming Iran
 Another issue that may be examined further will be a classified interagency "estimate" on Iran prepared by the National Intelligence Council under Mr. Gates's chairmanship in May 1985.
On Tuesday, Mr. Gates admitted for the first time that he had pressured the State Department to go along with the analysis, completed just before the United States began to secretly sell arms to Iran. The report warned of mounting internal instability in Iran and concluded that Moscow had made significant inroads into the country at the expense of the West.
In addition, despite a long-held policy of trying to prevent arms sales by any country to Iran, the report argued that the degree to which Washington's allies, including Israel, "can fill a military gap for Iran will be a crucial measure of the West's ability to blunt Soviet influence."
The report, which varied widely from previous analyses on Iran and was reversed the following February, became the basis for a formal directive on Iran that urged the United States to provide "selected military equipment" to Iran.
 
Dispute Over 'Footnote'
 In his testimony, Mr. Gates recalled how he had persuaded Morton I. Abramowitz, then the State Department's director of intelligence and research, not to insert a dissenting opinion in a "footnote," although Iran specialists in the State Department continuted to hotly contest the report's conclusions.
"So that there was no alternative view presented?" Senator Bradley asked.
"That is correct," Mr. Gates replied, "because I felt that the view that they had, as they had written their footnote, really didn't represent an alternative view."
Mr. Abramowitz declined comment today, but a State Department official involved in the controversy said Mr. Gates had pressed the point at Mr. Casey's behest.
In his two days of Senate confirmation hearings, Mr. Gates argued that the issue of tailoring assessments was highly subjective, and presented himself as a boss who eagerly sought out alternate views.
"When I was a young analyst I was absolutely convinced that the refusal to accept my analysis was politically motivated by the people on the seventh floor at the agency," Mr. Gates told the Senate Intelligence Committee on Monday, referring to the executive suites occupied by the Director of Central Intelligence and his top aides.
"At the other end of the spectrum, as a policy maker, I have been absolutely convinced at times that the C.I.A. and the intelligence community went out of their way to stick their thumb in the eye of the policy maker and to make them look stupid."
 
Differences With Shultz
 He spoke publicly for the first time about his differences with former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who told the Iran-contra committees in July 1987 that long before the Iran-contra affair emerged he had "come to have grave doubts about the objectivity and reliability of some of the intelligence I was getting," a criticism that aides to Mr. Shultz have said was leveled at Mr. Casey and his deputy and protege, Mr. Gates.
Mr. Gates said he believed that Mr. Shultz was referring to the agency's negative assessments of the Philippines in the wake of the overthrow of President Ferdinand Marcos, Angola under its current government, and to a lesser extent, the Soviet Union.
Mr. Shultz, now a professor of international economics at Stanford University, declined to comment on Mr. Gates's nomination, but senior officials who worked for him said the battles with Mr. Casey and Mr. Gates included genuine differences of opinion as well as a feeling that some of the intelligence had been shaded.

HEADLINE: Ceramic Vessels, Painted

BYLINE: By LISA HAMMEL

 BODY:
Although Rudy Autio is one of the elder statesmen of modern American ceramics, he continues to try new ideas. Sixteen of Mr. Autio's recent works can be seen at the Helen Drutt Gallery New York, 724 Fifth Avenue (near 57th Street), through Oct. 26.
In the early 1970's, after two decades of decorating his pots with abstract patterns, Mr. Autio decided to paint figures on the surfaces of his vessels. His renderings of male and female nudes, horses and other creatures became more distinct over the years, while the shapes of his pots turned increasingly abstract. 
 The pots have now passed tabletop size and are on their way to monumentality; they stand close to four feet high. To his hand-built cylinders, Mr. Autio adds protuberances that evoke such shapes as the ventricles of the heart. They become some part of the anatomy of his figures -- the stretching arm of a woman, perhaps, or a man's bent leg.
There is an expansiveness in Mr. Autio's more recent work. Not only are the vessels larger, but the painted figures seem almost weightless.
Much of American ceramics today has roots in Japanese traditional pottery. At Gallery Zero (11 Rockefeller Plaza), pieces by major Japanese potters who work within traditional modes can be seen. Through Sept. 28, 30 pieces by Kiyotsugu Sawa are being shown. Mr. Sawa works at Shigaraki, an old pottery center near Kyoto.
Shigaraki stoneware was put on the map in the first half of the 16th century, when it was discovered and favored by influential tea masters who were then establishing the ritual of the Japanese tea ceremony. The tea masters considered the rustic, unpretentious ware appropriate for the contemplative tea ceremony, which is meant to remove the participant from the distractions of everyday life.
The ware certainly does have a coarseness of texture and an unfussy form. But it no longer seems simple. For centuries the Japanese have seen art in this ware, which is born of the local granitic clay and baked in special wood-fired kilns.
Among the specifics that are valued are the bold shapes of the tea leaf jars, with their natural shiny ash glazes set off against pebbly surfaces; the rosy orange hue of the clay itself, often with scorch marks from firing; the economically incised surfaces, which look as if grasses had been pressed into the body, and the dramatic cracks in pieces that have split in the firing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says That Obstacles to Soviet Loans Will Be Overcome

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Senior American officials studying the crippled Soviet economy said today that the Bush Administration expected to solve the problem of American banks' resistance to $500 million in Government-guaranteed loans needed to sell American grain to the needy Soviet Union.
"We don't think that's going to be a problem," said an official traveling with a special delegation led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. "The President made his mind up." 
 Anxious Soviet officials are pressing for as much quick foreign aid as they can get to shore up their food stocks for the winter.
They are trying to make a case to visiting delegations from the United States and elsewhere that they are making progress with their transitional government and its emergency plans for national reconstruction afterthe aborted Kremlin coup last month.
"We retain a sense of optimism," Mr. Brady said after conferring with Ivan S. Silayev, chairman of the transitional government's economic management committee. Officials planning solutions to the nation's economic and political crisis were "serious and realistic," Mr. Brady said, adding that he found little evidence of the"games playing" of the past in elaborate plans for renewal.
 
Winter Does Not Wait
 Talking with reporters before meeting Mr. Brady, Mr. Silayev invoked the ultimate Soviet alarm for urgent action. "It is winter, and it does not wait," he said. He estimated that the winter will be free of hunger if enough is done in the way of domestic preparation and foreign aid.
The larger task of building economic and political bonds among the separate republics of the now defunct Soviet Union will take 10 to 15 years, by the latest estimate of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The Soviet leader, who is head of the transitional State Council in which he is joined by 10 leaders of the nation's republics, offered the estimate in the newspaper Izvestia. He said that "within the next two or three years" new government processes and positive chan ge should take place. This was as close as anyone has come to offering a time frame for the latest emergency promises of reform, which remain vague on details and timing.
 
Silayev to Stay
 For this national task, Mr. Silayev finally made clear his own plans, reversing a previously announced decision that he would return to his post as Prime Minister of the Russian federated republic, the nation's largest and most populous. Instead, he chose to stay with the transitional union government as economic chairman and informal Prime Minister under the State Council, the decision-making body that Mr. Gorbachev heads. The council is to rule the nation until a new constitution and new union treaty can be worked out.
Mr. Silayev said a factor in his decision to stay was the wish of the Russian federation's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, who had received a commitment from President Gorbachev that since Russia contains a majority of the Soviet nation's population, land and wealth, the post should be held by someone from Russia.
Mr. Yeltsin, now the key official in engineering reconstruction plans among the suddenly sovereign republics, caused a flutter in Moscow today by feeling ill at work and taking the day off. Early reports circulated that he had suffered "heart trouble," but they were later denied. Such phrases are used very loosely here to cover a variety of moods and non-cardiac illness, and Mr. Yeltsin's office said he was expected to be back Thursday to open a session of the Russian Parliament.
Soviet and Russian officials have asked for more than $20 billion in aid from Western nations and Japan in recent weeks. But theBush Administration has been having trouble obtaining simpler, smaller guaranteed loans from American banks wary of the Soviet nation's creditworthiness.
The first $600 million of these loans finally had to be obtained through foreign banks. The Bush Administration is seeking lenders for another $500 million worth planned for Oct. 1, although Mr. Silayev said after speaking with Mr. Brady that he hoped the process might be speeded up, along with the final installment of $400 million due in February.

HEADLINE: JORDAN CAUTIOUS ON PEACE SESSION

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 18

 BODY:
On the eve of a visit here by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, senior Jordanian officials expressed pessimism that the American effort to assemble a Mideast peace conference next month can yield concrete results resolving the 40-year Arab-Israeli conflict.
With more than 30 percent unemployment, an $8 billion foreign debt and a cutoff of Arab financial aid, Jordan is facing the burden of caring for a new flood of impoverished Palestinian refugees being expelled from Kuwait at the rate of 34,000 a month. Jordanian officials are angling for rewards in exchange for attendance at the peace talks. 
 Crown Prince Hassan said in an interview that it was "high time" for incentives to be made to Jordan in order to enlist its help in the peace process. He warned that further financial or political pressure on Jordan by the West or hostile Arab countries, who are punishing Jordan over its support of Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis, will be counterproductive.
 
Incentives and Limits
 "Jordan and the Palestinians have been squeezed to the limit," said Prince Hassan, who is heir to the Jordanian throne.
"There is a recognition of the centrality of Jordan's geopolitical role," the Prince said. "But I've said time and again that if that role is going to be triggered by pressure, then that is not enough. The time has come for some form of incentive and understanding. If pressure is the medicine, certainly we have been over-medicated. We don't want the patient to die."
He also stressed that there are limits to the accommodations that Jordan can make to facilitate the peace process, especially if they come at the expense of Palestinian representation at the talks and Palestinian national demands. He stressed that Jordan has a large constituency of Jordanians who are of Palestinian origin and whose sentiments cannot be discounted. Palestinians living in Jordan are variously estimated at 50 to 60 percent of the country's population.
 
'Threshold of Reconciling'
 "When speaking about pressure, I would like to remind, in whatever way that is possible, that we also are clearly under constituents' pressure," the Crown Prince said.
A prominent Jordanian businessman who requested anonymity said that "we would have a revolution on our hands here" if Jordan were perceived to have signed "the death certificate of the Palestinian state."
Both the United States and Israel have ruled out any participation by the Palestine Liberation Organization in the talks and there has yet to be an accord on who will represent the Palestinians. The United States has proposed that they be included within a Jordanian delegation, something that Jordan has yet to agree to.
Jordanian officials also said it was high time for an Arab reconciliation that would bring Jordan back into the Arab fold and end the ostracism of Jordan by Arab countries that sided with the United States against Iraq.
"We are on the threshold of reconciling with our enemy, Israel, but we have not not yet reconciled amongst us," Foreign Minister Abdallah al-Nusur said on Monday.
The Arab gulf countries, primarily Saudi Arabia, have suspended their annual aid of $500 million to this country. Saudi Arabia has also ended its free supply of oil to Jordan, forcing the country to buy its oil from Iraq.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Trial of Casey

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On Nov. 10, 1982, the day Leonid Brezhnev died, as all the sages of Congress and media thumbsuckers were speculating on the Kremlin succession, Director of Central Intelligence William J. Casey sent a C.I.A. assessment to President Reagan.
The last sentence of that memo concluded with the Director's personal judgment: "As for me, I bet Andropov on the nose and Gorbachev across the board." 
 Horseplayers know that on the nose means "to win," and across the board is a hedged bet "to win, place and show," or to come in among the first three. Bill Casey's intelligence judgment was sound: the K.G.B.'s Andropov won, and his protege, the little-known Gorbachev, was placed in the line of succession after the apparat chik Chernenko.
That's the sort of valuable prediction that we pay Directors of Central Intelligence for. Casey was extraordinarily good at that, but you would never know it from the ghoulish impeachment trial now going on in the guise of Senate confirmation hearings of Robert Gates.
Looming in the background is the contemptible charge that this lifelong patriot, while running the 1980 Reagan campaign, conspired with Ayatollah Khomeini to delay the release of American hostages lest credit go to President Carter. That's a late hit by political sore losers.
His widow, Sophia Casey, has shown me documents about his suspicions that Mr. Carter would pull an "October surprise." In a Nov. 2, 1980, memo to Reagan, Casey dismissed a potential Carter ransom effort as likely to be seen as "a desperate last attempt to manipulate the hostages again for political benefit"; Casey's judgment was that "we should say very little and leave it that way."
As C.I.A. chief, did he comprehend the Soviet threat and incipient economic rot? Yes to both: when he reported at the outset that Moscow was behind state-sponsored terrorism, doves clucked indulgently -- but now we're getting the evidence of how right Casey was. And even when C.I.A. analysts led the dovecote to misread the Soviet economy, he was on target with his personal assessment of Kremlin economic weakness and inability to cope with our arms spending pressure.
What about the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan contras from sales of arms for Iran? I have no doubt that Bill Casey personally supervised Ollie North's illegal operation, backdated findings, wrongfully misled Congress and brought deserved shame on his agency and President.
My old friend and I had a severe falling-out about that time, but now I believe this arrogance and degeneration of judgment in his final years had much to do with a tumor destroying his brain.
In the Gates hearings, we are hearing only of the diseased, temperamental Casey, not of the healthy, insightful hard-liner who contributed so much to the victory over Communism. Nobody, not even Senator Warren Rudman, is willing to provide such perspective during the Senate's first posthumous impeachment trial.
Mr. Gates cannot defend his old boss and patron if he wants to be confirmed. On the contrary, he must distance himself from Casey's concluding lawlessness, despite pockets of guilty knowledge all around. The nominee properly admits he should have known more of the illegal diversion, should have told his boss he had a need to know; frankly the likelihood that he would then have blown the whistle is remote.
Let's assume Mr. Gates has an excellent forgettery and was deft enough to stay on the frayed fringe of guilty knowledge. Assume also this frustrated careerist will keep his sworn word to resign rather than obey a Presidential order to pull the wool over Senate oversight -- a promise he refused to make last time up. Should he be confirmed?
Yes. He's a cold fish but he knows his stuff about economic intelligence, and if anybody's eyes have been lifted to the necessity of truth in covert action, it's O. Ye Gates. Unlike the bad Casey, he has little political backing to be arrogant about; like the good Casey, he remained vigilant toward the Soviet Union when even his colleagues went starry-eyed.
Casey's impeachment in absentia is not the American way. The time for Senate overseers to kick a man is when he is up and causing trouble, not when he is safely in his grave.

HEADLINE: A Cowardly Vote for the Jobless

 BODY:
House Democrats displayed neither courage nor sense on Tuesday when they voted to extend unemployment benefits for the long-term unemployed without raising taxes to pay for the plan. By raising the deficit, the bill would effectively violate last year's tortuously negotiated budget law, paving the way for further violations as the delayed pain from deficit reduction takes hold.
The plight of the unemployed is serious. Each month more than 300,000 Americans exhaust the standard 26-week limit for unemployment benefits; these families can face loss of their homes or apartments, if not worse deprivation. The House bill would extend benefits for up to 20 additional weeks, at a cost of over $6 billion. 
 The problem is that Congress refuses to pay -- a fiscally reckless evasion of last year's deficit-reduction law, which required that new programs be paid for by new taxes or by compensating cuts in other programs. The House Ways and Means chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, offered a plan to raise payroll taxes on high-paid workers, but his fellow Democrats wouldn't go along.
Some tried to mask political cowardice as virtue, contending that tax hikes would worsen the recession. But the claim is false: since the new revenues could be immediately returned to the private economy in the form of higher benefits, the Rostenkowski plan would not dampen spending.
The House bill is similar to one Congress approved in August; this one, however, eliminates the loophole that allowed Mr. Bush to sign but not institute the new benefits. That invites a certain Presidential veto.
The Senate now has the opportunity to make the bill right. By adopting the Rostenkowski plan it can help the unemployed, make the payroll tax fairer and preserve the deficit-reduction law. But it will take more guts than were demonstrated this week in the House.

HEADLINE: Albany Shouldn't Cut Corners in the Courts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 6 report that New York State budget cuts would make it necessary to lay off 495 court employees should be of serious concern to this state's citizens.
The resulting substantial closing down of civil parts of the courts will cause further unacceptable delays in the resolution of citizens' claims. Justice delayed is justice denied, and such delays will have an adverse effect upon the already faltering economy of the state. 
 I respectfully offer alternative suggestions to Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, who is one of the finest chief judges New York State has ever had, as well as to the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
It is not clear whether or not the layoffs include employees of court administration. If not, such layoffs should first be directed in the area of court administration, in substantial numbers, before any reduction takes place in the number of employees in the civil parts, which will directly affect the rights of litigants.
The public interest would be better served if the saving involved in the pending layoffs of 495 vital court employees were instead to be made by modest reductions in the individual staffs of the state's more than 200 legislators. The saving might also be made through other very possible legislative economies, which I prefer not to enumerate. The Governor should act to find the funds to avoid further deterioration of the courts.
The courts of New York State have been seriously overburdened with criminal and civil litigation, and shamefully treated by the legislative and executive branches of government for too long. Some 20 years ago, Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld helplessly complained that the courts were being starved.
If the approaching layoffs seriously impair the proper functioning of the courts, as they apparently will, and if no relief from the other branches of government is forthcoming, the judiciary must resort to the courts, its final alternative.
 
FRANK J. PINO
Jamesburg, N.J., Sept. 7, 1991
 
The writer has served in both houses of the New York State Legislature and as a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: From Unemployment, Into Self-Employment

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: SUDBURY, Mass.

 BODY:
When Susan LaCroix, an out-of-work chef from Lowell, Mass., visited the local office of the Massachusetts Department of Employment and Training in April of last year, she was intrigued by a notice saying some would-be entrepreneurs could collect unemployment insurance benefits while they started their own businesses.
Ms. LaCroix, 33 years old, had recently lost her job at the Appleton Inn in Lowell, and she knew finding another chef's position would not be easy in the dismal Massachusetts economy. Having long harbored a dream of owning her own business, she applied to the helping-hand program. In a lottery of 587 applicants, Ms. LaCroix and 104 other people across the state were chosen. 
 The 24 weeks of benefits provided a cushion as she set up Epicurean Catering in the kitchen of the Lowell Girls' Club. Supported by her biweekly unemployment checks, as well as seminars, workshops and counseling supplied by the state, Ms. LaCroix has built a profitable business.
"The program really allowed me to focus on my business and get it started," Ms. LaCroix said. "It provided great support and gave me the time to pound the pavement to develop new clients."
State officials said that 60 percent of the 105 participants in the first program were considered successfully established before their 24 weeks of benefits ran out. Nils Nordberg, the Massachusetts Commissioner of Employment and Training, estimated the program had already saved the state $125,000 in unemployment benefits.
The program, called the Massachusetts Enterprise Project, is part of a series of demonstration projects set up by the United States Department of Labor to find ways to get unemployed workers back into jobs. Two state projects, the one in Massachusetts and one in Washington, have focused on self-employment, and the Labor Department has spent more than $1 million on them.
In Washington's program, which started in 1989 and ended last year, each participant in the state received a one-time up-front payment averaging $4,200 from a Federal research grant. Data on the success of the program are still being gathered.
Stephen Wandner, director of these experimental projects for the Labor Department, said the Massachusetts program had been offered to all 50 states. Only Oregon and Minnesota also expressed interest, he said, but they backed out when told they would have to make up any shortfalls by dipping into their unemployment insurance funds. Massachusetts, however, decided to go ahead.
Participants in the Massachusetts entrepreneurs' program are not required to actively seek jobs in order to receive benefits.
Besides drawing upon state unemployment insurance money, Massachusetts also found partners from the business community. The Boston-based Shawmut Bank, for example, provided more than $100,000 in small-business loans, while individual business executives donated their expertise for counseling. And the owner of an office park provided office space for seminars.
 
Beach Towels and Energy Audits
 Michael Cass, a 37-year-old former roller-coaster operator at an amusement park in Springfield, Mass., said the program allowed him to start manufacturing and selling a product that is a combination garment, beach towel and slipcover for beach chairs. Mr. Cass has patented the product and is hoping to sell a large order to the Hyatt Hotel chain.
Ted Davis, a 45-year-old mechanical engineer from Brimfield, Mass., lost his job at Combustion Engineering Inc. in Windsor, Conn., when it was acquired by Asea Brown Boveri A.B., the Swedish energy giant, in 1990. After being accepted in the Enterprise Project, he started a company that performs energy audits and consulting.
"I had actually incorporated before I joined the project," Mr. Davis said. "But the business never got off the ground." He said the state program "allowed me to work on my business without worrying about looking for a job and coming into the unemployment office."
After initial success, he said, the recession cut into his business. Still, he says, "I'd rather take a night job and keep the business going than return to what I was doing before."
Pamela Cole was laid off as a software consultant by one of the many computer companies outside Boston on Route 128. Now, with state help, she has begun a service of photographing horse-and-carriage competitions and selling her work to contestants. "Revenues are increasing all the time," said Ms. Cole, a 47-year-old New Bedford resident.
Mr. Nordberg, the state employment commissioner, said he was happy with the results thus far but added that it was too early to call the program a success. Small business failures are legion, he noted, and it will be several years before the new entrepreneurs can demonstrate that they have created established businesses.
Massachusetts lost 157,600 jobs between July 1990 and July 1991 and currently has about 120,000 people drawing unemployment benefits. "We are constantly looking for alternative ways of getting people back to work sooner," Mr. Nordberg said.
 
Self-Employment a Trend
 The Massachusetts plan exemplifies a growing interest in self-employment as a career option. "The idea of self-employment as an alternative has not been well explored in this country," said Bonnie Dallinger, director of the Enterprise Project. "But there has been a growing interest in it over the last 10 years by such disadvantaged groups as single women, minorities and the unemployed."
In a report published last October, Mr. Wandner of the Labor Department noted that most Western European nations had already set up self-employment programs as alternatives to unemployment compensation. The Massachusetts project was modeled after a successful program in Britain.
In the last decade, self-employment has grown tremendously in the United States. The Small Business Administration says the number of sole-proprietor and "micro" businesses rose to 13.8 million by 1986 from 9.73 million in 1980 and continues to grow. A more recent survey of nearly 3,000 new businesses by the National Federation of Independent Business showed that 50 percent of all new businesses had two employees or less, and only 10 percent had more than 10 employees.
The survey, in fact, showed that contrary to popular belief, the new businesses survived: 77 percent were still operating after three years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rise Tied to Concern On Soviets and Persian Gulf

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly in light trading yesterday, influenced largely by political uncertainty in the Soviet Union and increasing tension in the Persian Gulf.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was quoted at $348.30 a troy ounce, down 30 cents. A late bid at New York's Republic National Bank quoted gold at $348.25, up 5 cents. 
 Currency traders said the dollar traded in a narrow range throughout the session, and found little inspiration from a new report on the United States trade deficit.
The Commerce Department said the July trade gap climbed to $5.9 billion, the biggest imbalance since January. It was 55.6 percent higher than a revised June deficit of $3.79 billion.
Jerry Egan, chief currency dealer for the Bank of Boston, said the trade report activated a slight selling of the dollar, but that it recouped the losses later.
 
Haven for Investors
Curtis Perkins, a trader for the Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said traders bought dollars on reports that the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, was experiencing poor health, and the imminent movement of American warplanes to the Persian Gulf to enforce the cease-fire agreement with Iraq.
International investors typically buy dollars in times of unsettling events as a safe-haven investment.
The German mark is under particular pressure because of Germany's economic ties with the Soviet Union. Many financial analysts believe the Soviet Union will have difficulty repaying its Western debt, and they speculate Germany's economy could be hurt as a result.
The dollar rose slightly against the mark in active trading, closing in New York at 1.6885 marks, up from 1.6845. In late European trading, the dollar closed at 1.6892 marks, up from 1.6808.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7280, from $1.7317 late Wednesday. In New York, sterling cost $1.7300, more expensive that $1.7285 late Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.45 yen, closing at 134.40 yen. It was quoted at the same rate in late trading in London and New York, unchanged from late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.4755 Swiss francs, up from 1.4715; 5.7525 French francs, up from 5.7400; 1,264 Italian lire, up from 1,260, and 1.13525 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13715.
In the precious-metals markets abroad, gold rose in London to a late bid price of $348.75 a troy ounce, up from $348.10 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $348.50 an ounce, up from $348 late Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 98 cents an ounce to close at a $349.69.

HEADLINE: Claims Filed By Jobless Show a Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell in early September, but the drop was largely dismissed as a fluke related to the Labor Day holiday.
In the week ended Sept. 7, first-time claims for unemployment benefits were filed by 402,000 people, a decrease of 17,000 from the 419,000 recorded for the previous week, the Labor Department said today. 
 It was the lowest level of new claims since the last week of July, when there were 400,000 people making their first trip to unemployment lines. The drop of 17,000 was the biggest improvement since a decline of 21,000 for the week ended July 20, when claims fell to 404,000.
Because the first week of September included Labor Day, however, there were only four days to file claims, and analysts therefore hesitated to read too much into the decline.
In addition, the number can be extremely volatile from week to week. Economists generally prefer to see a substantial drop in claims for at least three or four weeks in a row before declaring that hiring is increasing.
Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company, said the four-week average of new claims was at 416,000, only a slight improvement from the previous four-week average of 423,000.
"It's still indicative of a labor market that's anything but buoyant," he said. "Employers are hiring reluctantly and still looking for ways to shave costs."
Still, the 400,000 level of early September is far better than the peaks of spring, when more than 500,000 people a week were filing claims.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Getting the Benefit Of Military Cuts

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE primary economic benefit to the United States of the collapse of the Soviet empire is, potentially, the opportunity to make deep cuts in military spending and use the savings to eliminate the budget deficit, tackle domestic problems, or some combination of both.
Of total American military spending, about 60 percent has gone to block the Soviet threat to Western Europe and deter Soviet nuclear attack. Yet military spending is still running close to $300 billion, in real terms nearly what it was in 1989, the year the Berlin wall came down and the Warsaw Pact collapsed. 
 And Pentagon plans call for total military spending, including atomic energy and the strategic weapons stockpile, to come down only 22 percent over the next five years. Measured in constant 1992 dollars to eliminate effects of inflation, military spending is projected to decline from $295.2 billion in the 1992 fiscal year to $252.5 billion in 1996. Pentagon planners call this plan their irreducible minimum and say further cuts would jeopardize national security.
But a new study for the Brookings Institution, "The Post-Cold War Defense Program," by William W. Kaufmann of Harvard and John D. Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at Brookings, contends that much deeper cuts in military spending could be made over the next decade without weakening national security -- and with important economic gains. The test of the United States as a superpower, they say, "will be whether it can now arrive at a more realistic balance between its military and economic power."
Their "low option" plan for cutting the military budget calls for spending of $2.2 trillion over the next 10 years, compared with $2.5 trillion in Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plan. But the Kaufmann-Steinbruner study maintains that the Cheney projections are too low, because they do not take into account real increases that will be required starting in 1997 for next-generation weapons procurement planned by the Pentagon. Allowing for such additional costs, the authors project the Pentagon's spending plans to reach a total of $2.8 trillion over the next 10 years, or $620 billion more than their low option plan.
That plan would achieve its savings by scaling back both nuclear and conventional weapons. In the nuclear area that would include reconfiguring the B-1B bomber from a penetrating bomber to a less expensive cruise missile launcher; terminating the B-2 bomber program at 15 aircraft; deferring deployment of the small intercontinental ballistic missile, and reorienting the Strategic Defense Initiative to a research effort.
For nonnuclear forces, the low option plan calls for continued upgrading of current combat aircraft, while delaying production of next-generation successors; postponing a range of capabilities aimed at enhancing the Army's ability to contain a Soviet attack; extending the life of the C-141 airlift aircraft and terminating the C-17A, and canceling the SSN-21 attack submarine and procurement funds for two new aircraft carriers.
Despite these cuts, the plan would enable the United States to respond in the same way it did in the Persian Gulf war, except that four carrier battle groups would be used, instead of the six stationed in the Persian Gulf.
Deeper cuts in military spending could be achieved, the study said, by adopting a "cooperative security" arrangement in which the leading military establishments, including the Soviet Union's, would be organized to prevent aggressive actions anywhere in the world. International regulations would guide the movement of forces, concentration of tactical aircraft and the nature of research activities. This arrangement would impose not only new global responsibilities on America's allies but also "a meaningful shift in the assumptions used to guide investment in U.S. forces."
Cooperative security, by relying more on other nations' forces and slowing down reaction times, could bring total United States military spending down to $2 trillion over the next 10 years, helping to save a total of $800 billion.
By the year 2001, American military spending would be less than half its current level. The huge cut would reduce the drain on national savings, stimulate capital formation and economic growth, create more jobs and provide resources to meet other critical national needs.
But the cooperative approach would demand exceptionally committed leadership, here and abroad. It would require countries like Germany and Japan to increase their global responsibilities. And it would require the United States to accept restraints on its freedom to take unilateral actions. For the United States to accept such restraints would be, the authors say, "internally very difficult," but they insist that "international events mandate a serious effort to make this transformation and are likely to compel the United States to debate it as a viable security option."
President Bush's effort this week to force Saddam Hussein to comply with United Nations resolutions shows how hard it would be for the United States to accept collective restraints on its freedom of action -- and how important it is to be perceived as acting in the common interest of peace-seeking countries. The big military savings and economic gains will demand political vision and large concepts of what is involved in creating a new world order.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed, and interest rates were little changed again yesterday. Market participants sold securities for a time after the Government reported that the merchandise trade deficit rose sharply in July and that initial unemployment claims fell slightly in the week ended Sept. 7.
The effects of the reports were not long-lived, however, and buyers emerged at the lower price levels. 
 Traders said that most of the activity was being conducted by Wall Street professsionals.
"Over all, I don't think the true investment community is doing anything, and won't be shaken out of the market until or unless the economic numbers start painting a much different picture," one government securities trader said. "The gyrations we are seeing right now are merely a function of dealers either being too long, or being too short."
Another set of generally weak money supply statistics also failed to provoke much of a reaction.
Late yesterday the Federal Reserve reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended Sept. 9.
M-2, the monetary aggregate the Fed tracks most closely, rose by $2.6 billion during the week.
Before the announcement, Wall Street analysts had been expecting that all three aggregates would show large increases.
For example, most economists had projected that M-2, which fell very sharply in the week ended Sept. 2, would rise by more than $6 billion.
 
30-Year Bond Offering
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 14/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.91 percent, compared with 7.92 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 7/8 in late trading, down 1/ 32, to yield 7.60 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, unchanged on the day, to yield 6.16 percent.
In the secondary market for short-term Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.18 percent late yesterday, up two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.23 percent.
The Treasury held its monthly auction of new one-year bills yesterday.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 5.57 percent on the new bills, up from the average rate of 5.36 percent at the one-year bill sale a month ago.
Companies continued to take advantage of the current low and stable interest rate environment by offering new debt issues.
Among the issues priced yesterday was a $350 million offering of 10-year guaranteed bonds for the Victorian Public Authorities Finance Agency, the financing arm of Australia's state of Victoria.
The 8.45 percent securities were priced at $99.933, to yield 8.46 percent, 86 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the offering. The securities are rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The size of the offering could expand, because immediately following the pricing Victoria announced it was making a tender/exchange offer for a total of $350 million bonds maturing in 1998 and 1999.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Phillips Petroleum Company offered $300 million worth of 30-year debentures at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won the securities, which were reoffered to investors with a coupon of 9.18 percent, and were priced at $100, or par, 1.24 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for 10 years, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point in active trading.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds said that prices of most widely quoted municipal issues were little changed at the end of a fairly quiet session.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened During July

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The nation's foreign-trade deficit widened sharply to $5.9 billion in July as soaring imports overwhelmed a modest rise in exports, the Commerce Department reported today.
The sudden deterioration, which followed a June deficit that was the lowest in eight years, was generally anticipated by analysts, many of whom cautioned strongly against interpreting the $2.4 billion jump in imports as a sign of current economic strength that reflected a pickup in consumer demand. 
 "We're seeing very weak consumer spending," said Richard D. C. Trainer, chief market economist at the Bank of Tokyo. He noted that the trade figures covered July and that data already out for August had shown weakness in retail sales and other aspects of the economy.
But while there was considerable agreement on these points, analysts differed as to what the import surge did represent and whether they should be encouraged or discouraged by the $300 million rise in exports in July.
Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank, dismissed the import rise, saying it mainly reflected relatively late shipments of Christmas-season merchandise to cautious importers who had been hesitant about building up their holiday inventories. Others said it might reflect optimism by businesses stocking up for what they hope will be a buoyant post-recession holiday season.
 
Growth Estimate Is Trimmed
 Elliott Platt, a senior analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, took a decidedly dim view of today's figures, contending that they implied that the recovery from recession was "off to a slower start than we had thought." He said he was trimming his estimate of third-quarter growth in gross national product to a 1 percent annual pace, from 1.5 percent.
"These numbers seem to suggest that trade will be a drag on the economy in the current quarter" because more of the nation's demand for goods was met by foreign suppliers and less by domestic ones, he said.
But Willard A. Workman of the United States Chamber of Commerce, expressing a minority view, said the big advance in imports of consumer goods and automobiles "suggests there may be some easing of American consumers' concerns about the U.S. recession" and that higher imports of capital goods reflect plans by industry to make investments.
 
Exports Called 'Static'
 Still, Mr. Workman was downbeat about July exports, which he called "relatively static" because of generally sluggish global economic activity.
Mr. Trainer also called exports "somewhat disappointing" even though they rose to their third-highest level on record. But Mr. Niemira said he was encouraged that exports did not decline as he had thought they would.
Imports totaled $41.2 billion, up 6.2 percent from $38.8 billion in June, with consumer goods rising $1.1 billion, and the categories of motor vehicles, parts and engines, and capital goods each rising $600 million. New cars from Japan edged up only slightly, but the overall American deficit with Japan surged to $3.8 billion, from $3.2 billion in June and $2.4 billion in May.
Exports were $35.3 billion, up eight-tenths of 1 percent from June's $35 billion, with the biggest increase a $400 million gain in industrial supplies and materials and the biggest decline a $700 million loss in capital goods.
The Commerce Department revised the June data to show a trade deficit of just $3.8 billion, $200 million better than the initially reported deficit, which had been the lowest since June 1983.
The $1.7 billion June surplus that the United States enjoyed with Western Europe dwindled to almost nothing in July, while deficits increased with China (to $1.3 billion, from $1 billion), with Taiwan (to $900 million, from $700 million), with Canada (to $500 million, from $400 million) and with Hong Kong (to $300 million, from $100 million).
The surplus with Mexico rose to $400 million, from $300 million, and remained unchanged with the Soviet Union, at $100 million.
 
Oil Imports Drop
 Reflecting a decline of four million barrels and an average price drop of 31 cents a barrel, the nation's bill for imported oil edged down to $2.9 billion, about half the total deficit, from $3.1 billion in June.
In advanced technology products, the American surplus was $2.2 billion, compared with $3.6 billion in June, the report also showed.
Without seasonal adjustment, the overall July deficit was $7.7 billion, double the $3.9 billion recorded for June. On a seasonally adjusted constant-dollar basis, the deficit swelled to $5.8 billion, from $3.7 billion. Using a three-month moving average, the deficit in current dollars rose to $4.8 billion, from $4.4 billion.

HEADLINE: A Fuel-Efficient Grab for Power

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 19

 BODY:
About 18 years ago, the Honda Motor Company got a lot of attention when it displayed its Civic, which had an unusual, fuel-efficient engine that satisfied pollution concerns.
In two weeks, Honda will introduce a Civic model whose engine could have a big impact on a current debate: whether fuel-efficient cars need come only in small packages. 
 The 1992 Civic VX, which can comfortably seat up to five people, is equipped with a four-cylinder engine that Honda expects to get a Government fuel-efficiency rating of 55 miles a gallon on the highway and 48 miles a gallon in the city. That would compare with the rating for the Geo Metro, among the most fuel-efficient cars sold today, and other mini-cars that seat only two people comfortably and accelerate relatively slowly.
But perhaps most important, Civic's VTEC-E engine with 94 horsepower is more powerful than the power plants found in many comparably sized cars.
The new Honda Civic, which is expected to be priced at about $10,000, means that Honda engineers may have accomplished what Detroit auto makers had long maintained would be difficult or impossible. It has married a highly fuel-efficient engine with a relatively roomy car that performs suitably for normal everyday use.
Detroit, in fact, is concerned that the fuel-efficient Civic VX may become a powerful weapon in the hands of those who favor stiffer auto fuel-efficiency standards. Within the next few weeks that issue is expected to intensify as Congress begins to debate pending energy legislation.
"The numbers seem to be there, and if the performance is good, this car means that the Japanese have opened a new chapter in the debate, and all the old responses are simply not appropriate," said Leon Mandel, publisher of Autoweek magazine.
"If you are a legislator who's only interested in fuel savings and the environment, then this is going to be a devastatingly persuasive argument," he added.
 
An Improved Lean Burn
 One of the more striking things about the engine is that it does not involve any brand-new technology. Honda used a so-called lean-burn approach that mixes more than the usual amount of air with gasoline. In the past, lean-burn technology has achieved lower fuel consumption. But the engines have also provided less pep because the engineers have found it difficult to stabilize combustion and precisely control the mix of air and gas.
Honda appears to have overcome these problems with the lean-burn VTEC-E by incorporating sophisticated control mechanisms developed in Honda's Formula One race-car engine. The mechanisms open and close piston valves with a high degree of accuracy and variability, providing better pickup at low engine speeds and more horsepower over all. The name VTEC-E is an acronym of Variable valve-Timing and lift Electronic Control system-Economy.
The Civic DX with the VTEC-E engine will be built exclusively in Japan and will begin appearing in American showrooms in October. Other Civic models will continue to be built in Honda plants in Alliston, Ontario, and Marysville, Ohio.
The new car is larger than the subcompact Civic it replaces -- almost large enough to be classified as a compact and roughly equivalent in size to the Toyota Tercel or Chevy Cavalier. Early reports from auto magazines judge the Civic peppy, comfortable and efficient.
But the General Motors Corporation, the domestic auto maker with the most extensive engine-research effort, has been throwing cold water on Honda's new vehicle ever since the engine was announced in late July. G.M. engineers contend that the engine does not represent a big technological breakthrough, and G.M.'s Washington lobbyists do not want their adversaries in the fuel-efficiency debate using it as a rationale for tougher Federal corporate average fuel efficiency, or CAFE, standards.
Honda does not want stiffer fuel-efficiency rules any more than domestic auto makers. But if the standard is raised from the current 27.5-miles-a-gallon fleet average that each auto maker is required to meet, Honda wants to avoid one of the pending Congressional proposals: a national fleet average that would be set a standard for the industry as a whole, with each manufacturer required to improve by the same percentage over current levels. G.M. and Honda, for example, might both be required to make their fleets, say, 10 percent more fuel efficient.
Honda sees such a system as punishing the most fuel-efficient manufacturers, because the percentage approach would mean that the auto maker with the highest current miles-a-gallon average would have to make the greatest mileage improvement. "The percentage approach punishes the one who does the most in fuel efficiency," said a Honda spokesman.
Domestic auto makers oppose stiffer fuel-efficiency standards, too. But if the standard is to be raised, they say a percentage increase is preferable; their fuel-efficiency averages tend to be lower because they are full-line producers of large and small cars.
A G.M. spokesman said the company's engineers had studied and become quite familiar with lean-burn technology, but he said it could only be used on very small engines. Moreover, lean-burn engines emit abnormally high amounts of pollution from oxides of nitrogen, making the engine too dirty for new, stricter clean-air standards.
Indeed, Honda cannot sell the high-efficiency Civic VX in California, where current clean-air rules are most stringent. Instead, Honda will sell a Civic VX in that state with less fuel-efficient engines. Elsewhere, Honda will sell the VTEC-E as well as alternate engine types. Honda engineers, meanwhile, are continuing work on a new catalytic converter that might solve the engine's pollution problem, a spokesman said.
 
The Bryan Proposal
 Senator Richard Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, has proposed raising the industrywide fleet average to 40 miles a gallon from the current company-by-company target of 27.5 miles a gallon. The new level, to be achieved through the percentage-increase method, would be required by the year 2001. Senator Bryan's supporters are expected to cite the VTEC-E as proof that technology can still bring great improvements in fuel efficiency.
Dan Becker, a lawyer for the Sierra Club, an environmental lobbying group, said the VTEC-E and other recent announcements of fuel-saving technologies -- like a new type of engine camshaft developed at Clemson University -- "blow the credibility of the U.S. auto industry out of the water."
American auto makers have long argued that the only way they can meet the most extreme fuel-efficiency proposals currently before Congress is by making tiny, slow cars that are unsafe in crashes because of their smaller mass. But other legislators, armed with claims by scientists and environmentalists, have argued that the automotive industry is simply dragging its feet on engine development.
Honda's latest Civic, the fifth generation of the car since the first version appeared in 1973, stirs memories in Detroit and Washington of the first Civic's CVCC engine. The CVCC was the first engine to meet Federal emission standards without a catalytic converter, a startling development in an era when the Big Three were bemoaning the expense and difficulty of catalytic-converter technology, and environmentalists were pressing for stiffer emission standards.
The Civic, moreover, was the most fuel-efficient car on the road during the nation's initial panic over gasoline availability, during the 1973-74 Arab oil boycott. In its own way, the 1992 Civic VX three-door hatchback could prove as ground-breaking as the first Civic.
 
An Evolving Philosophy
 Honda's business philosophy has changed slightly over the last year with the promotion of Nobuhiko Kawamoto to president and chief executive. Mr. Kawamoto, a former racing engineer who was once head of research at Honda, has been preaching the need to make the company's vehicles ever more responsive to such growing environmental concernss as energy depletion, air quality and recycling, said Shigeaki Kato, a Detroit-based Honda spokesman.
Although the VTEC-E engine has limitations, in that it will be available in only one car model and cannot be sold in the state with the most auto buyers, Mr. Kato said Honda was nevertheless intent on introducing it. The company, he said, wants to gauge customers' reaction and demonstrate that the auto maker's environmental concerns are genuine, not merely a response to looming legislation.
Mr. Kawamoto was to have delivered a speech in August that was canceled after the death of the company's founder, Soichiro Honda. The text sought to convey the company's sense of its mission. "We must focus our attention," it read, "on the balance between what seem to be the opposite needs of reducing emissions and improving fuel efficiency while providing performance characteristics that improve the overall driving experience."

COMPANIES
Salomon Brothers has uncovered two additional violations of trading rules, Government officials said. The additional violations, which the firm is expected to announce today, include another instance of illegal bidding involving S. G. Warburg. [D1.]
Time Inc. Magazine Co. said it would lay off 105 editorial employees at six magazines. The editorial cuts follow 500 layoffs on the business side that Time Inc. made recently. [D1.] 
 After union officials charged that A.T.& T. had falsely blamed technicians for the breakdown on Tuesday, company executives admitted that some alarms were not working and that managers had not followed proper procedures. [D1.]
First Union was named the winning bidder for Southeast Bank of Miami. Southeast was closed late in the day and its Florida branches will reopen as branches of First Union of Florida. [D1.]
An industry organization plans to bid for Executive Life and says its proposal would give policyholders "significantly better" benefits than those promised in the bid led by Altus Finance. [D2.]
Honda will introduce a new Civic in two weeks whose engine could have a big impact in a current debate: whether fuel-efficient cars need come only in small packages. [D1.]

Gov. Florio and Allstate argued about whether the company was actually losing money on car insurance in New Jersey. [B6.]
 
THE ECONOMY
The nation's foreign-trade deficit widened sharply to $5.9 billion in July as soaring imports overwhelmed a modest rise in exports, the Commerce Dept reported. [D1.]
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell in early September, but the drop was largely dismissed as a fluke related to Labor Day. [D5.]
The New York City Council overrode Mayor Dinkins's veto of a bill requiring price stickers on supermarket items. [B1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Soviet officials doubled their estimate of their foreign food needs for the coming year, to $14.7 billion. [A1.]
The U.N. authorized Iraq to sell oil to buy food and essential civilian supplies. [A1.]
 
MARKETS
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply in the morning but gave back most of their gains later. The Dow rose 6.48, to 3,024.37. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed and interest rates were little changed again. [D14.]
Live cattle futures prices surged to a two-month high after the Government reported a smaller number of cattle being fattened for slaughter than expected. [D15.] The dollar rose slightly. [D15.]

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

LENGTH: 1121 words

BYLINE: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Friday, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Palestinians suddenly softened their stand today after indicating Thursday that they could not yet agree to accept Washington's invitation to a proposed peace conference because the Bush Administration was unwilling to meet some of their minimum political demands.
In a surprise reversal early today, West Bank Palestinian leaders suddenly decided to resume talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d about their terms for the conference and sent one of their senior negotiators, Hanan Ashrawi, to Amman for talks with Mr. Baker. 
 Palestinian officials said Thursday that they were still seeking assurances from the United States that their right to "self-determination" will be guaranteed before they go to the conference. They also wanted assurances that during any period of autonomy for Palestinians on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip they, rather than the Israelis, would have control over basic resources, and that the United States would support an interpretation of United Nations resolutions that would enjoin Israel to trade land for peace. While Mr. Baker is willing to give Palestinians general assurances consistent with previous American policies, they do not go far enough in any of these key areas to satisfy the Palestinians.
In a joint news conference in Amman Thursday, Secretary Baker and King Hussein of Jordan implored the Palestinians not to miss the opportunity to attend this peace conference, tentatively scheduled to begin next month. Mr. Baker vaguely hinted that if the Palestinians did not agree soon to attend on the terms being offered by Washington, the conference might have to start without them -- although that was not what the United States wanted.
It was the first public indication from the Secretary of State that he is having difficulties enticing the Palestinians to the talks, having already won the conditional support of Syria, Jordan and Israel.
Addressing the Palestinians, Mr. Baker said: "I believe that this is the best opportunity that has presented itself for a long, long time, and I also think that it is going to be a long, long time before the bus ever comes by again. And if this opportunity is missed, in my opinion, Palestinians have perhaps the most to lose, because Palestinians have perhaps the most to gain from taking advantage of this opportunity."
King Hussein, for his part, said: "Time is short. This opportunity may not come again -- ever."
On Monday, the Palestinian representatives from the West Bank and Gaza Strip met with Mr. Baker in Jerusalem to discuss a draft letter of assurances that the Secretary was prepared to give them regarding Washington's position on the conference and what the Palestinians could expect.
The Jerusalem talks, however, were inconclusive, and Mr. Baker suggested that they meet again while he was still in the area. The Secretary suggested the Palestinian representatives come to Amman during his stopover here.
Upon Mr. Baker's departure from Jerusalem on Monday, a senior American official told reporters that it would be "a real test of Palestinian intentions" toward the peace talks if they showed up in Amman Thursday. American officials were clearly disappointed not to find them here.
Palestine Liberation Organization officials said Chairman Yasir Arafat ordered the three Palestinians who have been negotiating with Mr. Baker during his stopovers in Jerusalem not to meet with him in Amman, because Mr. Baker had refused in his meeting with Palestinians on Monday to give them the assurances they had been seeking about the outcome of the peace conference.
Arab diplomats say there is another issue as well. If Mr. Arafat is going to sanction non-P.L.O. Palestinians to take part in a peace conference, he wants to be compensated with an end to the political and economic boycott of the P.L.O. that has been mounted by Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf Arabs since Mr. Arafat came out in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
However, at 2:30 this morning, Jordanian officials contacted Mr. Baker and told him they had been informed that Miss Ashrawi was ready to come from her home in Ramallah in the occupied West Bank to meet him in Amman for further discussions. This move was apparently ordered by Mr. Arafat after heavy pressure from Arab governments who have been telling the P.L.O. that they will never have an American Administration more sympathetic to their cause and should not alienate Washington.
American officials are hoping that Miss Ashrawi will also use her visit to Amman to begin talks with Jordanian officials on forming a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to the peace conference. Such an alliance could expedite the convening of the talks.
 
Syria Is 'Eager'
 American officials say that Syria is "eager" for the conference to begin and may well be ready to go to talks with Israel, even without the Palestinians. At a news conference in Damascus on Wednesday the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, pointedly refused to rule this out. The participation of Jordan, however, where the majority of the population is of Palestinian origin, is much more uncertain.
King Hussein would find it very difficult to attend without a joint Palestinian delegation approved by the P.L.O.
According to a senior P.L.O. official, Mr. Arafat does not believe that Syria or Jordan would dare sit down with Israel, without Palestinians in attendance.
Mr. Baker has negotiated with the Palestinians through Faisal al-Husseini and Zakaria al-Agha, as well as Miss Ashrawi. They, in turn, took their instructions from the P.L.O. in Tunis.
During the seven meetings Mr. Baker has held with the Palestinians in Jerusalem, they have raised several points that they wanted to be assured of before they attended the conference. Since the United States is refusing to let the Palestinians be represented at the talks by the P.L.O., it has been very important for the three local leaders to try to extract from Washington certain symbolic assurances that would compensate for the fact that their preferred representative would be barred from the negotiations as a concession to Israel.
Mr. Baker is now in the process of distributing similar assurances to Syria, Israel and Jordan -- the other key participants.
"The truth is," said a senior Administration official involved in the talks with the Palestinians, "after they lay out their symbolic demands, they have been quite reasonable. They would like to come. But nothing ever gets nailed down with them. We think they have given in on a point and then two meetings later it gets raised again. No one knows what is settled and what isn't with them. Everybody is getting a little bit impatient."

HEADLINE: 2,500 Connecticut Workers Are First Round of Layoffs

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Layoff notices went out to about 2,500 state workers today, the first wave in what could rise to 8,000 dismissals as Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and labor unions battle over an unraveled package of concessions linked to the state's new income tax.
The layoffs, and the threat hanging over every state agency that more could come soon, have made the pain long promised by Connecticut's budget troubles suddenly and uncomfortably real. 
 Earlier this week Mr. Weicker accused the union members, who were his allies in lobbying for the wage tax, of reneging on a $346 million package of wage and benefit concessions. Union leaders in turn said the administration was looking to force the layoffs to convince disgruntled residents that the tax would be accompanied by significants cuts in state spending.
Both sides repeated their arguments today, with Mr. Weicker saying concession talks must produce "real savings" and labor leaders saying that the state wants blood for blood's sake. After eight hours of talks, the Governor's representative described the two sides as "very far apart."
And workers like Patty Constantine, a clerk in the Department of Environmental Protection's accounting division, found themselves in the middle.
 
Bumping and Confusion
 "I'll just be on the unemployment line," said Ms. Constantine, a 40-year-old single mother who got her pink slip this morning.
Mr. Weicker has said that 5,500 more layoffs could be necessary if unions do not agree to givebacks, including giving up a raise already being received by nearly half the workers. And the prospect of even more pink slips rose today when Republican leaders in the General Assembly announced a drive to repeal the income tax.
Their proposed replacement budget, though not fully drafted and considered a longshot by many legislators, would include much deeper cuts in state spending than any previously proposed budget -- and would cause, they conceded, more layoffs.
The pink slip received by Ms. Constantine is the first step in a prolonged process. Most state worker get four to six weeks between notice and removal from the job, depending on the terms of their union contracts. And many who were given notice today will not lose their jobs because their seniority will allow them to "bump" someone with less seniority onto the layoff list.
Because many people now on the layoff list will bump their way off it, the impact on state services and even the final number of dismissed workers won't be known for several weeks.
"We don't know how far this is going to go," said Ann Overby, a senior clerk at the Department of Consumer Protection who got her notice today. Ms. Overby has been in the Department for 14 years and has already decided to use her right to bump. "We may get in a position where I'm out the door also."
Ms. Constantine said, "I'm just going to hold on to a little faith that like the last time it won't come to fruition -- hope springs eternal."
Department administrators and agency commissioners said the layoffs would not go unnoticed by residents using state services. At the Department of Motor Vehicles, an agency that many residents deal with, 295 people got notices, about 8 percent of the 3,900 member work force.
 
Thinking of Snow
 In other departments, the losses were even greater. At highway maintenance office, for instance, 230 people got notices, or about 11 percent of the 2,000-member staff. Transportation Commissioner Emil H. Frankel said that snow removal would take longer if those layoffs go through: Secondary roads in rural areas would probably have to wait 24 to 48 hours for a snowplow while resources were concentrated on main roads.
At the Department of Consumer Protection, where 20 out of a total of 174 workers received notices, Commissioner Gloria Schaffer said that the measuring scales on home heating oil trucks, commercial bakers and retail food markets would get far fewer spot inspections than they do now.
As employees gathered to commiserate, there were scenes of compassion. At the Department of Public Works' public safety division, where two officers out of 15 got notices today, one stepped forward to take voluntary retirement to open up a job.
 
'Try Not to Think'
 "I've been there, I know what it is to be laid off," said Officer Michael Dellaripa, 70 years old and a state employee for 18 years.
But his decision probably won't help Jose M. Agosto, a fellow officer who got his pink slip this morning. Mr. Agosto, who is 35, has about three months less seniority than the other laid-off officer and will thus be second in a line of two to fill Mr. Dellaripa's old spot. "You try not to think about it," Mr. Agosto said.
Some people can't help thinking about it. Lori St. Amand, a 28-year-old communications officer at the Department of Environmental Protection, did not get a notice but expects to get laid off anyway -- she bumped someone of the layoff list last time, and now there are only three people in her job class with less seniority.
Ms. St. Amand and her husband are applying for a mortgage to buy a house in Berlin, and are meeting this week with bank officers.
"It's worse having been through it once before," she said. "Do you continue with the plans you've made and hope for the best, or -- well, what else can you do?"
Negotiatons about 6:30 P.M., with no plans to meet again until next Monday. "We are very far apart on some very key issues, including wages and job security," said Saranne P. Murray, the state's chief negotiator.
"My members are saying, 'Don't give in,' " said Steven Perruccio, president of the 7,000-member Connecticut Employees Union Independent.
