HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Text of Gates's 1984 Memo to Casey On 'Straight Talk' About Nicaragua

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The following is the text of a memorandum from Robert M. Gates, then the C.I.A.'s deputy director for intelligence, to William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, made public today by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio. It was dated Dec. 14, 1984.
1. It is time to talk absolutely straight about Nicaragua. To recap where we are: 
 -- Based on all the assessments we have done, the contras, even with American support, cannot overthrow the Sandinista regime. Whatever small change they had to do that has been further diminished by the new weaponry being provided by the Soviets and Cubans.
-- The Soviets and Cubans are turning Nicaragua into an armed camp with military forces far beyond its defensive needs and in a position to intimidate and coerce its neighbors.
-- The Nicaraguan regime is steadily moving toward consolidation of a Marxist-Leninist government and the establishment of a permanent and well armed ally of the Soviet Union and Cuba on the mainland of the Western Hemisphere. Its avowed aim is to spread further revolution in the Americas.
-- The FDN [Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the main contra organization] has been denied American assistance. Without further assistance by February, all the information we have suggests the contras are going to begin heading into Honduras. The Hondurans will then be faced with some 12,500 armed fighters (whom the Hondurans see as closely allied with Alvarez [General Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, the chief of the Honduran armed forces], thereby potentially unsettling Honduras itself).
-- Flight of the contras into Honduras will be followed not only by their families but presumably by a second wave of refugees and others who, seeking abandonment of American efforts to force the Sandinistas to alter their regime, will see the handwriting on the wall, determine that their personal futures are in peril and leave the country. It is altogether conceivable that we could be looking at an initial refugee wave from Nicaragua over the first year of 150,000 to 200,000 people (the [illegible ] the contras alone could account for 50,000).
-- Failure of the United States to provide further assistance to the resistance and collapse of the contra movement would force Honduras to accommodate to the Nicaraguan regime. One result of this would be the complete reopening of the channels of arms support to the Salvadoran insurgency, thereby reversing the progress made in recent months.
-- These unsettled political and military circumstances in Central America would undoubtedly result in renewed capital flight from Honduras and Guatemala and result in both new hardship and political instability throughout the region.
2. These are strong assertions but our research as well as the reports of our people on the spot (for example our COS [chief of station] in Honduras) make it possible to substantiate each of the above points.
3. What is happening in Central America in many ways vividly calls to mind the old saw that those who forget the past are condemned to repeat it.
-- In 1958-60 we thought that we could reach some sort of an accommodation with Castro that would encourage him to build a pluralistic government in Cuba. We have been trying to do the same thing with the Nicaraguans, with the same success.
-- In Vietnam, our strategy consisted of a series of measures applied very gradually and over a long period of time. With each step of new U.S. involvement the gradual approach enabled the enemy to adjust to each new turn of the screw so that by the end of the war, even in the face of the most severe bombing, the Vietnamese had developed enormous tolerance. Half measures, half-heartedly applied, will have the same result in Nicaragua.
-- In 1975, the United States President announced that American assistance to UNITA in Angola was in the national interest of the United States and strongly urged the Congress to support military assistance to that group. The Congress turned it down, thereby not only proving that the United States would not involve itself in any significant way in the third world to combat Soviet subversion and activity but, moreover, that the Congress could effectively block any moves the President did wish to make. The Boland Amendment and the cutoff of aid to the contras is having the same effect again, showing the Soviets and our third world friends how little has changed in nine years, even with a President like Ronald Reagan.
In a variety of places, including Vietnam, negotiations in effect became a cover for the consolidation and further expansion of Communist control. While they might observe whatever arrangements were reached for the first weeks or as long as American attention (particularly media attention) was focused on the situation, they knew they could outlast our attention span. Usually within a relatively short period of time they were openly violating whatever agreements had been achieved.
4. The truth of the matter is that our policy has been to muddle along in Nicaragua with an essentially half-hearted policy substantially because there is no agreement within the Administration or with the Congress on our real objectives. We started out justifying the program on the basis of curtailing the flow of weapons to El Salvador. Laudable though that objective might have been, it was attacking a symptom of a larger problem in Central America and not the problem itself.
3. It seems to me that the only way that we can prevent disaster in Central America is to acknowledge openly what some have argued privately: that the existence of a Marxist-Leninist regime in Nicaragua closely allied with the Soviet Union and Cuba is unacceptable to the United States and that the United States will do everything in its power short of invasion to put that regime out. Hopes of causing the regime to reform itself for a more pluralistic government are essentially silly and hopeless. Moreover, few believe that all those weapons and the more to come are only for defense purposes. Only when we acknowledge what the objective is in Central America can we begin to have any kind of rational discussion on how to achieve it. As long as one maintains the fig leaf of curtailing the flow of arms to El Salvador, all other efforts can easily be politically dismissed.
6. Once you accept that ridding the continent of this regime is important to our national interest and must be our primary objective, the issue then becomes a stark one. You either acknowledge that you are willing to take all necessary measures (short of military invasion) to bring down that regime or you admit that you do not have the will to do anything about the problem and you make the best deal you can. Casting aside all fictions, it is the latter course we are on. Even new funding for the contras, particularly in light of the new Soviet weaponry, is an inadequate answer to this problem. The contras will be able to sustain an insurgency for a time but the cost and the pain will become very high and the resistance eventually will wither. Any negotiated agreement simply will offer a cover for the consolidation of the regime and two or three years from now we will be in considerably worse shape than we are now.
7. The alternative to our present policy -- which I predict ultimately and inevitably is leading to the consolidation of the Nicaraguan regime and our facing a second Cuba in Central America -- is overtly to try to bring down the regime. This involves a mustering of political force and will, first of all within the Administration and second with the Congress, that we have not seen on any foreign policy issue (apart from our defense rearmament) in many years. It seems to me that this effort would draw upon the following measures:
-- Withdrawal of diplomatic recognition of the regime in Managua and the recognition of a government in exile.
-- Overt provision to the government in exile of military assistance, funds, propaganda support and so forth including major efforts to gain additional support in international community, including real pressure.
-- Economic sanctions against Nicaragua, perhaps even including a quarantine. These sanctions would affect both exports and imports and would be combined with internal measures by the resistance to maximize the economic dislocation to the regime.
-- Politically most difficult of all, the use of air strikes to destroy a considerable portion of Nicaragua's military buildup (focusing particularly on the tanks and the helicopters). This would be accompanied by an announcement that the United States did not intend to invade Nicaragua but that no more arms deliveries of such weapons would be permitted.
8. These are hard measures. They probably are politically unacceptable. But it is time to stop fooling ourselves about what is going to happen in Central America. Putting our heads in the sand will not prevent the events that I outlined at the beginning of this note. Can the United States stand a second Cuba in the Western Hemisphere? One need only look at the difficulty that Cuba has caused this country over the past 25 years to answer that question.
9. The fact is that the Western Hemisphere is the sphere of influence of the United States. If we have decided totally to abandon the Monroe Doctrine, if in the 1980's taking strong actions to protect our interests despite the half of criticism is too difficult, then we ought to save political capital in Washington, acknowledge our helplessness and stop wasting everybody's time.
10. Without a comprehensive campaign openly aimed at bringing down the regime, at best we somewhat delay the inevitable. Without U.S. funding for the contras, the resistance essentially will collapse over the next year or two. While seeking funding from other countries to the contras could help for a time, it is essential to recognize that almost as important as the money is the fact of the United States support both from an economic and political standpoint. Somehow, knowing that Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore are behind you does not carry the same weight. Economic sanctions surely would have a significant impact in the initial months, but unless accompanied by a broad range of other actions this impact will diminish over time and we will find ourselves with a Nicaragua even more closely attached to the Soviet Union and Cuba than we have now.
11. All this may be politically out of the question. Probably. But all the cards ought to be on the table and people should understand the consequences of what we do and do not do in Nicaragua. Half measures will not even produce half successes. The course we have been on (even before the funding cut-off) -- as the last two years suggest -- will result in further strengthening of the regime and a Communist Nicaragua which, allied with its Soviet and Cuban friends, will serve as the engine for the destabilization of Central America. Even a well funded contra movement cannot prevent this; indeed, relying on and supporting the contras as our only action may actually hasten the ultimate, unfortunate outcome. -- ROBERT M. GATES

HEADLINE: Higher Food Aid Would Tax Soviet System of Distribution

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
American experts said yesterday that Moscow's doubling of its request for food aid to $14.7 billion for the coming year would, if granted, be a greater challenge to the Soviet Union's ability to distribute the food than the West's ability to supply it.
Last year, the Soviet Union's total food imports were $9.8 billion. About half of the total was imports of grain like wheat and corn, with the remainder being meat, soybeans, dairy products and other foodstuffs. In the past, Moscow has paid for these imports mainly from the hard currency it earns by exporting commodities like oil and gold, and by borrowing from Western banks. 
 Yet with oil and grain production down and Western banks reducing their loans to the troubled Soviet economy, Moscow is being forced to ask the West to help it meet its needs for food and fodder for livestock.
But American experts contend that even if the West agrees to a massive dose of food aid, it might not help people in the Soviet Union much.
 
Problems of Distribution
 "The problem isn't so much shortages as pricing and distribution problems," said Keith Crane, a senior economist at PlanEcon, a Washington-based consulting firm.
For example, Mr. Crane noted that the price of agricultural commodities sold by private cooperatives in the Soviet Union is 18 times the prices offered by the state. Consequently, farmers in the republics are holding onto their crops rather than sell them to a central Government whose authority in economic as well as political matters is widely questioned.
The distribution difficulties were stressed in a speech Wednesday night by Frans Andriessen, the European Community commissioner for external affairs. He cited the great difficulties in organizing the distribution of even the $300 million in food aid agreed to by the Community last December, noting that most of that has not yet been distributed.
Commodity markets in the United States showed little reaction to the new food request from the Soviet Union. Analysts said that the request was vague and that there was no indication what the Western response might be.
 
Excess Capacity in West
 Moreover, judging from Mr. Luzhkov's explanation of Moscow's request for aid from the Community, it appears that much of the request is for financing and not immediate food that would quickly deplete commodity stockpiles.
And unless there is a huge and unforeseen demand for immediate supplies, the West should have the capacity to meet increased demand for foodstuffs through planting unused farmlands and dipping into stockpiles.
"There's plenty of excess production capacity in grains in the United States," said David Lehman, an economist at the Chicago Board of Trade. "We should be able to easily mmet the demands of the Soviet Union."

HEADLINE: Market Unmoved by Iraqi Export Action

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The world oil market appeared to take little notice of the United Nations' decision yesterday to allow Iraq to resume limited exports, because buyers had been expecting the move for weeks. But experts said Iraq could still cause a price jolt, because President Saddam Hussein might not go along with the conditions tied to the sale or because bureaucratic problems could delay exports.
In the long term, however, a return of Iraqi oil to world markets would tend to push prices lower, and some analysts believe that this United Nations decision, which covers a six-month period, is likely to be the beginning of uninterrupted sales by Iraq.
 
$1 Billion in Parts

 The United Nations said Iraq could export $1.6 billion worth of oil over six months, which at current prices comes to about 500,000 barrels a day. This is a substantial increment on world markets; for example, the combined quotas of all the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is now 22.3 million barrels a day. OPEC is scheduled to meet on Tuesday in Vienna, and the organization may set a new quota based on anticipated demand for oil and production from around the world, including Iraq. 
 Before the war, Iraq's quota was 3.14 million barrels a day, but according to Thomas Blakeslee, an oil expert at Pegasus Econometric Group, of Hoboken, N.J., "they need approximately $1 billion in parts to get production back up to those levels." Mr. Blakeslee said 500,000 barrels a day is the maximum that the country could export now; others put the figure slightly higher.
The exports would be through a pipeline across Turkey, which before the war handled 1.2 million barrels a day, according to Mr. Blakeslee.
Iraq will face problems in re-entering world markets, experts say. "All the other sellers have locked their markets up," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, in New York. "They're going to have to force their way into the system," he said. Normally an exporter can offer a buyer continuity, he pointed out, but all Iraq can offer is price, so the price will probably be lower than usual.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil promised for delivery next month closed yesterday at $21.76 a barrel, down 8 cents. Before the war, Kirkuk crude, the type that Iraq would be exporting, usually sold for $2.75 to $3 a barrel below the price on the Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Havana Closes Communist Congress to Outsiders

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Faced with a severe economic and political crisis, Cuba has announced that for the first time in the 32-year leadership of President Fidel Castro the coming congress of the island's ruling Communist Party will be closed to foreign delegations and journalists.
The departure from previous practice, a number of experts on Cuban affairs said, reflects a sense of uncertainty within the Cuban leadership bordering on disorientation after the announcement by the Soviet Union last week that it was withdrawing its troops and ending its economic subsidies to the island. 
 But some of the specialists noted that the decision also reflected a growing view in Cuban society and elements of the party that fundamental changes were needed. They pointed out that in announcing the decision to keep the congress closed to outsiders Cuban officials said they were anxious to allow delegates to express their opinions without inhibition.
"It seems they are intent for the first time in having a serious discussion rather than a simple ratification of the official line," said William LeoGrande, an expert on Cuban affairs at American University in Washington, referring to the congress that begins Oct. 10. "They know they must come out of this with at least a modest program of change."
With vital Soviet aid to Cuba dwindling and endangered and the Communist system that Havana adopted three decades ago in virtual eclipse around the world, Mr. LeoGrande and other experts said the Cuban leadership now faced the daunting task of formulating a persuasive message of hope to a population whose living standards have sharply plummeted over the last two years.
"They have got to come out of this congress with some sort of program that convinces the people that things are somehow going to get better," Mr. LeoGrande said.
Originally scheduled for early this year, the congress, Cuba's fourth since the formal adoption of a socialist, one-party system in 1972, has already been repeatedly delayed as serious shortages of most foods and consumer goods have worsened and events abroad have propelled Cuba further into isolation.
At preparatory meetings with grass-roots members last year, Cuban officials privately acknowledge, harsh criticism of everything from the country's leaders and system of government to restricted personal freedoms and growing material hardships was voiced by many participants. As the complaints grew more numerous and louder, the local meetings were quietly canceled.
But as signs of discontent among Cubans have continued to grow in recent months, the 65-year-old Mr. Castro has delivered increasingly stern warnings both to would-be reformers and dissidents against attempts to bring about fundamental changes in Cuba's tightly controlled political system. Particularly strong language has been used to condemn market economics and multiparty pluralism.
Nonetheless, experts here who closely monitor Cuban developments say that despite these warnings there have been signs that Cuba's dire economic situation is forcing consideration of a number of innovations, among them the limited reintroduction of private enterprise in the agriculture and service sectors.

HEADLINE: U.N. PERMITS IRAQ LIMITED OIL SALES FOR CIVILIAN NEEDS

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 19

 BODY:
In the most significant easing of its Gulf war trade embargo so far, the Security Council authorized Iraq today to sell $1.6 billion worth of oil over the next six months to buy food and other essential civilian supplies and to compensate victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
But the carefully phrased resolution said all the money raised by these oil sales must be paid directly to the United Nations, which will earmark one-third for compensation payments and make sure the rest is spent only on imports approved by the Security Council. [Excerpts from the resolution, page A10.] 
 The decision followed a report on Iraq's humanitarian needs, which was prepared by an expert team that visited the country under the direction of Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations official in charge of humanitarian affairs in the Persian Gulf. The report said the country faced "critical" shortages of food, medicine and other supplies as a result of the embargo and recommended that Baghdad be allowed to sell $2.5 billion worth of oil to buy them.
 
'An Affront to Sovereignty'
 It is not clear whether Iraq, which sees the new resolution as an affront to its sovereignty, will agree to sell any oil under the strict terms the Council is imposing.
Iraq's United Nations representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, told the Council the new resolution confronts Baghdad with two choices "one more bitter than the other."
Either the country refuses to pump any oil and continues to endure the privations of the Council's trade embargo, he said, or else it abandons "sovereignty" over its natural resources in return for what he called "a limited respite."
The decision on oil sales came as the Security Council continued to wait for Iraq to say whether it would allow the United Nations inspectors searching for Iraqi arms to use helicopters in their quest or whether it would refuse, risking a new armed confrontation with the United States and its allies.
The United States has warned that it may send armed helicopters and warplanes to escort the inspectors unless Baghdad guarantees them safe passage anywhere inside Iraq.
The new Council resolution was adopted with 13 members in favor, Cuba opposed and Yemen abstaining. The measure says the actual oil will be immune from seizure by those with financial claims against Iraq.
It gives Iraq the responsibility for finding buyers for its oil and pumping the supplies from its northern oilfields down a pipeline through Turkey to the Mediterranean coast. Buyers will pay directly into a special escrow account controlled by the United Nations Secretary General to keep President Saddam Hussein's Government from getting its hands on any of the money.
Iraq may then order from foreign suppliers the food and other essential humanitarian goods it needs. Once these orders have been approved by the Security Council committee overseeing sanctions, the Secretary General will release money to pay for them.
But inspectors appointed by the United Nations will oversee both the pumping and selling of the oil as well as the purchase and distribution of the imported goods to insure that they conform with the Council's terms.
In fact, only about $1 billion worth of oil revenues will be available for humanitarian imports because the other $600 million will be used to start paying compensation to the victims of Iraq's invasion as well as for paying for the cost of finding and destroying its weapons of mass destruction, returning stolen property and demarcating the frontier with Kuwait.
 
'No Quarrel With the People'
 The United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said the new resolution showed the international community's "concern for providing Iraqi civilians with humanitarian assistance."
Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said the resolution showed the Security Council has "no quarrel with the Iraqi people who have suffered greatly at the hands of their leaders."
Speaking for France, the Council's President, Jean-Bernard Merimee, called on Iraq to accept the payment mechanism and start selling oil as soon as possible in order to meet its humanitarian needs.
Whether Baghdad will do so remains unclear, however. In August Iraqi officials warned Prince Saddruddin that they would never sell their oil if the revenue was all taken away by the United Nations, saying this was an intolerable insult to the country's sovereignty.
And since then Ambassador Anbari has continually denounced the payment mechanism the Council has been designing as unacceptable to Baghdad.
Many diplomats, however, say they believe Iraq will start selling oil in the end, just as it has eventually accepted all the Council's Gulf war resolutions after first denouncing them and refusing to cooperate.
Failure to take up the Council's oil sale offer, they argue, would leave President Hussein personally responsible for his people's privations and rob him of the chance to strengthen his own position by alleviating their suffering.
Nevertheless, many say they believe President Hussein is testing the Council's will to enforce its resolutions, believing that the international community is growing tired of the Gulf crisis and becoming distracted by events in the Soviet Union and elsewhere.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Helmick Mess Could Hamper U.S. Pursuit of the Gold

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Robert Helmick's resignation on Wednesday as president of the United States Olympic Committee after questions about his business relationships has undermined the stability of the organization, say some Olympic officials, who fear that the situation could affect public confidence in Olympic efforts and financial support.
By yesterday, the committee was moving quickly to limit damage from the episode, which began earlier this month when Helmick admitted to other U.S.O.C. officers that he had worked as a paid consultant to groups seeking greater ties to the Olympics. 
 A meeting of the 22-member executive committee was arranged for Monday in Colorado Springs to discuss procedures for electing an interim president to serve through next year, when the Winter Games will be held in France and the Summer Games in Spain.
At the same time, Harvey Schiller, the U.S.O.C. executive director, who was drawn into a controversy of his own earlier this week with the United States ski federation, said he would press forward to strengthen ethical guidelines and provisions that require officers and staff members to disclose relevant business ties to the Olympics.
He also said a growing number of officials was supporting the idea of creating an external review process. Arnold I. Burns, a former United States Deputy Attorney General, was hired last week to review Helmick's business affairs.
 
Worried About Preparation
 But while the initiatives were gaining momentum and other Olympic officials expressed optimism that the ordeal would pass quickly, more than a few raised concerns that training by United States athletes for next year's Olympics and revenue streams that support their preparations could be affected.
Their concerns were especially critical in a period of economic sluggishness, in which Americans -- many of whom balk at the notion of professionals' competing in the Olympics -- are being asked to support Olympic efforts now certain to include athletes like Michael Jordan, the basketball star, who earns millions of dollars in salary and product endorsements.
 
Counting Money Before It's In
 One official, who insisted that his name not be used, said that the U.S.O.C. had expected to spend $18 million from the sale of 1992 Olympic coins for improvements to the Olympic training complex in Colorado Springs. Construction is scheduled to begin in February.
But public perceptions of mismanagement, unethical behavior or chaos at the top, he said, could reduce the sales, anticipated to be more than $25 million. He and others also wondered whether corporate executives might decide to reduce their spending on Olympic programs until issues of leadership are sorted out.
The concerns were exacerbated on Tuesday when the United States ski federation accused Schiller of offering additional money in grants in exchange for ski passes and equipment. He denied the accusations.
Confidence in the leadership seemed to be further eroded when the International Olympic Committee announced yesterday that three of its members would investigate Helmick's business arrangements. Helmick has been an I.O.C. member since 1985 and on its 12-member executive board since 1989.
"They might take the position, 'Well, this is something I had better wait and see who comes in,' " said George Steinbrenner, one of three U.S.O.C. vice presidents, referring to possible reaction of corporate leaders. "These guys want to see confidence in the ability to lead."
Chuck Foster, the U.S.O.C. secretary, said it was incumbent upon the remaining officers to act quickly in assuring sponsors, who contribute a large part of the $298 million four-year budget, that Helmick's problems do not permeate the organization.
"We have to call the sponsors; that's the primary thing," Foster said. "We also need a plan to reassure the American people and athletes that things are going along as scheduled."
The first change is likely to be the election of an interim president, although no clear favorite has emerged. On Monday, the executive committee is expected to set forth the process for identifying candidates and schedule the election. Schiller said the election would probably be held during the next meeting of the board of directors in late October.
That person would serve through the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, next year, after which a nominating committee would be appointed to produce candidates for full four-year terms.
Several individuals with strong ties to the Olympics have expressed an interest in the position on an interim or longer basis, including William Simon, a former U.S.O.C. president; Anita deFrantz, a former Olympic rower who was named to the I.O.C. five years ago; Michael Lenard, a U.S.O.C. vice president, and Foster, a former official in the United States Figure Skating Association.
Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, who was brought into an Olympic leadership position by Helmick three years ago, has disavowed any interest in the presidency, as the interim or four-year successor to Helmick.

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
Auction fever flared briefly last Friday during an afternoon sale of 19th-century furnishings and bric-a-brac at Sotheby's in New York. Midway through the dispersal of elaborately carved and gilded commodes, chairs and chandeliers, a bidding duel in the pre-recession style developed between two dealers vying for a pair of damaged seven-foot stone candelabra, which Sotheby's had estimated would bring $6,000 to $8,000.
It was when the numbers reached $150,000 that the contest narrowed to two dealers: Carlton Hobbs of London, whose brother, John, placed bids for him from there by telephone, and Bernard Steinitz, who flew over from his Paris gallery and bid in person. They battled on, propelling the price to $330,000 -- more than 40 times Sotheby's presale estimate -- and Mr. Hobbs became the new owner. 
 Mr. Hobbs said by telephone from London this week that he disagreed with the description in Sotheby's catalogue, which states: "A pair of gilt-bronze jasper torcheres, third quarter of the 19th century, possibly Russian."
"They're earlier, made probably between 1800 and 1810 at a French factory, Sarreguimines, in Lorraine," he said. "Sarreguimines invented a paste of pulverized stone that, when polished, had the authentic appearance of stone with a glasslike surface -- the finish on these candlesticks."
Mr. Steinitz disagreed with both Sotheby's and Mr. Hobbs on various points. "They may not be Russian; they could be Swedish," he said this week by telephone from Marseilles, France. "But the shape has nothing to do with French style. I am pretty sure they are foreign, not French."
The only matter on which there was any consensus this week among the bidders, watchers and dealers in 19th-century furnishings was that Sotheby's presale estimate for the torcheres was ridiculously low. "I was really astonished by the estimate," Mr. Steinitz said. "They are incredible quality, very rare. Anybody could see they are very special."
Mr. Steinitz said the candelabra -- soaring Neo-Classical columns of a purple-red stone, flecked with pink and banded with gilded bronze flowers, grape vines and leaves -- are far more impressive when seen in person than they appear to be in the catalogue.
Both torcheres are chipped on the bases and the tops, and the base of one candleholder has been broken in three parts and repaired, said Elaine Whitmire, Sotheby's specialist in 19th-century furnishings.
Mr. Hobbs was not seriously concerned by the chips. "They can be repaired," he said. What does matter, he said, is where, when and of what the candleholders were made.
"It was clear in the catalogue photograph that this was no ordinary stone," Mr. Hobbs said. After studying the photograph with a very strong magnifying glass, he said, he decided that the torcheres were probably made of a paste of pulverized stone in a special process that was developed before 1802 at Sarreguemines.
"Having seen Sarreguemines stone in three vases at Trianon, I thought this was a good possibility," he said. "The condition report I had from Sotheby's bore this out. I also asked the opinion of a couple of people in New York. I haven't seen the candlesticks yet, so I can't be that emphatic, but I bet they are Sarreguemines." He also said the bases of the candleholders and the vases at the Grand Trianon at Versailles are all bell-shaped.
Yesterday, Mr. Hobbs was shown a magazine article reproducing a watercolor drawing of what appears to be an identical candelabrum from the National Archives in Paris. The article, by Denise Ledoux-Lebard, a writer on period French furniture, says the candelabrum in the drawing is similar to one presented to the Empress Josephine by the town of Dieppe.
Ms. Whitmire said the unidentified sellers are descendents of Henry C. Gibson of Philadelphia, an heir to a distillery fortune who owned them in the 19th century and died in 1891. They were unable to identify the torcheres or to say when they were acquired for the Gibson mansion on Walnut Street.
Before the sale, she said, she changed her mind about only two matters. "The torcheres are marble, not jasper," she said. "And I said then that they might sell for about $50,000."
On the rest, she stood firm. "I have to go by my gut reaction: I still think they are Russian. I have nothing to go on that would suggest anything else. Russians were doing things a little bit later than the French. Originally, I thought they were made in the 1860's. Now, I think they may be from 1835 to 1850. As for the glasslike surface, some marbles have that, too."

HEADLINE: Film Festival: The Spirit Is the Focus

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
IN years to come, the 29th New York Film Festival, which opens at Lincoln Center tonight with "The Double Life of Veronique," may be remembered as the festival that got religion.
It's not that the 33 films representing 20 countries preach any kind of consistent doctrine; their attitudes toward spiritual and religious matters could hardly be more diverse. It is that an unusual number of this year's selections touch on issues of religious identity, faith and mystical connection and explore a split view of human existence that might be described as spiritual versus technological. 
 Two of the American selections, both of which will soon have commercial releases, have already raised eyebrows and provoked debate after advance screenings.
The novelist Michael Tolkin's first film, "The Rapture," which plays Sept. 30 and Oct. 1 at the 17-day festival, tells of the conversion to fundamentalist Christianity of a Los Angeles telephone operator (played by Mimi Rogers) who gives up her promiscuous life when she accepts Jesus. The film goes on to imagine an Armageddon in which the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse are seen galloping across the heavens in sequences that suggest a low-budget parody of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind."
David Mamet's "Homicide," which closes the festival on Oct. 6, stars Joe Mantegna as a Jewish homicide detective who is caught in ethnic and ideological crossfire that involves militant Jews, neo-Nazis, angry blacks and his non-Jewish fellow officers, who he feels look down on him. Epithets fly across the screen, and the film bares chasms of hate.
But if religion has a strong place in both films, it creates more problems for the characters than it solves. Neither film ends happily.
For Mr. Tolkin, making a movie without a pat feel-good ending was one of his goals.
"In the 70's, I saw no conflict between loving a movie like 'Close Encounters,' which I saw five times, and loving Fassbinder," he said recently. "But as Hollywood discovered that absurd happy endings worked with audiences, the need for them became a kind of drug that masked Reaganism and voodoo economics. Movies began to feel like Nuremberg rallies where the audiences were united against a scapegoat. I didn't want the audience to be a mob at the end of the movie. That's why I decided to make a negative spectacle. 'The Rapture' is as much a response to 'Close Encounters' and 'E. T.' as it is about fundamentalism."
Mr. Mamet said recently that the themes of "Homicide" emerged almost unconsciously while he was adapting a more conventional police story based on the experiences of his cousin Eddie Mamet, a New York City police captain.
"The older I get, the more my material comes from unlooked-for places," the film maker and playwright said from his home in Boston. "It would be easy to capitalize on a certain technique and just write 'American Buffalo' and 'House of Games' again.
" 'Homicide' was something I was fighting against. I was writing a cop story, and out of nowhere came this bizarre story of a Jewish police detective. After 10 days, I decided that maybe it was the story I should be following. Both as a citizen looking around the city in which I live and also as a Jew, it's disturbing to see what looks like not only a resurgence of racial hatred, but a legitimization of racial hatred."
Two of the documentaries in this year's festival also deal with issues of Jewish cultural identity. "The Other Eye," a documentary co-directed by Johanna Heer and Werner Schmiedel, which will be shown Wednesday, evenhandedly examines the life and work of G. W. Pabst, an Austrian film maker who directed some early film classics and later worked in Hollywood. His reputation went into eclipse after he returned to Austria in 1939 to direct films for the Nazis.
Alan Berliner's documentary "Intimate Stranger," which will be shown Oct. 3, investigates the cosmopolitan life of his grandfather, a Palestinian Jew who was brought up in Egypt and after World War II kept his family in Brooklyn while he worked in Japan in the textile business.
 
Mystical Motifs
 Mystical and allegorical motifs run through many of the other selections as well. Krzysztof Kieslowski's "Double Life of Veronique," which opens the festival tonight with screenings at both Avery Fisher and Alice Tully Halls, imagines a bond between two young women, one in Poland, the other in Paris, who are identical, lead similar lives, and mystically sense each other's existence in the world. The film, which stars Irene Jacob in the dual roles, represents a marked departure in mood by the Polish director whose dour 1987 film, "A Short Film About Killing," scrutinized homicide and capital punishment with a relentless clinical intensity.
"By having the same person play two different persons, I wanted to express a human message, to show that we are all alike and at the same time completely different," the director recently said, speaking through an interpreter.
"The central idea of the film is the question of communication between two people that is not obvious. It's something you feel without understanding where it comes from. I think we all have it."
 
Direct and Indirect

Atom Egoyan, the young Canadian film maker who wrote and directed "The Adjuster," which will be shown Thursday and Sept. 28, explores what he describes as "the difference between the way one represents oneself and the notion of mediated dealings and emotions in a society overwhelmed by representational devices."
Noah Render, the film's title character, is an insurance company representative who helps families figure out their property losses after a catastrophe. He is so solicitous that he is viewed by clients as almost a saint. His wife, Hera, is a government-employed movie censor who secretly tapes the pornographic films she classifies. The couple lives in the model home for an uncompleted housing development that has been abandoned. Noah's clients are put up in a motel that Mr. Egoyan said he was tempted to name the Ararat.
The film was inspired, he said, by a fire that destroyed his parents' home two years ago on New Year's Eve.
"From out of nowhere came this person who said he was the adjuster," he recalled. "I began to fantasize what would happen if someone in that job felt so distant from his own life style that he used his function to comfort himself. And I thought it would be interesting if his mate were someone involved with protecting life style by judging images you cannot see."
 
Shakespeare Plus
 Allegorical references also run through "My Own Private Idaho," Gus Van Sant Jr.'s film, which will be shown next Friday and Sept. 28, about two young male prostitutes from the streets of Portland, Ore., who go to Italy in search of the mother of one of them. Mr. Van Sant's screenplay directly connects the story to Shakespeare's "Henry IV." Its Falstaff character is a cocaine-snorting chicken hawk, and its King Henry a wheelchair-bound urban mayor. In several scenes, the characters express themselves in an updated style of Shakespearean verse.
Mr. Van Sant said he was inspired by the Orson Welles movie "Chimes at Midnight," which was also based on the Shakespeare play. The actual plot, he said, emerged from the confluence of two short stories and a screenplay he had been working on simultaneously.
"The world that Shakespeare was creating really seemed to relate," he said recently. "There are certain things about Portland and the Northwest that are kind of medieval. It's in the buildings and in many of the people who live there and what they wear. The overall theme of the movie is about home and family and displacement and searching for that."
Shakespeare comes to the fore in Peter Greenaway's "Prospero's Books," an iconoclastic interpretation of "The Tempest" in which John Gielgud not only portrays Prospero but voices most of the other characters' dialogue as well. The interpretation treats the events of the play as a fantasy in Prospero's mind that is so potent it actually affects events. Using advanced video technology as well as film, Mr. Greenaway creates surreal scenes that dramatize Prospero's seething imagination and also suggest that the actor, the playwright and the character are synonymous. The movie, which will be shown Sept. 28 and 29, takes its title and some of its thematic imagery from the books that Prospero took with him when he was exiled from Naples. The film's most important addition to Shakespeare's text is its illustration of the 24 books that are mentioned in the play but are not described.
"I don't think there's much point in making historical movies just to make historical movies," Mr. Greenaway said recently. "What makes this particular project relevant to the end of the 20th century is the concern for knowledge. What do we do now that we know we can manipulate DNA and have the secrets of the hydrogen bomb?"
Similar themes are explored in the Japanese director Jun Ichikawa's film "No Life King," which will be shown Sunday and Monday. The drama centers on a children's computer game that is reputed to kill those who play against it and lose.
Richard Pena, the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which presents the festival, and the chairman of the film selection committee, described the movie as "a portrait of the savage heart of technological Japan."
"Beneath this extraordinary, brightly lit and controlled present, there is amazing superstition and myth that is literally driving that society," he said recently. "The children are surrounded by machinery, but the driving forces in their lives are the curses that are associated with these machines."
Even "Beauty and the Beast," the festival's tribute to Walt Disney, fits the magical mood of this year's festival. The two showings of the studio's newest animated feature on Sept. 29 and Oct. 2 will be the first time the festival has screened a work in progress. The print to be shown is about seven-eighths finished. The unfinished parts demonstrate the steps of the animation process, from pencil sketches to fuller drawings. The film includes six songs by the team of Alan Menken and Howard Ashman, who composed the score for "The Little Mermaid."
Putting together a film festival suffused with so much spiritual and magical imagery was not a deliberate intention of the selection committee, which included several critics and Mr. Pena and Wendy Keys of the Film Society, Mrs. Keys said.
"We're not even aware of those threads until after we've made our selections," she said. "But as often happens, when we actually assess our final selection, it's astonishing that these trends emerge."
Summing up the mood of this year's festival, Mr. Pena suggested that it expressed "a post-80's sensibility."
"It has something to do with the lack of guarantees, of there being strict structures to obey or even ideals to work toward," he said. "In a larger sense, it has something to do with the collapse of things in Eastern Europe. A lot of the films are about having your legs suddenly cut out from under you and looking for new guarantees and new structures. That leads to the theme of search."

(Fineline Features/Abigayle Taraches; Miramax; The Film Society of Lincoln Center)

HEADLINE: The Puzzling George Bushes

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is former chief Washington correspondent and former executive editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most interesting questions about President Bush near the end of his third year are why he makes the appointments he does and why he loves to fight at home and concentrate on making peace and refereeing fights abroad. Both involve his attitude toward the responsibilities of Congress, and the record indicates that he regards Congress not as a partner whose advice and consent are required by the Constitution but as a barrier, even a nuisance, to be overcome.
 He's a puzzle. He is always appealing for unity and a kinder, gentler America, and then choosing officials and policies he knows are bound to raise a storm. He chose Senator Dan Quayle to be Vice President, John Tower to be Secretary of Defense, John Sununu to be chief of staff, Clarence Thomas to sit on the Supreme Court and Robert Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, and wondered why anybody objected. 
 In the process, he said, and said again, that in choosing Judge Thomas he never even considered his race. This was widely regarded here as the most remarkable and ridiculous statement since he insisted that Mr. Quayle was the best qualified Republican to be Vice President. Meanwhile, he rejoiced in the end of the cold war and a future new world order, and then nominated Mr. Gates, a cold war spymaster, who inevitably revived the old contra controversies the President was urging everybody to forget.
 The Republican convention, despite its doubts, approved Mr. Quayle. The Senate rejected Mr. Tower. Mr. Sununu didn't have to get anybody's approval except the President's, and even the President has been embarrassed by Mr. Sununu's muscular right-wing politics and bad manners.
Mr. Bush's punishment for insisting on what he wants and vetoing what he doesn't want is that often he doesn't like what he gets. Incidentally, he probably won't like Clarence Thomas, if he gets him on the Court, for Judge Thomas hasn't been faithful to anybody's agenda in the past, including his own.
If so, this will not be a new experience for Mr. Bush. He always seems to win "great victories" and then wonder what, if anything, he got out of them. He invaded Panama and got Manuel Noreiga, and now doesn't know what to do with him. He snookered the country into war in the gulf to punish and get rid of Saddam Hussein, but after more than 100,000 enemy dead, which was scarcely noticed, that scoundrel is still presiding over the wreckage of Iraq, including its nuclear installations. And now Mr. Bush apparently is thinking about going back in. He "saved" Kuwait for "democracy," then rescued the same old family autocracy there.
But he's happy with the result, for he came out of these two wars with more popularity than when he went in, widely proclaimed as a wizard in the conduct of foreign policy.
 So you have to give him credit -- about $200 billion a year! He vowed to deal with the budget deficit without taxes ("Read my lips!") but sort of reversed himself. He declared war on drugs; announced he would be "the education President"; lectured the Soviets from the back of a golf cart on the glories of sharing power; blamed the Democrats for the homeless, unemployed and budget and trade deficits -- and, funniest of all, sold this package to the people with such success that the Democrats' big hitters all decided they would rather "spend more time with the family" in 1992 than challenge him.
Few people will weep for these dropouts, who don't have the will to fight for their convictions or the courage to fail. But this only emphasizes the problem about Presidential appointments, for George Bush, in a confusion of loyalties, is likely to choose Mr. Quayle for more four years, if the convention, in a customary fit of absent-mindedness, lets him get away with it.
Like most Presidents coming into their 70's, even George Bush will have to pay attention to his fluttery heart and rely more on the people he appoints to help him with the decisions he has to make.
Far more important than what happens to Messrs. Thomas, Gates, Quayle or even Bush is what happens to a country that is so casual about the way it appoints the people the President needs to help him reach decisions.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Reclaiming the Victory

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Spare us the astonishment and indignation that the Bush Administration puts on about Saddam Hussein's naughtinesses. Maybe then we will see how to get rid of the man.
Did Mr. Bush, after keeping Saddam Hussein in power, truly believe that he would accept defeat, out of sheer gentlemanliness? Did Mr. Bush think that after Saddam so carefully hid all those missiles and chemical and bacteriological weapons he would hand them over to U.N. inspectors, to make their day fruitful? 
 Mr. Bush called Saddam a Hitler. Did he believe the fellow would become a reformed Hitler?
The Administration might be cynical but it is not stupid. The U.S., having defeated Iraq militarily, fled victory. The reason was that Saudi Arabia and Syria wanted us to do so.
They were justifiably terrified that a relatively representative government might emerge in Iraq out of the rebel movements -- and that it would be contagious. So the U.S. signed up with the evil idea of allowing Saddam Hussein to remain in power along with his terrorist Baathist political party and the gang around him. It did have the wistful hope that one of the gang would put a bullet in his brain. Nobody obliged. Saddam Hussein lives and maneuvers in growing power, he, the party and the gang.
This is embarrassing to Mr. Bush. But he will not admit error. A President? But a lot of the rest of us can -- Americans like myself who thought Mr. Bush really meant not just to save the Kuwaiti rulers but end Saddam Hussein's tyranny, just because he said so. We are lucky trust is not a crime in this country -- nor brings death as it did to the Kurds.
Done is done. But ending the befogging mock astonishment might give us clarity to see what to do now.
First, stop playing mouse to the Saddam cat. He grabs every chance to defy the U.N., for military advantage and to preen before the Muslim world. He carried out arms-collecting raids in contemptuous violation of the U.N. cease-fire line. He showed U.N. inspectors weapons and nuclear facilities -- when they knew the exact sites. He blocked them with bullets or bureaucracy from hunting for what they could not pin down. And he continues to use war and terror against the Kurds and Shiite rebels.
Sending planes to protect the inspectors will stop him -- once. Then he will move again, and again, as long as he is in power.
Short range, a small but permanent and powerful military base in Iraq could provide continuous protection for U.N. operations. It would remind Iraq that its leader has sacrificed their sovereignty.
But as Senator Albert Gore, the Tennessee Democrat, and a handful of other members of Congress say until they are hoarse, the basic policy toward Iraq must change.
One pistol, though a happy thought, will not be enough. Iraq would remain under his fellow-killers and their party -- like killing Hitler to promote Goring.
What's needed is what Mr. Bush has not come up with -- a political strategy, understood by Americans and Iraqis, to remove Saddam Hussein and his state despotism.
The U.S. should give full political and public opinion support to the Kurds -- and to the Shiite rebels too, instead of assuming no Iraqi dissidents want or can be trusted with freedom.
Food and medicine from Iraqi funds should be sent into Iraq and distributed by U.N. specialists -- particularly to rebels and their families -- under guard, without Saddam Hussein's permission.
War crimes tribunals should try Saddam Hussein and his top leaders in absentia, making it clear to all others that to stick with them is to invite the noose. Defectors should be protected, and rewarded.
Military action may be needed on a spot target basis. But if the U.S. at last uses its political and economic power against him, with the clear ethical goal of ending his tyranny, the war damage done to Iraq already should make repeated massive attacks unnecessary.
To accomplish the end of the tyranny, Mr. Bush must concede that Saddam Hussein and his gang are the agents of disorder and instability, not their victims. Only so can the victory be reclaimed and the Persian Gulf war justified.
Otherwise, Saddam Hussein will continue to rule in Iraq, and continue to grow in power until he is ready to fight again -- Saddam, the son of Saddam or the clone of Saddam.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 573 words

HEADLINE: Don't Tie U.S.-Soviet Relations to Cuba

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The thrust of "Fortress Cuba, Lonely Cuba" (editorial, Sept. 8) is on target. Cuba is no longer a problem to anyone but itself. Its troops are out of Africa. For all practical purposes, the guerrilla wars are over in Latin America. And the United States need no longer fear a Soviet military threat mounted from Cuba; indeed, as affirmed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Moscow is beginning to reduce its military presence on the island. Further, the Cuban economy is in dire straits; the time when it might have been an attractive model for other Latin states has passed. 
 Thus, as you point out, it would be folly for the Bush Administration to listen to the hard-liners who wish to intervene militarily to topple Fidel Castro. Fortunately, no evidence suggests the Administration intends to go that far. Quite the contrary, President Bush recently stated publicly that the United States has no aggressive intentions against Cuba -- one of the reasons, surely, that the Soviets can begin to withdraw their troops.
In other ways, however, the Administration is listening to the hard-liners. Indeed, its Cuba policy seems to be dictated by the ultraconservative Cuban American National Foundation. Does it make any sense, for example, to spend some $20 million a year of taxpayer money for TV Marti to transmit into a black hole? If Cuba is no longer a problem, why should we waste our money? And wasted it is. TV Marti is neither seen nor heard in Cuba. The answer to why we do it is that TV Marti was and is the foundation's baby. The foundation wants it, and so the Administration turns backflips and members of Congress salivate to comply.
The same is true of the amendment sponsored by Senator Connie Mack of Florida, which will again make it unlawful for United States subsidiaries incorporated abroad to trade with Cuba even under carefully delineated conditions. Aside from an initial cost to the Cubans in going over to other suppliers, the amendment will harm the Cubans almost not at all. They will simply turn to the other suppliers. But it will cause us tremendous problems with such countries as Canada, which rightly sees the amendment as nothing less than a demand for extraterritoriality.
Why do it then? So that the Florida Congressional delegation, joined by most of their colleagues from the other 49 states, can pander to the foundation. Never mind that it harms the national interest; it lets our lawmakers strike anti-Communist postures. It is a habit of which they apparently cannot break themselves even in this post-cold-war world.
Finally, given that Cuba is no longer a significant problem, would it make any sense to make the suspension of Soviet-Cuban trade a precondition to an expanded relationship with the new Soviet Union? (And despite the Administration's talk of billions in continuing Soviet aid, Moscow and Havana have for some time been conducting their trade largely on a commercial basis; Mr. Gorbachev's statement of Sept. 9 simply reaffirms that economic ties will move increasingly in that direction.)
Relations with the Soviet Union (or Russia) are of fundamental importance to the United States; the Cuban issue is a minor irritant. Making the second hostage to the first at this crucial moment in history would be irresponsible.
 
WAYNE S. SMITH
Director of Cuban Studies
Johns Hopkins School
of Advanced International Studies
Washington, Sept. 13, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Memo Shows Gates Sought Big Anti-Sandinista Effort

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
In a 1984 memorandum, Robert M. Gates, who was then Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, proposed an extensive American campaign to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, including bombing raids on Nicaraguan military targets.
"These are hard measures," Mr. Gates wrote in the memo, which condemned even President Ronald Reagan's efforts in behalf of the Nicaraguan resistance as "half measures, half-heartedly applied." 
 "They are probably politically unacceptable," Mr. Gates said, "but it is time to stop fooling ourselves about what is going to happen in Central America."
He predicted that Nicaragua would become "another Cuba," fostering Soviet expansion, and that Washington would have failed again to prevent the spread of Communism, as he said had happened in Vietnam.
 
Memo Addressed to Casey
 The memo of Dec. 14, 1984, was written to William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence. It was released today by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, during the hearings on Mr. Gates's nomination to the post held by the late Mr. Casey.
Mr. Gates was not asked publicly about the memo today and it was not clear what his motives were; he may have been intending to be deliberately provocative in an effort to open the debate on Nicaragua policy that he said was lacking. Mr. Gates advocated overt actions, not secret ones, and did not recommend circumventing the Congressional ban on American aid to the contras fighting the Sandinista government.
But his analysis and his proposals went further than Mr. Casey himself and underscored Mr. Gates's hard-line views on Soviet expanionism, which some of his Senate critics say led to his more recent conclusion that the changes in the Soviet Union were not genuine and lasting.
The memo also strikes at questions raised by some Democratic senators about whether Mr. Gates, as the senior official in charge of intelligence analysis, stepped outside that role and crossed the line between providing neutral analysis and advocating policy positions.
 
'I am Quite Surprised'
 After Mr. Metzenbuam read out portions of the memo at today's hearing, John McMahon, Mr. Gates's predecessor as Deputy Director for Intelligence, said: "I am quite surprised by what you read and I don't know what prompted Bob to do that."
In the memo, Mr. Gates concluded, "The contras, even with American support, cannot overthrow the Sandinistas."
"The truth of the matter is that our policy has been to muddle along in Nicaragua with an essentially half-hearted policy because there is no agreement within the Administration or with the Congress on our real objectives," Mr. Gates said.
Mr. Gates said Washington should move beyond its then-stated goal of halting the arms flow to the leftist rebels in El Salvador and work overtly to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, doing "everything in its power short of invasion to put that regime out."
He said this should include four measures:
*Withdrawing United States recognition of the Nicaraguan Government in favor of a government in exile.
*"Overt provision to the government in exile of military assistance, funds, propaganda support and so forth."
*Economic sanctions that could include a quarantine, "combined with internal measures by the resistance to maximize the economic dislocation to the regime," an apparent reference to a campaign of sabotage.
*"Politically the most difficult of all, the use of air strikes to destroy a considerable portion of Nicaragua's military buildup (focusing primarily on the tanks and the helicopters)."
"If we have decided totally to abandon the Monroe Doctrine, if in the 1980's taking strong actions to protect our interests despite the hail of criticism is too difficult," Mr. Gates wrote, "then we ought to save political capital in Washington, acknowledge our helplessness and stop wasting everybody's time."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Decline While Gold Has Mixed Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar, weighed down by interest rate concerns, continued its slide against the major foreign currencies yesterday.
Gold prices were mixed, rising in New York after falling overseas. 
 Analysts said the dollar was hurt by statements by a German official that interest rates in his country will remain at their high levels.
The official, Wilhelm Nolling, president of the state central bank of Hamburg, also said rates could go higher if labor unions received wage increases in their next contract negotiations.
Mr. Nolling's comments lifted the mark and helped take a further toll on the dollar, which has been falling recently along with United States interest rates.
The dollar, like all currencies, draws support from higher rates, which increase foreign demand for American investments. So as rates drop in this country or rise overseas, the dollar tends to slide.
The Federal Reserve's decision a week ago to lower its discount rate half a percentage point, to 5 percent, has taken a heavy toll on the dollar. An article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, which said the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates further to stimulate growth in the money supply, did not augur well for the dollar.
The dollar fell to 1.6845 German marks in New York, from 1.6885 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6850 marks from 1.6892.
Overseas traders said the absence of any fresh economic news and the approach of a holiday in Japan on Monday kept activity light. Many traders in New York and other foreign exchange centers were squaring their positions in advance of the weekend.
The dollar fell to 134.15 Japanese yen in New York from late Thursday's 134.40. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 134.72 yen, up 0.32 yen, and in later London trading, it was quoted at 134.25 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.7315, from $1.7300 late Thursday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7290 from $1.7280.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.46985 Swiss francs, down from 1.4755; 5.7395 French francs, down from 5.7525; 1,260.00 Italian lire, down from 1,264.00, and 1.13445 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13525.
Gold prices edged higher in New York after falling overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange, gold picked up 20 cents and closed at $348.50 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $348.30, up 5 cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Tops $1.10 a Pound For First Time in 5 Months

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices topped $1.10 a pound for the first time in five months yesterday as industrial users scrambled to lock in supplies.
Copper for delivery in September rose 3.10 cents, to $1.101 a pound, on New York's Commodity exchange. It was the highest settlement of a near-term copper contract since April 19. 
 Analysts said United States copper users were seeking to rebuild their stocks after letting them drop during the recession, but most available supplies are not conveniently situated.
The situation has aroused speculation that some industrial users will take delivery of copper through the September futures contract, which expires next Thursday. The price of September deliveries has risen about 10 percent in the last month.
The market's strong tone is strictly "a near-term phenomenon," said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.
"Once the pipelines are filled and the cash metal moves to market, we'll probably see some renewed selling," he said.
But William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures, saw the possibility of a longer-term rally as a result of expected declines in copper exports from the Soviet Union and Zaire and firming demand in Europe, North America and the Far East.
Grain and soybean futures prices dropped on the Chicago Board of Trade after a whipsaw session in the soybean market linked to uncertainty over the extent of frost damage in Iowa and Minnesota.
Wheat for delivery in December settled 3 1/2 cents lower at $3.30 1/2 a bushel; December corn fell 3 1/2 cents, to $2.50 a bushel; December oats were unchanged at $1.29 1/2 a bushel, and November soybeans fell 4 1/2 cents, to $5.99 a bushel.
Live cattle futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in profit taking after Thursday's strong gains. Feeder cattle and hog futures ended mixed but pork bellies plunged in a late round of pre-weekend profit taking.
Live cattle for October delivery finished 0.30 cent lower at 73.37 cents a pound; September feeder cattle rose 0.03 cent, to 86.40 cents a pound; October live hogs fell 0.28 cent lower, to 46.57 cents a pound, and February frozen pork bellies dropped 1.65 cents, to 49.47 cents a pound.
Most energy futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange, helped by news that shipments of Soviet petroleum products from Odessa had been halted and on word that Brazilian oil workers will continue an 11-day old strike despite a court ruling that it is illegal.
Light sweet crude oil for October delivery rose 21 cents, to $21.97 a barrel; October heating oil ended 0.65 cent higher at 62.50 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline fell 0.09 cent, to 60.90 cents a gallon, and October natural gas rose 7.2 cents, to $1.742 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: BTR Bids $2.55 Billion for Hawker Siddeley

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
In the third major takeover bid in Britain in five days, BTR P.L.C, an industrial conglomerate, offered about $2.55 billion today for the Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C., a diversified industrial manufacturer.
Hawker Siddeley's board said it would fight the bid. The businesses of the company, whose sales totaled $4.2 billion last year, include electric motors and power equipment, instruments and controls, batteries, rail and industrial goods, and servicing aircraft engines. 
 Analysts said the unsolicited bid confirmed their view that the takeover market in Britain, which had been moribund since the end of 1989, was coming back to life. "We will not necessarily go back to the boom of 1989, but we will see a slow upsurge in large bids," said Philip Healey, the editor and publisher of Acquisitions Monthly, a British magazine.
The analysts cited several reasons that the takeover boomlet was occurring now -- falling interest rates and a rising stock market, which make it easier to finance acquisitions; the economic recovery in the United States, a large market for many British companies, and the widening belief that the British recession has bottomed out.
"The takeovers tell you that corporate U.K. is fairly confident about the prospects for a recovery," said Michael Armitage, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The BTR bid follows two others by industrial conglomerates: Williams Holdings' $1.2 billion hostile bid for Racal Electronics, an electronics and security company that is expected to be only marginally profitable in its current fiscal year, and Hanson P.L.C.'s $606 million friendly bid for Beazer P.L.C., the troubled construction and building materials company.
Hanson, Williams and BTR all have reputations as shrewd buyers of industrial companies. They typically have not overpaid and have succeeded in improving the profitability of the parts of the acquisitions they have kept by exercising tight management.
In the last three weeks, 11 bids have been made for publicly held British companies, with a total value of more than 3.1 billion, or about $5.35 billion, Mr. Healey said. That compares with a total in the first eight months of the year of 2.8 billion. The 11 include BTR's friendly $34 million bid for Rockware Glass Ltd., a British glass and packaging manufacturer, and American Brands' hostile $494 million bid for Invergordon, a whisky distiller.
Analysts also see as potential takeover targets: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the big food and drinks companies that might interest other food giants; the Asda Group P.L.C., a British supermarket concern with dismal profit margins; Pilkington Glass Ltd., the glass manufacturer, and Amec, a construction company, which would both profit from an economic upturn.
"Many people are looking around for cyclical companies that would benefit from an upturn and whose profit margins are not so great and could be improved," said Philip J. Wolstencroft, an equities strategist at Smith New Court Securities Ltd.
 
Reasons for Bidding
 In bidding for Hawker Siddeley, BTR's chairman, Sir Owen Green, said he thought his target, whose profits have been falling in recent years, could do better under BTR. "Hawker Siddeley shareholders have endured their company's underperformance for a decade," he said.
But Hawker Siddeley said its management was in the middle of a program to improve profitability by cutting costs and fine-tuning its businss mix. The analysts said both assertions had some validity.
In trading on the London International Stock Exchange today, Hawker Siddeley's shares rose by 1.18, or about $2.04, to 7.58, or $13.08. That inidcates investors think a higher bid will come from BTR or someone else: BTR offered Hawker Siddeley shareholders a package of cash and BTR shares that it valued at 7.41, but which was worth 7.27 based on BTR's closing price today, or 7 in cash.
In London, BTR's shares closed at 4.10, or $7.07, off 13 pence, or 22 cents.
