HEADLINE: A Look at the New South Africa

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN; CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is the Johannesburg bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
THERE is a country of sunshine, sandy beaches, verdant mountains, flaming sunsets and star-blanketed night skies, a land of friendly people and exotic wildlife as marvelously diverse as Creation itself. It is a place where the dollar stretches twice or three times as far as it does on Cape Cod or in the Bahamas, where a good dinner can cost less than $20, a bottle of vintage wine $5 and an air-conditioned B.M.W. sedan rents for hardly more than a Volkswagen at other vacation destinations.
Before you rush to book a trip, there is one more detail you need to know -- the place is South Africa. 
 So many visitors have remarked on the landscape of South Africa that the late writer Alan Paton used their response as the title for his novel, "Ah, but Your Land Is Beautiful!" Beautiful, undeniably, but for years avoided by all but a handful of American tourists because of a system that legislated the worth of its citizens according to the color of their skin. The affront to human dignity created by apartheid drastically reduced South Africa's desirability as a vacation destination; tourists want to believe the best of the places they pay to see.
"I believe that without apartheid, South Africa would be much farther down the road than it is," said Spencer Thomas, the executive director of the South African Tourism Board in Pretoria.
With the dismantling of apartheid undertaken by President F. W. de Klerk, South Africa is getting second looks from travel agents as an enticing and little-known destination. Only the sporadic outbreaks of violence in the segregated black townships, removed from the tourist centers, continue to undermine its appeal.
President de Klerk's reforms have gone far toward eliminating the problems of marketing South Africa to tourists. "We've received several inquiries from investors saying, 'We believe tourism has a great future in South Africa. Tell us how to get involved,' " Mr. Thomas said, though he declined to identify the investors.
Most tourists will travel for the scenery and wildlife. Many Americans have heard of luxury resorts like Mala Mala near Kruger National Park, in the eastern Transvaal, but cheaper outdoor adventures abound, like the trail walk through the Umfolozi wilderness reserve in northern Natal to view the rhinoceroses, lions and other game. The three-day walk, run by the Natal Parks Board, currently costs 400 rand, about $140, including food, shelter and armed guides -- and, not suprisingly, it has a six-month waiting list. There are tent safaris in other national parks, rafting or kayak excursions on the Orange or Tugela Rivers and hikes in the Drakensburg, a mountain range in southwestern Natal, whose windswept peaks reach 10,000 feet. For those who prefer to laze on a beach, Plettenberg Bay, Cape Province, offers South Africa's answer to St. Tropez, where the local jet set go to winter.
For American tourists, the political stigma is no longer the main barrier to a visit, but rather the distance to be traveled and the cost. At present, there are no direct flights to Johannesburg from the United States. The journey from New York requires two overnight flights and a day between them sitting in some European airport. Although the trip is less strenuous with a stopover in London, Paris or Lisbon, Mr. Thomas said most overseas visitors want a direct flight.
Direct flights seem inevitable once South African Airways and a reciprocal United States carrier, yet to be named, renegotiate the landing rights abrogated in 1986 when the United States Congress imposed a sanctions package. The sanctions were repealed in July this year. Austrian Airlines, China Airlines in Taiwan and Cathay Pacific in Hong Kong have recently inaugurated regular flights to South Africa.
The full fare for what adds up to 20 hours of flying from New York is expensive -- currently $2,353 one way from New York -- though excursion rates can bring the round-trip price down to $2,100. Once in South Africa, the tourist will find that the rand, now worth less than 36 cents, will buy in Johannesburg's hotels, restaurants and shops what a dollar buys in the United States. The rand is weak against the dollar -- presently about 2.86 to $1; some years ago the rand was worth $2.
Not everyone has avoided South Africa and its relatively low prices. According to the Government statistics, over a million foreigners visited in 1990, although many were not ordinary tourists. They generated nearly $1 billion in foreign exchange earnings and supported 300,000 local jobs. Over half of these visitors came from neighboring African countries, including 255,998 from Zimbabwe, crossing the border to shop or see relatives. Other foreigners came on business. Fedhasa, an organization representing the South African hotel, restaurant and beverage industries, regards only about a quarter of the foreign visitors as conventional tourists.
"The true tourists are where we see the greatest expansion," said Peter Hearfield, the executive director of Fedhasa, estimating that their number could quadruple to one million in three years. The Government is studying how to sell South Africa as part of a regional destination that would include Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia.
Americans accounted for 47,425 visitors in 1990, or nearly 11,000 fewer than in 1985, before the sanctions. By comparison, 135,404 traveled from Britain, many of them to visit relatives, and 83,443 from Germany. Americans still need a South African visa, and for years every applicant was scrutinized as a potential anti-apartheid agitator; now getting a visa takes two or three weeks.
With 17 African airlines now serving South Africa, Mr. Thomas said, he also anticipated a growth in tourists from other African countries. "They are a very important source of revenue for us," he said. "I think the markets in black Africa have been underestimated in the past."
Many travelers from other continents, of course, will be attracted by winter sunshine. Because South Africa is in the Southern Hemisphere, winter in New York becomes summer in Johannesburg. Summer is hot, with lots of humidity around Durban and showers in the afternoon around Johannesburg. The winter generally is more akin to California's mild weather. Cape Town can be ideal in January and February when Durban, another port city, swelters in the high humidity of the Indian Ocean. Horst Witt, head of Senator Travel Service in Johannesburg, sends his clients on the Garden Route, a lush coastal drive from Port Elizabeth to Cape Town, from October to April, and to Kruger National Park, one of the country's great game reserves, from May to October.
With nearly 92,000 hotel beds nationwide, South Africa offers a sophisticated infrastructure, its telephone system and roads superior to those in almost any other African country. Service is another matter; tourists find it uneven at restaurants, stores, banks and even the state-owned South African Airways. Attentive service is not a tradition and South Africans are not used to catering to tourists. "Presently a service ethic is lacking and standards are perceived to be dropping in most sectors of the industry," said a government study released in June.
However, hotels like the Mount Nelson in Cape Town or the Royal in Durban rank among the world's best in service, luxury and ambiance. Other hotels popular with tourists include the Carlton in Johannesburg, the Cape Sun in Cape Town and the Burgerspark in Pretoria, and there are many first-class, smaller country inns like, for example, the Coach House in Tzaneen in the eastern Transvaal. Holiday Inns is the only major hotel chain so far. Americans are likely to admire the luxury of the Blue Train, which makes the 900-mile trip between Johannesburg and Cape Town and has been compared in its opulence to the old Orient Express. Because of the distance and cost involved in a visit, travel specialists expect South Africa to continue to attract individual tourists rather than group tours.
For all the world attention focused on apartheid, the irony is that a tourist may never see it. Hotels, restaurants, theaters and sports events are integrated in the cities. Johannesburg, with its throngs of black shoppers, looks as unself-conscious in its variety of people as New York. The drab black townships, where the political violence has occurred, have been tucked well out of sight of the tidy white suburbs.
It is possible to see the high spots of South Africa without ever confronting squalid squatter camps fashioned from cast-off shipping crates, corrugated metal and plastic. The apartheid legacy is not something that the Government is eager to market.
Even so, private entrepreneurs run tours to Soweto, the country's largest and most famous township, and the tour guides, who live in Soweto, talk candidly and sometimes angrily about conditions there. The Natal Museum in Pietermaritzburg is one of several museums assembling a permanent exhibition demonstrating what life for the black majority has been like under apartheid. Johannesburg's Market Theater complex (which has drawn racially mixed audiences for years) offers plays by Athol Fugard and other South African playwrights that grapple with the apartheid experience. And South Africans, black and white, seem almost eager to share their thoughts and experiences with visitors.
The Government has committed itself to developing the country as a vacation destination, in part to generate more jobs for blacks. "Travel, tourism and hospitality have a vital role to play in solving many of the socioeconomic problems facing our society in the years ahead," President de Klerk told a Fedhasa meeting in August. However, although the Government has done a study about promoting tourism, it has yet to set aside any funds for that purpose.
The uniqueness of South Africa is characterized in one lovely nature preserve that ends abruptly at the Cape of Good Hope, not quite the southernmost tip of Africa. That distinction belongs to Cape Agulhas, a less dramatic promontory some 65 miles to the east. But from the old lighthouse atop the cliffs at the Cape of Good Hope, one peers into what pre-Columbian navigators supposed was the edge of the world.
Beyond the ragged rocks throwing up towers of sea spray lies a slate blue sea that stretches beyond the horizon toward Antarctica's frozen shores. The sandstone cliffs below are populated with hundreds of Cape cormorants, hardy brown waterfowl with wingspans as formidably sleek as a jetfighter's. Tucked below the headlands between the Cape of Storms and the Cape of Good Hope lies a crescent of bright sand as fine as salt. The rolling dunes give way to the moors, where one passes ostriches and baboons, and sometimes zebra and antelope.
Alan Paton's friends got it right: this land is beautiful.
 
 
 
TOUR AGENCIES REPORT SURGE OF INTEREST FROM CLIENTS
 Tour operators in the United States say that interest in South Africa had increased considerably by the time the United States suspended its economic sanctions against South Africa this summer.
According to the South African Tourism Board, 1990 was the first year that the number of foreign visitors entering South Africa surpassed the one million mark. Of those, 59,503 were from the United States and Canada, compared with 46,058 in 1987 when sanctions were firmly in place.
"When Mandela was released, South Africa was put back on the map," said Jacky Keith, whose Boston-based Esplanade Tours now offers eight South African itineraries. In the nearly two months since the lifting of sanctions, Esplanade and other companies, including Safariworld in New York, which started offering tours to South Africa two years ago, have noted a "tremendous" increase in inquiries.
Many of these inquiries are hedged with a wait-and-see attitude, but if political reforms keep coming, said Gil Zalman, president of Safariworld, "South Africa may become the main tourist attraction in Africa by 1993 or 1994."
People interested in going to South Africa may wish to bear in mind the State Department's travel advisory (July 19, 1991), which cautions that the "political situation in South Africa remains unsettled," and the potential for right-wing, pro-apartheid violence may increase.
The advisory notes that tourist areas, such as game parks and beaches, are unlikely to be affected.
Visas, which can be obtained from the South African Embassy and consulates in the United States are free. At least two weeks, preferably one month, should be allowed for processing.
The South African Tourism Board, 747 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; telephone (212) 838-8841, can provide a list of the more than 20 companies that offer tours from the United States. They include the following:
Abercrombie & Kent International, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521; (800) 323-7308), which suspended all its South African tours when sanctions went into effect five years ago, is resuming them next year.
Discoveries of Southern Africa, a 15-day exploration of South Africa, Zimbabwe and Botswana, combines visits to Johannesburg and Cape Town with game-viewing in Chobe National Park in Botswana and sightseeing at Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe. Prices are not yet available.
Esplanade Tours, 581 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116; (800) 628-4893, offers a 21-day Grand Tour of South Africa, which includes a three-night safari in Kruger National Park, a cultural tour through Swaziland and Zululand, a trip down the scenic Garden Route, which runs along the Indian Ocean between Port Elizabeth and George, and a ride on the luxurious, blue-painted
Blue Train from Cape Town to Johannesburg.
The cost is $5,663, round trip from New York and other East Coast cities. Departures are monthly.

HEADLINE: New Mexico's Mysterious Anasazi Ruins

BYLINE: By DAVID LASKIN; DAVID LASKIN is a frequent visitor to the Southwest.

 BODY:
THE blinding sun searches deep into the crevices of rocks that were hewn, dressed and arranged centuries ago. The patterns and placement of the broken walls stand in perfect harmony with the surrounding land forms. A lizard scurries out, then freezes on a stone that was darkened ages since by the soot of ceremonial fires. If it wasn't for the pinon pines, the scrub juniper and the sheer canyon cliffs, one might almost imagine oneself at some remote Greek ruin hidden away in Thessaly or the Pelopennesus. But this is New Mexico, and these are the ruins of great towns built by the prehistoric Anasazi people.
For 1,000 years, from about A.D. 500 until their dispersal around 1500, the Anasazi, whose name is a Navajo word that means "the ancient ones," lived in pueblos and cliff dwellings built in the canyons and high mesas of the Four Corners region (where Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona and Utah meet). Visitors to northern New Mexico will find no better introduction to the beauty and the enduring mysteries of Anasazi culture than the 34,000-acre Chaco Culture National Historic Park and the 32,000-acre Bandelier National Monument. 
 Chaco, a rather grueling day trip (ending with 20 miles of dirt road) or easy two-day trip from Santa Fe or Albuquerque, was the ancient center of Anasazi civilization and contains the most extensive Indian ruins north of Mexico. Bandelier, less than an hour's drive from Santa Fe, affords a rare opportunity to view Indian ruins in a magnificent setting of mountain, canyon, river valley and pine forest. The Four Corners region contains a number of other important Anasazi ruins, notably Canyon de Chelly National Monument in Arizona, Mesa Verde National Park in Colorado and Hovenweep National Monument in Utah. But Chaco and Bandelier together reflect the full range of Anasazi architecture and design, and their ingenuity in adapting strikingly different terrain to suit their needs. And the drive from one to the other crosses some of the most spectacular scenery in the Southwest.
Ten centuries ago, Chaco was the Rome and the Mecca of Anasazi culture, the spiritual and political capital from which hundreds of miles of roads radiated to outlying pueblos scattered through a region the size of Scotland, the economic hub to which merchants journeyed from as far as Mexico to store and trade beans, corn, copper, pottery, macaws and turquoise. Thirteen separate pueblo villages of as many as 800 connected rooms rose from the floor and rim of the broad, low-walled canyon. Hundreds of people lived and worked here, and no doubt thousands came each year as pilgrims, artisans, traders, perhaps even as tourists.
Yet the first word that comes to mind when you enter Chaco Canyon today is wasteland. From the north, dirt roads approach the canyon through an arid plateau of sagebrush, greasewood, juniper scrub, a few dilapidated Navajo churches, distant glimpses to red mesas. As far as the eye can see there is no escape from the withering desert sun. Time itself seems to fall away as one moves across this forbidding terrain.
Abruptly, a few miles inside the park gate, the road twists and plunges, and one finds oneself in the sheltered, reassuring embrace of a canyon. The sudden descent into this other world is a bit like falling down Alice's rabbit hole, an impression that is enhanced by the sight of strange heaps of stone thrust up like miniature mountain ranges from the canyon floor. On closer inspection, these turn out to be the first of the Chaco ruins.
The main ruins at Chaco are Pueblo Bonito (beautiful town) and Chetro Ketl (a word of unknown origin and meaning), the neighboring towns where Anasazi architecture and workmanship reached their peak. Here is the logical place to begin an exploration.
The aspect of Pueblo Bonito that strikes you most immediately is its monumentality. Shaped like a vast D measuring some 500 feet across, Pueblo Bonito was very likely the largest structure in the Southwest when it was completed in the late 11th century. But the pueblo derives its power from more than size alone. After you have spent some time wandering through the ruins, you come to see that Pueblo Bonito is a carefully and intricately planned city, its form perfectly aligned with the canyon wall behind it and the pattern of its connected chambers as complex and finely articulated as a honeycomb -- but a honeycomb made not of pulp but of sandstone. Like the great Gothic cathedrals of Europe, which were built a short time later, Pueblo Bonito consumed the lives and artistry of generations of workers, yet the overall effect is a grand, hypnotic unity.
Balancing the monumentality of the pueblo's design is the exquisite, almost gemlike fineness of the masonry work. Every wall is sheathed inside and out in a kind of abstract mosaic of flat, smoothly dressed sandstone pieces that shade in tone from salmon to oxblood. Masonry styles changed over the centuries from a rather crude stacking of slatelike fragments to an incredibly beautiful pattern in which a single layer of large rectangular stones alternates with multiple layers of slender chinking stone chips. It comes as something of a shock to learn that the Anasazi covered all of their stunning masonry work with mud plaster.
Chetro Ketl, though roughly contemporary with Pueblo Bonito, differs markedly in design. Shaped rather like a massive E, the pueblo once had a colonnaded gallery that ran for some 90 feet along its front face. Archeologists speculate that this structure, unique in Anasazi buildings, may show the influence of Mexico's Toltec civilization, the forerunner of Aztec culture.
The plazas of both Pueblo Bonito and Chetro Ketl are studded with stone-lined sunken cylindrical structures known as kivas. It is believed that the Anasazi, like their Hopi and Zuni descendants, used kivas as places of worship, ritual and ceremonial gathering. But important questions remain unanswered at Chaco: Why did the pueblos have so many kivas, as many as 40 at Pueblo Bonito alone? How did the so-called great kivas (often measuring more than 60 feet across), differ in use from the smaller kivas? Why, if the kivas served a religious function, were some of them filled with rubble or garbage?
At Pueblo Bonito and Chetro Ketl one must content oneself with peering down into the kivas, but across the canyon at the ruins of Casa Rinconada, the great kiva -- the largest one at Chaco with a diameter of 63 1/2 feet -- has been partly restored and opened to the public. Shorn of the flat timbered roof that once rested on immense pillars of ponderosa pine, its stone fireboxes cold and bare, its ceremonies of smoke and drums and flickering light fallen silent long ago, the great kiva now inscribes a perfect circle in the desert sky, strangely reminiscent of the oculus in the dome of Rome's Pantheon.
After the intensity, the harsh grandeur and the desolate magnificence of Chaco, the serenity of Bandelier comes as a blessed relief. Situated at 6,000 to nearly 7,000 feet and surrounded by the rounded blue humps of the Jemez Mountains, Bandelier has the hushed, sheltered aura of a secret enclave, a "literal paradise . . . a walled garden," as the art historian Vincent Scully called it. The ever-flowing Rito de los Frijoles (bean creek) runs along the canyon floor, supporting a ribbon of delicate green in the center of the canyon. Stands of mature ponderosa pine climb the brown slopes, their high branches casting patches of precious shade. Meadows of tall rustling grasses run right up to the foot of pink tuff cliffs that are as pocked and pitted as Swiss cheese. The holes in the stone are the result of the erosion of pockets of gases that were trapped in the volcanic ash that settled over the region a million years ago.
To travel from Chaco to the ruins at Bandelier is to move from the center of a civilization to an outpost, from the pinnacle to the decline. Though Bandelier's pueblos, cliff dwellings and kivas date from a later period than those at Chaco, they are inferior in workmanship, design, scale and technology, reflecting the general decline of Anasazi culture after the break-up of the Chacoan system in the late 12th century. For the casual visitor to Bandelier, however, there is ample compensation for the quality of the ruins in the beauty of the setting.
Most visitors to the national monument stick to the easy mile-long loop trail that circulates through the main ruins, leading from the visitor center up into the canyon wall and back along the river. The first ruin one encounters is Tyuonyi (chew-OHN-yee), the dominant village at Bandelier, which once had 400 rooms arranged in a ring around a central plaza. The pueblo's ring pattern is still just discernible, but time has worn the soft tuff walls down to mere waist-high stumps.
Past Tyuonyi, the trail climbs up into the north side of Frijoles Canyon, and ladders propped up against the canyon wall ascend to rooms that Anasazi scooped out of the pink tuff. In peak summer season, small groups gather at the bases of the ladders to wait for a turn. The ruins trail continues to the Long House, a series of attached apartments and storerooms that runs for 800 feet along the base of the canyon wall.
Though Bandelier attracts more people than Chaco (300,000 visitors a year compared with 90,000), it also affords more opportunities to escape them. Unlike Chaco, Bandelier is a hiker's park, with more than 70 miles of trails in its its 50 square miles.
The easiest trail is the half-mile hike along the shaded banks of the Rito de los Frijoles to the Ceremonial Cave, an isolated cluster of apartments and kivas built high up in the canyon wall under an overhanging lip of rock. You make the literally breathtaking ascent to the semicircular cave via four ladders that rise a total of 140 feet up the canyon face (prominent signs warn off those with heart problems or fear of heights). The small kiva sunk into the rock has been completely reconstructed and roofed over, and you can lower yourself into it on a ladder just as the Anasazi did. You truly feel reborn when you rise from this stone womb into an almost perfect hemisphere of sky, mountain, pine and rock framed by the pink tuff lip of the overhang.
Even more rewarding and challenging is the six-mile hike to the ruins of Yapashi Pueblo and its shrine of the stone lions. Centuries of weather have eroded the pair of crouching mountain lions to hardly more than humps of stone. Yet the remote shrine remains sacred to the Pueblo Indians, who walk as far as 400 miles to leave offerings of deer antlers or eagle feathers inside the ring of boulders encircling the lions. Without the delicate green cottonwoods and the sheltering walls of Frijoles Canyon, Yapashi is open the winds that blow clean and dry through the desert.
Hiking through the back country of Bandelier, sitting in the great kiva of Casa Rinconada or standing in the dark stone cube of a perfectly preserved room at Pueblo Bonito, one feels that the Anasazi -- the ancient ones -- are close, very close beside one. And something of that sensation persists even after the return to "civilization." The flat-roofed adobe dwellings, the geometric designs of Pueblo Indian pottery, the intricate beadwork of turquoise jewelry, perhaps most of all the deep reverence for the forms of the land: all of these are part of the heritage of the Anasazi. The beauty of northern New Mexico is, one realizes, a beauty that the Anasazi both understood and helped to create.
 
 
 
VISITOR'S GUIDE TO THE PARKS
Chaco
 Chaco Culture National Historic Park is a three- to four-hour drive from Albuquerque or Santa Fe, with the last 20 or so miles on dirt roads. The most direct route is to pick up Route 44 off I-25 at Bernalillo and drive west to the turnoff to the park at Nageezi. A far more scenic approach from Santa Fe is to take Route 84 through Abiquiu (Georgia O'Keeffe's home) and to pick up Route 96 (west) at Abiquiu Dam and take this to Route 44. Dirt roads may be impassable in bad weather.
For information and road conditions, contact Chaco Culture National Historic Park, Star Route 4, Box 6500, Bloomfield, N.M. 87413; telephone (505) 988-6727.
Admission to the park is $3 per vehicle. The ruins are open year round, from sunrise to sunset, although the visitor center is closed on Christmas. The ranger-staffed visitor center has toilets, drinking water, a small museum and a bookstore, and there is a campground a mile away. Ranger-led tours and talks are offered as staffing permits. No food or gas is available. Fill up your tank at Nageezi before you set out and make sure you have plenty of fluids and a hat during hot weather.
The only lodging near the park is a small, spotlessly clean bed and breakfast next to the trading post at Nageezi, The Inn at the Post, Nageezi, N.M. 87037; (505) 632-3646. The cost is about $50 for a double and full breakfast. For dinner, there is a fully equipped kitchen open to guests (rudimentary provisions are available at the trading post).
 
Bandelier
 Bandelier National Monument is 46 miles west of Santa Fe on paved, scenic, clearly marked highways. Take U.S. 285 north to Pojoaque, then pick up 502 west and Route 4 south to the park gate.
Admission to the park is $5 per vehicle. The ruins are open year-round (the visitor center is closed on Christmas), 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. in summer, 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. in winter. The visitor center has toilets, drinking water, a bookstore, a small museum, a gift shop and snack bar. Frequent ranger-led tours depart from the visitor center, and there are other special programs and talks during the summer. The park runs two campgrounds and a picnic area.
For more information and for camping reservations, contact Superintendent, Bandelier National Monument, Los Alamos, N.M. 87544; (505) 672-3861.
There is a variety of accommodations and restaurants 10 miles away in Los Alamos, and even more in Santa Fe.

HEADLINE: Dual-Fuel Setups

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your story on Aug. 25, "Flipping Between Gas and Oil," was particularly relevant to consumers since it effectively highlighted many benefits of upgrading to dual-fuel systems in large apartment buildings. However, the article had a serious omission. Very often, the first step in the process is free. 
 Of special interest to your readers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, the area serviced by Brooklyn Union Gas, is our free customized "Energy Cost Comparison Report" for individual apartment-house owners and managing agents. The report gives fair, reliable estimates of savings and is helpful to apartment-house owners in obtaining low-interest loans through the "Energy Investment Loan Program" sponsored by New York State. The free service is also available to potential cogeneration users.
We also recommend to potential dual-fuel users independent contractors to handle technical assistance, and cost estimates for the installation. This service also is free.
Utility requirements for dual-fuel rates vary greatly. For example, we provide gas service to apartment buildings with as few as 16 units, while other companies do not. I strongly recommend that potential dual-fuel users contact their local utility to find out how to make the conversion process as economical as possible.
 
JOE ROTH
 
The writer is Senior Staff Engineer Account Management Services for Brooklyn Union Gas.

HEADLINE: Talking: Foreclosure;
Protecting Tenants' Interests

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
DURING the 1980's it became increasingly common to buy condominium units and one-family houses as investments and rent them to tenants to cover monthly carrying costs while waiting for the property to appreciate.
Often, the rent was below monthly overhead, which was not a drawback while the investor was still making money from other ventures and values were soaring. But with the slump in the economy and a decline in property values a growing number of small investors are becoming delinquent in their mortage payments, bankers report. 
 Can tenants safely assume they can stay on even if the unit goes to foreclosure? Who will pay for repairs or the water or fuel bill while things are being sorted out? And is the security deposit in jeopardy?
First, it is important to separate rent-regulated tenants or those renting from a professional landlord in a large rental building from those who are renting on the unregulated market from a private individual. The former should be protected, or at least insulated, from the owner's financial problems.
It is those in private arrangements who are in a tenuous position. Lawyers warn that no matter what protection they might think they have because they signed a lease, they may have to move out fast. "The lease is no protection," said Philip T. Aaron, a lawyer in Syosset, L.I., who specializes in representing lenders in foreclosure proceedings. Moreover, despite strict consumer laws regarding the safekeeping of security deposits, the tenants may never see those funds again.
However, if the tenants play their cards carefully they can lessen the financial drain and negotiate the chance to stay on, at least for a while. A handful of such tenants, among them one in Syosset, L.I., who had been renting a house being repossessed by the Dime Savings Bank of New York this spring, even seized the initiative and put in a bid to buy the house.
Any hint of impending trouble often starts with a seemingly inexplicable personality change by the owner. "He becomes less and less responsive to your needs," said Terence Beaty, director of special services for William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford, Conn. A few, terrified of losing the income stream, may become overly soliticious, he said.
"The first we knew about it was when the president of the condo association knocked on our door and told us that the owner hadn't paid his common charges for six months," said Jennifer Calderwood, a graphic designer in New York City who suffered through the ordeal last year while renting a three-bedroom condominum in Stamford, Conn.
Official notification normally comes when foreclosure proceedings begin. This is because the tenant is often named in any foreclosure action along with the owner. Richard Liebman, a lawyer in Rockville Centre, L.I., specializing in bankruptcies, explained that the tenants are normally named to facilitate a rapid eviction after the foreclosure action has been completed.
If the owner opts at this point for "deed in lieu" -- a method whereby he or she voluntarily hands over title to the lender rather than suffer through a lengthy foreclosure proceeding -- matters could speed up rapidly. Within weeks the property could be owned by the lender, who normally is eager to get the tenant out fast to spiff up the place for speedy resale, said Mr. Beaty.
Requiring the tenant to leave is legal, said Goldie Rotenberg, a real estate lawyer in Manhattan, because the lease is normally subordinate to the rights of the first mortgage holder. Even if the owner tries to sidestep foreclosure by declaring bankruptcy, she added, the lease will still be extinguished because liquidating that asset becomes a priority need of creditors such as the lender.
EXPERTS therefore suggest the tenant contact the lender fast to negotiate for both time and terms. "It's not unusual to get calls from the tenants," said Roger Williams, manager of asset recovery for the Dime Savings Bank of New York.
Sometimes the lender can be persuaded to give the tenant a cash incentive to leave immedately because eviction proceedings can take six months. Known as "cash for keys" or a "surrender allowance," it provides the equivalent of one or two months' rent in exchange for vacating the premises rapidly.
Although most lenders do not want to become landlords, some may be willing to make an interim arrangement if the market for the property is particularly soft. "It gives us an income stream while we're preparing for a sale," said George Petropulos, vice president for real estate investment at Peoples Bank of Connecticut.
A similar extension might also be granted by a court, said Mr. Aaron. If the tenant is willing to appear at the eviction proceedings and explain why he needs more time -- such as a chance for his children to finish the school year -- it could be granted.
The lender may not even charge rent for the interim months. "We don't charge because we don't want to be considered a landlord," said Mr. Williams of the Dime. "The liability is too great. Tenants see us as having deep pockets."
Moreover, most lenders do not want to be responsible for maintenance. But if the tenancy is going to be long-term -- perhaps because the lender thinks the property might be sold more easily with a good tenant in place -- such an attitude will not apply. Instead, a new lease may be drawn.
These experts admit that most tenants do not continue paying rent once they know their landlord is headed for financial shoals. "We only had two months left on our lease," explained Ms. Calderwood, "and refusing to pay was the only practical way we could recoup some of the $4,000 he was holding as a security deposit." Suing the owner would have cost too much, she said. Moreover, the lender was under no obligation to make good.
"If we never had the deposit," said Mr. Williams, "we can't be expected to pay it."
Of course, the tenant can fight the owner for the refund in Small Claims Court or contact the Attorney General's office. But the escrow account set up for the deposit (if there ever was one), say these experts, has often been cleaned out by the owner by then.
Any tenant who is uneasy about witholding rent should set up a separate account and deposit the rent until matters are cleared up, said Mr. Liebman. This account can meanwhile be drawn upon to pay vendors or for emergency repairs since it is unlikely that either the owner or lender will pay these bills.

LENGTH: 1431 words

HEADLINE: To Mixed Reviews, Education Chief Leaves the Stage

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
THE state's Education Commissioner, Gerald N. Tirozzi, is collecting a lot of plaudits these days. He has received commendations from the State Board of Education, the Connecticut Education Association and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s office, among others. But these are not the only mementoes Dr. Tirozzi will be taking with him as he leaves his post to assume the presidency of Wheelock College in Boston on Oct. 1.
Hanging from his office walls are numerous framed newspaper and magazine articles published during his eight-year tenure as chief of the State Education Department. One, published in The Hartford Courant's magazine in March 1988 under the headline "How Dare He?," chronicles the firestorm of controversy, including calls for his resignation, elicited by Dr. Tirozzi's call for greater racial integration of schools. "Gerry was constantly out being a very strong advocate for education," said State Rep. Nancy Wyman, a Tolland Democrat who is co-chairwoman of the General Assembly's Education Commission. "We were fortunate to have Gerry with us, and we are unfortunate to have him leave." 
 But that assessment is not universal. "I say good riddance," said Tom Scott of Milford, who served as a Republican legislator during the 1980's and now heads the Connecticut Taxpayers Committee. "He was incredibly out of touch with the needs of middle-income families in Connecticut who needed to rely on the school system. He's one of these social experimenters who has his head and mind into the stratosphere somewhere, trying to manipulate the youth of America to suit his own ideology."
Generating strong reactions is not unusual for Commissioner Tirozzi. Even the timing of his departure has elicited some speculation that he is leaving because he senses tougher political times ahead with the arrival of the Weicker administration. Such speculation makes the Commissioner bristle.
"I know there are some who think I'm running away," he said. "To them I'd like to say, 'I said I wanted to be a college president, and that's what I'm doing.' "
The state Board of Education has begun to search for a replacement for Dr. Tirozzi. Until a successor is appointed, Marilyn A. Campbell, who served as an acting deputy commissioner, has been named Acting Education Commissioner.
Dr. Tirozzi, 54 years old, began his career in New Haven, where he grew up. Young Gerald, whose father drove a beer truck, was urged by his school counselor to prepare for a factory job, but he went on instead to earn a doctorate from Michigan State University. He became a teacher in 1959, then rose through the administrative ranks to become New Haven's School Superintendent in 1977.
 
Second-Highest Teacher Salaries
 In 1983, on the day he was appointed Commissioner, the Federal Government released "A Nation at Risk," a stinging indictment of the nation's schools. Dr. Tirozzi seized the opportunity to help shape a broad package of reforms that earned national recognition.
During his administration state spending for education rose to $1.3 billion in 1991-92 from $685 million in 1984-85. The state's average teacher salaries have become the second highest in the nation, after Alaska's. The average teacher's salary in Connecticut is $44,736, compared to $29,437 in 1986. The average beginning salary is now $25,312, compared to $17,013 before the Education Enhancement Act, a state law passed at the Commissioner's urging in 1986. Among its provisions, the law provided additional state funds to districts that increased teacher salaries.
Dr. Tirozzi supported the creation of a broad program to raise standards for teachers, with beginners required to pass tests in their specialties and participate in training and assessment programs. Students, too, have been assessed through a program of mastery tests, which gauge their proficiency in the fourth, six, and eighth grades.
These changes are his legacy, the Commissioner said. "I think reforming teaching, dealing with salaries, dealing with rigorous standards, to me, were significant accomplishments," Dr. Tirozzi added.
Such improvements have helped allay fears of a teacher shortage, he said in a recent interview. He noted that Granby recently had more than 1,500 applicants for eight jobs. "In the early 80's you could hardly find a person who wanted to teach in a small rural district," Dr. Tirozzi said. He is also proud that some of Connecticut's highest teacher salaries are now being paid in the cities, he said.
But during the past few years angry taxpayers in numerous districts, citing high teacher salaries, have caused school systems to slash their budgets. As a result hundreds of the state's newly trained teachers face layoffs. And the state's allocations for some of the new teacher-training programs are also being reduced. Experienced teachers who were paid to be mentors to newcomers are now asked to volunteer their time instead.
But Dr. Tirozzi said he did not believe that the programs his administration created would fall by the wayside.
"I won't accept the scenario the sky is falling on education in Connecticut," he said. "It's not. My sense is that because we've laid a very strong foundation, that is so comprehensive and coordinated, it will be very hard to put chinks in its armor."
Commissioner Tirozzi is closely identified with the issue of school integration. In 1988 he infuriated many people by releasing a report that outlined the racial isolation in the state's school districts. As a result, many critics, including Mr. Scott, then a state senator, called for Dr. Tirozzi's resignation.
But he weathered the political storm and has encouraged the implementation of voluntary programs designed to promote integration, including those that encourage youngsters to cross school-district lines voluntarily, like a magnet school being built in Bridgeport. For the past several summers, a successful program has brought suburban youngsters into the Hartford schools.
"Dr. Tirozzi acted as catalyst," said Mark Waxenberg, president of the 30,000-member Connecticut Education Association, the teachers union. "I think that was his major contribution."
 
Inspired a Lawsuit
 The Commissioner "believed, and he still believes, each child is entitled to an equal education," Mr. Waxenberg said. "He stuck with it when it was not advantageous to do so. And I have to admire him for that."
John C. Brittain, a professor of law at the University of Connecticut credits Dr. Tirozzi with inspiring him to file a lawsuit, now pending, attempting to force school integration in Connecticut. Mr. Brittain called Dr. Tirozzi "courageous" for tackling the issue.
"Gerry Tirozzi definitely pricked the conscience of the state of Connecticut with respect to racial, economic and educational segregation between urban and suburban school districts," Mr. Brittain said.
But he said the Commissioner has recently backed away from the desegregation issue, a charge Dr. Tirozzi flatly denied.
"I'm not Superman," he said. "If someone thought any commissioner could solve this issue, I think that's unrealistic. I think my goal was to make sure Connecticut citizens were aware of the problem and couldn't walk away from it."
Mr. Scott said he blamed the Commissioner for the state's fiscal woes, which culminated in the recent passage of a state income tax.
"The state went overboard in salaries in terms that taxpayers, parents and students got nothing in return," Mr. Scott said. "Our property taxes are going up, our state taxes are going up, and we didn't get anything for it. Education hasn't improved."
 
'We Have Laid a Foundation'
 But Dr. Tirozzi maintains that the performance of youngsters will improve eventually, and that many people are too impatient for change.
"I think the kind of systemic change we're looking for is broad, systemic change," he said. "And I think that, based on what we have accomplished during my tenure, I am totally confident that we have laid a foundation upon which you can build."
Dr. Tirozzi said he regrets that he will not be able to implement a comprehensive early childhood education program for the state. He noted, however, that Wheelock College is strongly committed to training teachers to educate young children.
"My sense is this decade you will see a major educational policy shift toward the care and education of young children," he said. "This will be a platform to use the presidency of that college to impact on the national discourse on the care and education on young children. I want to be a part of that."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
New Hope for Bridgeport Housing Project

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
REDEVELOPMENT of Father Panik Village, one of Connecticut's oldest, largest and most notorious public housing projects, is under way in Bridgeport.
The hope is to produce a mix of private and public housing free of the problems that have given the project the reputation of being the city's most dangerous area. 
 The plan reflects the effort of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to limit public housing in any single area and to require sites where there are not already large concentrations of poor minority residents. That stipulation frequently sets off a "not in my backyard" reaction when new sites are sought.
In the case of Father Panik Village, H.U.D. has imposed a special restriction: The department's funds may not be released for construction of public housing until private developers produce nonpublic housing on the site.
"We want assurance of mixed-use development, not another large concentration of public housing," said Robert S. Donovan, deputy manager of the department's Hartford office. "It is H.U.D.'s intention to avert another Father Panik Village."
The project, bordering the Yellow Channel of the Pequonnock River, acquired its notoriety when drugs infiltrated Bridgeport in the 70's. By the mid-80's, it was among the most troubled districts in the state. With 1,400 apartments of 2 to 6 bedrooms in 48 buildings, it was unmanageable.
To reduce density, four buildings were torn down, but that only created a long windowless alley that fostered 24-hour traffic in drugs and guns.
At least 10 people have been killed in the project in the last five years alone, said Lieut. David Boston of the Bridgeport Police Department. An additional 29 severely vandalized buildings were demolished between 1987 and 1990.
Because the area has a large concentration of the poor and minorities, the Housing Authority can allow only 25 percent of new public housing, or 110 units, on the site. An additional 440 units permitted under zoning will be market rate. The authority is now faced with the daunting task of turning the 40-acre wasteland into an attractive complex with shops, offices and parkland.
"Our major concern is getting private investors interested, and, eventually, market-rate buyers and renters," said Clarence H. Craig Jr., the Housing Authority's executive director. "Given the history of the place it won't be easy."
Mr. Donovan believes H.U.D. might bend its special restriction for the first 20 units of public housing, for which competitive plans have been submitted to the Housing Authority by three architects: Zane Yost of Bridgeport, Leslie Feder of Manhattan and Wendell Harp of New Haven. "The way Mr. Craig described the project informally," Mr. Donovan said, "with no land cost, on a corner facing a thriving community center and a successful low-income apartment house, it could be viable."
In 1987, a suit was filed against H.U.D. and the Housing Authority in Federal Court by a group of residents and by nonresidents waiting for apartments. The residents claimed that their buildings were not decently maintained. People on the waiting list argued that apartments were kept vacant because the Housing Authority could not decide what to do next.
Under a 1990 out-of-court settlement, 385 units in the remaining 15 buildings were renovated and all the tenants were moved into them. The buildings will stand until March 1997, by which time everyone is expected to be relocated, and will then be torn down.
ORIGINALLY called Yellow Mill Village, the project was the dream of the Rev. Stephen J. Panik, a Roman Catholic priest. It opened in 1939 and was a model of its kind, landscaped and replete with food and service shops. Bounded by Crescent Street to the north, Pembroke Street to the west and Hamilton Street and Waterview Avenue to the south and east, it replaced a vast shantytown. When Father Panik died in 1953, the complex was renamed in his honor.
"Today there are no stores left," said Bessie Thomas, a resident since 1960 and member of a task force of municipal and civic leaders set up to aid the redevelopment. She walks to East Main Street to shop because it is not far enough to justify the $1.50 round-trip bus ride. The nearest supermarket can be reached only by car.
A marked shift in residents occurred after Federal law changed in 1983, requiring public housing residents to spend 30 percent of their income on rent and removing rent ceilings. "Many families moved out rather than pay more as their incomes rose," said Collin Vice, the Housing Authority's director of planning and development. "That left only the poorest of the poor."
So far, H.U.D. has spent $2 million for demolition and $38 million to relocate about 700 families throughout Bridgeport, Mr. Craig said. Half are in old buildings and may apply for a second relocation as better quarters become available. Another allocation will be required to relocate the last of the tenants.
To date, the authority has bought 130 units citywide for renovation, an additional 56 are under construction on properties bought from the city and 33 are being reviewed for approval by H.U.D.
Meanwhile, Michael Sheehan, a New Haven lawyer who represented the tenants in the suit, has filed objections to the Housing Authority's failure to comply with a relocation schedule. He charges that "another 206 units were supposed to have been provided by now."
Mr. Craig is trying to do so by enticing reluctant landlords to accept unit subsidies that remain with the apartment for 15 years, rather than tenant subsidies, which tenants take with them when they move. "We have applied to H.U.D. for 123 unit subsidies," Mr. Craig said. And under a so-called turnkey approach, new units may be built privately around the city and turned over to H.U.D., which would then reimburse the developer.
BUT David P. D'Aulisio, a local realtor and member of the task force, has found that "developers won't risk their own capital, although government backing makes them somewhat more interested."
"We are also having a problem with redlining by the banking industry in many neighborhoods, " he said.
"Realistically," Mr. D'Aulisio added, "we are looking at several years before we see significant development on the site. The stigma of a crime-ridden, drug-infested, poverty-stricken neighborhood in the country's first city to declare bankruptcy is not easily overcome."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Details from two redevelopment proposals for Father Panik Village, the troubled public housing project in Bridgeport. (Leslie Feder)(Zane Yost & Associates)

HEADLINE: Judges Giving Women Prison Terms More Like Men's

BYLINE: By MARY L. RAFFALLI

 BODY:
A YOUNG woman standing before a Nassau County judge in 1985 was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance and sentenced to three years' probation.
Another woman in a similar situation before the same judge in 1989 drew a sentence of one to three years in state prison. 
 Criminal-justice experts attribute the difference to changing attitudes toward women. The pattern stems from a combination of feminism, the emergence of crack, a political hard-line on drugs and the troubled economy.
According to the State Division of Criminal Justice Services, in 1985 about 70 percent of Nassau women who were convicted of a drug felony with no prior felony convictions, received probation. In 1989, the rate for female first offenders given probation plummeted, to 9 percent.
 
'Chivalrous Behavior Has Changed'
 Although similar trends are found in Suffolk, they are more dramatic in Nassau.
Criminologists say there has been a double standard, in that women have been sentenced to rehabilitation and probation based on issues surrounding motherhood and children. A senior research associate at the Criminal Justice Research Center of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, Dr. Ira Sommers, said:
"Now chivalrous behavior has changed with the call for equality. It is because of drug hysteria and changes in attitudes between the sexes that now women are actually being incarcerated once they are caught and convicted."
Some experts say the women's liberation movement is playing a major role. The chairman of the department of criminal justice at Nassau Community College, Peter Grimes, said:
"Our criminal-justice system sent men to prison, but women received the benefit of the doubt and were sentenced more leniently. But the system is changing, and women are not being given the benefit of the doubt, as they had been almost routinely in the past.
"Now the punishments for men and women are similar. As part of a move toward male-female equality, criminal justice removed the kid gloves."
The president of the National Organization for Women in New York City, Melodie Bahan, said: "To in any way tie the increase in women involved in crime to feminism is a little dangerous. It just gives people another reason to fight against women's rights, and that's ridiculous."
 
Matching the Men's Rate
 Nonetheless, compared with men, Nassau women had a much greater chance of receiving probation in 1985. By 1989, the probability was the same for both sexes. In 1985, 32 percent of male first offenders convicted of drug felonies were given probation, compared with 70 percent of their female counterparts. In 1989, the margin narrowed, as the rate of women given probation dropped to the men's 9 percent rate.
"Today," the executive director of the Education and Assistance Corporation, Rosemary Kelly, said, "it is very difficult for a judge to see Sam Smith, who sold drugs to an undercover cop, and give him one to three years upstate and then see Mary Jones, who has the exact same story and give her probation. For years they were doing that. But the women were fewer and farther between.
"Judges used to say, 'Poor woman, she deserves a break.' But not any more. Now the attitude is women wanted equality, and they're getting equality." Ms. Kelly's organization runs Treatment Alternatives to Street Crime and Stoplifting, another treatment program.
The conviction rates for first-offender men and women are approaching each other, with a decrease in the percentage of men who were convicted and an increase in the women's rate.
Although 48 percent of the women arrested for drug felonies in 1985 were convicted, 68 percent of the men were convicted. In 1989, however, 56 percent of the women and 63 percent of the men arrested in drug felonies were convicted.
Courtney Voses, a lawyer, said more women were committing crimes because of problems in the work place and home, as well as drugs.
"More women have drug problems and have a desperate need to go out and make money," Ms. Voses said. "They have family pressures. Some have six or eight children with no support systems. So they turn to crimes."
 
Expectations for Women
 Ms. Bahan said women were generally sentenced more strictly than men. "The system is inherently biased," she said. "There is a perception that women are not supposed to commit violent crimes, and people are outraged."
Others contend women's sentences are approaching the severity ofmen's terms because expectations for women have become similar to those for men. A lawyer, Adrian Diluzio, said: "In the movies as well as in the courts, we consider women to be more like men. And women are taking on qualities that were traditionally thought of as male qualities. They are more aggressive, take greater risks, and have more interest in the profits."
In 1987, Mr. Diluzio defended Jayne Stamen of East Meadow, who was accused of conspiring to have her husband killed. She was found not guilty.
As women's self-images have changed, there has been a shift in crimes women are committing. Up to the early 80's, women's crimes in Nassau were mainly limited to forgery and shoplifting.
"Today, the shift away from shoplifting is because of severe social, professional and economic pressures that are hitting women," Ms. Kelly said. "Going in and stealing a $50 blouse from Lord & Taylor is not going to help. They are selling drugs on street corners to undercover cops instead."
From 1985 to 1989, arrest statistics for Nassau women show a shift from larceny toward drugs. Over the four years, shoplifting arrests decreased 61 percent, and felony drug arrests increased 394 percent.
In 1985, at 44 percent, more women were arrested in larceny cases, usually shoplifting, than in any other felony. Seven percent were arrested for drugs. In 1989, 30 percent of the women arrested in felony cases were arrested on drug charges and 15 percent were arrested in shoplifting.
Professor Grimes said the reason for the shift is that drug dealing is more effective because it brings in more money faster, adding, "There's no fencing involved."
A professor of criminology at Hofstra University, John Wilderman, said: "Shoplifting was more of a diversion for housewives. It was a way of being deviant and getting excitement. Now most women committing crimes need to support a habit. You can't make much money from shoplifting and the probability of getting caught is higher."
 
Changes in Families
 Among the factors contributing to the increased drug activity by women in Nassau are limited financial resources, increased financial pressures and increased numbers of women who are the sole providers for their families.
"More women are responsible for a child, a family without a man, without any supports," Professor Wilderman said. "She is trying to keep a job and a home. Add to this the recession, and she reaches the breaking point. These are hard times, and people become desperate.
"That single mother has to pay $2 for bread instead of $1, but her income is the same or less. Now she can save half of what she expected or nothing at all. Eventually, she has to get the money somewhere else."
Women moved to crimes that had been previously committed mostly by men. Now, women are involved in street homicides and other street crimes like robberies and assaults. "These are crimes we never used to see committed by women," said Dr. Sommers.
 
A Woman 'Can Open Her Own Door'
 The increasing role of women in violent and drug crimes may also stem from a relaxation of men's protection of women in criminal endeavors. Mr. Diluzio said, "It used to be that drug dealers would say, 'I don't want my woman in the firing line.' Now they're saying" that the woman "can open her own door."
Public attention to drug felonies is increasing. "Women are more involved in a politically very unpopular crime," Dr. Sommers said, "and so they are bearing the burden of being caught committing the wrong crime for this era."
A spokesman for the Nassau District Attorney's office said, Ed Grilli: "Since 1986, with crack, we are seeing many women involved with drugs, especially selling. Women addicts sell to support their own habits but I'm sure women have been affected by the recession as well. And with crack dealing openly going on in neighborhoods, women see it as an opportunity to make money."
 
Selling in 'Drive Through' Areas
 Mr. Grilli said the county had never had a crime problem of the magnitude of crack. He named "drive through" areas, where crack is openly available on "every street corner" in Freeport, Glen Cove, Hempstead, Long Beach, New Castle and Rockville Centre.
The police have been conducting "street sweeps" since 1987, especially in Freeport and Hempstead, and arresting in some instances more than 200 people, Mr. Grilli said.
The Supervising Judge of County Criminal Court, Marie G. Santagata, said just a few women were brought in from sweeps, compared with men.
The large-scale entrance of women into work places previously occupied solely by men can mean that the women have become as vulnerable as men. Professor Wilderman said he was not surprised by the increase in female offenders, because "if you go into the swimming pool, you're going to get wet."
"You can't be involved in institutional life, occupationally, economically and in every other aspect, but not in the deviant aspect," he said. "Women were not criminals and not drug users because they were not visible. It's when they became shakers and makers that they became inmates."
"Women were given more options," Ms. Voses said. "They met many different people, did different types of work, and some were led toward crime."
 
'Women Don't Coddle Other Women'
 The increase in women working in the criminal justice system as judges, lawyers, police officers and the like may reflect how the system deals with women. "Women don't coddle other women," Professor Wilderman said. "They do not see them as dependent creatures in need of protection. Men tend to see a woman and say, 'Now here could be my mother,' or, 'Here could be my sister.' Women say, 'That could be me, but it's not.' They sympathize as peers."
Ms. Voses said that male lawyers were not more protective of women, but rather that female lawyers were. "Women go the extra yard for their female clients," she said. "I help with social work, day care, housing. I don't see them as peers. It's not a peer situation. It's a client-attorney situation."
Judge Santagata said she did take into account whether the defendant was a man or woman, but added:
"We consider everything. Probation does an in-depth study of each defendant, and with all that information, the court determines what decision would be best for the individual."
 
Increases in Jails
 "You're looking at a pattern, over time," a spokesman for the state's division of criminal-justice services, Richard Ross, said. "The pattern is clear no matter what any one number is." The agency receives and processes information from jails, probation departments, courts and police departments.
Jail statistics show increases in female inmates. In 1986, 995 women were admitted to the Nassau County jail in East Meadow. Last year the figure was 1,643.
Professor Grimes said, "Now more and more women are going to prison or jail, where in the past, they definitely would have received some sort of probation."
Since 1985, the number of men sentenced to prison has remained level. In Nassau in 1985, three female first offenders convicted of drug felonies were sent to prison, compared with 63 men. In 1989, the number of men was 67, but the women increased to 27.
"The whole ideology has turned right wing," Professor Wilderman said. "The prisons are filled up, and they want to build more whenever, wherever they can -- floating prisons, prison blimps. And why just for the men?"

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

BILL OF RIGHTS RUN
The 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights will be celebrated today with a 10-kilometer run from Tom Paine's Cottage in New Rochelle to St. Paul's National Historic Site in Mount Vernon, where a daylong festival will be in progress. Runners may sign up from 8:30 to 9:45 A.M. at the Paine Cottage at 983 North Avenue for $11. The race begins at 10 A.M. 
 After proceeding through Eastchester and Pelham, the run will wind up at St. Paul's at 897 South Columbus Avenue, in time for the presentation of winners' plaques at noon.
 For the rest of the day, visitors may tour the historic church and the Bill of Rights Museum, stroll through a Revolutionary War encampment, watch a demonstration of a reproduction of an 18th-century printing press, view an early bookbinding exhibition, debate the Bill of Rights with costumed Colonial Americans, listen to strolling costumed musicians, sample Colonial cookies and receive a copy of the Bill of Rights printed on the premises.
St. Paul's is a national shrine because it was there that the printer John Peter Zenger, whose reporting about a corrupt election brought his arrest on charges of libel, was tried and acquitted in 1735. His ordeal led to the inclusion of freedom of the press in the Bill of Rights.
Everything is free but the cookies. Call 667-4116 for more information.
 
COLONIAL FAIR
 Back at Tom Paine's Cottage inNew Rochelle, the Huguenot Thomas Paine Association and the New Rochelle Historical Society have scheduled a Colonial Fair Saturday from noon to 4 P.M.
Children will be shown how to walk on stilts, make clothespin dolls, do stenciling and make a Colonial quilt. They will also ride ponies and go to "class" in a one-room schoolhouse. For grownups there will be plants, raffles, books and refreshments.
Admission is free. Proceeds from games and sales will benefit the association. The cottage is at 983 North Avenue.
 
LANGELLA AT LONG WHARF
 Frank Langella, best known for his interpretation of "Dracula" on stage and screen, has the role of Junius Brutus Booth, the 19th-century Shakespearean actor and father of Edwin and John Wilkes Booth, in "Booth Is Back," opening this week at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.
The play was presented in a workshop production this summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts and marks the first foray of Austin Pendleton, an actor and director, into playwriting. Previews begin on Tuesday; the opening is Oct. 3 and the run extends through Nov. 3.
Raphael Sbarge will portray Edwin Booth at a time when he was preparing to take his father's place on the American stage. The elder Booth had sunk into alcoholism and despair as his career faltered with changing public tastes. The tumultuous relationship between father and son forms the framework of the play.
Performances are scheduled Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M., Saturdays at 4 and 8:30 P.M., Sunday at 2 and 7:30 P.M., with occasional Wednesday matinees at 2 P.M. Tickets for previews are $17 and $19, for later performances $27 to $32. The phone number for the box office is (203) 787-4282. Long Wharf is just off Route I-95. Look for signs on the highway.
 
DANNY GLOVER IN FILM
 "To Sleep With Anger," winner of a Sundance United States Film Festival prize last year, will be shown Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. in the New Rochelle Public Library. The first of a series of five award-winning films, it was written and directed by Charles Burnett and stars Danny Glover as a Southerner who creates discord and suspicion in a close-knit black Los Angeles family while visiting them.
Afterward, Dr. James O'Brien, chairman of the communication arts department at the College of New Rochelle, will lead a discussion of the film. A donation of $2 is requested for admission.
 
STERNHAGEN TALK
 Another event at the New Rochelle Public Library that will be free and open to the public is a talk by Frances Sternhagen. She will discuss "My Life in the Theater, My Life in the Movies" on Thursday at 7:45 P.M. in the library theater.
The actress has appeared in "Driving Miss Daisy," "Equus," "On Golden Pond" and many other Broadway and Off Broadway productions and has received two Obie awards, a Tony award and a Drama Desk award.
 
WHALE-WATCHING TRIP
 Each spring and fall the Long Island Sound Task Force, based in Stamford, offers excursions to Cape Cod to watch whales. The next one will take place from this Friday to next Sunday and includes two trips on Captain Avellar's whale-watching fleet out of Provincetown accompanied by a trained ecologist. Two nights' lodging at the Provincetown Inn, two breakfasts, a dinner and a lecture are included in the $190 cost.
Sightings of pods of humpback, minke, fin and right whales have been reported on previous trips along with schools of white-sided dolphins. Call (203) 327-9786 for more information or to sign up.
 
MAKING A SHAKERE
 How to make, string and play an African shakere, a traditional calabash gourd instrument, is the subject of a five-session workshop at Philipsburg Manor on Route 9 in North Tarrytown, beginning Wednesday at 7:30 P.M.
James Hawthorn Bey, known in music circles as Chief Bey, has recorded with and toured with such noted musicians and dancers as Olatunji and Pearl Primus and has 60 years' experience as an expert in African drums, songs and dances.
The course costs $100 and is suitable for all ages. Call 631-8200 for more information.
 
A FIGHTER FOR CHILDREN
 Marian Wright Edelman, founder and president of the Children's Defense Fund in Washington, will speak at a fund-raising dinner Thursday at 6 P.M. in the Tarrytown Marriott Hotel.
Tickets are $65, and the proceeds will be used by the Westchester Clubmen and the White Plains Family Y.M.C.A. for a program to improve the outlook for black male schoolchildren 10 through 12.
Ms. Edelman, who was the first black woman admitted to the Mississippi bar, began her career with civil rights cases and became involved in defending the Child Development Group of Mississippi, one of the largest Head Start programs in the country. In 1968 she founded the Washington Research Project, which became the Children's Defense Fund in 1973. It has been an advocate for such issues as national child-care legislation, prevention of teen-age pregnancy and children's health.
The Clubmen, an organization of black professional and business men, and the Y will provide diverse activities for boys selected by their schools as most at risk. The activities will include homework assistance, personal-fitness routines, group games and other help aimed at developing academic and social skills.
At the dinner, awards will be presented to individuals who have made significant contributions to the welfare of young people. Tickets can be obtained by calling 328-0585 or 636-3413.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Safest Bet for Uncertain Times

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
It has been an uncertain September for stock market investors, and analysts are still divided over the outlook. It is an on-the-one-hand, on-the-other-hand story, but it appears that the safest bet is in countries where interest rates are expected to fall and economic recoveries look ready to begin.
On the one hand, the stock markets in Britain and Hong Kong, where the key equity indexes repeatedly reached record highs this summer, have lost their momentum. The market in Germany is stuck in a narrow range. Norway is declining. Italy has faded. 
 On the other hand, there are some signs that things might improve. France hit a new 1991 high last week, and the market in Japan, where hope is growing for a cut in the official interest rates, has shown some bounce.
In addition, a further interest rate cut in the United States is possible, and this could lead to drops in Japan and England. Economists are beginning to see signs of a recovery in the economy of the old East Germany, which could ease the load on the unified country's locomotive, the old West Germany. Inflation is coming down around the world.
But, back on the first hand again, the economic recovery in the United States is looking weak while the recovery in England seems even shakier. The economies in both Germany and Japan, which had been the areas of strength as the world economy slowed, are now slowing themselves.
Politics are also unsettled. Reports of heart trouble for Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic and hero of the resistance to the coup in the Soviet Union, could worry markets. The civil war in Yugoslavia continues. Last week there was a threat of renewed military action in Iraq. And the potential cost of feeding the Soviet Union this winter is escalating.
"The basic reason that stock markets are having a difficult time reaching higher ground is that we are still not seeing global liquidity growing by very much, and there is simply not enough liquidity to finance a recovery and push equity prices higher," said Thomas R. Robinson, chief international equity strategist at Merrill Lynch.
Lower interest rates would increase the liquidity, he said, but he thinks central banks are being stingy and are still focusing on the threat of inflation.
"We have seen the occasional burst in one market," he added. "But we still have to be unusually attentive to valuations and earnings because the global markets are really just moving sideways."
Despite the list of uncertainties, Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, has a feeling, based "on nothing tangible," that there will be a rally around the world in October. "A lot of good things are happening around the world," he said, listing declines in inflation, economic change in Latin America and the collapse of Communism.
Because of this feeling he has increased the portion of stocks in his portfolio to 60 percent from 55 percent. Bonds remain at 40 percent and cash goes to zero.
"Sixty is more like a base rate," he said. To keep the equity holdings in a portfolio much below the 60 percent level, he said, one has to be convinced of a bear market because equities are the best performing asset over time. "If you get really bullish, you want to be at 70 percent," he said.
Mr. Biggs notes that there is disagreement about the current outlook, even within his firm. Byron Wien, another Morgan Stanley strategist, still believes that stock markets will fall soon.
But Mr. Biggs said one reason for his belief in an impending rally is that so many investors and analysts have already decided to be "basically pretty cautious." Mr. Biggs is betting against the conventional wisdom.
Mr. Robinson of Merrill Lynch is taking a more cautious approach but is also focusing on falling interest rates and incipient economic recoveries.
According to this strategy some of the best opportunity is in North America. The United States and Canada are on the firm's preferred list, because of both lower interest rates and hopes for the recovery. This is contrary to the conventional wisdom about the United States, Mr. Robinson acknowledged, because many analysts argue that its stocks are expensive when compared with other markets. But he said the recent cut in United States interest rates makes values look better and a recovery will improve earnings expectations.
Britain is also favored and France is liked. Both have the chance for lower interest rates, although the French Government has stubbornly resisted cutting rates this year because of the weakness of the franc and its commitment to fight inflation. And these markets' valuations are more attractive than the American market.
But Japan, even after its recent bounce, is not on Merrill's list, although many other analysts like Tokyo just because interest rates are expected to fall. Mr. Robinson says the market is still subject to a downturn because company earnings may be disappointing as the economy slows down. There is also the impact of the scandals involving Japan's leading investment firms. "We think the investors will still want to be cautious," said Mr. Robinson.
