HEADLINE: When the Regulators Stood Still

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE and STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
John H. Gutfreund sought the unusual audience, and on the hot and humid afternoon of Monday, June 10, the chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., the most powerful firm on Wall Street, was ushered into the imposing third-floor office of Robert R. Glauber, with its heavy, Victorian-style furnishings and dark oil portraits of unsmiling, bygone financiers.
More than anyone at the Treasury Department's headquarters in Washington, Mr. Glauber, the Under Secretary for Finance, is responsible for regulating the monthly auctions at which the Treasury sells billions of dollars in securities to finance the Government's huge debt. Evidence had been piling up that Salomon might have broken the rules -- particularly the rule aimed at preventing any one firm from hogging too many of the securities at a given auction. Mr. Gutfreund had come to Washington to try to head off an investigation that Mr. Glauber's team had quietly initiated. 
 The meeting lasted less than 30 minutes, Mr. Glauber recalls. But as summer turns to fall, that brief conversation begins to look like the start of a new direction in the unfolding Salomon Brothers scandal -- one in which the firm's fraudulent auction bids in the names of unknowing customers, much in the news today, take a back seat to a larger and more troubling issue.
The new concern is whether Salomon acted alone; whether the Wall Street firm and a few big customers -- perhaps acting together -- cornered the market in two-year Treasury notes auctioned last May 22, forcing others to pay exorbitant prices to acquire them. If that is the case, then the Salomon scandal goes far beyond the aberrant behavior of Paul W. Mozer, who was chief of Salomon's Government trading department, and a few assistants who helped Mr. Mozer rig bids in the names of customers without their knowledge.
That broader case would spotlight the failure of Mr. Glauber and E. Gerald Corrigan, the 50-year-old president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- the two officials most responsible for regulating and supervising the Treasury market -- to curb Salomon and perhaps other firms earlier this year.
By mid-May, their staffs had detected, in a new study, a striking pattern of aggressive bidding going back to the spring of last year. But until the May 22 auction, this behavior had not distorted Treasury securities prices, so regulators had no compelling reason to act, in the opinion of Mr. Glauber and his staff. Indeed, Mr. Gutfreund sought the June 10 meeting to contest the Treasury's concern that Salomon's behavior and the distorted pricing after the May auction were linked.
"This was a meeting that he set up; we did not ask him to come in," Mr. Glauber said last week. "He told us some things and we listened. We could have asked him more about the May auction. But we listened."
 
Some Missing Questions
 Nor did Mr. Glauber ask Mr. Gutfreund about auctions in February and April in which Salomon had executed what seemed to Treasury to have been excessive bids. And soon after the June 10 meeting, Mr. Glauber made a fateful decision. He decided to postpone until August at the earliest consideration of any proposed changes in Treasury auction rules designed to prevent the concentration of purchases in a few hands.
"You don't want to rush in and make modifications with a sledgehammer until you know the full extent of the problems," Mr. Glauber said. "Rushing to judgment in this kind of market is a mistake. And we do not know yet whether we know the full extent of what happened."
But the reluctance to act raises troubling questions about the close-knit relationships among the Treasury, the Fed and the primary dealers like Salomon who play the major role in financing the huge Federal debt. Did those relationships lull the regulators into a false sense of confidence that the Government securities market was free of corruption?
Even within the ranks of the Treasury and the Fed, which through its New York office conducts the principal Treasury auctions, there is criticism that regulation of the Treasury markets -- where $5 billion to $12 billion in new notes and bonds are auctioned monthly -- had become too lax and too trusting.
"The plain fact is that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York is on the front line," said a high Fed official in Washington, who declined to be identified. "They see all the data and they are in daily contact with the dealers. They are the source of identifying problems and sounding the alarm."
 
Cast of Characters
 Whatever the criticism, the Treasury, the Fed, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department are conducting civil and criminal investigations of the Treasury securities marketplace. And Salomon officials, who have tried to characterize the scandal as one limited to Mr. Mozer and a few misbehaving confederates, do not discount the possibility that the misbehavior might go well beyond the firm.
The main evidence leading in this direction so far is twofold: The study showing Salomon to have been a far more aggressive bidder in Treasury auctions than had previously been disclosed and the frequency with which the firm illegally used the names of others to buy securities that it secretly kept for itself. Two firms whose names have been used more than once were Quantum Fund and S. G. Warburg & Company.
Warburg, a London-based investment house, is itself a primary dealer in Treasury auctions. Quantum is a mutual fund that invests the savings of others, often in Treasury securities. Both deny that they had any knowledge of Salomon's activities.
The Treasury and the Fed have turned up a startling trend. In a retrospective study, requested by the Treasury and completed by the Fed in mid-May, they found that in three different auctions, over 13 months, Salomon had acquired more than 75 percent of the notes and bonds sold, either in its own name or as an agent for customers. And in nearly 30 of the approximately 230 weekly or monthly auctions held since early 1986, Salomon had bid for and acquired up to 50 percent of the securities.
"Only Salomon would commit the capital required to take such aggressive positions," said Michael E. Basham, a key Treasury deputy under Mr. Glauber until early September, when he left to join Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company Inc. "Regulating the Treasury market is really regulating Salomon."
The Fed study showed that before the spring of 1990, not even Salomon had accounted for 75 percent of any auction. So the new figures should have aroused the Fed's and the Treasury's suspicions that Salomon might have been trying to exercise undue control over the market, some critics say. Apparently, they didn't.
No rule bars Salomon from acquiring most of the securities at an auction, as long as it bids for 35 percent or less in its own name, with the rest ordered for customer accounts. But some argue that the huge chunks taken by Salomon in March 1990 and then in February and April of this year should have prompted the New York Fed to check whether Salomon might have been violating auction rules, as it turns out it was.
"Enormous power over a particular market segment can lead to arrogance, can lead to conclusions that it's within a firm's power to do things that would be unlawful and that might lead to temptations to do so," Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., told a Congressional committee this month.
Mr. Corrigan's people are now making such checks part of their regular routine. But such policing goes against ingrained habits. Mr. Corrigan, a Fordham-trained economist who has spent most of his career in the Federal Reserve system, told Congress this month that the Treasury auction system "has worked incredibly well until now." He testified that the Fed's relationship with Salomon and the 38 other primary dealers who purchase most of the securities at the auctions has been much more that of a trusting business relationship than a regulatory one.
"The data and information we collect from primary dealers are aimed at providing broad insights into the workings of the market," Mr. Corrigan told the Securities Subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee in written testimony. "Information gathering activities have never been structured with a view toward enforcement or compliance activities."
The fourth time that Salomon went above the 75 percent mark was on May 22, only a week after the Treasury had received the revealing Fed study. More than $12 billion in two-year notes were sold that day. Immediately after the auction, however, other traders trying to acquire the new notes to meet obligations to sell them to customers, found themselves forced to pay excessively high prices.
Within days, the uproar on Wall Street over the unusual "squeeze" -- resulting in big losses for some traders -- was noted in Congress. Mr. Glauber's staff on May 29 asked the S.E.C. to begin an investgation, the first ever undertaken by that agency into the Treasury market. And Mr. Basham telephoned Salomon on June 4 to express the Treasury's concerns. "My call was a modest attempt to get them to unwind their position," Mr. Basham said. Six days later, Mr. Gutfreund paid a visit to Mr. Glauber in Washington.
At 62, Mr. Gutfreund is a decade older than Mr. Glauber, but the two men are similar in height and build (about 5-foot-7 and stocky) and in intensity. While Mr. Gutfreund is a hard-driving Wall Street trader, Mr. Glauber, a Harvard economics professor temporarily on leave, works endless hours trying to shepherd the Bush Administration's bank reform legislation through Congress.
Because of the banking bill, the investigation of Salomon's trading practices was, in June, a lesser priority for Mr. Glauber -- and it remained that way until August, when Salomon suddenly disclosed that Mr. Mozer, the head of its Government desk, and a few of Mr. Mozer's staff had purchased Treasury securities in customers' names apparently without their knowledge. The practice illegally circumvented the 35 percent maximum purchase for a single buyer.
 
A Matter of Delays
 Mr. Mozer had told Mr. Gutfreund in April of some of these violations, but he made no mention of them at the June 10 meeting in Mr. Glauber's office. Indeed, Mr. Gutfreund's long failure to report the transgressions to the Fed or the Treasury cost him and other top Salomon officials their jobs in mid-August, after the bid-rigging was finally revealed.
In early June, sitting on a couch in Mr. Glauber's office and puffing on a cigar, Mr. Gutfreund spoke only of the squeeze on the two-year notes -- admitting its existence, but arguing that such squeezes are not all that uncommon and can be the result of natural market forces. As he left, he handed Mr. Glauber an envelope of charts, which have yet to be made public, intended to illustrate his case. Mr. Glauber did not tell the S.E.C. about the meeting, although the S.E.C. had been working on the case.
Mr. Gutfreund in June and Salomon today offer various explanations of how a squeeze can occur naturally. With interest rates declining, as they have in recent months, a new Treasury note sold at auction for a yield of, say, 6 percent, gains in value as market interest rates decline below this level. The greater value increases the demand for the notes. A price squeeze can then develop if traders need to acquire some of the notes because they had sold them to others even before they owned them in so-called "when-issued" trading in advance of the auction. Such traders are called short-sellers.
"The development of a squeeze does not imply any deliberate effort by holders to 'corner' the issue," Salomon said in a question-and-answer press release. "Indeed, the possibility of squeezes is inherent in when-issued trading."
But the May two-year notes ended up mostly in the hands of Salomon and three funds -- Tiger Investment Inc., Quantam and Steinhardt Partnership Inc. With short-sellers seeking to borrow or purchase roughly $6 billion of the May notes, or half the issue, the price squeeze continued until July, as Salomon and Steinhardt in particular appeared to hold their positions. Now the S.E.C. is trying to determine whether Salomon and the others somehow worked together to obtain such control.
"Ultimately, the public debate will be whether this was a case of pre-agreement or coincidence," said an executive who trades in Treasury securities at a Wall Street firm.
Like many of Salomon's prior infractions, the May auction prompted some Treasury officials to rethink the rules. They and the New York Fed considered but rejected a proposal that would have limited all traders in the primary market to 35 percent of an issue for both themselves and their customers. Conforming to the current 35 percent ceiling, a primary dealer could theoretically buy 100 percent of an issue on behalf of itself and two customers.
Instead, Mr. Basham said he viewed the problem as one of disclosure. Because the largest Wall Street firms know the positions of their customers and often financed their purchases, they are able to use this information in their own trading in the after-auction secondary markets and could thus cause squeezes.
 
A Postponed Rule
 The proposed solution, circulated in June as a memo from Mr. Basham, was a two-part rule. First, a company that sought to acquire more than 5 percent of an auction would have to make the bid directly to the Fed and not go through a primary dealer. This would reduce the chances of phony bidding. And, secondly, any bidder acquiring more than 20 percent of the securities at an auction would have to publically disclose its holdings, a rule roughly analogous to S.E.C. regulations for stock market investors.
Such proposals most likely would have drawn opposition from the largest primary dealers, and Mr. Glauber decided to postpone its implementation until he could solicit the industry's views. The plan was to make a presentation in early August, at a meeting in Washington of the Treasury Advisory Borrowing Committee, a group representing primary dealers, including Salomon. Mr. Glauber and some of his staff were tied up in Congressional hearings on bank reform, and the presentation was postponed until early September.
But Salomon's bombshell confession about unauthorized bids came in mid-August. Now Mr. Glauber and Mr. Corrigan are awaiting the outcome of the various investigations under way before making any changes in the rules -- changes that would substitute regulation for the old mutual trust in the marketplace.
"This was a gentlemanly world, where one's word was very, very important," said a lawyer for Salomon. "You see on doillar bills the phrase 'In God We Trust.' At the Treasury Department, there was a view of, 'In the primary dealers we trust.' " Now that trust is gone.
 
 
 
WHY SALOMON'S SUDDEN AGGRESSION?
 The Salomon scandal raises a tantalizing question: Why now? Why haven't dealers in Treasury securities broken the rules so flagrantly in the past? No one has a definitive answer, but there are various theories.
The main one is disregard of moral standards coupled with Salomon's pay incentive system -- a sort of 1980's Wall Street mentality reaching the Treasury security market well after the retreat of Ivan Boesky and Michael Milken. Salomon's traders in this market receive annual bonuses tied to the profitability of their operation, and in pursuit of bigger bonuses they cheated, many analysts say.
In doing so, they took advantage of lax auction supervision by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which supervises the auctions for the Treasury. "The Fed felt that anyone who would be admitted to the inner-sanctum of doing business with the Fed as a primary dealer was virtually by definition an honorable person," said Francis Schott, an economic consultant and a former research director at the New York Fed.
There are other theories, as well. The recession has produced a steady decline in interest rates since last year. That has made made the prices of Treasury securities rise, emboldening Salomon and other investors to take big positions. Finally, the disappearance of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., another major trader in Treasuries, left the field wide open, perhaps encouraging Salomon traders to operate more aggressively.

Chronology: "Solly's Folly: A Recap"
 
1990
 
March 27: Salomon Brothers and its customers buy more than 75 percent of a two-year Treasury note issue.
 
June 27: Paul Mozer, head of Salomon's Government securities desk, bids for more than 100 percent of the four-year notes up for auction. A few days later, Michael Basham, then a Treasury official, warns Mozer about excessive bidding.
 
July 10: Mozer bids for more than 100 percent of an auction of 30-year bonds issued by the Resolution Trust Corporation. Treasury rejects the bid and puts a 35 percent ceiling on the bids by a single buyer at a particular yield.
 
Dec. 27: Salomon bids for 47 percent of an auction of four-year notes, exceeding the ceiling by purchasing notes in the name of Warburg Asset Management apparently without its knowledge.
 
1991
 
Feb. 21: Salomon and its customers bid for 105 percent, and acquire 57 percent of the five-year notes auctioned. Two customer bids, Warburg and Quantum Fund, are apparently unauthorized. When the New York Federal Reserve Bank complains that the Warburg bid violates a technical rule, Mozer changes the name on that bid to Mercury Asset Management, another S. G. Warburg unit.
 
April 25: Salomon and its customers bid for 61 percent and acquire 51 percent of the five-year notes acquired by improperly inflating the bid of a customer, Paul Tudor Jones.
 
Mid-May: Fed review of auction awards back to early 1986 shows that most of Salomon's purchases were less than 45 percent, but in three cases, starting in March 1990, they exceeded 75 percent.
 
May 22: Salomon and customers, mainly Steinhardt Partners Ltd., gain control of nearly all the two-year notes auctioned. A Salomon purchase involving Tiger Investments is partially unauthorized. Others attempting to buy the notes after the auction are forced to pay exorbitant prices, prompting complaints of a squeeze.
 
May 29: Treasury asks the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate the squeeze.
 
June 4: Basham calls Mozer to express concern about the squeeze.
 
June 10: In a meeting, John Gutfreund, Salomon's chairman, tells Robert Glauber, Treasury's Under Secretary for Finance, that the squeeze could have resulted from natural market forces. He is not asked about and does not mention the unauthorized purchases.
 
Aug. 9: Gutfreund tells Glauber that the Mercury bid in February was apparently unauthorized and admits to having known this since April.
 
Aug. 14: Salomon announces publicly that Gutfreund an other top executives had known since April of the illegal purchases.
 
Aug. 15: Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Fed, tells Gutfreund that he and other top management must go it Salomon is to remain a primary dealer in the Treasury market.
 
Aug. 16: Gutfreund and Thomas Strauss, Salomon's president, resign. Shareholder Warren Buffett becomes interim chairman.
 
Aug. 18: Treasury suspends Salomon from bidding at securities auctions, but within hours Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady midifies the ban to allow Salomon to bid for its own account.
 
(Sources: Congressional testimony, interviews and data from Salomon Brothers, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.)

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A 2,000-Hour Guarantee

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
In a few weeks, about 3,000 construction workers, chosen by a complex formula that includes years of service and training, will get an unusual offer from B.E.& K. Inc. The Birmingham, Ala., construction company will agree to pay them for 2,000 hours -- a year of 40-hour weeks -- plus a vacation and full benefits, in 1992. They, in turn, must agree to work whenever B.E.& K. needs them, and not to work elsewhere.
It is the kind of trade-off that factory and office workers take for granted. But it is apparently a first in construction. "It's time we brought some stability to our workers, too," said T. Michael Goodrich, 46, B.E.& K.'s president. 
 That's not a new idea for Mr. Goodrich. While pursuing his civil engineering and law degrees, he spent summers working at his father's Tennessee construction company. "I saw lots of workers driven out of the industry by the insecurity," he recalled.
The industry never lost its appeal for Mr. Goodrich, though. In 1972, after working as a clerk for a judge for two years, he joined the then-fledgling B.E.& K. as legal counsel. B.E.& K. now is a billion-dollar industrial construction company, one of the country's largest.
Its new stab at stemming the labor outflow seems strangely timed, however. July's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for non-housing construction workers was 16.7 percent. With workers so outnumbering jobs, it would seem that no company need sweeten the pot.
Moreover, the program's economics are predicated on a heady upturn in business. "If we've miscalculated, the liability could cost us more than we can afford," Mr. Goodrich said.
He insists the rewards warrant those risks. The general labor glut masks the chronic shortage of highly skilled workers. Mr. Goodrich is hoping that the guaranteed work will act as a blue-collar version of a golden handcuff.

HEADLINE: In Mexico, Fears of Free Trade Melt

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: NAUCALPAN, Mexico

 BODY:
AMBIANCE S.A., a small manufacturer of hotel furniture and hand-painted plastic sculptures in this industrial town on the outskirts of Mexico City, was devastated when Mexico agreed in 1986 to open its market to foreign competition.
With the drastic reduction in the tariffs that had protected Mexican industry for seven decades, the country's hotel chains began importing mass-produced American tables, chairs and desks. Mexican gift shops that had stocked native figurines began filling their shelves with imported steam irons and pocket radios instead. 
 Almost overnight, Ambiance's sculpture sales fell by nearly a fifth and its furniture sales dropped by two-fifths. "There was a high risk of losing everything," said Mauricio Aguilar Duran, who, with his brother, founded the company in 1978.
But Mexico's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 108-nation organization dedicated to free trade, seems to have had its intended effect. It forced many industrial companies to become more competitive.
Ambiance, already suffering from a national recession and then hit by the effects of a 1989 hurricane in Cancun that hurt many of the hotels that were the company's best customers, was forced to prospect outside of Mexico for business. In the last 12 months, the company has exported half of its sculptures, at a modest $150 or less apiece. And thanks in part to the recent American fascination with all things Southwestern, its furniture division, now a separate but affiliated company called Arexxa, sent almost 90 percent of its output to the States.
Sales of the two climbed to a combined $1 million last year. And to fill increasing demand, the company has had to buy plastic figurines from smaller companies and paint, package and market them. The success has more than made up for the failure of another division, producing garden furniture, wiped out by cheaper imports.
GATT membership, Mr. Aguilar said, "helped me prepare to compete a little more. It has been advantageous."
The tariff drop, coupled with a devalued peso, helped boost total Mexican exports of manufactured goods to the United States by more than 100 percent since 1985, to $19.3 billion last year. Imports have climbed at about the same rate to about the same level, indicating that the two economies have become more integrated.
"It's allowing each country to specialize, to take advantage of its strengths, and that has resulted in a more efficient use of resources, particularly in Mexico, because it's so much smaller," said Gene M. Grossman, a professor of economics and international affairs at Princeton University.
Confounded by the failure of protectionism to produce sustained growth, dozens of developing countries have joined free-trade organizations, hoping to uproot domestic cartels, clear the way for competition and spur export-led growth. Ambiance's experience shows the pain and the promise that small businesses in the developing world -- and the United States -- can reap from free-trade policies. And its successful shift to exports may be a harbinger of how Mexican companies may respond to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which the United States, Mexico and Canada have been negotiating for the last three months and which Mexican executives like Mr. Aguilar now aggressively support.
For decades, Mexico led many other poor countries in assessing tariffs on some imports and requiring hard-to-obtain import licenses for others. Duties ran as high as 100 percent and more; some products were banned outright.
The practices were aimed at allowing domestic industries to grow and acquire the economies of scale needed to compete internationally. But these policies instead often gave rise to powerful and politically connected cartels that turned out merchandise of pitifully poor quality.
Not surprisingly, when Mexico decided to join the GATT, its business community was deeply divided. Small-scale producers of factory equipment, like boilers, fought with particular vigor, afraid that they might be wiped out by the superior quality and relatively low prices of the multinationals.
While painful, the transition was not as difficult as many feared, in part because of an unexpectedly healthy flow of foreign investment, which has averaged $2.9 billion annually for the last five years, up from $1.8 billion in 1985, according to the Mexican Government.
Just as important, said Jagdish Bhagwati, a professor of economics and political science at Columbia University, is that domestic manufacturers tend to make different trade-offs in quality, price and speed of delivery than do multinationals, allowing them to compete successfully in the same markets.
Programs to help small companies become exporters also eased the pain. Under one of them, Ambiance got certification from the Banco Mexicano de Comercio Exterior that allowed it to circumvent some paperwork for exports and imports. The bank also guaranteed 80 percent of Ambiance's bank loans -- a significant advantage in a country where the Government has used credit restrictions as a weapon against inflation. (The program is so helpful, in fact, that the United States is trying to ban it under the new trade agreement arguing that it is a form of subsidy).
Only companies with a certain level of sales and a high percentage of sales from export qualify for the certification. And applicants are required to produce extensive, five-year cash flow statistics and provide a detailed business plan for the next five years.
Export programs aimed at helping small businesses are relatively rare in the third world, according to Richard E. Feinberg, executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council, an economic development research center in Washington. Even those in the United States have long suffered from being little known. "In the U.S., we've talked endlessly about how the exports are concentrated in the Fortune 500," Mr. Feinberg said. "And we're still talking."
In addition to the liberal lending policy, Ambiance enjoyed a few lucky breaks. Not every small third world manufacturer can count on a fad on the order of the current American craze for Southwestern furniture. Like hundreds of East Asian electronics companies, Ambiance also benefited from the openness of the American market to its products. And the lower Mexican tariffs on imports also proved to be a plus -- finally making affordable the foreign machinery needed to improve quality and produce in large quantities.
One of the imports stands against the back wall of the figurine factory here, a fairly simple piece of machinery attached to a yard-long arm with a nozzled tip. Ambiance uses it to extrude packaging foam in shapes that safely snuggle its heavy plastic figurines, many of them reproductions of art works, for the long trip to the United States.
Mexico does not produce comparable equipment, Mr. Aguilar said. But since it joined the GATT, the extruders have become more affordable; tariffs on them have dropped to 20 percent, from 40 percent.
Now, some business leaders are pulling for a trade agreement that would eliminate Mexico's average 10 percent tariffs on American products, in exchange for eliminating America's average 4 percent charge.
Raul Herrera Zafra, the sales manager of Colombin Bel S.A. de C.V., part of the Cydsa group, is one of them. In a northern industrial zone of Mexico City, Colombin Bel has 360 people making polyurethane foam for the automotive, electronic, medical, furniture and mattress industries. Its latest foam, which self-extinguishes if set on fire, is being used by Chrysler of Mexico, and Mr. Herrera would like to export it to Detroit.
One of the biggest obstacles, he said, is a 15 percent United States tariff on imports of such foam from Mexico, which he hopes will be reduced under the free trade agreement. "Only by means of open competition can Mexican enterprises grow," he said. "We have gone with crazy ideas that don't work for many years."
Colombin is also hoping for lower tariffs on Mexican imports of foreign machinery. Many of the large chairs and other furniture now sold in Mexico are still stuffed with natural fibers, often harvested from trees, Mr. Herrera said. But high-precision cutting machines from abroad would allow furniture to be stuffed instead with polyurethane foam.
"The machines are indispensable," he said, "not to replace workers but to enrich them."
 
 
FACING ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES
 When the Bush Administration sought Congressional approval this spring to negotiate a free trade agreement with Mexico, some of the toughest opposition came from environmentalists and labor unions concerned that American companies might move their factories south of the border to take advantage of weak environmental and worker safety rules and even weaker enforcement of what rules exist.
Since then, the Mexican Government has tightened environmental rules, shut down some of the worst polluters and increased the spending of its environmental protection ministry sevenfold.
"It's a good start," said Alex A. Hittle, the international coordinator at Friends of the Earth, a Washington-based environmental group. "One of the things propelling this is the free trade agreement, and once it is done and gone, it'll be interesting to see if this continues to go forward or sags back."
The environmental moves could eventually encourage consolidation of certain industries into the hands of the strongest companies. Mauricio Aguilar Duran, the owner of Ambiance S.A., a furniture and figurine maker that has benefitted from reduced trade barriers over the last five years, said the campaign was already making a difference.
Just six months ago, the environmental ministry shut down a foundry making bronze figurines on the same street as Mr. Aguilar's factory. The foundry's unions have occupied the site in protest, he said, preventing him so far from buying the factory and expanding his own overcrowded operations. But the potential is there.
Worker safety has received far less attention. "In the United States, they have goggles, safety aprons, gloves, special shoes and a yellow line on the floor that tells the worker where not to go," Mr. Aguilar admitted. "In Mexico, we don't have this."

HEADLINE: All About/Batteries;
Keeping a Gadget-Mad Nation Charged Up -- and Safe

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
From boom boxes to camcorders, Walkmen to cordless drills, portable power means batteries -- lots and lots of them. Americans now consume 2.7 billion of these household batteries a year. Most end up as trash in landfills and incinerators.
But many environmentalists and governmental officials are concerned that the metals used in batteries will get into drinking-water supplies as landfills leak or as incinerator-stack emissions fall to the ground. All dry-cell batteries -- different from car batteries, which have a liquid electrolyte -- store electricity through chemical reactions that usually involve two different and often toxic metals. 
 According to a draft report prepared earlier this year by the Environmental Protection Agency, household batteries account for 52 percent of the cadmium and 88 percent of the mercury found in trash, though less than 1 percent of all municipal solid waste by weight. Small amounts of the metals, if ingested, can damage the nervous system or increase the risk of cancer.
As a result, several states, including Connecticut, have recently passed laws requiring that batteries containing cadmium be easily removable from appliances for disposal. Other legislation, much calling for the recycling of materials in batteries, is pending in several states. Several dozen communities, including some in New York, have begun programs to separate batteries from other trash for reclamation.
The initiatives could shift the balance of power from single-use batteries to rechargeables. Not only can they be used and recharged about 300 to 1,000 times, but their manufacturers seem more agreeable to recycling.
Single-use batteries are the largest category by far of the $3.3 billion battery market, which is estimated to be growing 4 percent to 5 percent a year. Two companies -- Duracell International Inc., once a unit of the Union Carbide Corporation, and Eveready, a unit of the Raltson-Purina Company -- account for 80 percent of the sector. A number of other companies like Ray-O-Vac, Kodak, Panasonic, Sony and General Electric, fight for the remaining share.
The environmental issue has made rechargeables the fastest-growing market segment, according to industry executives. The largest producer is Gates Energy Products, a unit of the Denver-based Gates Corporation, a rubber products company. Its batteries are sold under dozens of names by a number of retailers including Radio Shack. Its own brand is Millennium. Gates said the market for rechargeables is about $330 million a year, or 10 percent of the overall market.

 
 
'Green' Batteries
Environmentalists Push Rechargeables
 The makers of single-use batteries, like Duracell and Eveready, say they have defused environmental concerns by removing all but a tiny fraction of mercury from their best-selling alkaline batteries.
"The ingredient of concern is mercury and all the battery companies have done a lot to remove it from their products," said James J. Donahue, Jr., a spokesman for Duracell.
Even so, environmentalists say that using batteries once and throwing them away adds to the trash that must be disposed of and contributes to the depletion of the resources that go into them.
"Based on first principles, you would argue for rechargeables," said Richard Denison, a scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "One rechargeable can replace hundreds of disposables."
Popular guides for environmentally correct consumer behavior, like "50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth," published by Earth Works Press in Berkeley, Calif., typically recommend rechargeable batteries. The E.P.A. recommends using them in small appliances "whenever possible."
Producers of single-use cells note that rechargeables tend to lose their charge much faster on the shelf and can hold only about a quarter the power of an alkaline cell of equal size. Prices for rechargeables are two to four times higher than for single-use cells.

 
 
The Cadmium Question
Lingering Problems With Toxic Metals
 The most popular type of rechargeable battery has environmental problems of its own. It is the nickel-cadmium battery found in "cordless" appliances that stay plugged in when not in use. Each year, millions of portable vacuum cleaners, camcorders, shavers, electric drills and flashlights are sold with rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries. Most of them are sealed in the appliances at least in part to prevent users from trying to replace failed batteries with conventional ones. Attempting to recharge single-use batteries can cause them to swell up, leak, or even explode.
This means that each year tens of thousands of rechargeable batteries, containing an estimated 1,200 tons of toxic cadmium, are going into landfills and incinerators as the appliances are discarded.
To prevent this, three states, Connecticut, Minnesota and Vermont, have passed laws requiring that the batteries be easily removable so they can be discarded separately when they or the appliance wear out. More states are expected to follow with similar rules. The intent is to induce customers to separate the nickel-cadmium units from other batteries so the toxic materials can be recycled.
The makers of nickel-cadmium rechargeable batteries have broken away from a broad industry group, the Battery Producers Alliance, to form the Portable Rechargeable Battery Association. "Our initial focus is to promote the recycling of nickel-cadmium batteries," said Norm England, the new group's executive director. "We want to do pilot projects so we can figure out the economics" of recycling.
Since there are no facilities in this country to recover cadmium from batteries, initially they will have to be shipped overseas. And any group collecting batteries in quantity risks coming under E.P.A. hazardous-waste rules, which greatly increases costs.
As a result the single-use battery producers are cool to recycling efforts. Mr. Donahue said the industry would support recycling if it were economically practical. But the value of the materials, like zinc and manganese, is not high enough to cover the collection and processing costs. "In the absence of recycling, there is no better method of disposal than household trash," Mr. Donahue said.

 
 
A Hydride Substitute
It Has Fewer Uses And Costs More
 Putting aside their current enthusiasm for recycling, some makers of rechargeable batteries have tacitly acknowledged that problems associated with cadmium will probably limit the product's use in the future. So they are developing new batteries that use various metal hydrides instead.
The new battery favored by many manufacturers has many of the same characteristics as nickel-cadmium, without the disposal problem. But its differences may limit its application.
For example, the hydride battery can hold twice as much power per unit as standard nickel-cadmium, but it discharges in storage at twice the rate. According to Gates, which is developing a hydride substitute, a fully charged hydride battery would lose its charge after standing for two months. The new batteries are also likely to be more expensive than nickel-cadmium batteries, at least when first released.
The hydride battery also cannot put out power as fast as nickel-cadmium, so it probably will not be suitable for power tools and appliances that drain batteries rapidly. At the moment, that leaves only nickel-cadmium and small, sealed lead-acid batteries for those applications.
 
 
 
SAVING THE ENVIRONMENT, AND MONEY
 How do the costs of using rechargeable batteries stack up against those for their disposable counterparts? The difference can be quite dramatic, according to a recent study.
The analysis -- conducted at Carnegie-Mellon University and cited in the World Wildlife Fund's study "Getting at the Source: Strategies for Reducing Municipal Solid Waste"-- assumed that a cassette player was operated for two hours a day over a three-year period using four batteries. It also assumed alkaline batteries would last five hours, and that the nickel cadmium rechargeables would last two hours.
After three years the alkaline-battery user would have gone through 876 cells at a cost of $657. The four original rechargeable batteries would still be in use, so that total battery purchase cost was estimated at $11.
But the rechargeable user faces costs for the recharger and the power consumed in recharging. The study estimated the cost of the recharger at $10 and the power cost for 1,095 recharges at $5. The total cost of rechargeables would be $26, or a savings of $631.
The environmental savings are just as impressive, according to the study. The disposable batteries would pile up 24,100 grams of trash, including 105 grams of toxic mercury, compared with 90 grams of waste from the rechargeables. The rechargeables would add 16 grams of toxic cadmium to the environment, the study concluded.

HEADLINE: From Manhattan Project to Seventh Avenue

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
Teflon is no longer just about pots and pans.
This fall, the protective surface treatment developed by the chemical division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for kitchenware also protects fashion wear. 
 "Teflon's just awfully good at repelling spills, and it's completely undetectable," said Cyrus Clark, whose company designs Teflon-treated fabrics for use in bed linens, curtains and upholstery.
Discovered 53 years ago, Teflon, the brand name for polytetrafluoroethylene, has become synonymous with water and stain repellancy in the kitchen. Now the word Teflon is showing up on tags dangling from sleeves of uniforms, ski parkas and raincoats. Scores of outerwear manufacturers are offering Teflon-covered garments.
And there are other applications in evidence along Seventh Avenue: wool business suits, leather gloves and jackets, skirts of cotton chintz, silk blouses, scarfs, dresses, neckties and childrens' clothes. Textile mills are shipping Teflon-treated cloth to fabric stores.
Du Pont emphasizes the economic incentive: fewer dry cleaning bills. It says that wet or oily blotches can be wiped away and that stains wash out more easily in the laundry.
Will Teflon-treated garments reduce business for the dry cleaning industry? "It most definitely won't make us sit by the phone, the equivalent of the lonely Maytag repair man," said Norman Oehlke of the International Fabric Care Institute, a trade group in Silver Spring, Md. "It'll be good for everybody, including us; the Teflon coating will make stains more easy to remove.
"It may even be a boon to business, another service that we can offer."
About 2,000 drycleaners now offer to apply Teflon to any garment, whether or not it was originally treated with Teflon.
Du Pont says the coating is undetectable by sight, smell or touch and that a fabric's natural properties of breathability, weight and drape are unaffected.
Teflon is a fluorine-based compound that was discovered by Du Pont in 1938. The polymer material resists interacting chemically with anything else; for that reason it was used in the early 1940's to pack radioactive materials used to build the atom bomb. It was later used to make electronic wire casings, and in 1960, during a Christmas promotion at Macy's, it was introduced in nonstick kitchenware.
 
Goodbye Zepel
 In the last five years, the company said, research was conducted to try to make Teflon in a liquid form so that it could be used to protect fabric. Development was completed last fall. Teflon is replacing Zepel, Du Pont's previous stain repellent, which is being retired.
"We reformulated Teflon to use it on all new categories of surfaces, including soft and delicate fabrics," said Gary De Bay, the worldwide brand manager for Teflon.
In its initial liquid form, it is applied to most garments at the textile mill phase as a final step after dyeing. It may be sprayed or rolled on, or a fabric may be dipped in a bath to cause the Teflon to absorb and coat every fiber. Life expectancy on a wash-and-wear garment, for example, a uniform, is about three years.
Another Teflon treatment can then be applied; Du Pont estimates a new application to a trenchcoat, for example, would cost about $10.
Among the range of Teflon-coated apparel available to consumers this fall are a hand-painted silk scarf in muted mauve, celery, rose, gray and black, designed by Tamara Maas for Lippin International ($125), as well as the designer's hand-painted silk jacket with silk batting, in orange, coral, grape, black and chartreuse ($395). Both are available at department stores nationwide.
A three-quarter length trench-style raincoat by Portrait with a floral print of subdued blue, green and mauve, is $189 at Macy's, Plymouth and Nordstrom. Aris/Isotoner makes womens' gloves protected with Teflon, $26 unlined, $30, lined, at Macy's, Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale's, A. & S. and Stern's stores.
Cotton shorts, $35, shirts, $40, nylon jackets, $70, and caps, $9, made by 10-X, are treated with Teflon and sold at sporting goods stores nationwide. Teflon-permeated parkas by Roffe are $195 to $240 at Paragon Sports and Scandinavian Ski Shop. A man's trench-style raincoat by Whaling, $400 at Lord & Taylor, is waterproofed by Teflon.
A buttery yet water and stain proof leather jacket by Laurence Roy, available at Tannery West stores nationwide, is $395.

HEADLINE: New Cafes: Tradition Without Smoke

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
In the 1950's, cafes were dark places filled with cigarette smoke and bohemians. In the 80's, they were soaring, noisy spaces inhabited by black-clad women and baby vegetables.
Now, cafes are flourishing in yet another form. A number of small cafes concentrating on coffee, tea, desserts and a few salads and sandwiches have opened in the last year or so, particularly in downtown Manhattan. They're not restaurants calling themselves cafes but small, relaxed meeting places, although not usually dark and smoky. 
 For restaurateurs, cafes are appealing because they require a relatively small initial investment and are simpler to run, requiring a smaller inventory and a less sophisticated work force than restaurants.
For customers, they seem to suit the new tone of the time: informal and unpretentious, requiring less of a commitment than going out for a real meal at a real restaurant. Although prices for individual items like a cappuccino for $2.50 may be high, the total bill for an afternoon or evening out is small, a benefit when even the affluent feel uncomfortable with heavy spending.
 
From Cozy to Lively
 The cafes are as varied as their owners. Some, like Anglers and Writers at 420 Hudson Street, are woody, cozy places where real moms turn out apple pie; others, like The City Bakery at 22 East 17th Street, are stylish, lively meeting places. Often, they are tucked away on side streets, like Edgar's at 255 West 84th Street.
The City Bakery, which was opened in December by Maury Rubin, a former producer and director for ABC, attracts farmers and customers from the nearby farmers' market as well as photographers and advertising peple who work in the neighborhood. Metal tubes filled with newspapers and magazines cover one wall.
"Cafes allow people to relax a little bit more," said Natasha Halmovich, the manager. "Restaurants are like going to the theater. Cafes are like going to the movies."
Cafes are places to sit and talk, to sit and read, to sit and watch the passing parade. It is against the informal rules of a cafe for patrons to be rushed out of their chairs. Cliff Barda, who was recently in New York from Seattle to visit his daughter, spent most of one day at Dean & DeLuca Coffee-Tea at 121 Prince Street, which met his two requirements: "The coffee has to be good and the ambiance has to be friendly."
 
'Permissive Atmosphere'
 The lack of table service, he said, encourages lingering. "It's a kind of permissive atmosphere," he said. "Table service makes you feel more claustrophobic."
Mr. Barda, who directs a mental health center, said he often takes his paperwork to cafes in Seattle. "It's a European influence that has finally come over here," he said. "It's acceptable now to pass time in cafes."
Cafes are also the logical destination for those who have given up drugs and drinking, and find bars or clubs unappealing. "If you're going to a cafe, you don't have to be confronted with it," said Angela Lukacin, manager of Caffe Giardino at 25 Cleveland Place near Spring Street.
The small, unpretentious cafe with its large garden attracts artists and writers, but it is also a resting place for tourists who have been wandering through nearby SoHo and Little Italy. Andreas Dietze, an advertising agency copywriter from Germany who had just arrived in New York, stopped for coffee after walking from Grand Central to Battery Park and then up to SoHo, a trek that took far longer than he expected. "It looks so little on the map," he said.
Flora Bochinis, a retired teacher who has always lived in New York, likes cafes because they are casual.
"There used to be loads of them," said Ms. Bochinis, who was having ice cream with a friend at Caffe Donatello at 207 Waverly Place, a new Italian cafe in Greenwich Village. "We used to sit all night for a dollar. It was marvelous. Little by little, they became restaurants and bars."
The resurgence of cafes pleases her, because it means that people will be more likely to socialize. "In a restaurant," she said, "you go and sit down with one person and nobody comes over." Cafes are also cheaper. Her friend, Laurrie Brinckerhoff, was having a toasted cheese sandwich and a salad, something in keeping with her tighter budget since she became unemployed.
 
The Roots of Their Owners
 The tide of international immigrants to the city shows up in the new cafes, with many reflecting the roots of their owners. The Adore on 17 East 13th Street is run by Yukihito and Makie Yahagi, Japanese immigrants. Caffe Novecento at 343 West Broadway was opened six weeks ago by Hector Rolotti, an Argentinian of Italian descent. Caffe Tina at 184 Prince Street is owned by two Italians, Tina Launi and Pino Di Bartolo, and could easily be in a small town in Italy.
Some define themselves by their coffees, others by their teas. Le Poeme, at Prince and Elizabeth Streets, with Corsican and French specialties, has teas like rasberry, blackberry and fresh ginger.
Craig Bero, who owns both a cafe, Anglers and Writers, and a restaurant, Village Atelier, said cafes seem more in keeping with the times. A cafe, he said, offers simplicty, with lower expectations and fewer promises.
They can be places to dream, though. Sylvia Stein was drinking coffee and eating a croissant at Caffe Rafaella on Seventh Avenue near 10th Street, fantasizing about moving to Santa Fe and opening a Jewish deli. The closest she has come to restaurant experience was her acting stint on the soap opera "As the World Turns."
"I was a waitress in a deli," Ms. Stein said. "I wore yellow polyester on national television."

HEADLINE: Camera

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
A camera for mixed media, one that may be a harbinger of a new kind of filmless photography, is coming to the United States from Japan.
The impact of television and the computer is being acknowledged by the Fujix Digital Still Camera, which takes 21 color images on a reusable Fujix IM-8S electronic memory card. Its manufacturer, Fuji, sees a many-sided market -- for family pictures, photojournalism, for desktop publishing, for engineering and product design. 
 The memory cards can be played through a standard television set using the camera's built-in playback function, or recorded into a personal computer for viewing and use.
High-quality prints can be made from the memory cards, according to Fuji, and next fall the company will provide lab services for transferring memory-card images onto Photo CD's -- a system developed by Eastman Kodak and Philips Electronics to allow photographs to be transferred to compact disks for display on television screens.
Now being sold in Japan, the camera will appear on the American market in April, shortly after the 1992 Comdex Exhibition in Chicago.
In 1988, Fuji developed the world's first camera that recorded pictures on digital memory cards -- the DS-1P. A year later, as an experiment, the camera system was offered for sale in Japan. This is a new and improved version of the original Fuji memory-card camera.
When the card is inserted into the Fujix DP-100 Memory Card Processor, the compressed images can be moved quickly into personal computers like the Apple Macintosh and I.B.M.
Photographs of the camera show it to be almost palm-sized and shaped more like a small video camera than a traditional 35-millimeter still unit. The Fujix Digital features automatic focus, a 3x zoom lens with capacity for closeups, rechargeable batteries and a built-in playback function for immediate viewing on a television screen.
The camera weighs about 1 3/4 pounds. The memory card is 2.2 millimeters thick and about the size of a business card.
Shutter speeds run from a quarter of a second to 1/749 second, with aperture setting from f/2 to f/11. Through-the-lens metering can be used for available light and taking pictures with the built-in flash. Photographers have a choice of automatic or manual exposure.
The electronic flash features quick recharge, has an automatic power save function, and can be set for automatic flash-on when needed.
Drive modes are for single-frame recording, continuous or with a self-timer. Erasing faulty images is accomplished from the last frame, backwards.
To power the camera, the engineers have wisely chosen rechargeable battery packs, and long-life lithium batteries for the memory backup system.
With image compression, the user has a choice of three modes -- "fine," which produces 5 frames a card, "normal" for 10 frames and "economy" for the maximum 21 frames. The imaging device contains 390,000 pixels, or picture elements.
An American market price has not been set yet. In Japan, the camera sells for around $5,000.
According to Fuji, three elements will help in creating a new market for its digital system: the increase in popularity of PC work stations; the development of computer networks throughout the world and the imminent appearance of high-definition television, or HDTV, in the marketplace. With these forces in play, Fuji believes there will be a great need for the taking and transmitting of digital pictures quickly.
"High-quality image transmission," said a Fuji spokesman, "is possible at a quick seven seconds per frame, making the system ideal for the coming information network era."
What else is new at Fuji?
People in the Memphis area have until the end of this month to see what Fuji believes is the world's largest photographic mural. It is a picture of the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, U.S.S.R., and is part of the Catherine the Great Exhibition at the Memphis Cook Convention Center. Fuji photographic materials were used in creating the super mural, which measures 92 feet by 15 feet.
Fuji is about to place on the American market this fall an ultra-compact video projector, the P-40U, which can be used with any camcorder, VCR or video disk player that has a video output terminal. It projects an image ranging in size from 6 to 40 inches measured diagonally. The lens is a 55-millimeter, f/2.8. It can be powered by AC or a camcorder battery. It is so small it fits easily into a camcorder bag: 33/16 by 27/16 by 71/16 inches. List price: $799.

HEADLINE: Rural Towns Trying to Lure Retirees to Bloster Economy

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Using advertising, videos, toll-free hot lines and booths at recreational vehicle conventions, small towns from Idaho to Alabama are fighting decline by marketing themselves to retirees.
Many of the most aggressive towns are inland places far from the sunny retirement belt of Florida and the Southwest, like Guntersville, Ala., Hot Springs, Ark., and Chewelah, Wash. And they are having success, luring significant numbers of older people who find traditional retirement meccas overbuilt, crime-ridden and unaffordable. 
 Many civic leaders say it is now far easier and more lucrative for rural towns to attract older people -- with their pensions and savings -- than new factories or office parks. Companies often demand millions of dollars in tax abatements and new roads and other repairs, they say. But retirees and their hundreds of thousands of dollars in assets are being enticed with a brochure, a tour, a handshake and a smile.
 
Healthy, Wealthy and Wise
 "These migrants are healthier, wealthier and better educated than most Americans," said Mark Fagan, a professor at the Center for Economic Development and Business Research at Jacksonville State University in Alabama, which is helping 94 Alabama municipalities attract older people.
On average, Mr. Fagan said, the retired couples who have settled in Alabama have annual incomes of $35,000 and assets of more than $250,000.
"They pay for their homes with cash and spend most of their income locally," Mr. Fagan added. "It is like having an export industry to bring in out-of-state dollars."
In addition, the retirees place few demands on the most expensive of local services, the public schools.
The marketing campaigns come after a decade in which many rural towns that depended on agriculture, mining and manufacturing had some of their sharpest population declines in this century, as young people moved away in search of jobs.
With 20 million Americans expected to retire in the next decade, experts say, the futures of many towns may depend on their ability to grab a piece of the retirement trade.
Most of America's 2,400 rural counties outside of metropolitan areas had sharp drops in population in the last decade. But some 480 counties, many of which include retirement resorts, saw their populations jump by 16 percent as retirees settled in year round.
As a result, more than 200 rural communities that were losing population have tried to tap into the senior market with home-grown marketing campaigns, Mr. Fagan said, and growing numbers of other towns are inquiring about them. Many of the established programs are now reporting significant successes.
Chewelah, a town with fewer than 2,000 residents, 45 miles south of Spokane, has attracted 35 retired couples in the last two years with ads in retirement magazines, a toll-free hot line and a video made for $750 by high school students, town officials say. These all boast of Chewelah's nearness to golf courses, ski slopes and hospitals.
"If you had a heart attack in my office this very minute," Gloria Davidson, the town's Mayor, said in a telephone interview, "you would be in Spokane in 15 minutes by helicopter."
The arrival of the retirees, Ms. Davidson says, has created jobs by spurring the opening of a bakery, a restaurant and a beauty shop.
 
Unpaid 'Ambassadors'
 Other places have added a more personal pitch.
Kennewick, Richland and Pasco, Wash., together have trained 49 residents to act as unpaid "ambassadors" on their business trips and vacations. The ambassadors offer middle-aged people promotional literature and bumper stickers. Together with ads and a toll-free hot line, officials say, the campaign has attracted 35 retired households.
In Alabama, the four-year-old state program has purchased $100,000 in ads in national retirement publications and advised towns on how to market themselves. The campaign has drawn 15,000 queries from out-of-state residents and several hundred retirees have settled in the state.
Guntersville, Ala., a town of 7,000 along the Tennessee River that lost its major employer, a textile factory, in the early 1980's, attracted 250 retired couples in the last three years with magazine ads and commercials on ESPN, the cable sports network, during the network's coverage of fishing tournaments.
The retirees, town officials say, have revived business in banks, real estate offices, marinas and golf courses.
 
Going Home Again
 In North Dakota, the Legislature this year financed Operation Back Home Again, a program designed to help towns across the state trace the graduates of their high schools as far back as 1950 and ask them to return for their golden years. In Mississippi, county development agencies and the Mississippi Power Company have set up booths at national boating, fishing and recreational vehicle conventions.
Hot Springs, a lakeside city of 32,000 in central Arkansas, has attracted more than 500 households in the last two years with its ads in retirement magazines, town officials say. When retirees arrive, they are met by blue-coated volunteers, who offer tours of the town, including its new art galleries and shops. Meanwhile, the guides sing the praises of retirement in the Ozarks.
"This is a garden," said Richard Bingham, a 59-year-old tour guide in Hot Springs who moved from South Pasadena, Calif., in 1987. Mr. Bingham recalls that rising pollution, crime and real estate prices made Southern California less and less inviting as a place to retire.
So he sold his home there for $250,000 and bought a three-bedroom house on a lake in Hot Springs for $100,000. He also bought a 24-foot boat, and put $75,000 into a local bank.
"It just got too darned crowded," Mr. Bingham said of California." It used to take me 30 minutes to drive to downtown Los Angeles. In the last year it took an hour and a half to two hours."
 
Traditional Areas Slip

The dimming luster of traditional retirement areas may just be starting to appear in census findings, said Stephen Golant, a professor of geography at the University of Florida in Gainesville.
In 1987, for example, Florida estimated that it would have 2,542,000 residents over the age 65 by 1990, based on past growth of the state's retired population. But the 1990 census found that the state had only 2,389,000 residents over 65, an indication, Mr. Golant said, that the migration may have slowed.
The youngest people now making plans for retirement, who will be joined by the oldest members of the baby boom in the next five years, are increasingly asking about small towns far away from traditional retirement resorts, said Kate Greer, the editor in chief of New Choices, a magazine aimed at retirees.
"I sense a real change in attitude," Ms. Greer said. "These people are asking, where do I really want to retire?"
Mr. Golant cautioned, however, that rural towns could be disappointed in the long term by the arrival of retirees. Although Mr. Fagan estimates that each retired couple has the same economic impact as 3.7 factory jobs, Mr. Golant said the retirees did not create the types of well-paying jobs that towns would gain by attracting businesses.
"Certainly they will generate jobs in recreation, personal services and health-related activities," Mr. Golant said. "But it is not clear the presence of retirees will generate higher-paying jobs that are generally related to management, research, technology and finance."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Outrage Index Rises; Wall St. Feels the Heat

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
SINCE the mid-80's, the nation has been swept by a seemingly endless wave of scandals from the world of finance. Defining the era are figures like Dennis Levine, with his briefcase full of insider-trading cash, Michael R. Milken, the junk bond billionaire whose machinations led to the demise of Drexel Burnham Lambert, and John H. Gutfreund, the head of Salomon Brothers Inc., who turned a blind eye on wayward Treasury bond traders. The cumulative weight of all this turpitude raises the question of whether American business has suffered a moral collapse.
But the people who carefully monitor such trends seem to believe that business is no more or less ethical than it was a decade ago, or two or three. "These things don't change that much," said District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, who should know. Today he heads a sweeping investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the rogue financial institution. As a young Federal prosecutor in the 1960's, he helped convict a head of the New York Stock Exchange.
Easy money no doubt bred looser morals during the 
 1980's Wall Street boom, just as it did during the go-go 60's, when fake investment opportunities poured out of "bucket shops," not to mention the raging investor abuses of the Roaring Twenties.
What seems to be new is that business on Main Street as well as Wall Street is increasingly caught between clashing economic and societal forces that are dramatically raising the cost to companies of ethical lapses. Those same forces are also increasing the rewards to firms that manage to stay honest.
On the one hand, argues Gary Edwards, president of the Ethics Resource Center in Washington, a nonprofit group that advises companies on ethics, the more intense the competition -- from restructuring, deregulation, sluggish growth, foreign rivals -- the more pressure on employees to bend the rules. "Hard times, like booms, breed bad ethics," he said.
But amid the hard times, Americans are becoming more and more concerned about morality. This is reflected not just by mounting outrage over abuses by the rich and powerful but by growing struggles over abortion, animal rights and the environment. "Moral issues are increasingly becoming the political issues of our age," said Robert W. Fogel, an economic historian at the University of Chicago. "Wall Street is one of the arenas in the struggle for a moral life."
The moral indignation is also laced with old-fashioned American populism. "The outrage is exacerbated by a sense of envy of the large amounts of money earned by a relatively few people on Wall Street," said Samuel L. Hayes 3d, a professor of investment banking at the Harvard Business School. For example, Paul Mozer, the disgraced Salomon trader, earned more than $10 million in the last three years.
Not surprisingly then, the cost of such behavior to firms has increased exponentially. "The grievous economic harm is done in great boxcar numbers," said Harry Keefe, a bond trader and founder of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Even with illicit profits of millions, he added, "the gain is so small and the potential damage is so large." And it is getting larger. New sentencing guidelines that are scheduled to take effect Nov. 1 call for vastly larger fines and more prison sentences. But for a firm caught breaking the rules, and for its employees, customers and stockholders, $100 million fines and jail terms may be the least of the costs.
Take the case of Salomon Brothers Inc. A few weeks ago it was the most profitable powerhouse on Wall Street. Since early September, when Salomon executives admitted failing to report irregularities by some of their bond traders, Salomon's value has plunged by a sickening $1.6 billion, 40 percent of its market capitalization. If investigators uncover much more wrongdoing, Salomon's very existence, along with thousands of jobs, could be at stake. By contrast, its profits on the illicit trades were estimated at no more than a few million dollars.
The shock waves can extend far beyond one firm. The fall of Mr. Milken's firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., took down the entire junk bond market.
At the same time, however, the virtuous can look forward to greater rewards. Today, on Wall Street, companies with intact reputations are picking up clients who no longer feel comfortable with Salomon, and seeing their stock prices soar in the bargain. "Ethics has been shown to be good business in the case of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley," said Mr. Hayes. There is also the prospect of increasing scrutiny. "There's a lot of political capital to be won by identifying yourself at the forefront of policing society, particularly the rich and powerful," said Mr. Fogel. The trend, which began with the savings and loan cleanup, seems to be accelerating.
As a result of the cases of Salomon and B.C.C.I. -- it illegally acquired an American bank, for one thing -- the Federal Reserve will get more power and more money to bolster oversight. Many experts welcome that development. "More money to prosecute wrongdoing would re-establish the profitability of obeying the law," said Mr. Hayes.
But the fervor is for tougher enforcement of existing rules governing finance, more than for an increase in regulation back to pre-Reagan levels. Both political parties as well as big business groups oppose re-regulation on the ground that it would undermine efficiency and global competitiveness. Rather, the hope is that making examples of a few wrongdoers will act as a deterrent and spur greater self-policing.
Businesses are adapting to the new reality with self-protective measures. "The trend is toward higher standards and greater efforts by companies to comply," said Joseph Badaracco Jr., who heads the Harvard Business School's ethics program. Since 1980, when few companies did more than publish a code of ethics, 90 percent of financial service companies have instituted formal ethics codes and 30 percent have begun ethics training sessions for their employees.
Crackdowns have already begun on Wall Street. Shearson Lehman Brothers, for example, recently suspended two traders accused of stock manipulation. Companies are also rethinking their pay and bonus systems. "An incentive system in which rewards are based on individual performance really tested the moral fiber of people that had hairline faults," said Mr. Hayes.
Ultimately, every business must create its own ethical climate. "Warren Buffet is trying to re-create a sense of community that ties everybody's fortunes to the fortunes of the firm, that means when one goes down, all go down," Mr. Hayes added, referring to Salomon's new chairman. "That concentrates the mind."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For Mario Cuomo, All Roads Lead to Home

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
IN eight-and-a-half years as Governor of New York, Mario M. Cuomo has generated a significant body of political folklore.
There are the legendary Wednesday night basketball games with his staff, in which the 59-year-old Governor uses sharp elbows to compensate for his age and chronically bad back. There are the solitary walks around Albany's Lincoln Park, where dressed in a jogging suit he ponders the events of the day. There are the pre-dawn telephone calls from an aide in New York City, who reads Mr. Cuomo the headlines from the morning papers. 
 But few of those images can compete with Mr. Cuomo's obsession with sleeping in his own bed. Of the 3,187 days that Mr. Cuomo has been Governor, he has, by his staff's count, spent only 36 nights away from the Executive Mansion.
As the emerging field of Democratic candidates gathered at the national party's fall meeting in Los Angeles this weekend, those closest to Mr. Cuomo cited his reluctance to travel as one of the reasons he has shied away from a race for the White House. His absence from the meeting and his stay-at-home record may be the most convincing evidence that he is not planning a Presidential campaign, they said.
 
Flying the Red-Eye
 Four times since taking office, Mr. Cuomo has flown to California and back on the same day. He took the red-eye back to Kennedy International Airport on the night he delivered his triumphant keynote address at the 1984 Democratic National Convention in San Francisco. When he attended the four-day Democratic convention in 1988, he flew to Atlanta and back on the first day, then flew back down and returned on the third day.
As in most years, the Governor's one-week vacation was spent in the Executive Mansion last month, where he could read and work the phones without wearing a suit or making appearances.
When Mr. Cuomo leaves on Saturday for a rare week-long trade mission to Japan, it will be only the second overseas trip of his three terms as Governor. The first was to the Soviet Union in 1987.
"He kept asking whether we could do it in three days," Tonio Burgos, a former aide, said of the planning for that trip.
To many of Mr. Cuomo's aides, the Governor's distaste for extended travel is an endearing quirk, a trait that testifies to his workaholism and his single-minded devotion to the state. They regularly squeeze it for every possible drop of political symbolism.
But in light of the undying talk of Presidential races, it is a quirk that also raises intriguing questions.
Why does a man with such immense intellectual curiosity have so little interest in exploring the world? Can he thoughtfully address issues of global politics when he has seen so little of the globe? Does his reluctance to go abroad hurt the state's ability to attract foreign investment and trade?
Does Mr. Cuomo dislike being away from Albany because of an extreme devotion to his job or because he is, in the words of several aides, "a control freak"? And did the prospect of a grueling travel schedule discourage a run for the Presidency?
Like most questions concerning Mr. Cuomo's complex psyche, many of those are unanswerable, particularly without the Governor's help. He declined repeated requests last week to discuss the subject.
Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's eldest son and closest adviser, said the infrequency of his father's travels this year -- only seven out-of-state trips and one overnighter -- demonstrates that he means what he says about not running for President.
Meyer S. Frucher, another frequent adviser, said that Mr. Cuomo has given few out-of-state speeches attacking the Bush Administration because he has tired of being hounded by the Presidential question. "Whenever he does it, whatever he says is obscured by the political perception that this is being done to enhance Presidential ambitions," Mr. Frucher said. "I think it truly frustrates him and inhibits his interest in traveling."
Clearly, Mr. Cuomo does not dislike travel itself. He frequently flies about New York and has taken 163 out-of-state trips while Governor. His Zen approach to flying in the rickety state plane, despite its occasional emergency landings, has demonstrated that he has no fear of flying.
But it is equally evident that Mr. Cuomo does not like to stay gone. He does not sightsee. He does not eat at restaurants. He does not seek out political leaders or policy experts. He does not linger. A voracious reader, "he travels in between the pages of books," said Vincent Tese, his director of economic development.
One aide said that Mr. Cuomo dislikes the social requirements of a visiting head of state. Others suggested it has more to do with his work habits. "When he travels, he doesn't feel plugged in and that for him is an annoyance," said Gary G. Fryer, a former press secretary.
Mr. Fryer and other advisers suggested that Mr. Cuomo feels more control over the gears of government and his own political fate in Albany.
The issue of control was reinforced 10 days ago when reporters got hold of a confidential memorandum that advised the Governor to "track the media as much as possible in advance" of his trip to Japan "and control its behavior as much as possible during the tour."
Spokesmen for Mr. Cuomo dismissed the memo from longtime aide Stephen Schlesinger as "ridiculous" and said the Governor had never seen it.
What is clear is that Mr. Cuomo's reluctance to travel extensively separates him from most governors. During 1990 alone, governors from 26 states and territories made 54 trips abroad, according to a survey by the National Governors Association. Gov. William Donald Schaefer of Maryland, for example, has taken nine foreign trips to 22 countries in his four years in office.
Some governors and mayors come under intense criticism at home for excessive globetrotting. But officials with business groups said the trips can be invaluable for promoting trade, tourism and investment.
Mr. Tese said it is less important for the Governor of New York to travel abroad because the state has a world financial and diplomatic center. In addition, Mr. Tese and Mr. Cuomo's wife, Matilda, have served as surrogates for the Governor on frequent trips overseas.
If the Japanese recognize next week that Mr. Cuomo is bestowing a special honor by visiting their country, they will not be alone. When Andrew Cuomo was asked what it meant that his father had spent only 36 nights away from Albany, including two nights at his wedding, he thought for a second and then said: "It means I'm very lucky he came to my wedding."
