HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Some Things Are More Vital Than Money When It Comes to Creating the World Anew

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
THE United States, the world's one remaining superpower, also has the world's biggest hole in its pocket. The national debt, just $1 trillion a decade ago, is now $3.5 trillion. The Federal budget deficit is expected to swell the national debt by $362 billion in the fiscal year 1992, which begins Oct. 1. And the net foreign debt -- foreigners' assets in this country minus Americans' assets abroad, measured at their current replacement value -- swung from a surplus of $364 billion in 1982 to a deficit of $412 billion in 1990, a $776 billion plunge that is still going on.
Yet the United States, with "more will than wallet," in President Bush's words, is still taking the lead in efforts to deal with crises all over the world: dispatching American planes to Saudi Arabia to force Saddam Hussein of Iraq to yield to United Nations inspection of his nuclear, biological and chemical warfare plants; pressing the Israeli Government to change its settlement policy in the occupied West Bank by holding up $10 billion in loan guarantees for resettling Soviet Jewish immigrants; trying to achieve a Middle East peace agreement; seeking to prevent economic and political chaos in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe; trying to construct what Mr. Bush calls a new world order while maintaining the world's largest military budget and tackling (or, his critics would say, neglecting) America's own social, economic and environmental problems. 
 Is the United States suffering from what Paul Kennedy of Yale, in his book "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," called "imperial overstretch," straining its resources and bringing about its own decline, as great powers have done throughout history?
Or is the analogy false, as other scholars, like Joseph S. Nye Jr. of Harvard, argue? In his book "Bound to Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power," Mr. Nye contends that assertions of American economic decline are based on a misreading of history. Since the early post-World War II period, the United States gross national product has indeed declined from about one-third of total world output to one-fourth.
But Mr. Nye maintains that the big bulge in America's share of the world's G.N.P. during and immediately after World War II was highly exceptional: the American economy soared as the nation became the arsenal of democracy and, unscathed by the war, led world reconstruction. Other major industrial powers, especially the defeated enemies Japan and Germany, were devastated and needed years to rebuild and modernize their economic and social structure.
With America's help, they gradually did so, and by 1975 the United States share of world production slid back to its prewar level of about 25 percent, reaching an equilibrium it has maintained ever since.
 
Depending on Others
 Nevertheless, America's heavy dependence on foreign and domestic debt to pay for its growth, which was interrupted in the last year by a recession, raises serious questions about the stability and soundness of the economy.
For the first time in its history, the United States had others finance one of its wars, raising $54 billion from allies for the operation in the Persian Gulf. In fact, the United States received $33 billion more than the war cost it, temporarily easing the budget deficit and balance of payments.
But can the United States count on other countries to finance its future military actions? Or will the only superpower be so severely constrained by its lack of money that it will be reduced to the role of mercenary or forced to surrender its freedom of action, in both military and economic affairs?
As though from the grandstands, the United States has been watching the Soviet republics, the newly independent Baltic states, and other Eastern and Central European countries struggling to emerge from Communism and become efficient market economies. If they succeed, this is a development rich in potential for the United States and the world economy.
In a sense, the end of the cold war provides the kind of opportunity for world economic growth last seen at the end of World War II with the modernization of Europe, Japan and the newly industrialized countries of the Pacific rim. But the United States cannot finance another Marshall Plan.
This does not necessarily make the country a pitiful, helpless giant. As global leader, it can mobilize the capital and energies of other countries and help clear the way for private enterprise to build the new world order.
 
Menage a trois
 The burdens this time will have to be cooperatively shared. If the collapse of the Soviet Union has made the once bipolar world "unipolar" with respect to military force, it has become "tripolar" economically, with the United States, Japan and Germany (or, in regional terms, North America, the Pacific Rim and the European Community) bound together in a complex relationship, both rivalrous and interdependent, like a tempestuous marriage.
Depending on the way the menage a trois behaves, the relationship may split apart or strengthen and mature. Threesomes are inherently unstable, however; the immediate danger, the Japanese believe, is that the Americans and Europeans will gang up on them.
Only the United States, playing both unipolar and tripolar roles, can lead the world toward greater stability. For its military power enhances its political influence, and that in turn permits it to shape global events in a way that neither Japan nor Germany, still laboring under the stigma of their wartime aggressions and atrocities, can do.
Despite the careless way it has managed its own financial affairs, America's superpower status also enables it to acquire, borrow or print the money it needs to pay for activities it chooses to undertake. And it can mobilize the resources of others through international bodies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
This power to lead and raise financial resources could help pay for the reconstruction of the Soviet economy (or whatever it becomes), arrangements for peace and economic development of the Middle East, and the rescue of the third world from debt and economic decay.
As the British economist D. H. Robertson said 70 years ago, "Money is not such a vital subject as is often supposed." Political power, dependent not only on military and economic strength but also on a nation's reputation for using power with integrity and disinterestedness, outweighs money, which can be created or borrowed.
But only if the powerful does not lose its credibility, whether by careless financial behavior, political ineptitude or moral hypocrisy. If the United States does not succeed in putting its own social and fiscal affairs in better order, it will be that much more difficult for it to lead the way to a new and better world order. Right now, no other country can take its place.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
At Many Papers, Competition Is At Best an Illusion

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
IN a sad reflection of the hard economic times for newspapers, four venerable afternoon papers, in Richmond and Roanoke, Va., San Diego and Charleston, S.C., have recently announced that they will soon join the legion of departed afternoon dailies. The afternoon paper in Newport News was merged into the morning paper in late August. Their demise is illustrative of a newspaper landscape that is being steadily transformed by decades of pressure from rival media and a national life style that has altered reading habits.
Some of the changes are evident in figures that show a drop in the total number of newspapers. But some important breaks with the past are concealed by statistics: in a signficant number of cities, for instance, what seem to be two separate newspapers are actually products of the same reporting staff, with minimal differences in news content. The most dramatic change in the last two decades is the decline in the number of communities with competing papers. 
 The most recent announcements of closings have prompted a round of nostalgia for the languorous pleasure of curling up after supper with the local afternoon daily. According to the common wisdom, the afternoon paper has become a relic of the 1950's, like black-and-white television, the Cleavers and the Hula-Hoop.
In fact, there were still 1,084 afternoon papers in the United States last year, compared with 559 morning papers, according to Editor & Publisher, the authoritative industry magazine. True, there used to be more P.M. dailies. In 1960 there were 1,459 afternoon papers and only 312 morning papers. It is also true that the total afternoon circulation of 21 million is about half the 41 million circulation of morning dailies.
But the average profit margin for afternoon papers almost certainly outstrips that of morning papers. Small papers, which afternoon papers tend to be, often have lower overhead. They tend to be located in small one-paper towns, and for most there is no compelling reason to switch to morning publication.
 
A Dying Breed
 Indeed, what is passing from the contemporary scene is not so much afternoon papers as competing papers in the same community. There are 63 communities with two or more daily newspapers, compared with 172 in 1980, according to John Morton, a newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. And only 12 of them have separately owned, fully competitive rivals, compared with 35 a decade ago. Paramount among these fully competitive markets is New York City, which has four battling dailies, all published in the morning. Other cities with at least two rival papers include Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Houston, Washington and Little Rock, Ark.
Another 20 cities have separately owned papers that have merged in what are called joint operating agreements, in which both papers continue to compete as news organizations but combine advertising, production and circulation departments. Among these cities are Honolulu, Nashville, Detroit and San Francisco.
In the 31 other two-newspaper towns, including Richmond, Newport News, Charleston and San Diego, a single owner publishes both morning and afternoon papers. Until 1980, when there were 115 such situations, the two papers, though commonly owned, were usually fierce rivals with separate news staffs. For instance, at the morning Courier-Journal and the evening Louisville Times in Kentucky, the two staffs worked in the same sprawling room, but they rarely spoke except to needle each other. The right to sneer at the other paper was earned with scoops and hard, fast work and the real beneficiaries, of course, were the readers.
 
Unrivaled Coverage
 But maintaining two news organizations is very expensive and the trend in the 1980's was to merge rival news staffs. The illusion of competition was maintained by continuing to publish the afternoon paper under its own name as though it were independent. The next step was usually to close the afternoon paper altogether.
The news staffs of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times merged in 1985, and The Times has since closed. The news staffs of the morning News and Courier and The Evening Post in Charleston were merged in 1981. Sept. 30 will be The Post's last day of publication.
Two of the few remaining commonly owned, but truly competitive, morning-afternoon combinations are the morning Richmond Times-Dispatch and the evening Richmond News Leader and the morning San Diego Union and evening San Diego Tribune. But the Tribune is scheduled to close early next year, The News Leader next June.
In Louisville, Charleston, Richmond, San Diego and every other city where the afternoon paper has been marked for the junkpile, the owners have argued that a strengthened morning paper will serve readers better. But the appeal of an afternoon paper to loyal readers can be almost irrational, to the amazement of some newspaper companies.
In January, Landmark Communications announced that it was studying whether to discontinue the name of the afternoon Ledger-Star, in Norfolk, Va., and call it by the same name as the morning paper, The Virginian-Pilot. The two news staffs merged in 1982 and both papers now carry the same editorial page. By and large, The Ledger-Star was simply the afternoon edition of The Virginian-Pilot, and everyone knew it.
Sandra Mims Rowe, the executive editor of both papers, said that the plan was eventually to discontinue the afternoon edition. But she said research showed that despite the similarities the papers were perceived to be different. And Ledger-Star readers not only preferred an afternoon paper; they also wanted one with its own identity. In June, Landmark announced that The Ledger-Star would keep its name, and Ms. Rowe said that plans to abandon it have been shelved indefinitely.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
China Takes on the Role of Enemy No. 1 to the West

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
WITH the disintegration of the Soviet Communist regime, a vacancy emerged for the position of "evil empire" for Americans to revile. Now there are signs that China will fill the vacuum and become America's chief ideological adversary and symbol of much that Americans find offensive -- but in a style far different from Moscow's.
This "new cold war" -- as Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, refers to the tensions between China and the West in a document circulating among officials -- is unlike the competition between America and the Soviet Union in some fundamental respects. Beijing does much to offend American values, but does much less to threaten American interests. There are indications that China may be supporting rebels in the Indian state of Assam, part of which China claims as its territory, but in general China appears uninterested in supporting terrorism or in backing insurgencies in Latin America or southern Africa. 
 "I don't think it has a strong inclination to cause mischief around the world," said Kenneth G. Lieberthal, a China scholar at the University of Michigan. "I think right now the Chinese leaders are extremely worried about how China will fit constructively into the world. I don't think this is a leadership that is looking to support international revolution. I don't think this is a leadership that is seeking to disrupt trends toward global stability."
 
'Trying to Lie Low'
 China may annoy the United States by selling weapons to volatile areas, but this is neither new nor rooted in ideology. The army sells weapons for reasons associated not with Communism but with capitalism: its budget is falling as a share of the economy, and it wants to earn hard currency. Nor is China likely to become a rallying point for developing countries. Its ideology and system no longer have much appeal abroad, and it seems ambivalent about whether it really wants to be a leader of the third world. Well-placed Chinese say that in a document stamped "Top Secret" and being distributed to some officials, the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, asserted that China will not try to assume a conspicuous role as rival to the West.
"They're trying to lie low," said a Western diplomat. "They're trying to separate ideology from foreign policy." One reason, no doubt, is that continued growth in trade with the West is a paramount economic need.
Still, a Chinese official recently said that "events may drive us inevitably" to a position of confrontation with the West. In the United Nations Security Council last year, Beijing rather than Moscow stayed aloof from the Western consensus to attack Iraq -- serving notice that China can use its veto to block construction of a new international order on a Western blueprint. China still asserts that Communism will inherit the earth. And the leadership periodically acknowledges that it sees itself in fundamental competition with the West.
"This is a struggle between the two basic adversaries, socialism and capitalism," the People's Daily declared recently. The press asserts several times each day that "enemy forces at home and abroad" are trying to sabotage China. The result is that China has accepted by default the role of spokesman for the diminishing circle of Communist countries. It is also becoming the de facto spokesman for those developing countries that view Western complaints about political prisoners as invasions of local sovereignty.
In fact, there are a number of countries where rights abuses are more pervasive than in China -- Myanmar, formerly Burma, and North Korea, to name two of China's neighbors -- but those countries get less scrutiny. Moreover, most have not elevated repression to an ideology by boasting about "the people's democratic dictatorship" or by trying to debate the West on human rights issues. China's prickliness risks making it a symbol in the 1990's of recalcitrance and repressiveness.
Meanwhile, China's stance makes it clear that any American exultation about "the collapse of Communism" ignores a huge exception. In fact, far more people live under hard-line Communist regimes today than did three years ago: the 290 million Soviets, 16 million Czechs, 17 million East Germans and all the other East Europeans who have discarded Marxism are far outnumbered by the 1.1 billion Chinese who since the Tiananmen Square crackdown of 1989 have endured a born-again Communist regime.
 
A Reversal of Hopes
 And the effect of the crackdown on American-Chinese relations has only been magnified by the reversal of hopes in the West that China was progressing toward democracy. In that sense, the emergence of China as America's chief new adversary on the subject of human rights has as much to do with changes in perceptions as with changes in reality in China over the last three years. The regime then and now imprisoned anyone who challenged the system, then and now occupied Tibet by force, then and now backed the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, then and now sold missiles to third-world countries -- and then and now oversaw improvements in health care and living standards.
"It's a deceived-lover syndrome," suggested a Western ambassador in Beijing. "Too many people had too rosy a picture of China, and now some of these people feel guilty about their innocence and gullibility. So now they're coming back with a vengeance."
Yet to some of China's Western critics, the perception that Beijing is not as threatening as Moscow simply makes it more contemptible. The first thoughts about China that come to mind in the United States these days are likely to be not of cuddly pandas or thriving entrepreneurs, but of tanks and prisons. With the Soviet Union deflated, Iraq defeated and Libya quiescent, no country more than China stands up so brazenly for ideologies and values that most Americans find outdated or evil.

HEADLINE: U.S. Already Lining Up Support for Zionism Move

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
As President Bush considers calling for a repeal of the resolution equating Zionism and racism in his address here on Monday, American diplomats have already begun seeking support for such a move at the General Assembly session now under way, officials involved in the effort say. But they add that it is uncertain whether a repeal move would succeed.
The 12 European Community countries told the United States they would support such an effort, but warned that securing a convincing repudiation of the resolution at the current session would be difficult and carried political risks. 
 A repeal by any margin might help President Bush mend fences with Israel and its supporters in their dispute over housing loan guarantees. But many countries have warned the Administration that if it wishes to demonstrate that the United Nations as a whole has rejected the position it took in 1975, it would need to muster a substantial majority in favor of repeal. Officials have also warned that a repeal measure would run the risk of being watered down by amendments.
But some lawyers argue that as the "Zionism is racism" resolution is one of the few that have never been reaffirmed or recapitulated by the General Assembly in subsequent votes, the organization has already shown that it no longer believes in it.
The measure, one of the most controversial the Assembly has adopted, was passed on Nov. 19, 1975, as Resolution 3379, at the urging of Arab and other third-world countries with support from what was then the Soviet bloc.
The resolution identified Zionism as "a form of racism and racial discrimination" and "most severely condemned" it as "a threat to world peace and security."
That denunciation was supported by 72 members, with 35 opposed, 32 abstaining and 3 countries not taking part in the vote. The United States and all Western countries voted against it, as did a number of developing countries including the Bahamas, Honduras, the Ivory Coast and Uruguay.
The resolution was adopted at a time when third-world members of the General Assembly, backed by the Soviet bloc, were taking an aggressive anti-Western stance, securing the adoption of numerous resolutions critical of Western political and economic beliefs and practices.
Diplomats argue that the collapse of Communism and the more moderate and chastened attitude taken by most developing countries these days is an important reason for pushing for repeal now.
Another is that Israel recently scored a significant political victory at the United Nations when the 54-member Economic and Social Council, representing a cross section of the world's countries, voted overwhelmingly to admit it to the Economic Commission for Europe.
 
Israel Gaining Support
 To the surprise of many Western observers, only the Arab members of the Economic and Social Council voted against Israel, which appled to join the European commission because the Arabs had already refused to admit it to the Economic Commission for Western Asia. Geographically Israel belongs on the Western Asian panel, but the panel's Arab majority has kept it out.
The recent vote was seen by some diplomats as a sign that many developing countries were no longer prepared to vote against Israel on principle and a warning to the Arabs they might find themselves embarrassingly isolated if they opposed repeal of Resolution 3379.
Just how the United States might try to repeal the resolution is also a matter of debate within the Bush Administration, officials say.
A new resolution rescinding or canceling the Assembly's assertion that Zionism is racism would run the risk of being amended in ways that weakened its impact. An alternative approach would be to reintroduce the original resolution equating Zionism and racism and ask the General Assembly to vote it down. But while few countries would vote for such a resolution today, to be convincing this tactic would require a huge no vote and not simply a large body of abstentions.

HEADLINE: The Arithmetic of Help: Israeli Loan Guarantees

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The tense battle between the United States and Israel over loan guarantees began here months ago with a mixture of sober economic projections, dry market analyses and more than a bit of raw, seat-of-the-pants flying.
Israeli officials knew that a huge number of Soviet Jews would be heading their way over the next few years, and a million people seemed like a reasonable forecast. It also had the advantage of being a neat, round figure -- one easy to digest. 
 To absorb so many people, American help was needed in the form of Government loan guarantees. On that score, $10 billion seemed like a reasonable, and conveniently round, figure.
"There's nothing very scientific about it," acknowledged Amos Rubin, economic adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. "You're talking about a wave of immigration, and you don't know how many and how soon."
 
A 5-Year Arrangement
 Of course, Mr. Rubin said, the numbers were far from randomly selected, and when stirred together they translated earlier this month into a formal Israeli request for $10 billion in loan guarantees from the United States.
They would be spread over five years, and would be used to help create jobs, schools, housing, roads, sewerage and other essentials for the masses of Soviet Jews expected to try carving out a new life here.
It all seemed straightforward enough, until President Bush stunned Israeli leaders by declaring that the loan guarantees, which Israel says it must have to avert hard times, would have to take a back seat for now to a hoped-for Middle East peace conference.
His firmness in demanding a delay in Congressional action, and Israel's sharp, at times emotional reaction to a development it had not anticipated, have combined to create one of the nastier disputes in years between this country and its chief ally and benefactor.
 
No Handout, Israel Emphasizes
 What Israel wants, officials here feel they must say again and again, is not a new American handout, something they recognize is not realistic to expect in this time of huge budget deficits in Washington. Rather than loans, they are looking for loan guarantees, which amount to an endorsement by the United States of Israel's credit-worthiness.
Their request is not exactly as cost-free, as some Israelis contend, because by law Washington must set aside some cash as a contingency fund against the possibility of Israeli default. But that is likely to require an outlay in the area of several hundred million dollars, far from $10 billion, and Israel says it is prepared to pay that expense itself.
The real point here for Israel is that, with the United States as its guarantor, it would presumably be able to obtain lower interest rates and more favorable loan terms than it could on its own in borrowing from commercial banks or other financial institutions.
Their country, Israeli officials say, has never defaulted on a loan and is not about to start now. Therefore, they argue, the risk to the United States and the cost to its taxpayers are minimal. But should the assistance be denied, the potential damage to Israel might be considerable.
"The loan guarantees are essential precisely because we know that to absorb the immigrants, we have to encourage mass investment and borrowing," Yaacov Frenkel, governor of the Bank of Israel, said in an interview. "Without them, I've no doubt that unemployment will be much higher and that there will be tremendous suffering among Russian and Ethiopian immigrants."
 
Toting Up the Numbers
 Government economic planners, when they settled last spring on the estimate of a million Soviet Jews by the mid-1990's, calculated that they needed $60 billion to $70 billion to deal with the influx.
More than half of the total, they said, could be paid from internal sources, like domestic borrowing, tax revenue and money from the sale of Government-owned businesses -- part of a privatization program that has yet to get fully off the ground. That left $25 billion to $30 billion to be raised overseas, with most of it expected to come from the sale of Israel Bonds, contributions from Jews and other traditional sources.
But not all of it. The size of the borrowing was so large that it strained Israel's fund-raising abilities. There remained a sizable segment -- $10 billion, it was decided -- to be obtained, and that is what the Israelis hope to raise with the help of United States loan guarantees. Not only would bank interest rates be lower with this American blessing, officials here say, but the loans could be stretched out over the next three decades.
And, they add, they could obtain a 10-year grace period on repayment of the principal, no small matter for a country where a third of the budget is devoted to repaying old debts.
"During the next 10 years, we will need to pay only the interest on the $10 billion," said Dan Halperin, a former Finance Ministry official who now works with a Tel Aviv-based economic consulting firm.
 
New Wrinkle in U.S. Law
 Of concern here is the new United States law requiring the Bush Administration to create a special cash pool to back up the loan guarantees.
In 1975, when New York City asked for similar assistance, it cost the Federal Government nothing. Now, Washington must set aside this reserve fund under a system known as "scoring." It could range anywhere from one-half of 1 percent of the total guarantees -- a set-aside of $50 million in this case -- to 8 percent, or $800 million.
Israeli officials fret that even if the Bush Administration does in time approve the assistance, it might "score" the guarantees uncomfortably high. That, they say, would be interpreted by banks as a message of no confidence and would, in turn, boost interest rates.
As the Israelis see it, they are a better risk than many might think for a country with a lumbering, state-guided economy that relies on American aid, loans and gifts for roughly an eighth of its gross national product.
The negative features of this economy are visible enough. Unemployment is 11 percent and climbing, annual inflation is running at 20 percent, taxes are high and the Government has proved inadequate in meeting the needs of the nearly 350,000 Soviet immigrants who have already arrived during the last two years.
 
Unemployment of the Intelligentsia
 Providing jobs has proved especially elusive, for unlike most immigrant groups, this one is highly educated, filled with physicians, engineers and computer experts. There are simply not enough openings here for all of them. "They have to be productively employed," Mr. Frenkel said. "It's very easy to have them nonproductively employed, but it's a useless way to go."
Yet despite the considerable downside, Israeli officials insist that their credit is good, and Salomon Brothers, the New York-based investment bank, agreed in a report issued this month. Israel should not be lumped among the debt-hobbled, along with Poland and Brazil, the report said, but rather should be seen as comparable to other advanced and democratic countries like Spain, Ireland and New Zealand, all of which have better credit ratings than Israel.
This country's overseas debt of $24 billion, while high, has held steady for several years and now accounts for a shrinking share of the gross national product -- 31 percent last year, according to the Bank of Israel, compared to 64 percent in 1983. "We're far from a situation where the U.S. has to write off $7 billion of debts as it did with Egypt during the war," Mr. Halperin said.
Then again, Israel does have it easier than many borrowers. More than a third of its net foreign debt of $16 billion (subtracting the country's bank deposits and other overseas assets) is in Israel Bonds, generally bought by Jews in other countries who often view their bond purchases as donations. In addition, the regular economic aid received from the United States -- $1.2 billion this year -- goes largely to help Israel repay debts to Washington.
 
A Way to Pare Down the State?
 "In effect, Congress is paying itself back," said Alvin Rabushka, head of economic policy research at the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies in Jerusalem.
Professor Rabushka is a free-market advocate in a society where state controls remain thick. While most economists here forecast great hardships, including higher unemployment and taxes, if the loan guarantees are not approved, he is not persuaded that the requested American assistance is a blessing.
"Israelis like to argue the private sector is so small that it can't absorb all the Soviet Jews, and so the Government must do it," he said. "But the reason the private sector is so small is that the Government of Israel is so large and has prevented the private sector from developing."
"The loan guarantees," Professor Rabushka said, "would continue this trend."

HEADLINE: Neighbors Challenge New York's Tax Reputation

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Recently approved changes in Connecticut's taxes, which will be phased in starting on Oct. 1, are the latest in a series of regional tax increases that could change the competitive dynamics of the New York metropolitan area, accountants and relocation specialists say.
Not only does Connecticut now have an income tax, but last year, New Jersey, which had been relying more heavily than most other states on property taxes, raised its income tax and imposed a surcharge on its business tax. 
 "Both New Jersey and Connecticut have radically different tax structures than they did a year and a half ago," said Jonathan Adams, chief economist at the Real Estate Board of New York.
The end result will be to bring New Jersey and Connecticut more in line with the relatively high tax burden imposed by New York City and New York State, a convergence that will become all the more noticeable when state and local taxes are deducted on Federal tax returns. While some tax specialists predict that this may reduce some of the economic tension among the three states, others think that viewpoint ignores a far larger and more worrisome threat: instead of leaving New York for a neighboring state, businesses and individuals earning high incomes may simply leave the region altogether.
But if one chooses to remain in the region, where is the most favorable tax climate? For individuals, the answer depends on the level of income earned, where they work and whether their towns impose high property taxes. For companies, it depends on the kind of business they are in.
Even so, accountants who regularly analyze the region agree that certain generalizations can be made. From a pure tax standpoint, New York City is still far and away the worst place to live and work.
The state and local income tax bill for a married couple in New York City with two children and a combined income of $100,000 would be $7,481, or more than twice as much as the $3,225 they would pay in the region's most favorable tax location, New Jersey, according to an analysis by Arthur Andersen & Company.
 
An Added Burden
 For businesses, a company with $50 million in income is also at a considerable disadvantage in New York City. Assuming that 20 percent of its income is generated in its home state, the company would pay $2.1 million in New York City, $1.2 million in other localities within New York State, $1.3 million in Connecticut and $941,700 in New Jersey.
Companies in New York City, by contrast, not only have to pay much higher corporate income taxes, they also have to pay a slew of other less visible taxes, like a commercial rent tax and an unincorporated business tax on income derived from partnerships.
"In many cases, when you have a corporate headquarters in New York you pay about twice what you would if your corporate headquarters were in New Jersey," said James P. Sweeney, the northeast regional director for state and local tax services at Arthur Andersen.
Accountants say that determining the optimal location for individuals is also complicated. Families with incomes below $40,000 tend to do best in Connecticut, since the state's new income tax was crafted to fall most heavily on those with higher incomes.
 
The Property Tax Factor
 Many married couples whose income falls between $75,000 and $125,000 would be better off in New Jersey. But once their income gets over $150,000, the tax advantage swings back to Connecticut, where the maximum rate is 4.5 percent, compared with 7 percent in New Jersey. Before 1991, the top rate in New Jersey was 3.5 percent.
This analysis comes with certain caveats. In some towns in New Jersey and Westchester County, property taxes may be so much higher than in Connecticut that they wipe out any advantage from a lower personal income tax.
And the difference between locations becomes more or less moot for individuals working in New York City, because the city and state impose an income tax on all who work within their borders. Since those taxes are typically higher than the applicable income taxes in either New Jersey or Connecticut, and since both states give their residents a credit for New York State taxes, income-tax rates for individuals in Connecticut and New Jersey become much less relevant.
Add to that the fact that both state and local taxes can be deducted from income in figuring Federal taxes and the result is that the tax differences among the three states are no longer so distinct.
"If you run all the numbers, there's less of a tax reason to move from one place to another," said Phil L. Krevitsky, regional tax partner at Ernst & Young.
 
A Minimal Difference
 One Manhattan company that compared the tax rates in New York and Connecticut concluded that when the Federal, state and local rates were combined, the tax burden would be 46.99 percent in New York, compared with 41.59 percent in Connecticut. A comparable calculation for New Jersey yields a tax rate of 40.22 percent.
Theoretically, New York City, which has long been criticized for imposing hefty taxes, should benefit from this merging of tax rates.
"In a psychological sense, New York has been aided," said Carl Weisbrod, president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation. "The sense that somehow you can escape to a tax haven has been reduced, if not eliminated, by the actions of states around the region -- and the entire country."
Perhaps, but that has not stopped businesses from leaving New York. New Jersey's Department of Commerce and Economic Development reports that 40 companies from New York with an average of 115 jobs each expanded their operations or relocated completely to New Jersey in the first half of this year. That is up from 20 for the same period last year.
And the Westchester Business Partnership says that in the last 18 months, more than 110 companies have moved there, the majority of them from Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Long Island.
 
Gauging Quality of Life
 But individuals familiar with the reasons for those moves said they do not think taxes played much, if any, role. In Westchester's case, "quality of life" issues headed the list, said Connie Freid, director of the economic development for the county. And in New Jersey, personal and corporate tax rates are unlikely to be the motivating force since both had just gone up.
"I don't think taxes are as significant an item as people make them out to be, said George R. Zoffinger, commissioner of New Jersey's department of commerce and economic development."
Consider the experience of Datability Inc., a manufacturer of hardware that links computer networks that moved from Manhattan to New Jersey earlier this year. Leslie Shinto, the company's marketing and communications manager, said the company began thinking about leaving New York only when it realized it was expanding so rapidly that it needed more space at an affordable price. It ultimately secured 45,000 square feet of newly refurbished space in Carlstadt, N.J., for the same price it had been paying for 18,000 square feet on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. "Taxes were not a primary consideration," Ms. Shinto said.
The reasoning behind Datability's move reflects that of many other companies, relocation specialists say.
 
Awaiting the Impact
 "Other things being equal, taxes are nowhere near the major consideration," said Ted M. Levine, president of Development Counsellors Inc., which helps local governments attract businesses. "It's probably 10th or 12th on the list." Mr. Levine cited more important factors like the quality and availability of labor, and the proximity to markets and suppliers.
Real-estate brokers in Connecticut say that so far they see no sign that people from Westchester or Long Island are deciding not to move to Connecticut because of the newly imposed income tax, or alternatively, that local residents are rushing to sell their homes and move out.
Even Tom Scott, who waged a vitriolic campaign against the tax changes as the head of the Connecticut Taxpayers' Committee, says he does not know anyone who is thinking of leaving the state, although he attributed that inertia to hopes the tax would be repealed.
Harder to determine is the long-term impact of the new taxes on Connecticut's business climate. Before the latest changes, corporate income taxes in the state were the highest in the country.
 
Southern Alternative?
 Murray Gerber, the chief executive of Prototype and Plastic Mold Company, a plastics manufacturer in Middletown, Conn., plans to move his company from the state.
"I just hung up on a call with my real estate broker," he said. "I'm trying to rent or sell my building and move to where my business can be more competitive." Mr. Gerber, the former chairman of the state's Business and Industry Association, established his company in Connecticut 23 years ago and it now has about 70 employees.
On a recent vacation to Georgia he discovered that state's budget was the same size as Connecticut's, even though it has twice as many residents. He filled his car with gas for 99.9 cents a gallon, compared with at least $1.20 in his home state. He saw beautiful houses for $150,000 to $170,000 that would have cost at least $500,000 back home.
While Mr. Gerber does not know where he will move and has no specific plans to move to Georgia, he insists he is serious about relocating so his company can earn a better profit.
 
Threat to Mid-Atlantic
 Higher taxes, then, may not determine the best place to live and work within the region, but they may make the entire region unattractive. "New York was always a high-tax state, but now with Connecticut and New Jersey raising taxes, it may force people to question whether they want to be in the mid-Atlantic," said David Shulman, who analyzes the real-estate market for Salomon Brothers.
It is a danger public officials in the region seem to recognize. "It's a concern that all of us face," said Mr. Weisbrod, who is in charge of retaining companies in New York City. "I think that is a major threat."
Many economic development agencies in cities and states across the country are working hard to lure companies. They regularly shower companies in high-tax areas like New York, Connecticut and New Jersey with direct mailings that explain the cost-advantages of moving. They typically follow up with a barrage of telephone calls, luncheons and seminars.
Richard Knowlton, president of the Savannah Economic Development Authority in Georgia, says he has seen "a significant increase in the last six months" in interest from companies in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York, and in other high-tax states.
While executives rarely cite taxes specifically among their top reasons for wanting to move, Mr. Knowlton said, "they talk about how hard it is to be successful, and the burden the government is putting on them." His organization is not shy in reminding Connecticut executives about the state's new income tax. "We certainly point out the fact that that advantage is no longer there," he said. "We would definitely use that in our presentation."

HEADLINE: CUOMO TO PROPOSE A STATE TAKEOVER OF MEDICAID COSTS

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to announce next week that he will support a state takeover of the hugely expensive and rapidly growing share of Medicaid costs currently paid by New York City and other local governments, Cuomo administration officials said today. The announcement would be a major policy shift for the Governor, who warned the city three months ago not to expect such a takeover anytime soon.
To negotiate such a takeover and to push it through a politically divided Legislature will require great technical and political dexterity. But Mr. Cuomo's advisers characterized his planned announcement as a significant step intended to build momentum behind the concept. 
 The measure, which would allow the state to receive some tax revenues that now go to localities, could ultimately save more than $1 billion a year for the financially troubled city, although such savings would probably not be realized until the end of the century. The savings for county governments statewide could approach $2 billion by 1999, Cuomo aides said.
 
Future Appears Less Removed
 In mid-July, Mr. Cuomo disappointed Mayor David N. Dinkins by saying that a state Medicaid takeover was "a projection for the removed future." While the Governor never rejected the idea, city officials interpreted his pronouncement as a devastating deflation of their hopes for fiscal relief from the state.
Cuomo administration officials said the Medicaid announcement was to be the centerpiece in a pair of speeches that the Governor would deliver in New York City on Monday night and Tuesday morning. In the speeches, which Cuomo aides are promoting as highly important, Mr. Cuomo plans to propose a variety of legislative and administrative measures that could provide state help to the city.
In addition to the change in Medicaid, the primary government health-care program for the poor, Mr. Cuomo is expected to announce a number of economic development initiatives that would be bankrolled by the state and its public authorities. The proposals may include several transportation and housing construction projects.
 
Relieving Local Governments
 The Governor is also likely to discuss the need to reduce state-imposed requirements on local governments, a reduction called mandate relief, and to suggest a number of fiscal maneuvers that would create cash for the city. He did not return a telephone call to the Executive Mansion today.
Advisers to Mr. Cuomo said he would spend the weekend selecting from a menu of proposals collected by his staff in the last three months. He is to disclose his plans on Monday night to a group of business, union and civic leaders gathered at Mr. Cuomo's request by the New York City Partnership. Reporters will not be admitted to that speech. The Governor will repeat his message at a breakfast sponsored by the Association for a Better New York on Tuesday morning. There are no plans to broadcast either speech.
Cuomo administration officials said the Governor hoped to create a sense of action and recovery after a year in which the city has suffered a deficit of both cash and morale. With budget cuts taking a noticeable toll on basic services and with the violence in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn straining race relations, the city has been seized by an almost tangible malaise.
"What's necessary is to give the city and the world the sense that things are happening, that New York's not going down the toilet," said Meyer S. Frucher, a former Cuomo aide and frequent adviser to the Governor. "That's the significance. It's important that there's a sense out there that the forces are coalescing."
Because of Mr. Cuomo's delicate relationship with the Dinkins administration, the Governor's task is a politically sensitive one. Aides said Mr. Cuomo knows that he must not appear to be upstaging Mr. Dinkins, a longtime friend and the first black mayor of a city where most residents are members of minority groups. The two men discussed Mr. Cuomo's proposals by telephone today.
In July, shortly after the state and city had both approved excruciatingly difficult budgets, tensions between the Cuomo and Dinkins administrations reached a peak. The Governor made it clear he was annoyed by a memorandum written by First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and later leaked to the press that suggested that the city did not want the state's advice on its plans for reorganization.
Cuomo administration officials have drafted the Governor's proposals with little advice from either the city or the Legislature. City officials were briefed on the broad elements of Mr. Cuomo's ideas last week, including the Medicaid takeover.
 
Dinkins Aide Praises Idea
 Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said today that "any move in that direction would be well received."
New York City's Medicaid costs for the current year are estimated at approximately $2 billion, and they are expected to increase at an annual rate of nearly 15 percent. The growth in the program has been driven by a rapid increase in the city's welfare rolls that has accompanied the economic downturn.
The Federal Government pays half of all Medicaid costs, which currently total $12 billion in New York State. New York is one of the few states that requires local governments to share the remaining cost, and the 25 percent share that the state requires of its counties is the highest in the country.
The cost-sharing arrangement puts severe strain on the budgets of urban counties, where most Medicaid recipients live, and that burden tends to grow at times of economic distress, when local governments can least afford to shoulder it.
The Cuomo administration officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the Governor's proposed takeover of the local share of Medicaid costs would be phased in and would be completed by the year 2000.
They said Mr. Cuomo would propose financing the takeover through a "tax swap," in which a share of local taxing authority would be transferred to the state. The officials said the trade would involve the personal income tax in New York City, and the sales tax in all other counties.
The Governor's embrace of a tax swap, which has been championed by the Citizens Budget Commission and other civic groups, represents a shift from the position he took last July.He argued then that the only way the state could afford a Medicaid takeover was "to raise a huge tax -- and that just isn't going to happen."
Under the tax swap concept, local governments would profit over the long term because the growth in Medicaid costs would probably outpace the growth in revenue generated by the taxes that would be sacrificed.
State officials would hope, meanwhile, that an economic recovery would increase tax revenues while paring the Medicaid rolls. And the state would insist that a variety of measures be adopted to contain Medicaid costs.
Mr. Cuomo, the Republican-led State Senate, and the Democratic-controlled Assembly have proposed a number of such initiatives in recent years, ranging from eliminating some services covered by Medicaid to reducing reimbursement rates to hospitals and nursing homes. But because of different views between the houses, many of the proposals have not been adopted.
"Until we see Medicaid costs that are closer to a more manageable rate of growth, we couldn't consider a takeover," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "We wouldn't rule it out, but our priority continues to be Medicaid reform."
Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said that cost containment would be critical to the success of any takeover.
 
'It Has This Horrendous Growth'
 "The very reason we want to get rid of it is the same reason the state doesn't want to take it over," he said. "In addition to being so expensive, it has this horrendous growth to it. And once the state takes it over, it has it forever."
Although some small counties have Medicaid costs that are infinitesimal compared to New York City's, Mr. Crawford predicted that all county governments would support a state takeover. "The rate of growth in Medicaid is about the same upstate and downstate," he said.
But even within the Cuomo administration, some officials said they were skeptical that small counties would endorse the proposal. Such a refusal, they said, could cause political problems in the Senate, which is dominated by Republicans from upstate and Long Island.
"I don't know how eager they're going to be about a takeover that primarily benefits cities with large numbers of poor people," said one administration official. "And even in New York City, I think the reaction will be that it's not enough."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
A Long, Painful Road for Expos

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Dave Dombrowski and the Expos have left Montreal. The Expos should return next season. Dombrowski won't.
The Expos returned to Montreal last week after an unexpected road trip to New York and Philadelphia. They had planned on playing Chicago at Olympic Stadium this weekend, but they took another unexpected trip -- to Chicago. In fact, they will be on a road trip the rest of the season, traveling from Chicago to St. Louis to Pittsburgh to St. Louis to Pittsburgh. 
 Barring rainouts, the Expos will have played their last 25 games in other teams' parks. Structural problems with Olympic Stadium forced the impromptu journey. First, a 55-ton concrete beam fell from the side of the stadium. Then engineers found beams that they thought should be reinforced. It was indignity piled on ineptitude for the worst team in the National League East.
As if the Expos didn't offer a close enough resemblance to a sinking ship, Dombrowski fled to Florida and not just on a season-ending road trip. The 35-year-old general manager opted to take that job with the expansion Marlins.
Dombrowski, of course, had to receive permission to speak with the Marlins, and Claude Brochu, the Expos' president, granted it. The decision seemed strange, considering that only last year Dombrowski and the Expos received various individual and organization awards and earlier this year Brochu extended the general manager's contract through next year.
"Dave and I had an understanding," Brochu explained. "If he had an opportunity which he particularly wanted to explore, I would let him do so. We agreed to that sometime back. When Carl Barger asked for permission, when I spoke to Dave about it, he said he would like to explore it. I had to live by our agreement."
Furthermore, Brochu said, he felt the club had a good replacement in Dan Duquette, who had served as assistant general manager for two years.
Immediate speculation about Dombrowski's departure centered on a falling out between him and Brochu. The men, however, had a good working relationship and were friends.
Dombrowski, however, had become uncomfortable with the economic constraints that the new ownership placed on the baseball operation. One Montreal man close to Dombrowski said that the young executive found it difficult establishing himself among his older, more experienced peers and felt almost embarrassed by some of the moves he had to make because of the restrictions.
For example, he traded Tim Burke to the Mets for Ron Darling knowing that he would have to turn around and trade Darling because of his salary. In his 16 days with the Expos, Darling became an instant hit in Montreal because unlike other eligible free agents, he talked about wanting to stay.
Also, Dombrowski, for the first time in his three-year tenure, was being criticized by the Montreal news media, starting with his giveaway trade of Otis Nixon to Atlanta. He reacted much like Joe McIlvaine did in New York when he began to suffer criticism for the Juan Samuel trade. McIlvaine left the Mets for San Diego and now Dombrowski has departed Montreal for Miami.
Will any other members of the Expos's front office follow? The word among colleagues from other clubs is that Dombrowski would like to take Gary Hughes, the scouting director; Frank Wren, the assistant scouting director, and John Boles, the player development director.
"Why not, while you're at it?" Brochu said, laughing. "All these people are under contract with us through '92. We made an arrrangement with Carl Barger and David that any approaches would be completely confidential. We'll decide as a club if we will let them talk to these people. It would be a little difficult in one fell swoop to replace them all internally. We would probably have to go outside if we elected to do that. We'll be pretty tough about it. If it's going to harm us in any way, shape or form, we won't do it."
 
Politics Oust the Astros
 The Expos's unplanned journey without end rivals the tour of America the Houston Astros have planned for next season. The Astros will vacate the Astrodome for 28 days so it can host the Republican National Convention.
Richard Griffin, media relations director for the Expos, noted the two trips and said: "The last 28 days on the road and we don't even have a Republican convention in our ball park. We don't even have Republicans. We have Liberals, Conservative and N.D.P. -- New Democratic Party."
 
Blacks Out of the Picture
 Dombrowski and Duquette got new jobs last week, and so did John Hart, who was named general manager of the Cleveland Indians. Not long before, Whitey Herzog was given that role with the California Angels. This week, the Colorado Rockies will name their general manager.
Just like that, the major leagues have five new general managers, and they still don't have a black general manager. (Two club presidents were also named recently, and they weren't members of minority groups either.)
Unless they did it secretly, the two expansion teams didn't even interview a black candidate. Secretly or otherwise, they didn't interview Bob Watson, the Astros' very capable assistant general manager and the most experienced black executive in a front office.
"No one asked permission to talk to me," Watson said. "The job would have been a tremendous challenge, and I would like to have at least been considered for that challenge. I would like to have been a part of the interviewing process to let people know what my thoughts are and get my name out there. But that didn't happen. That's baseball."
The people doing the hiring, Watson added, have to entrust their business to the people they hire. "Owners don't feel they can trust minorities," he said. "John McMullen felt he wanted to give me the opportunity. I appreciate it."
The two expansion teams apparently interviewed separate lists of candidates, although Steve Ehrhart of the Rockies said it was not planned that way. The Marlins interviewed Dombrowski, Bill Lajoie of Atlanta and Doug Melvin of Baltimore. The Rockies met with Walt Jocketty of Oakland, Ralph Nelson of San Francisco, Duquette, Joe Klein of Kansas City and Mike Port, formerly of California.
Ehrhart said the Rockies spoke by telephone with Herzog, Dallas Green, Jack McKeon and Murray Cook, all former general managers, but they didn't have in-person interviews.
 
The Free Agent 8

When Gary Carter catches -- against most left-handed pitchers -- the Dodgers have a starting eight that consists totally of imported talent. Carter, Brett Butler and Darryl Strawberry were signed as free agents. The Dodgers acquired Eddie Murray, Kal Daniels, Juan Samuel, Alfredo Griffin and Mike Sharperson in trades.
Discussing the dearth of homegrown talent, General Manager Fred Claire said: "We have a commitment. We want to be competitive, so we've turned to free agents and trades and we've been competitive. But we've worked hard at player development. I believe in our young talent."
The Dodgers have long been considered one of the most fertile organizations for homegrown players, but they also have a reputation for overvaluing their prospects, luring other teams into giving better players than necessary for them in trades. Claire, however, seems to be more realistic than his predecessor, Al Campanis.
"We're not overloaded," Claire said. "There isn't a club in baseball that has a surplus of young talent. A surplus? No. But a future? I believe we have a future."
Asked to list the players closest to making it in or to the majors, Claire named catcher Carlos Hernandez, first baseman Eric Karros, shortstop Jose Offerman, third baseman Dave Hansen, centerfielder Tom Goodwin, left fielder-first baseman Henry Rodriguez and pitchers Pedro Martinez, Jamie McAndrew and Mike James (starters) and John Wetteland and Zakary Shinall (relievers).
Martinez is the 20-year-old brother of the Dodgers' Ramon Martinez. A right-hander, the younger brother compiled an 18-8 record and 2.28 earned run average as he rocketed through the Dodgers' system this year, from A to AA to AAA.

HEADLINE: Chicago Treats 47 in Congress to a Free Weekend

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
At a reception for influential out-of-town guests on Friday, with the ting of wine glasses filling the room, Mayor Richard M. Daley chuckled at how well things were going during this city's first "Congressional Weekend."
A few months earlier, the Mayor had invited the entire United States House of Representatives here for an all-expenses-paid weekend to show off Chicago and to push his Federal spending wish list. All the lawmakers had to do was show up; the city was paying for everything with hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from local corporations. 
 On Thursday, 47 Representatives, many accompanied by spouses, arrived here, including Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington. And for the rest of the weekend, they are being entertained.
 
Baseball and a Boat Ride
 By this evening, the Mayor had taken them on a boat ride and to a baseball game. On Friday, he took a select group on a helicopter tour of the city, so he could push his dream of a third airport for Chicago.
Wedged in with the sightseeing, there has been criticism. Dick Simpson, a former city alderman who plans to run for Congress next year, called the visit "a four-day boondoggle that is nothing more than a corporate funded weekend vacation."
While there is nothing wrong with members of Congress coming to Chicago on "a real fact-finding mission," Mr. Simpson said, "the agenda is packed with private cocktail parties, private gourmet dinners and a breakfast at a private club," he said. "If they were on a genuine investigation attempt, they would have met some of Chicago's 80,000 unemployed or the children who can't get into the underfunded Headstart program or the families victimized by the highest murder rate in Chicago's history."
 
The Top Destination
 The Chicago weekend came just seven days after Public Citizen, a research organization founded by the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, issued a report that said House members accepted nearly 4,000 trips in 1989 and 1990 that were paid for by corporations or trade groups. Chicago was the top destination.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat and the co-host of the Congressional weekend, is one of Mr. Simpson's potential opponents next year.
Before this weekend's visit, Mr. Rostenkowski sought the advice of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, which said the trip was within House guidelines because the city is paying for it.
While not one dime of city money is being spent, Chicago is paying for the weekend with the more than $330,000 donated by corporations, according to a mayoral spokeswoman.
Mr. Daley and the lawmakers shrugged off the criticism and scoffed at the very mention of the "J" word -- junket.
"I get criticism all the time," Mr. Daley said. "They get it all the time. It comes with the territory."
The Mayor said one reason he wanted the representatives to come to Chicago was to see first hand the problems facing urban America.
 
Glitter and Flash
 Asked why the representatives were largely shown the city's glitter and the flash and were kept far away from some of the neighborhoods that have become killing fields, Mr. Daley said "they see it everyday in their own districts."
"I'm basically trying to promote Chicago," Mr. Daley said. "We have to rebuild America. America spends too much time on international issues and not enough time on problems in America."
Representative Howard Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, said the weekend was "a very useful way to expose us to the issues that are being faced by urban communities everywhere."
"This country for too many years has abandoned any kind of urban agenda," he said.
 
'A Fact-Finding Mission'
 Blowing a cloud of cigarette smoke toward the ceiling of a dining hall where his colleagues were finishing lunch on Friday, Representative William O. Lipinski of Chicago, said, "I wouldn't call this a junket at all."
"I don't even know what junkets are," he said. "This is a fact-finding mission."
Nearby, Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana, telephoned his district office. For Mr. Jefferson, a first-term Congressman, the weekend was an opportunity to get to know his colleagues and "the issues" better and a chance to visit his relatives. He has two aunts and three sisters in the city.
"I saw them last night," he said Friday afternoon. "I talked to them about their impressions of the city and its problems. They wanted to make sure I saw both sides of town; folks who are doing well and folks who aren't. But I suppose the idea of these things is to show us the progress a city is making."
 
Visits to Other Cities
 Mr. Jefferson said he went on a similar weekend visit to New York City last spring. Congressional weekends have also been held in Detroit and Philadelphia.
"In New York, we saw the typical tourist sites," he said. "The bus trips took us through some depressed areas but on the way to somewhere else."
When asked if he thought this trip was a junket, a whirlwind of parties and free lunches, he sighed.
"We always get the heat and the fire," he said. "If we listen to that, we'll always stay home. To think we could become the slave of an industry because someone helped us with a plane ticket is absurd."
A few minutes later, Mr. Jefferson was one of only 13 representatives to go on a bus tour of an industrial park and ice cream flavoring plant, where they were given small boxes of chocolate covered almonds.
And as the bus headed back to the hotel, a Congressman said, "I wanted some ice cream."

HEADLINE: Late but Eager, '92 Democrats Assemble

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21

 BODY:
With a blast at President Bush, a blithe dismissal of the polls and some blunt rejections of politics as usual, the Democrats who would be President assembled here today and began, in earnest, the scramble for the nomination.
"Welcome to what is clearly the start of the 1992 campaign," declared a beaming Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "It feels good, doesn't it?' 
 The seven candidates and potential candidates here today were speaking to an important group: The 413 members of the Democratic National Committee are automatic delegates to next year's nominating convention and play crucial roles in party circles. Party leaders have waited, with some anxiety, for a field to present itself, and they were ready to be wooed -- at cocktail parties and hallway huddles and at today's formal committee meeting, which was the first full-blown cattle show of the 1992 campaign.
 
'Passport Presidency'
 Mr. Brown set the tone with a swipe at President Bush, asserting that he was conducting a "passport Presidency" focused strictly on international affairs. The men running for President, or contemplating a run, quickly took up the attack, particularly Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa.
Mr. Harkin, who announced his candidacy last week, scoffed that "we've never had a drought as long as this one," waiting for "trickle-down economics" to trickle down. Mr. Harkin, running as the standard-bearer of traditional Democratic liberalism, asserted that Mr. Bush "loves having his picture taken with working people" and boasted of eating pork rinds to show his empathy with the working class.
But all the posing, Mr. Harkin asserted, will be unavailing.
Mr. Harkin offered himself as the unashamed, guilt-free, true-believing Democrat in a field that includes several candidates who argue that the party must change. "I'm going to run as a Democrat," Mr. Harkin said. "I know who I am. I know what I am."
Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has argued that the party needs to refashion its appeal to the middle class, called for a philosophy that stresses opportunity, responsibility and community. He talked of his own humble roots, which were nevertheless always infused with hope, and contrasted that background with the poor children growing up today in the inner cities.
"For 23 years, since Robert Kennedy died, except for a brief interlude in the late 1970's, the Democratic Party has failed in its historic responsibility to protect the American dream," he said. "Our generation of Democrats can reclaim that role."
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, suddenly back at the center of Presidential speculation, delivered a rousing appeal for the party to remember its responsibility to aid working people, to reorder Federal spending priorities to emphasize domestic needs, to "love our troops when they are no longer troops," and to show it with housing and education and jobs.
Mr. Jackson, who was long expected to sit out the 1992 race but has recently said he was giving serious consideration to a third campaign, also reminded the party of its responsibilities to minorities. "If we fought for our minority members, who represent part of the substance of our party, as the Republicans have fought for Clarence Thomas, who is simply a symbol for them, we'd have an even playing field and all would prosper," he said.
 
Attack on Special Interests
 Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who is still exploring a race for the nomination, delivered a scathing attack on contemporary politics and the influence of special interest money on it. The Democratic Party, he asserted, could choose to deliver itself to the "bondage" of special interest money or it could choose to break those ties and ally with the people.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts reflected the sudden cockiness of the Democrats in defiance of the pundits and polls. "George Bush, this is the first day of the end of your presidency," he declared as he took the stage.
Mr. Tsongas, who announced his candidacy last spring and was the only candidate in the race for several months, attacked Mr. Bush as a man without a core. "George Bush says he's for civil rights," Mr. Tsongas said. How do you make the journey, "if you have a core, from that statement to Willie Horton," Mr. Tsongas demanded. He was referring to the black convicted murderer whose case was frequently cited by Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign, a strategy that was widely criticized as appealing to racial fears.
Mr. Tsongas ended his speech with a poignant account of how his successful battle with cancer had changed his attitude toward life and politics, and made him begin to think of the obligations that one generation has to another. The policies of the present Administration, he said, were "generationally immoral."
Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, the most recent Democrat to begin exploring a run for the nomination, used today's speech to assail both parties and cast himself as a truth-teller speaking out for the middle class.
"George Bush, I've got a message for you," Mr. McCurdy said in remarks prepared for delivery. "If you take credit for the collapse of Communism, a 40-year process that happened to culminate on your watch, then you must also take credit for the failed savings and loan. You must take credit for tripling the national debt."
As is often the case at Democratic National Committee meetings, there were subplots. Much of the buzz was around Mr. Jackson. Some of his supporters expressed concern over maintaining their influence and roles in the party if Mr. Jackson does not run.
Former Mayor Larry Agran of Irvine, Calif., also spoke to the committee today.

HEADLINE: Many Black Voters Face Quandary Over '92 Race

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Bruce Lightner, the Raleigh, N.C., businessman who organized home-state Presidential campaigns for the Rev. Jesse Jackson in 1984 and 1988, is still waiting for his call to action this year.
Like other politically active black voters across the country, he is in something of a quandary as the 1992 election campaign finally gets underway and two leading black figures -- one declared, one not -- hover at the edges of Presidential contention. 
 Faced with a sudden array of Democratic choices, a shortened campaign season and the absence so far of the single well-known candidate who has laid claim to minority support in the past two Presidential contests, there are no sure predictions of where usually reliable black Democrats will turn.
"Like most people, for us it's going to be a feeling-out process on all these candidates," Mr. Lightner said.
 
Not So Sure for '92
 Mr. Jackson said last week that he was actively considering a third Presidential run this year. But Mr. Lightner, who brought Mr. Jackson to within a few percentage points of besting Senator Albert Gore in North Carolina's 1988 primary by delivering a concentrated black vote to the polls, is dubious.
He also said he did not plan to withhold his support in the hope that Mr. Jackson will make a late entry into the race.
"I think he has made his intentions clear," he said of Mr. Jackson. "If he was going to do something, I would like to think he would have made that known at least to his closest supporters by now."
Many black politicians have long insisted that black voters should not be treated as a monolithic, liberal voting bloc that will automatically support Democratic candidates.
But the altered campaign scenario, and particularly Mr. Jackson's role in it, has spurred anxious debate among elected black Democrats who are searching out a power niche in 1992.
 
Wilder's Route
 L. Douglas Wilder, the Governor of neighboring Virginia and the nation's first black elected state chief executive, has already begun his campaign, trying to stake out a more conservative middle ground that de-emphasizes race.
"Doug Wilder would like very much to simply have the issue of his control of the black vote accepted as a given," said Milton Morris, director of research for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group on black issues. "But it's not likely that Jesse is going to allow Doug Wilder to just inherit black community support."
Representative Charles Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, is one of the leading black Democrats who has urged Mr. Jackson to consider a 1992 campaign. Without Mr. Jackson involved, he said, black voters might choose from among any of the remaining Democrats or, more importantly, choose "not to get involved at all."
After a meeting Mr. Jackson held last weekend with his advisers, other Jackson supporters were speculating openly about the possibility that Mr. Jackson could run. But some suggested that he might sit out the election and use his influence over the voters who have supported him to steer events during primary season.
 
Broker in the Past
 Mr. Jackson has relished his role as a broker in the past. In 1984, Walter F. Mondale waited anxiously until Labor Day before Mr. Jackson endorsed him. And in 1988, a widely publicized rift between Mr. Jackson and Michael S. Dukakis never fully healed, even after Mr. Jackson took to the road to campaign for the Democratic nominee, but not with him, in the general election campaign.
Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, a leading Jackson supporter, said it would take other candidates a long time to gain the sort of name recognition that Mr. Jackson already has.
"Should he choose not to run, the Democratic party can't win without him assisting," Representative Waters said. "Whether he is able to assist the Democratic Party depends on the Democratic Party's ability to work with Jesse."
Mr. Jackson's most committed supporters have not abandoned the hope that he might yet run, now that he has postponed his plans to be host of a Cable News Network talk show. An internal memorandum sent to Mr. Jackson by his chief aide, Frank Watkins, assessed his chances and concluded that Mr. Jackson could build on his 1988 base to win the primary and go on to defeat President Bush.
 
'This Is Open Season'
 But that strategy was delineated more than a month ago and relied on two crucial elements: that the California primary would be moved to earlier in the primary season and provide Mr. Jackson with an early boost, and that Mr. Jackson could transform the issue of statehood for the District of Columbia into a national theme.
A bill to move up the California primary was killed by state lawmakers this month.
Other advisers, like Ronald Walters, chairman of the political science department at Howard University, predict that Mr. Jackson would have a difficult time mounting a credible candidacy much later than next month.
"This is open season," he said. "The one thing he can't afford to do is jump out into a weak field and fail."
Both Governor Wilder and Mr. Jackson have expressed extreme distaste for any lineup that pits them against each other. Mr. Wilder, who has seized on economic issues and touted his success as a budget-balancing Governor, is more eager to be likened to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a moderate.
 
Similarities to Harkin
 And Jackson supporters see greater similarities between their candidate and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a liberal who emphasizes the plight of working people.
But Dr. Morris of the Joint Center said that black voters, like voters of other races and ethnic groups, tend to support candidates of their own group and are more likely to choose between Mr. Wilder and Mr. Jackson.
He said Mr. Harkin, who comes from a predominantly white state, is not familiar to many black voters. "I think it's going to take a while before anyone realizes, hey, this guy sounds like Jesse," he said.
By the time that happens, some speculated, it could already be too late for Mr. Jackson to lay claim to supporters who were with him in 1988.
"He needs to know that as the parade gets going, people will eventually put their floats in it," said Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn, a 1988 Jackson supporter who is chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. "They'll wait for a little while, but they're not going to let the parade get too far down the street before they join."
