HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Secret Plan for Israel

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
President Bush tested his strength against Congress and the Israeli lobby and won. There will be no vote on loan guarantees to resettle Soviet Jews in Israel until January, though no one yet wants to say so publicly.
But the President's victory in this brief, bloody, ugly and unnecessary battle will spiral into a sinkhole of unrealistic Arab demands and unquenchable Israeli suspicions -- unless he moves now to restore harmony with Israel. 
 He need look no further than a secret plan already floating around his office that would allow him to submerge the bitter quarrel over loan guarantees into the broader peace process, which is what he and the Israelis should have done before they squared off two weeks ago.
There is no easy way to finesse the money guarantee issue by itself. Prime Minister Shamir will not agree to freeze Israeli settlements on the West Bank and Gaza Strip in order to get the guarantees. Mr. Bush will not say yes to the money without the freeze.
The plan would bury concessions on the volatile freeze-guarantees issue in a larger package and use the lure of worldwide guarantees exceeding $20 billion to generate a political force for compromise in Israel. Its central premise is that Washington has to be both more generous to and more demanding of Israel.
Israel would receive: a $10 billion U.S. loan guarantee (though it would have to be appropriated at $2 billion annually rather than all at once as Israel wants); another $10 billion in guarantees from West European countries (including $5 billion from Germany) plus Japan, and Washington would provide hundreds of millions in guarantees for private investment in Israel. Few taxpayer dollars would be required, unlike the yearly $4 billion U.S. aid program.
In return Israel would suspend settlement activity in the West Bank and Gaza Strip without qualification. At the same time, Arab nations would suspend their boycott on trading with Israel, and the Palestinians would suspend their uprising in the occupied territories.
The aim of all this is an early Israeli-Palestinian agreement for limited Palestinian autonomy in these territories.
Obviously the plan contains an unexploded time bomb. The U.S. would surely keep pushing Jerusalem to cede land for peace, although the Administration has promised to oppose a separate Palestinian state. Such larger questions, however, are for another, later time.
It is hard to believe that Israel would turn down a chance to finance Soviet immigration and its economic future in exchange for simply stopping the disputed settlements. But it might do exactly that unless there is a shake-up in the power balance inside the ruling Likud bloc.
The plan tries to deal with that problem too. The idea is to make the aid offer so attractive that moderate Likudniks will force Mr. Shamir to say yes and break with Ariel Sharon, the Housing Minister and mastermind behind the drive for settlements.
Administration officials know this is a long shot, but also see it as their only shot. Mr. Sharon and Mr. Shamir both want to keep hold of the territories, and both are prepared to play hardball with Washington. But Mr. Shamir, they think, is not willing to strain ties with the U.S. to the point of losing his prime ministership.
And as Administration officials see it, Mr. Shamir is strong enough now to hold onto that job even if Mr. Sharon bolts. They reckon that the other right-wing factions would stay in the Shamir Government rather than walk out with Mr. Sharon and face the prospect of losing seats in an election. And it is pretty clear that the opposition Labor Party would also go along with a Shamir-led minority government rather than enter elections when Labor popularity is so low.
Administration officials say Mr. Bush now feels he has redressed the power balance with Congress and the Israeli lobby, and that he does not want to lord his success -- or risk losing it.
That leaves him free to think about the plan near his hands, about making Israel an offer it cannot refuse, about a vision so compelling that conservative Israelis will be willing to forgo their corrosive scheme of incorporating the occupied territories into Greater Israel and focus on the nobler dream of resettling millions of Soviet Jews in a merely great Israel.

HEADLINE: Threat to Veto Israeli Guarantee Imperils Talks;
Never Defaulted Yet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Cut Aid Now" (letter, Sept. 10), on the loan guarantee requested by Israel, Glenn Bering's reference to "the almost inevitable default on this loan" is baffling to anyone familiar with Israel's record on loan payments: Israel has never defaulted on a loan, even during times of great crisis in its economy and threats to its security. The guarantees are likely to cost the United States taxpayer not the ridiculous figure Mr. Bering suggests, but nothing at all, aside from negligible administrative costs. 
 Mr. Bering also refers to the settlement of Soviet Jews "in the United Nations-mandated Palestinian state under Israeli occupation." A minuscule proportion of Soviet and Ethiopian immigrants to Israel are settled in the West Bank.
More important, Mr. Bering fails to explain why the Palestinian state proposed by the United Nations in the 1947 partition plan (which called for the division of the British-ruled area between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea into two states, one Jewish and one Palestinian) never came into existence.
The leaders of the Zionist movement embraced that proposal, which allowed for the establishment of Israel in 1948. The rejection of this compromise by Arab leaders, and the subsequent invasion of Israel by seven Arab armies led to an Israeli victory and the failure of the initiative to form a Palestinian state. This has had tragic consequences for both Arab and Jew, but Mr. Bering's implication that Israel prevented the formation of that state is wrong.
The Shamir Government's policy of creating settlements in the West Bank may well harm the peace process and go against Israel's best interests; indeed, many Israeli political and military figures have been saying that for some time. Thus it may be justifiable for the United States, as a loyal but firm friend of Israel, to pressure the Shamir Government to halt those settlements in return for a concession from the Arab states, such as the ending of the Arab-led economic boycott of Israel by Western companies.
 
BENJAMIN D. SOMMER
Hillsdale, N.J., Sept. 11, 1991

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 15-20

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A.T.& T. Admits the Human Error Was on Management's Side 

When a switching station went out in Manhattan last week it sent the entire region into conniptions. Hundreds of flights had to be diverted as the region's airports closed. Five million long-distance calls were blocked. It was the third major shutdown of A.T.& T.'s long-distance service in less than two years. This time, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company cited human error. An inattentive crew failed to notice when a generator switched off, said Robert Garnet, a company spokesman. Union officials countered that it was the alarms that failed. Grudgingly, A.T.& T admitted management and technical lapses. This did not go unnoticed by its biggest rival. "A.T.& T. has described its system as self-healing and fully redundant," said Daniel F. Akerson, executive vice president of MCI, which came out with a new ad campaign in response. "Clearly it's not. Their reliability is more advertised than delivered."
 
Where Will the Chips Fall?
 
It may not be Operation Desert Storm, but the potato chip wars are heating up. After years of offering coupons and other promotional deals rather than cheaper prices, Frito Lay Inc., the nations No. 1 snack-food maker, has shifted strategies to win back market share lost to No. 2 Borden Inc. and No. 3 Eagle Snacks, a subsidiary of the Anheuser-Busch Companies. To do that, the division of Pepsico Inc. said it will cut costs. First, 1,800 jobs will go, saving the company $100 million. Those dismissals will mean a $91 million charge against Pepsico's third-quarter earnings. Which salty-snack maker will fare best? "It's a war and they are all bleeding," said Max Busetti, editor of the Food Industry Newsletter.
 
Salomon Raids the Piggy Bank
 
The scandal at Salomon Brothers Inc. tarnished its credit rating as well as its name. Though its rating is still higher than half of corporate America's, it is lower than Salomon's more reputable competitors. That makes it more difficult for Salomon to raise money cheaply in a business where profits are squeezed from fractions of basis points. Last week, Salomon disclosed that it had begun dipping into its rainy-day fund of securities, which may be worth as much as $15 billion. By selling securities to raise capital -- and agreeing to buy them back -- Salomon has set up an alternative to issuing commercial paper until Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Treasury Department and the 33 state regulators investigating the firm say it has cleaned up its act. That may take time.
 
The B-2's Fading Purpose
 
The Northrop Corporation's B-2 radar-evading Stealth bomber is a plane without a mission. With Communism in collapse, there may be no need to sneak in under Soviet radar to drop a cache of bombs. But last week Congress learned that the Stealth's lack of mission may not be its only problem: in tests, the big B-2 showed up on radar. For Northrop, that is a big problem. With the Pentagon's budget shrinking, the B-2 was ailing Northrop's last cash cow. The Air Force said it wanted up to 75 planes -- worth about $60 billion -- and has ordered 15. But the B-2 is in real trouble in Congress. "We are not going to give a blank check to the program," said Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska. Even without a blank check, Congress is in the hole for $30 billion on the B-2. Some fear that if the B-2 disappears, Northrop will drop off the scope as well.
 
G.E. Plays It Safe
 
Among the nation's biggest corporations, the General Electric Company -- with its high-tech emphasis -- is something of a risk taker. But last week G.E. showed itself to be very prudent. It announced it would take a $1.8 billion charge to cover medical and benefits obligations to future retirees. Most companies have until Jan. 1, 1993, to take the hit. G.E. decided to take it early.
 
Dirty Diaper Business
 
The rivalry between Toys "R" Us Inc. and Child World Inc. has reached a new level. Now they are fighting over, well, diapers. To lure customers into its stores, Child World announced a special on disposable diapers. But last week Child World said it learned employees from Toys "R" Us were slipping into its stores, loading up on diapers and reselling them. Child World threatened to sue Toys "R" Us. Child World was tipped off to the caper when three men in suits drove up to a Houston store and bought $100 worth of diapers each. Either something was fishy, or those three men had some baby.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
The Laggard Services Sector
 
If the future lies in services, as most economists are quick to say, the United States is in trouble. Economic growth in August was centered in mining and manufacturing. According to the Federal Reserve Board, factory and mine output rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in August. Though the gains were modest, this sector showed more vigor than the rest of the economy. "The manufacturing sector is the only area where we're seeing much strength," said David Wyss, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill.

When Spending Hurts
 
As consumers rouse from their recessionary slumber, they are beginning to spend. Trouble is, as they do, more boatloads of goods are coming stateside. According to the Commerce Department, imports exceeded exports by $5.9 billion in July. That was the largest monthly trade deficit since January and was an increase of 55.6 percent over June's figure.
 
Housing Recover Falters
 
For the nation's home builders, six months of interest-rate cuts have not been enough to keep the recovery from sputtering. According to the Commerce Department, housing starts were up by a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain in three months. The number of new permits issued also fell 4.9 percent, which signals even fewer construction starts in the months ahead. Since new construction fuels growth in other areas -- plumbing, furnishings, labor and even banking and insurance -- analysts looking at the figures were disappointed. "These numbers show a housing recovery losing steam, at least through August," said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Society in New York.
 
Perfect Resume for the R.T.C.?
 
Albert V. Casey, a former chairman of American Airlines and of First Republic Bank of Dallas, is now expected to fill one of L. William Seidman's jobs. Mr. Seidman is retiring next month as head of both the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Mr. Casey -- known as a tough manager -- is the leading candidate to head the R.T.C. The R.T.C. will manage the savings and loan bailout on a day-to-day basis. Mr. Casey has at least one qualification for the job few others could boast. Shortly after he became chairman of First Republic, it went under. It was one of the costliest bank failures in history.
 
The General Accounting Office said the savings and loan bailout will cost $191 billion.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Honda's Short Road to Market
 
It had to be one of the swiftest new-product introductions in automotive history. Last summer engineers from the Honda Motor Company in Japan said they had developed a thrifty new engine. They called it the VTEC-E. Last week, Honda announced the debut of the Civic VX, which is equipped with the first of those lean-burn engines. Honda expects the Civic VX to get about 55 miles a gallon on the highway and 48 miles in the city. But what is really remarkable about the new engine is that while its mileage is only 10 percent better than the next-best Geo Metro, imported by the General Motors Corporation, the Civic VX has about 30 percent more horses under its hood. According to Honda's critics at G.M., the new engine does not represent any big technological breakthrough. But if it is so easy, why didn't G.M. bring one out?
 
Keeping the Sushi Chefs at Bay
 
The bluefin, which is native to the North Atlantic, is a delicacy in the world's sushi bars. Environmentalists now worry it may be dying out due to over-fishing. Big bluefins -- put on ice and loaded onto planes -- can fetch $10,000 to $15,000 in Japan. So the National Audubon Society is proposing to have the bluefin listed as endangered under an international treaty. That would be the first time a commercial fish was deemed endangered. The United States Fish and Wildlife Services is expected to decide by Oct. 4 whether to recommend protection of the fish.
 
B.C.C.I. Punishment
 
The slow-paced investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International is finally yielding results. Last week, the Federal Reserve announced a $37 million fine against Ghaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi businessman, for acting as a front for B.C.C.I.'s 1985 purchase of the Independence Bank of Encino, Calif. Regulators also asked a Federal court in Manhattan to freeze Mr. Pharaon's assets. They were worried, it seems, that he would turn his holdings into transportable cash.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in Business Diary last Sunday about the Resolution Trust Company misidentified the source of a new $191 billion estimate of the cost of bailing out the savings and loans associations. It was made by the Congressional Budget Office, not the General Accounting Office.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1734 words

HEADLINE: Abandoned Housing Site Leads to Suit Over Pollution

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY

 BODY:
BY some accounts, Graig Arcuri, a housing developer, simply ran into a string of bad luck trying to build 140 luxury town houses on 40 acres of waterfront property here.
By other accounts, no amount of ill fortune justified the erosion and pollution left behind when Mr. Arcuri, faced with mounting debts and a failed project, apparently abandoned his plans and walked away. 
 In a lawsuit against the developer, two environmental groups claim that hard economic times notwithstanding, a builder must not be allowed to leave behind the remnants of a housing project to degrade the surrounding countryside.
The verdant hillside that Mr. Arcuri had hoped would become an affluent residential area has undergone dramatic changes in the four years since the Village Board of Trustees approved the developer's plans. No longer protected by natural ground cover, a section of the hillside has eroded, leaving a steep, deeply fissured incline leading down to a meandering creek and the Hudson River.
All that remains of Mr. Arcuri's initial effort to develop the land are two concrete foundations, one framed-in model town house, rubble from another building and narrow, unpaved roadways cutting across the land.
The Hudson River Fishermen's Association and the Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site are suing Mr. Arcuri, C. M. Realty Developers and Mount Mercy Associates. Mr. Arcuri is president of C. M. Realty and a partner in Mount Mercy Associates. The suit states that the developer violated and continues to violate mandates of the Federal Clean Water Act.
 
'We Want It to Set an Example'
 "This is an extremely important case," said John Cronin, Hudson Riverkeeper for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund. "We want it to set an example for other communities and developers to follow. The Hudson River should not have to pay the price for bad business."
The Hudson River Fishermen's Association, originally a citizen activist group dedicated to preserving the ecosystems of the river, is now part of the 2,000-member, Garrison-based Hudson Riverkeeper Fund.
The case against the developer is being prosecuted by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., senior lawyer for the Riverkeeper Fund and professor at the Environmental Litigation Clinic of Pace University's School of Law.
 
Called a Threat to Fish and Crabs
 The citizens' suit has been filed in United States District Court in White Plains. Citing Section 505 of the Clean Water Act, the suit claims that sediment-laden drainage from the two building sites flows into Wickers Creek through PVC pipes and along gullies caused by erosion. The discharges -- which include solid waste, wrecked and discarded equipment, garbage, rocks, sand and cellar dirt -- pose a threat to populations of freshwater fish and blue crabs in the creek, an estuary of the Hudson River, the suit says.
"This is somebody we couldn't ignore," Mr. Kennedy said last week, referring to Mr. Arcuri. "This guy dropped half a hillside and part of a house into a herring run."
The Soil and Water Conservation District for Westchester County inspected the site several times from 1987 to 1990 and informed the village that erosion and sediment control measures there were inadequate.
The erosion problem was first brought to the attention of the Hudson River Fishermen's Association by the Friends of Wickers Creek Archeological Site, a 20-member Dobbs Ferry group.
 
Inclusion in National Register Sought
 "First we passed the word along to the Village Board and the Mayor, but when they took no action, we came to the conclusion that we couldn't let this situation continue," said Thomas S. Morrison, chairman of the friends group. "We want proper conservation of the creek and all 40 acres. Right now, it is a blight in our community and a blight on the Hudson River."
An area covering less than an acre near Wickers Creek is being considered by the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation for nomination for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places, said Julia S. Stokes, the state's deputy commissioner for historic preservation.
Prehistoric archeological artifacts dating to the fourth and third millenniums and belonging to hunter and gatherer societies of coastal New York have been found at the site. Members of the Weckquaesgeek tribe were the first settlers of Westchester, and shells from oysters, which once abounded in the river and were a key source of food for the Indians, can still be found in the soil. Until 1644, when the Indians were massacred by Dutch settlers, members of the tribe spent the warmer months along Wickers Creek.
A dig on the site -- from which many artifacts of the early Indian period were unearthed -- was completed by Greenhouse Consultants, an Atlanta-based archeological company. Barry Greenhouse, the company's president, said the prehistoric materials had been turned over to C. M. Realty Developers, which paid for the excavation.
 
Moratorium on Sewer Systems
 The developer's lawyer, Stephen J. Mignano, said that despite Mr. Arcuri's good intentions to excavate the archeological material properly before proceeding with the development, and his efforts to construct a viable housing project there, other events had prevented the project from moving ahead.
"What we hoped would be a beautiful project eventually went down the tubes," the lawyer said.
In November 1987, shortly after Mr. Arcuri received approval from the village to build, the state imposed a building moratorium on new sewer systems feeding into the Yonkers Joint Wastewater Treatment Plant.
By the time the moratorium was lifted in May 1990, Mr. Arcuri was finally ready to build and sell the $250,000-to-$300,000 condominiums, but he faced a depressed real estate market, Mr. Mignano said.
 
Lender Now in Receivership
 Also, City Federal Savings Bank in Piscataway, N.J., the savings and loan institution that gave Mr. Arcuri the mortgage for the development, folded. The bank is now in receivership and managed by the Resolution Trust Corporation.
P. Christian Yates, assistant director for loans and other assets at Resolution Trust's Somerset, N.J., office, said City Federal had made a $25.6 million commitment to Mr. Arcuri. Although the full amount of the loan was never advanced to the developer, Resolution Trust is "working with the borrower to resolve the loans that have been made," Mr. Yates said.
In addition to his mortgage debt, Mr. Arcuri owes money to contractors who began work and were not paid, said Tara M. Wall, a third-year law student at Pace who is assisting Mr. Kennedy with the suit. The total amount of those loans is not known. And Resolution Trust would not divulge the extent of Mr. Arcuri's debt.
The developer also owes the Village of Dobbs Ferry $185,000 in liens and taxes and the Town of Greenburgh $912,965 in taxes. Officials of both jurisdictions said that they have been unable to contact Mr. Arcuri to collect the money.
"Mr. Arcuri has been a thorn in our side," said the Dobbs Ferry Village Administrator, Margaret Slavin. "But this is an unfortunate story. Talk about bad luck."
 
A Trail of Bad Debts
 Mr. Mignano said his client had left a trail of bad debts and continued to be difficult to contact.
But, despite what many people believe, the lawyer said his client's "intentions are good."
"This is not Darth Vader we are talking about," Mr. Mignano said. "This is a man who ran into some hard times."
From a plaintiff's point of view, though, there is little sympathy for Mr. Arcuri's failures. Mr. Cronin said it was not bad luck but miscalculation that led to the current situation, because the developer failed to plan for all contingencies.
"Now there's a public price to pay," Mr. Cronin added. "And the question is, Will the people who said that everything was going to be rosy be held accountable?"
Jennifer Johnson, a project manager for the Trust for Public Land, a national nonprofit conservation organization, called Mr. Arcuri's story "a classic example of a bad loan that the rest of the country is paying for. That's definitely a hot issue these days."
 
Public Access to Waterfront a Goal
 The Trust for Public Land, which is based in San Francisco and has an office in Manhattan, is working with the developer and the Resolution Trust Corporation to obtain land to provide public access to the waterfront area and possibly to protect the archeological site, Ms. Johnson said.
"There may be a way," she said, "to work out a scenario whereby the developer gets out of a tough situation, the town gets something back and the public gains access to the river."
The trust wants to obtain land to connect the Old Croton Aqueduct Trailway to the waterfront.
"Hopefully," Ms. Johnson said, "we can work out a crisis situation with some capital from the trust."
Mr. Mignano said his client is still interested in moving ahead with the project if his debt situation is resolved. Matthew P. Carey, clerk-treasurer of Dobbs Ferry, said the village would welcome news that "somehow Mr. Arcuri became solvent again and the project could go forward."
 
$250,000 a Year in Taxes Possible
 Mr. Carey estimated that the village would realize about $250,000 a year in taxes if the property were developed.
Mercy College, however, is negotiating to buy the land and build a dormitory there. Because the college is a tax-exempt institution, that plan -- if realized -- would represent a significant loss in taxes for the village, Mr. Carey said.
Mr. Cronin called Dobbs Ferry "a partner in desperation with Mr. Arcuri." He said the Fishermen's Association and the friends group want the site restored and used in "a responsible way."
In the meantime, the plaintiffs are proceeding with the lawsuit. "Our primary goal is to have the creek cleaned up and the situation remedied," Mr. Kennedy said. "We won't agree to any settlement that doesn't include that."
 
Facing Penalties of $25,000 a Day
 "In the past, polluters have been reluctant to go to court," Mr. Kennedy said. "They have sought to settle."
Under the Clean Water Act, if the case goes to trial and the court finds the defendants guilty, the judge could order them to pay civil penalties of $25,000 for each day of violation.
"Instead of paying the U.S. Treasury," Mr. Kennedy said, "polluters often set up a fund to contribute to the local environment."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 43; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Scrapbooks of a Black Heritage

BYLINE: By Ira Berlin; Ira Berlin teaches history at the University of Maryland and is an editor of "Freedom: A Documentary History of Emancipation."

 BODY:

WILLIAM DORSEY'S PHILADELPHIA AND OURS
On the Past and Future of the
Black City in America.
By Roger Lane.
Illustrated. 483 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press.
$29.95.  
 For some, history is not a silent chronicle of past events but an active conversation between the past and the present. So it was for William Henry Dorsey, the scion of one of 19th-century Philadelphia's most prominent African-American families, and so it is for Roger Lane, a professor of social science at Haverford College and the author of "William Dorsey's Philadelphia and Ours," a long look at the evolution of African-American life in that city after emancipation.
The nature of black life in 19th-century Philadelphia fostered such conversations. The presence in their city of the African Methodist Episcopal Church (the nation's first independent black denomination), the Institute for Colored Youth (the most prestigious black secondary school, founded just before the Civil War), the American Moral Reform Society (a pioneering black civil rights organization) and the Grand and United Order of Odd Fellows (the largest black fraternal association) sharpened the historical consciousness of black Philadelphians. Some kept journals and diaries or wrote histories of their own. Others formed historical associations and organized exhibitions of their personal memorabilia. Still others systematically preserved the evidence of their own time for posterity.
First among these historically minded black Philadelphians was William Henry Dorsey, an artist whose wealthy father had founded one of the city's most successful catering businesses. Beginning early in the 1870's and continuing for roughly 30 years thereafter, he clipped nearly every article (or so it seems) concerning black people that appeared in the city's numerous newspapers and periodicals. To these he added reports, posters, catalogues, flyers, menus, playbills, commemorative plates and coins and numerous portraits -- many of the latter apparently by his own hand. In all, he put together 388 scrapbooks amounting to more than 30,000 pages.
Dorsey's scrapbooks reflect a wide range of interests, from notarial records to dialect poetry, from sermons to minutes of ward meetings, from the records of celebrations of births, confirmations, graduations and weddings to accounts of deaths -- quiet ones as nature took its course and angry ones at the hands of assassins, vigilantes and lynch mobs. A simple review of the subjects addressed, racial nomenclature employed and tone expressed in the documents that Dorsey assembled alone makes Mr. Lane's history a splendid guide to the changing lives of urban black people between the end of Reconstruction and the beginning of the great migrations from the rural South to the cities of the North.
Dorsey's massive collection of memorabilia provided the raw material for W. E. B. DuBois's classic book "The Philadelphia Negro: A Social Study" (1899), and was the foundation for yet another Philadelphia-based African-American institution, the American Negro Historical Society. But with Dorsey's death in 1923 and the subsequent dissolution of the society, the collection was shifted from place to place and parceled out among interested parties; after years of neglect and inattention, it was, to all intents and purposes, lost. The recent rediscovery of part of the collection at Cheyney State University among the effects of Dr. Leslie Pinckney Hill provided Mr. Lane with the occasion to continue the discussion that Dorsey began.
For the most part, Mr. Lane's tale is not a pleasant one. Most 19th-century black Philadelphians were poor, very poor. Like poor people everywhere, they died young and lived uncomfortably, eating badly and sleeping fitfully in houses that offered little protection from the elements. Their crowded neighborhoods showed death rates "two and even three times higher than those for whites"; they were also sites of vice, mayhem and murder. For Mr. Lane, an expert on the history of crime and the author of an earlier book on racial crime in Philadelphia ("The Roots of Violence in Black Philadelphia, 1860-1900"), this last matter is particularly significant.
But Philadelphia's black community was not of one piece. Following the primary thrust of recent African-American scholarship, Mr. Lane carefully delineates a complex social order in which "the better class" was distinguished from " 'V.C.N.s' or Very Common Negroes," Old Philadelphians (O.P.'s to the initiated) from the New, the skilled from the unskilled, Northerners from Southerners. Indeed, Mr. Lane greatly expands historical understanding of the black community's social structure, observing, for example, distinctions black Philadelphians made between those who boasted street addresses and those who resided on the alleys. Such fine differences were of utmost importance in a community where coachmen and waiters numbered among the elite. By elaborating them with such extraordinary precision, Mr. Lane does much to reconstruct the city William Dorsey loved.
Yet even the black aristocracy -- of which Dorsey was most certainly part -- enjoyed few opportunities for advancement since the black community was too poor to support its businessmen and professionals and too few to elect its politicians to public office. Ambitious, worldly and sophisticated, members of the highly educated black elite found it increasingly difficult to earn a livelihood. As the 19th century progressed, the task of transferring their elevated status to the next generation became extremely difficult.
For Mr. Lane, the key to understanding the dire circumstances of black Philadelphia was the near-total exclusion of black people from the industrial economy. White racial prejudice barred black men and women from factory labor, the most dynamic and productive sector of the economy. In 1870, fully three-quarters of African-Americans worked as unskilled laborers or domestic workers, nearly three times the rate for white immigrants. Only 4 percent of black workers were employed in white-collar jobs -- no matter how broadly defined -- compared to 15 percent for white immigrants and 35 percent for whites of native birth.
The ironclad proscription had numerous effects beyond the general impoverishment of African-American life. For one, it screwed down "the lid on opportunity," crushing the "black occupational pyramid . . . its top layers pushed close to the bottom, the bottom filled with people 'overqualified' for the jobs they held" and could not escape from. Dorsey, who lived off a small patrimony, apparently had no regular salaried employment until his appointment as a personal messenger to the mayor in 1879. He was then 42 years old.
Exclusion from the industrial order, Mr. Lane argues, had a profoundly subversive effect on community life because it denied black people the discipline that accompanied factory labor. Articulating an assumption that undergirds his work, Mr. Lane maintains that increased employment in factory and bureaucracy "demanded sober, disciplined, even regimented behavior" that, in turn, created increasingly well-ordered cities during the 19th century. One manifestation of this new "social psychology" was a sharp decrease in violent crime, particularly among industrial workers. But while Philadelphia's crime rate fell, that of the city's black population skyrocketed.
Mr. Lane's assumptions concerning the effects of industrialization reopen an old debate about the ways in which preindustrial and industrial culture shaped the lives of working people. His views will doubtless be challenged by those who see the industrial regime as the chief source of urban violence and disorder. Indeed, many historians argue that working people -- blacks among them -- employed the revivified remnants of the preindustrial past, both urban and rural, to create an urban order of their own, distinct from the regimentation that employers, the police and various "reformers" attempted to foist upon them.
Mr. Lane himself emphasizes that 19th-century black Philadelphians were an extraordinarily disciplined people, with high rates of literacy and low rates of alcoholism. They attended school longer than their white counterparts and avoided the almshouse at all cost. They had a strong tradition of mutuality and created a dense thicket of organizations -- church, schools, fraternal societies -- that knit black Philadelphians into a community that, however unsuccessfully, attempted to counter "simple racism openly applied."
Even those who dispute Mr. Lane's understanding of the implications of economic exclusion will appreciate his finely drawn portrait of black Philadelphia and the easy informality of the style that he uses to analyze the evidence Dorsey collected. But Mr. Lane is not content merely to remain in the past. Driven by a heartfelt interest in the future of his own city, he extends Dorsey's concerns down to the present. In so doing, he attempts to transfer the discussion of the origins of contemporary black America from the South, the plantation and slavery to the North, the factory and the city.
The ambitious effort to reconstruct contemporary black life that occupies the last section of Mr. Lane's book does not, however, meet the high standards set by its earlier historical analysis. Here the rich material Dorsey provided for interpreting the 19th-century city, the thick description of African-American life, is replaced by a thin one, often presented in a breathless manner as Mr. Lane rushes across the 20th century to connect the two Philadelphias. Set against the fine-grained portrait of Dorsey's Philadelphia is a hurried recital of the nightmarish realities of contemporary unemployment, domestic instability, illegitimacy, drug addiction, inadequate education and violence.
Mr. Lane's commentary on these disturbing circumstances -- which often draw on his own observations of the city -- are always informed, generally sympathetic and sometimes insightful. But they are rarely deep; in fact, they are often glib and occasionally platitudinous. Moreover, determined not to yield to what he believes to be an "exaggerated deference to black sensibilities"respecting the problems of city crime and poverty, Mr. Lane tries to maintain the same informality of style that enlivened his presentation of the clippings in Dorsey's scrapbooks. But in the grim context of today's inner-city life, what had worked so well earlier seems rudely out of place. Adopting, for example, the sexually charged language of the streets -- even if it is theirs -- to characterize the various types of work available to black men fails to do justice to the desperate problem of defining manhood in a society that, as Mr. Lane emphasizes, offers little meaningful remunerative work.
More than anything else, Mr. Lane's analysis reveals that the problems of contemporary inner-city Philadelphia are only partly a product of the legacy left by William Dorsey's Philadelphia. There is simply too much history between the late-19th-century city and the late-20th-century city -- and that history must be explained, not telescoped. Nevertheless, if neither his description nor his analysis of modern-day Philadelphia equals those he established in addressing William Dorsey's city, Mr. Lane has succeeded in continuing the conversation between past and present in a manner that invites others to join in as well.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
How to Revive Housing Starts

BYLINE: By CHARLES LOCKWOOD; Charles Lockwood is a Los Angeles-based consultant to the real estate industry.

 BODY:
In past recessions, housing construction jumpstarted the economy. That isn't happening now. There was a modest upturn earlier this year, but construction is sluggish in much of the nation. This year, new housing starts are projected to tumble to the lowest level since 1945.
Housing is not leading the economy out of recession because, despite declines in interest rates and prices, only 43 percent of all American households can afford to buy a median-priced home in their region. In much of the East Coast and California, affordability figures are worse. In greater New York, for instance, only 22 percent of households can buy a median-priced home. In San Francisco, the figure is a dismal 9.2 percent. 
 How can we make housing more affordable? First, the percentage of house prices devoted to inflated lot values must be reduced. Before 1980, lots represented about 20 percent of home prices across most of the nation. Today, they constitute 40 to 60 percent.
The rise is a result of man-made constraints on land use like restrictive zoning and slow-growth rules. And local and state governments often do not have enough money to extend infrastructure for new development, so improved land grows more valuable.
Obviously, more land must be made available by expanding the infrastructure more quickly. Local governments could rely more on user fees levied on developers. State governments might enact their own version of California's Mello-Roos Act. This enables municipalities to float bond issues to pay for infrastructure improvements within a designated district. Developers repay the debt incurred for their property, taking advantage of the municipality's lower cost of borrowing.
At the same time, governments must use zoning and tax incentives to encourage jobs to move to outlying regions more quickly. Otherwise, new residents of those areas gain home ownership only at the cost of a long commute.
In addition, zoning regulations should be changed to encourage high-density, wood-framed, three and four-story apartments. These are less costly to build than high-rise apartments, and spread high lot values over more units, lowering prices.
Another solution for affordable housing in high-cost regions is state-sponsored programs to assist first-time buyers in saving down payments for their homes. Michigan, for example, underwrites low-interest loans to homebuyers whose gross annual household income does not exceed $36,500.
Through such moves, America can avoid becoming a two-class nation of homeowners and non-homeowners.

HEADLINE: Blacks See Bias Trend In Job Cuts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
As big companies increasingly retrench, black professionals are becoming more concerned that they are being disproportionately hurt by widening layoffs and that their opportunities for advancement are becoming severely crippled.
At a convention of the National Black M.B.A. Association that ended yesterday in New York, one black corporate manager after another expressed those concerns, saying that the recession had caused many black professionals to lose their jobs and re-evaluate the worth of life in corporate America. 
 While many contend that blacks have always fared worse in employee cutbacks, many black professionals complain that the recent surge in layoffs has had a more severe impact on their ranks than previous ones.
 
Number of Factors
 Officials of the association and other experts point to a number of factors for this trend. They note that black employees often have less seniority than whites and that black executives generally do not have well-established ties with decision-making supervisors.
"Ten years ago, a company might have had the objective of increasing the black presence in its labor force to 10 percent, but that is not considered as important any more," said Derryl L. Reed, president of the M.B.A. association and assistant vice president of insurance services for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America.
"And when it is time to cut costs, black professionals get the brunt of it because there generally is no access to the decision makers," he said. "We're not a part of the good old boy network."
No one interviewed at the convention was aware of any figures showing how black professionals have been affected by corporate cutbacks compared with their white associates. And many companies undertaking layoffs contend that they have sought to make sure that black and Hispanic workers are not affected more severely than whites.
"We have a strong commitment to having a diverse work force," said Lesli Ferrell, manager of minority business development at Frito-Lay Inc., which last week announced huge layoffs affecting nearly all of its 250 manufacturing and distribution centers. "And black workers have not fared proportionately worse than the majority work force. Unfortunately with layoffs, you have to lay off people of all persuasions and backgrounds."
Still, nearly all of those interviewed at the convention said that black and Hispanic professionals were being disproportionately affected in corporate cutbacks.
Mark T. Standard, a former marketing representative with a large computer company who was laid off from the company's New York operations two years ago, said it seemed that black workers were disproportionately affected by those layoffs.
"Nearly every black person that I knew in the company got laid off," said Mr. Standard, who is now pursuing an M.B.A. degree at the University of Chicago. "It seemed that black people were fairly new to the company and everyone got downgraded in the downsizing. Middle managers were placed in the field, and those who were in the field were placed out the door."
The corporate cutbacks have also reduced the opportunities for emerging black professionals, college officials contend. Companies "aren't just going to schools and making fewer offers; they're going to fewer schools," said Sybil Collins Mobley, dean of the School of Business and Industry at Florida A.& M. University. "And when they do come, companies are not looking for 10 people to recruit any more, they're looking to hire one."
 
Shifting Specialties
 She added that she recently visited a West Coast company that had a work force of 56,000 a decade ago. "Now that company has 28,000 workers and an order to reduce by 10 percent," she said. "And situations like that -- which are abundant -- have created a tremendous problem for the black professional."
As a result, officials of the M.B.A. association, management consultants and heads of executive search firms have been urging black executives to move out of areas like human relations, personnel and corporate communications, which have been severely cut in the last few years.
In seminars, lectures and informal discussions among black professionals at the convention, the recommendation was to go into accounting, development, sales and engineering.
Mr. Reed, the association's president, said that this year's convention had an entire day devoted to seminars on entrepreneurism, adding that with a shrinking number of management jobs available, undertaking their own enterprises has become increasingly important to black professionals.
"We want people to realize that as the number of available jobs contracts in corporate America, they must look at other areas of opportunity," Mr. Reed said. "And we are urging people to use their layoff experience as an opportunity to pursue their own business ventures."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
San Diego Daily Fades as Market Outgrows It

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The letters in Neil Morgan's mailbox come from all over California, expressing dismay over the loss of an "old friend."
Mr. Morgan, the editor of the soon-to-be-closed San Diego Tribune read one aloud in his office: "I'm sorry I wrote some critical and not-nice remarks to your paper some months ago. But The Tribune, to me, was the very best publication always. And who has time to read a morning paper?" 
 Despite the outpouring of sympathy, Mr. Morgan asked, "So where was everybody when we needed them?"
Earlier this month, Copley Press Inc., the owner of The Tribune, announced that the afternoon newspaper would merge early next year with its much-larger sister publication, the morning San Diego Union. The Tribune, which began publishing in 1895, has been owned by Copley since 1928.
The combined paper, to be known as The San Diego Union-Tribune, is expected to publish morning and afternoon editions. Yet, the demise of The Tribune is another sign of the continuing decline of afternoon newspapers. In the last two months alone, afternoon papers in Richmond and Roanoke, Va., and Charleston, S.C., have announced plans to merge with morning papers. And the afternoon paper in Newport News, Va., closed at the end of August.
 
Stable Circulation
 The Tribune, by most measurements, is not a dying afternoon daily. But two papers are more expensive to operate than one.
Mr. Morgan called the merger "a dollars-and-cents move."
Over the last decade, The Tribune has held on to most of its readers. The paper, which reached a peak circulation of about 133,000 in 1979, now sells about 117,000 copies a day, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
But in that period, San Diego -- and The Union -- surged. San Diego's population has increased about 27 percent, to 1.1 million. And The Union's average daily circulation has grown to more than 271,000, from about 204,000 in 1979.
Meanwhile, Copley Press, like most other newspaper companies, has come under pressure to reduce its costs because of the advertising slump caused by the recession.
 
Two Plans for The Tribune
 The company would not disclose how much it expected to save by merging the two papers.
 Herb Klein, editor in chief of Copley Press, said the company had considered two plans for The Tribune. One was to make it an afternoon tabloid that would be completely different from The Union in order to attract readers.
"Or we could cooperate instead of compete," Mr. Klein said. "So we decided to take the best of both papers and combine them."
Helen Copley, publisher of the papers, has said there will be staff reductions at both papers as a result of the merger. And Tribune employees are assuming that they will take the brunt of the cutbacks.
Still, many employees at both The Union and The Tribune expressed cautious optimism about combining the papers.
"If it's done right, we could combine resources to make a super paper that covers Mexico, Arizona and more of California," said Steve Downes, an assistant news editor at The Union. "If I don't get laid off, it could be a lot of fun."
Some Tribune reporters and editors, however, are concerned about the tone of the combined paper. The Union is known as an extremely conservative voice in a conservative city. The Tribune is considered more independent, with a less conservative stance.
In addition, The Tribune focuses more closely on local issues than does The Union.
Many readers say they prefer The Tribune because it is the livelier, more aggressive paper. "The local columnists made the difference," said Don Canning, a deputy county prosecutor.
Indeed, The Tribune has won two Pulitzer Prizes -- one in 1979 for its coverage of a midair collision and the other in 1987 for its editorials on immigration reform.
Copley is not the only one likely to gain from the Union-Tribune merger. The Los Angeles Times, which publishes a daily San Diego County edition, is already studying ways to pick up Tribune readers, said Phyllis Pfeiffer, the edition's general manager. The San Diego edition currently claims a circulation of more than 75,000.
 
Desirable Readers
 The Tribune asserts that it has the kinds of readers that newspaper advertisers like. Unlike many afternoon newspapers, The Tribune does not cater to an older, blue-collar audience. Tribune managers say their studies show their readers are younger and more educated with higher incomes than Union readers.
"I'm satisfied we were the right paper for the right people, but came out at the wrong time of day," Mr. Morgan said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Disabled People Gain Roles in Ads and on TV

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
NBC could easily have promoted the premiere of "Reasonable Doubts" as a
recedent-setting event in the struggle of disabled Americans to enter mainstream society.
The series, which makes its debut Friday at 10 P.M., Eastern time, arguably breaks new ground by featuring a deaf actor, Marlee Matlin, who plays an assistant district attorney and delivers some lines in sign language. The plots of each episode -- the prosecution of criminals and romance with Mark Harmon, the co-star -- have little to do with disability. 
 Indeed, NBC executives bristle when the series is described as a program about the disabled. "This is a provocative adult drama," said Charisse McGhee, the network's vice president of current dramatic programming. "It's not that we don't take into account Marlee's hearing impairment, but that's not where the story line comes from."
 
A Growing Media Trend
 Still, the character in "Reasonable Doubts" is an example of a growing trend in television, advertising and marketing. From Corky, who has Down syndrome on the ABC series "Life Goes On," to models in wheelchairs in catalogues for retailers like Eddie Bauer and Nordstrom, to shots of wheelchair marathoners and people talking in sign language in commercials for companies like Chrysler and McDonald's, there is a steady stream of what advocates for the disabled call more "real life parts."
While ads including disabled people have been appearing since the early 1980's, more recent ones are displaying them in a greater variety of roles and are even treating disability with some humor. One commercial had the quarterback Joe Montana laughing as the singer Ray Charles, who is blind, was handed a Diet Coke instead of a Diet Pepsi.
"When I first saw it, I thought, 'Whoa, they're walking a fine line there,' " said Ted Bell, president of Leo Burnett U.S.A., which creates ads for McDonald's. "But it works. Ten years ago, you would never have done something like that."
The change comes as the Federal Government begins enforcing a Federal law that bans discrimination based on physical or mental impairments. Groups that lobbied for the law, like Media Access and the National Easter Seal Society, have also been working to change media and advertising portrayals of handicapped people.
 
'Slowly Beginning to Change'
 "Our situation is slowly beginning to change in the same way as it changed for people of color," said Paul K. Longmore, a visiting professor of history at Stanford University who is disabled and has been researching media protrayals of the handicapped. But, he added, "We're still at a point with disability where a lot of advertisers fear that we will drive viewers away."
Robert G. Thatcher, vice president of marketing at the Target discount division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, said that when an employee suggested that a photograph of a child in a wheelchair be included in a sales circular, he was enthusiastic, but also wary. Mr. Thatcher has a daughter who was born without a left hand, but he feared the ad could lead to complaints that Target was exploiting the handicapped.
The photograph, however, drew an opposite reaction. Target has received more than 2,000 letters of praise, Mr. Thatcher said.
Advocates for the disabled attribute such changes, in part, to a recognition of the economic power of handicapped people. They note that disabled people represent a large market that buys soap and toothpaste, and watches television, like other consumers. But many advertisers that have used disabled people in their ads say they are trying to reach a broad audience, not a niche market.
"Our customer base is everyone who eats," said Chuck Eberling, a spokesman for McDonald's.
 
Problems With Stereotypes
 But while disabled people have become much more prevalent in ads and television programs, advocates for the handicapped worry that certain stereotypes have arisen. Alan Toy, a disabled actor who uses crutches or a wheelchair, described how he usually auditioned for parts as an alienated Vietnam veteran or an embittered accident victim. While he recently appeared as a businessman in a commercial, he added, many advertisers and their agencies want wheelchair marathoners.
And the advocates say older stereotypes still prevail. "Good and Evil," an ABC situation comedy that will make its debut on Wednesday, has been sharply criticized by the National Federation of the Blind. In the opening epsiode of the satirical comedy, a blind man walks into a laboratory and, waving his cane in the air, proceeds to smash beakers.
An ABC spokesman said every character in the series was meant to be ridiculous and unrealistic.
For disabled people, "Reasonable Doubts" is a test of whether television viewers are ready to accept a disabled star on a weekly series that has little to do with disability.
"If this fails, it's going to be blamed on the disability issue," Mr. Toy said. "They're not going to do demographics that show Mark Harmon isn't cute any more."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Fall Migration to the Networks

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The first week of the new television season did not solve all the problems that have afflicted the three big broadcast networks over the last several years, but it almost certainly postponed any orders for "going out of business" signs.
Audiences returned to network prime-time programs last week in numbers that were sharply higher than those as recent as the week before. Network executives called this encouraging evidence that viewers still look to the networks for new fall entertainment. 
 Two weeks ago, the three-network share of the audience -- the percentage of viewers who were tuned in to network programs -- was only a 57. By contrast, on the first two nights of the new season that three-network share was well over 70.
 
A 91 Share in New York
 And on Thursday, when the Fox Broadcasting Company had strong programs of its own to entice viewers, the four-network share hit a high of 78. At 8 P.M. on Thursday in the nation's largest television market, New York, the four network broadcast stations hit a figure not seen since the cable invasion: a 91 share.
"Maybe the dire situation facing the networks isn't so dire after all," said Robert Niles, the vice president of research for NBC.
The evidence is still quite preliminary, of course; the networks had some good performances early last season that did not hold up. And there may be no immediate financial gain for the networks' early success because demand for network commercial time is still soft, advertising executives say.
But the strong ratings did indicate a surge of interest in network programs once again.
Several new series did well in their first episodes, but network executives were pointing to the especially strong showings of returning series. These longtime favorites included ABC's "Full House" and "Roseanne," NBC's "Cheers" and "The Cosby Show," Fox's "The Simpsons" and CBS's entire lineup of Monday night comedies. Indeed, each of CBS's shows scored its highest rating ever, with "Murphy Brown" at the top.
"Murphy Brown" benefited from the skillfully promoted interest in a cliffhanger plot line from last season involving the main character's possible pregnancy. The show scored a 23.8 rating with a 35 share for an hourlong special episode. (Each rating point equals 921,000 homes.) Very few programs in the last year reached a rating that high. The previous high for "Murphy Brown" had been a 20.
Even the advertising industry noticed the networks' success. "I think what it shows is that the networks have gotten back to blocking and tackling and doing the basics well," said Gene DeWitt of DeWitt Media.
One of those basics is stoking interest in the start of the new season. This summer, as network shares fell to new lows, network executives faced questions about whether the still-dominant rerun glut was going to drive more and more viewers away to cable channels during the regular television season.
The executives responded by saying that viewers would be back as soon as premiere week began.
"I think what you're seeing now is a strong argument for the power of premiere week," said Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group. He added that it was gratifying for the networks to perform so well last week, given the overwhelmingly congested climate of the fall season, with so many channels and programs seeking viewers' attention.
"Sometimes, you think the forest is so big if a tree falls you won't hear it unless it has firecrackers tied to it," he said.
For the third straight year, CBS tied its fall premieres to a promotion in conjunction with the K Mart Corporation. George Schweitzer, CBS's senior vice president of communications who initiated the K Mart campaign, said the network was improving it each year, and that this year's association with the Walt Disney Company (trips to Disney World were the top prizes) had greatly enhanced the promotion.
The K Mart campaign has helped CBS get off to outstanding starts in the last two seasons. But viewership fell off quickly for many of the CBS programs in those years. "The difference this year," Mr. Schweitzer said, "is we simply have better programs to promote."
 
'It's a Cliche but It's True'
 Indeed, what the early results demonstrate is that programs make all the difference, said Alan Wurtzel, the senior vice president of research for ABC. "It's a cliche, but it's true," he added. "When good programs are there, people come to watch."
The problem, Mr. Wurtzel said, is that viewers had 'no tolerance" for a show they did not like.
"We have an obligation to meet their expectations, or we'll lose them very quickly," he continued. "What the last few seasons have proved is that there is no longer an artificial floor."
The intolerance for lesser programs was also demonstrated last week. After the first two nights when all three networks put on series, specials or movies with strong appeal, ABC made two programming moves that executives at CBS and NBC found curiously lackluster for premiere week.
On Wednesday night, ABC inserted what amounted to a used cable movie instead of the strong comedies scheduled for that night. (Mr. Wurtzel said some of those shows had problems delivering episodes on time.) The movie, "Stop at Nothing," had already played on the Lifetime Channel; it was the first cable movie to switch over and play on a network.
But "Stop at Nothing" was watched by only 16 percent of the audience. Though both other networks did well on Wednesday night, ABC's movie helped push the three-network share down to a 66.
Then on Thursday night, ABC carried a repeat of the movie "Jewel of the Nile" against the season premieres of both "Cosby" and "The Simpsons" and again suffered the consequences. The network finished dead last in the four-way network competition on Thursday.
Mr. Wurtzel said it was important to ABC to make sure its shows were started well. "And if that means holding them off for a week or so, that makes sense," he added.
But both CBS and NBC said they believed in going all out in the first week. "The public is in a sampling mood right now," Mr. Poltrack said. "They will make decisions the first week that they will stay with all season. If you don't get them now, it'll take 10 or 12 weeks to get them through word of mouth or whatever."
Despite the strong showing in the first week, the economic picture for the networks is not necessarily brighter, Mr DeWitt said. But he agreed that the networks should be encouraged by the results of the season's first week. "The audience came back, just like it has for the past 30 years," he said.

HEADLINE: Insurance Reform in a Deadlock

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Despite widespread agreement that the auto insurance system is in dire need of reform in many states, most revamping efforts remain stalled or ineffective, forcing drivers to pay ever-higher rates and insurers to grapple with escalating legal, medical and car-repair costs.
The announcement last week by the Allstate Insurance Company that it planned to stop doing business in New Jersey, where it is the largest auto insurer, was the latest example of the confusion and frustration building around the issue in some populous states. 
 Allstate said New Jersey officials were unreasonably denying it rate increases despite years of losses and rising costs. New Jersey regulators and consumer advocates responded that Allstate's operations were simply inefficient and that the company should actually cut its rates.
 
A National Problem
 Here in California, regulators remain mired in a legal battle with the industry over whether the state can force insurers to roll back rates, as required by a ballot proposition passed nearly three years ago. Most drivers in California have long since given up hope of seeing the promised rebates anytime soon, and for many, rates have continued to rise.
Massachusetts, having tried both deregulation and extremely tight regulation -- only to find that neither system pleased consumers or the industry -- is now considering its third regulatory overhaul in 15 years.
While the auto insurance problems are most severe in New Jersey, California, Massachusetts, Texas, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and a handful of other states, they exist to some degree virtually nationwide.
Insurers have argued for years that they are trapped between rising costs over which they have no control -- for medical treatment, auto-body repairs, fraud and litigation expenses -- and a backlash against higher rates from consumers and among politicians who sense an emotional new issue.
Many insurers say that they are losing money in some states -- Allstate contends that it lost $72 million on auto insurance in New Jersey in the last year -- and that the business is only somewhat profitable in other states. Orrin Kramer, an industry consultant in Princeton, N.J., said auto insurers nationwide lost 1 cent for every $1 of premiums taken in from 1986 through 1990.
"Average profitability is substantially lower in rate-suppressing jurisdictions, making a mediocre business worse or totally uneconomical," Mr. Kramer said.
Other analyses, however, suggest that the industry is still profitable over all, and the nation's largest auto insurer, State Farm, which operates in every state, said its business was still reasonably healthy. C. A. (Pete) Ingham, the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company's general counsel, said the company had no plans to withdraw from any state, though it is battling regulators over rate issues in a number of states, including New Jersey. Indeed, despite some threats, few companies have actually withdrawn from big markets like California and New Jersey because of rate regulation.
Some companies, including the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, are withdrawing from the auto insurance business in many states. But their departures stem mainly from their use of independent agents to sell policies. These sales systems are expensive and increasingly uneconomical in the face of growing competition from insurers with their own sales forces, or from rivals that have dispensed with agents altogether and deal directly with customers over the phone and through the mail.
"We're talking about an industry with low profits, declining profits and a lot of problems," said Sean F. Mooney, an economist with the Insurance Information Institute, an industry-financed research organization. "The costs are going up and the prices aren't going up sufficiently to match the cost increases because of regulatory pressures, especially in states like California and New Jersey."
Consumer groups and growing numbers of politicians say insurance companies must learn to reduce administrative costs and live with less profit.
"There's a serious problem in that rates have gone up fast and many people can no longer afford coverage," said J. Robert Hunter, the head of the National Insurance Consumers Organization, a research and lobbying group. "The inefficient companies are going to feel pressure. The efficient companies will do fine and are doing fine."
 
Outstrip Cost of Living
 There is no question that rates have risen sharply over the last decade, making auto insurance a significant -- and sometimes unaffordable -- expense for drivers in many states. In part, the increases were a result of more accidents as roads have become more crowded, but the number of accidents appears to be leveling off.
Rate increases nationwide have significantly exceeded increases in the overall cost of living for the last nine years, with rates rising 6.8 percent last year compared with a 5.4 percent rise in the cost of living, according to the Insurance Information Institute.
In 1989, the most recent year for which figures are available, the cost of basic coverage in New Jersey, including liability, comprehensive and collision policies, averaged $1,074, the highest in the nation, according to the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The District of Columbia was next at $895, with California third at $875. New York was seventh at $798.
For many drivers, in those states as in others, rates were much higher, especially for those who live in urban areas, those with higher levels of coverage and those with bad driving records. In Los Angeles, for example, rates routinely exceed $2,000.
The least expensive state was Iowa, at $365.
 
The Faults of No-Fault
 For two decades, reform efforts have centered on no-fault insurance proposals. In simple terms, no-fault provides consumers with a trade-off: in return for a lower rate, they give up their right to sue for certain types of damages, especially in minor accidents. Under most no-fault laws, for example, a driver could not sue for pain and suffering damages after an accident that caused no significant physical injury.
Only 40 percent of payments by insurers for bodily injury liability claims cover actual economic losses like medical costs; the rest goes to payments for claims of pain and suffering and the like. Fewer lawsuits mean that fewer settlements and jury awards must be paid by insurers, who in turn could afford to offer lower rates.
More than a dozen states passed no-fault laws during the 1970's, but both industry and consumer groups consider most of them failures, and large states like California never enacted such laws. Typically, the laws state that a driver can sue only after exceeding certain minimum expenses created by an accident. Instead of dissuading drivers from suing after relatively minor accidents, it simply led them to try to run up their medical and other expenses to make it over the minimum and win the right to sue, industry executives and analysts say.
Industry and consumer groups agree that no-fault has worked fairly well in a few states, including New York and Michigan. Those states do not base the right to sue on monetary factors; rather, it is based on the type and severity of the injuries suffered. Regulators in other states, including Massachusetts, are discussing whether to modify their no-fault laws or draft new ones along such lines.
But enacting new or tougher no-fault laws has been almost impossible politically in many states, largely because of the opposition of trial lawyers, who have lobbied hard against any legislation that would limit the right to sue. Trial lawyers' groups have also made large campaign contributions to legislators.
Still, there appears to be new support for no-fault, or some variation of it. John Garamendi, a Democrat who took office in January as California's first elected Insurance Commissioner, ended months of fence-straddling on the issue three weeks ago when he came out in favor of a no-fault plan. Mr. Garamendi proposed that no-fault be part of a package intended to put caps on auto-repair and replacement costs, limit medical expenses and combat fraud.
It is unclear whether Mr. Garamendi's stand will help give new life to no-fault proposals in California, where the lawyers' lobby is particularly powerful. Many analysts, industry executives and consumer groups are instead watching Pennsylvania, which last year enacted legislation that gives consumers the right to decide individually whether they want no-fault, and lower rates, or traditional and more expensive policies with no restrictions on the right to sue.
 
A Need to Hold Down Costs
 On both the national and state levels, insurers and consumer groups are banding together to help control costs by pushing for more stringent safety laws, including lower speed limits and stricter enforcement of seatbelt laws, and by lobbying for other mutually beneficial changes like stronger bumpers.
But most agree that meaningful improvement will come only with broad changes that alter not only the civil-litigation system but procedures for medical-cost reimbursement and auto repairs.
"Ultimately, we'll have to get at the root of it," said Kay Doughty, the Massachusetts Insurance Commissioner, "like hospital bills and car-repair bills that are high."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Outlook for Fall Could Spur Cut in Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The beginning of fall is often accompanied by a quickening economic pace. This year may be different.
To a number of analysts, the economy is entering the final quarter of the year with less momentum than was visible when summer began. 
 This anemic outlook and the prospect of favorable inflation figures are the leading reasons why many analysts say there is at least an even chance that the Federal Reserve will lower short-term interest rates again, possibly some time next month.
"On a risk-reward basis, the Fed won't be penalized very much for doing too much" to insure the recovery, said Leonard J. Santow, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. But if "the economy turns down again and the Fed does nothing, Congress and the Administration won't be willing to take all of the blame."
 
Concern Over Manufacturing
 Economists are especially concerned about the health of the manufacturing sector, the area that in the July-September period appears to have been lively enough to insure that the economy expanded, albeit modestly, in the third quarter.
But the boost from production seems to be waning. Industrial production has risen for the last five months, but in the June-August period the rate of increase slowed markedly. And despite a rise in disposable incomes, consumer spending remained weak throughout the summer.
"We are coming around to the view that growth in the fourth quarter will be weaker than it was in the third," said Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco.
"I don't see anything that would give us more of a lift," he said. "At the same time, I don't think we are looking at one quarter of growth and then a relapse."
 
Autos Considered Key
 The key to continued growth in manufacturing over the rest of the year, economists say, rests with the auto makers. Unless auto sales stage a sharp rebound from current levels, the outlook is not promising.
"Auto production was the major reason for the lift in the industrial sector in the third quarter," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But it may not provide anything in the fourth. I would argue that the industrial sector will grow, but will do so with a good deal less intensity than it did in the third quarter."
Because of the questionable outlook for the economy, investors are already anticipating sharply lower rates. With rates already down on money market accounts and certificates of deposit, increasingly large amounts of money are being redirected out of banks and into higher-yielding fixed-income assets at mutual funds.
"We have had the highest level of sales in the last couple of years, particularly in bond funds," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "In talking with brokers, the pace accelerated in September. A genuine panic among retail investors is under way."
 
Await Bigger Spread
 Investors are buying longer maturities to regain some of the yield that banks are no longer offering. But so far the extension has been modest. Money managers said it was difficult to foresee circumstances that would push small investors into highly speculative 30-year bonds.
"Until yield spreads between 10-year notes and 30-year bonds widen out to more than a full percentage point, I don't think you will see much movement into bonds," said Loren A. Hansen, a senior investment counselor at the Northern Trust Company.
By the end of last week, yields on the Treasury's 30-year bonds stood at 7.88 percent. Ten-year notes, meanwhile, were yielding 7.56 percent.
A willingness to lengthen maturities ought to be good news for the Treasury, which is scheduled to hold auctions of two-year and five-year notes this week. And it is a welcome source of additional demand for the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
The decline in short-term rates is "helping all long-term, higher-yielding markets," said George Friedlander, a managing director at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "But a lot of the money that had been held in short-term accounts at banks that has moved into municipals should have been in tax-exempts to begin with."
 
Success for New Fund
 The strength of retail demand for tax-exempt securities was seen last week, when John Nuveen & Company, the big municipal bond mutual fund company, raised more than $1 billion in an initial public offering of shares in a closed-end fund investing in insured municipal securities.
Nuveen initially intended to sell 10 million shares in the fund. It ended up selling 75 million.
Analysts say the trend toward lower short- and long-term interest rates remains in place, but they add that further progress toward that end seems unlikely over the next week or so.
Indeed, with the exception of a report expected Wednesday on durable-goods orders, there is little on the economic calendar this week with the potential to spark much interest.
Because of the huge 11.2 percent rise reported for July, analysts will pay a good bit of attention to how durable-goods orders fared in August.
After such an enormous gain, most economists are projecting that new orders fell last month, possibly by as much as 5 percent.
A more modest decline, or an increase, would probably get a poor reception in the fixed-income markets.
