HEADLINE: Clarke Offering a Defense Of Record as Comptroller

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
With his nomination to another term as one of the nation's top banking regulators in jeopardy, Robert L. Clarke today defended his record of five and a half years as the Comptroller of the Currency and vowed to increase supervision of banks if he is confirmed.
In a letter to the head of the House Banking Committee today and in remarks he released that are to be delivered on Monday before an industry group, Mr. Clarke said his agency would be hiring 300 examiners in the next two years, the equivalent of increasing its field force by about 15 percent, and would also conduct examinations of small banks more frequently. 
 On Thursday, Mr. Clarke is scheduled to appear before the Senate Banking Committee in what is expected to be a confrontational proceeding. Responding to a torrent of personal and professional criticism in recent weeks, Mr. Clarke and his senior aides have been preparing to release new information about his finances and track record before the hearing.
The appointment of Mr. Clarke and several other senior regulators up for nomination may be pivotal to the Presidential election. With the health of the economy promising to be a key issue in the election, just 14 months away, the regulators' role has become magnified by their ability to stimulate industrial growth and consumer spending by controlling lending practices and the cost of credit. They also play a central role in deciding how fast to close insolvent banks and savings associations and in estimating the rescue costs for those troubled industries.
Neither of the other key regulators -- Alan Greenspan for another term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and William Taylor to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation -- faces significant opposition. Mr. Taylor will appear before the Banking Committee on Tuesday. No date has been set for Mr. Greenspan's confirmation proceeding.
But a number of officials, banks and Republican Party supporters have urged an easing of bank regulation and attributed tight lending practices in many regions to excessive regulation and examiners who responded too strongly to criticism that they were asleep in the years leading up to the banking crisis. At the same time, some lawmakers as well as the General Accounting Office have urged the regulators to continue to apply regulatory standards strictly to prevent the banking crisis from growing.
Mr. Clarke, like Mr. Taylor, is perceived by senior Treasury officials as a team player who will not openly break ranks with the Administration or exert the kind of independence exhibited by L. William Seidman, the departing chairman of the F.D.I.C., who often irritated officials in the White House and at the Treasury by speaking his mind.
Again today, a senior Administration official blamed regulators in part for the state of the economy and tried to maintain that the regulators' independence had made it difficult for the Bush Administration to alter what many economists see as a sluggish recovery.
"The banks have been terrorized and so have the examiners," the official, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said on the ABC News program "This Week with David Brinkley." "There needs to be a somewhat more refined discrimination. For example, with respect to real estate loans, they've essentially said all real estate is bad. That's ridiculous. Some is good. Some isn't good. And there need to be finer distinctions made so that good loans continue to be made."
Asked how officials can force greater lending if banks see it as too risky, Mr. Darman said: "It's influenced partly by their judgment, and they'll be influenced by their judgment about the economy, but also by the regulators themselves. They are somewhat independent by design, and so there's a limit on what we can do." He added that the recovery was "not coming up as strongly as we would want."
 
Opposition Growing in Congress
 Mr. Clarke's reappointment as supervisor of more than 4,000 banks, holding almost two-thirds of the industry's assets, was announced nine months ago by President Bush but has been delayed largely because of a growing view in Congress that he does not deserve another term.
Over the last few weeks, he has been the subject of an intense stream of criticism from the House Banking Committee, which rated his agency the worst of the major bank regulators; the General Accounting office, which said his office had mishandled the costly failure of the Bank of New England, and some Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee, who have urged him to step down.
Mr. Clarke declined a request for an interview before the Thursday hearing, saying through an aide that he was eager to use the hearing to respond to the growing number of questions.
Today he sought to defend his record in a letter and through the advance text of a speech to be delivered on Monday to the Consumer Bankers Association in Hot Springs, Va.
"I understand and share the anguish caused by the high cost of bank failures," Mr. Clarke said in a letter to Represenative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee. "But, frankly, I am dismayed when the O.C.C.'s regulatory activities are unfairly criticized."
Employing a strategy that has appeared to be working in recent weeks for Robert Gates, the President's nominee to head the Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Clarke also took a somewhat contrite view.
"Looking back with the clairvoyance that the passage of time provides, the O.C.C. could have devoted more attention to small banks," he said in the speech. "The criticism that we've received for being too tough has been exceeded only by the criticism that we've been too lax."
Last week, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, the head of the Senate Banking Committee, asked the Administration to reconsider the appointment of Mr. Clarke and strongly signaled that his confirmation hearing on Thursday would be confrontational. Other Democrats on the committee have also criticized the appointment as well as at least one Republican on the panel, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
 
Favorable Ethics Review
 On Friday, Mr. Clarke received somewhat better news from the Office of Government Ethics, which concluded that there was no evidence that his numerous personal investments in junk bonds were made "with disregard for ethics standards" and that there was no evidence that he had improperly used his position and privileged information for making investments.
The ethics investigators also found that Mr. Clarke had inaccurately disclosed a loan to a subordinate in his office but that it was the result of mistaken advice by unidentified ethics officials at the Treasury Department and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
The conclusions of the Office of Government Ethics largely mirrored the findings in June of an investiation by the Treasury Department.

HEADLINE: Poor Nations' Growth Hurt By Gulf War

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The world's poorest nations experienced financial setbacks last year, compounded by economic shocks from the Persian Gulf crisis, the World Bank said today in its annual report.
The lending agency, whose membership comprises 155 nations, said overall economic growth in the third world edged up 2.3 percent last year, the worst showing since 1982. 
 The situation was even more dire when the weak growth was measured against population increases in the developing nations, the report said.
 
Income Up 0.2%
 Per-capita income in the third world rose two-tenths of a percent in 1990, compared with gains of 2 percent in 1988 and 1 percent in 1989.
The poor economic showing was attributed to many factors, including the spillover effect of the economic slowdown in rich industrial countries and less growth in world trade.
But the report said many of the shocks stemmed from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August of last year, which caused oil prices to rise, disrupted trade flows and sent a flood of refugees streaming from the war zone.
The economic difficulties were widespread throughout the third world. Only in Asia did per-capita income rise in developing countries, the report said.
 
East Asian Growth
 Among the 18 countries in East Asia, per-capita incomes rose an average of 4.3 percent. The World Bank said slower-than-average growth in China was offset by vigorous gains in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.
The eight countries in South Asia, including India, Bangladash and Pakistan, experienced an increase of per-capita income of 2.1 percent in 1990, but the report warned that continued growth was threatened in India.
Developing countries in all other regions experienced declines in per-capita income last year. The biggest setback occurred in Latin America, where per-capita incomes fell by 2.6 percent last year. The report said the situation was most severe for Argentina, Brazil and Peru, as their economies continued to be plagued by high levels of debt.
 
African Nations' Effect
 The nations of sub-Saharan Africa, including some of the poorest countries in the world, saw per-capita incomes fall by 2.1 percent last year, while the developing countries in North Africa, the Middle East and Europe experienced a 1.3 percent drop in per-capita incomes, the first decline for the region since 1987.
The Eastern European countries had negative growth rates stemming primarily from the disruptions as they transform their economies to free-market systems.
The World Bank noted that it had increased its lending to former Soviet bloc countries to try to support their economic reform movements. Poland received the largest amount, $1.44 billion.
Only countries that are members of the World Bank qualify for loans. The Soviet Union has applied for membership but the United States has successfully led the effort to block it.

HEADLINE: NEW LAW TO BRING WIDER JOB RIGHTS FOR MENTALLY ILL

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
A Federal law that takes effect in July will provide far-reaching employment rights to the mentally ill, requiring most businesses to alter hiring practices and workplace conditions.
Psychologists and Government officials say they expect the law and the recently issued regulations explaining it to diminish the stigma of mental illness and reduce discrimination involving millions of Americans. At least 60 million Americans between the ages of 18 and 64 will experience a mental disorder during their lifetimes, Government economists say. 
 The Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, which applies to all businesses with 25 or more employees, bars employers from asking job applicants standard questions like whether they have a history of mental illness. Once hired, employees with these problems will be entitled to extra support and accommodation from their employers so long as they can perform essential job requirements. The rules will be extended in 1994 to cover companies with 15 or more employees.
 
Emerging Implications
 Many large corporations are only beginning to recognize the law's implications. Lawyers involved in mental health issues say companies are unlikely to try to get rid of mentally ill workers before the law takes effect, in part because many of these employees have not come forward and are hard to identify.
"As this law starts to be taken seriously, it will be a tool that protects people from the widespread and deep-seated fear and hostility toward any kind of mental illness," said Leonard S. Rubinstein, a lawyer who is executive director of the Mental Health Law Project, a public interest law firm in Washington.
The new Federal law does not protect workers who cannot perform the fundamental duties of their jobs, but it is nonetheless expected to have sweeping repercussions. Most states have laws protecting the handicapped, but disability-rights lawyers say many of those laws, including California's, exclude people with mental disabilities.
 
Few Current Cases
 Mentally ill employees have brought relatively few complaints under existing state laws. "Cases often aren't brought; people with mental illnesses don't assert their rights because of the stigma," said Ellen M. Saideman, director of disability law with the New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, a nonprofit group. "And a lot of employers have had no idea what their obligations are."
Under the new Federal law, Ms. Saideman said, "we expect more people will be aware and filing complaints."
The law covers a broad range of mental problems, including retardation and learning disabilities. It also protects workers who have overcome alcohol or drug addiction. Employees may still be dismissed for intoxication or for using illegal drugs at work.
Employers usually deal with mental illnesses and substance abuse as related problems, treated by the same counselors and institutions and provided for in the same budget. Drug and alcohol problems affect about 27 million people of working age, the Government estimates.
The cost of mental health care is growing rapidly while companies struggle to control health-care costs in general, and many businesses have limited payments for treating mental illnesses. Richard J. Sinni, a health-management specialist with Buck Consultants in New York, said many employers already spend 10 to 20 percent of their medical-benefits budgets on treatments for mental illness.
 
Medical Rejections Curbed
 Under the new Federal law, businesses cannot reject job applicants because they might add to a company's medical costs. But legal experts say the law does not prevent employers from limiting benefits for the treatment of mental illness, as many companies are now doing. Some seriously ill employees, for example, are forced into disability status and dropped after receiving disability payments for two years.
Federal officials estimate that at least 15 million adults will experience one or more of three types of severe mental illness -- schizophrenia, manic-depressive disorders or major depression -- in their lifetimes. And an estimated one of four Americans will have one of a wider range of mental problems, including anxiety disorders like claustrophobia, personality problems and mental retardation.
These would all be covered by the law. Conditions not covered include kleptomania, pyromania, compulsive gambling and certain types of sexual behavior, like transvestism.
"In the past, in the manufacturing and producing segment of the company, there has been more of a standard that a person is either 100 percent qualified for a job or not," said Kenneth R. Collins, manager of employee assistance programs at the Chevron Corporation. "That will have to be very carefully reconsidered." He said Chevron had been more flexible in making accommodations for office workers with mental disorders.
Special provisions for the mentally handicapped might be as minor and inexpensive as providing more frequent breaks or quieter work areas. "The law will not require a large amount of money for physical changes," said William A. Anthony, executive director of the Center for Psychiatric Rehabilitation at Boston University.
But for those who require hospital treatment, the cost can be $10,000 or more.
The law covers physical as well as mental problems, and regulations issued in July by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission are much more specific on the physical side. Most experts agree that workplace conditions for the physically handicapped have improved greatly over the last two decades, but they say enforcement has been spotty.
The National Federation of Independent Business, a lobbying group for small businesses, said about 10 members were calling each week seeking advice on their obligations under the new law. One business owner is trying to determine his rights in dealing with a mentally ill employee who refuses to take prescribed medication. Federal officials and business lawyers predict that the answers to such questions will be determined in thousands of lawsuits.
 
Possibility of Savings
 Mental illness is a drag on the economy and, in the long run, the law might actually save businesses money by reducing absenteeism and turnover and improving the productivity of the mentally ill, some psychologists say.
The National Institute of Mental Health said last year that mental illness had cost the nation $129.3 billion in 1988, of which $57 billion was in lost productivity.
The new law catches many companies unprepared, though none would publicly admit as much. "Many employers haven't thought about the implications of the act for accommodating mental disabilities," said Veronica Vaccaro, manager of mental health promotion with the Washington Business Group on Health, an employers' organization.
Some large employers like Wells Fargo, Prudential Insurance and Chevron already have committees of executives studying how to meet the new obligations. Other companies are considering how they may have to change their practices.
Federal law already protects the mentally ill at companies with Government contracts. So large contractors like the International Business Machines Corporation might not have to adjust their policies, although the new law could make employees more aware of their rights.
At many contractors, the mentally ill have advanced. Tony Cerqueira, the president of the Manic-Depression Depressive Association of Los Angeles, a support group, has worked for the Prudential Insurance Company for six years. Mr. Cerqueira, who is 34 years old, said he disclosed his illness, which he controls with medication, when he was hired to write group contracts. Two years ago, he was promoted to what he calls a high-profile auditor's position by a manager fully aware of his condition. "She is very supportive," he said.
Prudential, a Federal contractor, has a policy of encouraging the hiring of people with mental and physical disabilities. And a number of companies already have programs to recruit and train retarded employees; the McDonald's Corporation has hired thousands over the years.
 
Hiding the Disorder
 But most people with mental disorders say they still hide their problems. Patricia M., who asked that her name not be used, works on computer graphics for a large company in Manhattan. Although she has been there for 11 years, she said, "I have not told my bosses that I take medication for unipolar depression." The illness "hasn't really kept me from work," she added, "though sometimes it has been a monumental effort" to keep going.
Bryan Lawton, a clinical psychologist who is a vice president and director of employee assistance services with the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco, runs a program for people with mental disorders. "There are a number of unknowns" in the new law, he said, adding, "It's not going to be nearly as great of a burden as some people may fear." 
And Patricia M. Owens, a former Social Security Administration official who is a vice president with Thomas L. Jacobs & Associates, a disability consulting firm, commented, "Many of these people want to work and are going to try to minimize the impact of their disability."
Health-benefits experts say it is hard to figure the possible costs of complying with the new law. Dr. Mary Jane England, a psychiatrist who is president of the Washington Business Group on Health, said companies were already paying for many mental health problems -- through lost productivity and disability payments for physical ailments, like aching backs, that often have psychological causes.
But the law may help improve the productivity of the mentally ill by relieving the strain of prejudice.
"There is a lot of fear around mental illness," said Karen Danley, a program director with the Boston University rehabilitation center. "People feel vulnerable. They have all had some experience of being out of control or emotionally undone. When they see someone else who is labeled as mentally ill, it's scary."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A new law will provide far-reaching employment rights to the mentally ill, requiring most businesses to alter hiring practices and workplace conditions when it takes effect in July. Psychologists and Government officials say they expect the Federal law and regulations explaining it to diminish the stigma of mental illness and reduce discrimination involving millions of Americans. But companies are only beginning to recognize the implications. [Page A1.] 
 Efforts to overhaul auto insurance systems remain stalled or ineffective, forcing drivers to pay higher rates and insurers to grapple with escalating legal, medical and car-repair costs. [D1.]
Robert L. Clarke defended his record as Comptroller of the Currency and vowed to increase supervision of banks if he is confirmed. With his nomination to another term appearing in jeopardy, Clarke said his agency would hire 300 new examiners. [D1.]
Federal agencies are collaring industries and interest groups and getting them together to decide what new regulations will say. At stake are rules that govern everything from who may sit in the exit rows on airliners to how much a power plant can pollute. [A1.]
Black professionals are becoming more concerned that they are being disproportionately hurt by widening layoffs and that their opportunities for advancement are being crippled. [D1.] Blacks have been steadily returning to the South, reversing an exodus of nearly 50 years. [A1.]
 
Companies
As Wal-Mart and Target pursue aggressive expansion, their paths are crossing with increasing frequency. And with a revitalized K Mart in the fray, the battle for discount shoppers' hearts and pocketbooks promises to be among retailing's fiercest fights. [D1.]
Regulators have forced Alyeska Pipeline Service to spend at least $15 million repairing air-pollution control equipment because of a determined tipster. As the repair work progressed, Alyeska became deeply involved in an extensive undercover operation to root out people inside the company who secretly provided tips. [A14.]
 
The Media Business
The television networks attracted sharply higher audiences last week for the fall premieres of their prime-time programs. Executives called this encouraging evidence that viewers still look to the networks for new entertainment. [D1.]
Time magazine is trying to redefine itself as it conducts, with secrecy, a big redesign. Deirdre Carmody: Magazines. [D14.]
Disabled people are finding more "real life parts" in ads and on television as these roles gain acceptance from companies like Chrysler and McDonald's. [D14.]
The San Diego Tribune is not a failing afternoon daily by most measurements, but it is being merged into its sister paper, the morning San Diego Union, to cut costs. [D14.]
Mr. Peanut is being given a wider role in advertising for Planters, where he has served as the symbol of nut products for 75 years. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]
David J. Pecker is the new president of Hachette Magazines, the U.S. subsidiary of France's largest magazine publisher. [D15.]

The global economy is being buffeted by extreme poverty, sweeping changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, and lingering effects of the Persian Gulf war, the World Bank said. [D7.]

The economy is entering the final quarter with less momentum than was visible when summer began. As such, many analysts believe the Federal Reserve is likely to push short-term rates lower. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Three Killed in New Haven During a Sickout by Police

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
The City of New Haven experienced one of the most violent weekends in recent memory, the police said yesterday, with 3 people killed and at least 7 wounded by gunfire beginning Friday night. The killings occurred on a weekend in which many police officers called in sick to protest disciplinary action by the department.
The president of the police officers' union, Sgt. Louis Cavalier, said that as many as 60 officers called in sick beginning Friday night and that the department was operating at almost half strength on some shifts. Friday evening, for example, when 40 officers normally are on duty, only about 25 officers reported to work, he said. 
 Sergeant Cavalier said the union did not condone any move by an officer to call in sick unless he or she were ill, and he denied that there was any connection between the reduced patrols and any of the killings.
 
At Least 26 Killed This Year
 The shootings, including two deaths that resulted from a noisy gang fight outside a restaurant, brought the toll of slayings this year in New Haven to at least 26, compared with 16 in the comparable period of 1990. Some residents were asking yesterday if some of the violence over the weekend might have been prevented if more officers had been on duty.
"I'm sure if a police officer had been there they would have just gone out, or called for a backup or something and stopped it," said Chris Papanikolaou, co-owner of the Athenian Diner on Whalley Avenue, where the gang fight broke out early Saturday. Two people were shot to death and one person was wounded, the police said.
Mr. Papanikolaou said he routinely paid the city to have a uniformed officer assigned to the restaurant from midnight to 5 A.M. Friday through Sunday. But on Friday, as talk of the possible sickout protest swept the department, he said, he was told that no officers would be available.
 
'The Blue Flu'
 "Because of the blue flu they didn't have any extra officers," Mr. Papanikolaou said in a telephone interview.
Sergeant Cavalier of the union said that officers were angered by a decision on Tuesday by the city's Police Chief, Nicholas Pastore, to recommend disciplinary proceedings against two officers involved in the killing of a drug suspect in June. The officers had been cleared of any criminal wrongdoing.
The New Haven Register reported that the police officers' union voted on Thursday to ask the chief to resign.
"The morale at the New Haven Police Department is basically at an all-time low," the sergeant said. "The officers feel that they have a chief who is not concerned about their safety."
 
Coping With Sickout
 The Associated Press quoted Chief Pastore as saying on Friday that officers were being reassigned to cope with the sickout and that adequate police protection would be provided.
Sergeant Cavalier of the union said the officer who was to have worked at the diner on overtime had been instructed instead to work in a patrol car.
The two men killed in the melee in the parking lot at the diner were Hury Poole, 23 years old, and Andrew Pasley, 22, both of New Haven. In the other fatal shooting, a man was killed Saturday night as he apparently tried to rob a Sunoco gas station on Goffe Street. Two of the station's employees were wounded, one of them critically.
Sgt. Walter Kuntz, a Police Department spokesman, said that the slayings were still being investigated and that details were sketchy. He refused to comment on how any officers may have been reassigned on Friday night, saying that questions about staffing over the weekend would have to be answered by Chief Pastore.
Calls to Chief Pastore's office were not answered and the number at his New Haven home is unlisted.
 
Shoplifting Complaints
 Anecdotal accounts indicated that the police presence was lower in at least some areas of the city.
Jason Joyner, a security guard at the Chapel Square Mall, said that 10 to 20 officers usually patrolled the mall through part of the weekend, but that he could not recall seeing any in the last two days. He said that mall security officials had called the New Haven police three times over the weekend to report shoplifting incidents, but that no officer came to the shopping center.
"We had to let the suspects go," Mr. Joyner said. "There's nothing we can do about it."
Sergeant Cavalier said that the decision by Chief Pastore to discipline the two officers involved in the June shooting had inflamed anger that was already smoldering over stalled contract talks. The union members, who have been working without a contract since June 30, are trying to bargain with a city whose finances have been hit hard by the recession.
The two officers involved in the disciplinary inquiry, Giro Esposito and Thomas Herbert, killed a drug suspect after the man apparently tried to run one of the officers down with his car. The were both cleared of any criminal action by the Connecticut state Attorney's office, but the departmental inquiry ordered by Chief Pastore could theoretically result in their dismissal from the force.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Democrats Review Presidential Bids, Vowing to Avoid the Losers' Mistakes

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The ghost of elections past always stalks the hallways of Democratic National Committee meetings, and it was there this weekend -- lurking in the speeches, the slide presentations, and the black humor in the bars and lobbies of the grand old Biltmore Hotel, where the committee gathered for its fall meeting.
Implicit or explicit, the message from many of the candidates here was simple: I will not make the mistakes that the failed nominees have made. This helps explain why so many of them seem so eager to pummel President Bush, after watching Michael S. Dukakis, their most recent nominee, take so many body blows, so passively, in 1988. 
 It explains the scramble of most of the hopefuls to redefine their party's image -- from the pro-business liberal dogma of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts to the emphasis on personal responsibility by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. It also helps explain why even though Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska did not attend this meeting, he was the focus of much interest. Many in the party yearn for the charismatic candidacies of their glory years, and his allies say Mr. Kerrey, who will announce his candidacy on Sept. 30, has the ability to provide one.
In a slide show for the Democrats on Friday afternoon, focusing in large part on voting patterns and campaign mechanics from 1988, researchers from the national committee showed how that election might have been different.
On Saturday, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, another contender, drew some of the loudest applause of the meeting when he declared, "If I'm your nominee, you will not see hordes of young Iowans coming into your state to tell you how to run your state." Among the 413 members of the Democratic National Committee, that is a memory that dies particularly hard: The bright-eyed, overconfident young Northeasterners from the Dukakis campaign who, in the end, did not deliver.
But the new class of candidates says it will be different this time.
 
Presidential Cattle Show
 Seven Presidential hopefuls spoke to the committee this weekend, in a cattle show that became all the more important because the race is starting so late and the field is so little known, even to many of the more active Democrats gathered here. "I think they all did well," said Phil Angelides, the California Democratic chairman. "But there's such a low level of knowledge that people aren't so much jumping as watching."
Still, some Democrats, like committee member Jim Ruvolo of Ohio, said they thought Mr. Harkin and Mr. Clinton were particularly well received.
Mr. Harkin delivered his trademark mix of traditional Democratic liberalism and rough-edged populism. It was greeted with the hearty applause that usually generates from the party faithful, which is why some analysts say Mr. Harkin is a formidable force in the primaries, despite all the criticism that he is just another Democrat too liberal for the voters at large.
Mr. Clinton, as is his custom, called for a new emphasis on values, personal responsibility, and a government that brings a fresh approach to poverty, education and economic decline. But Mr. Clinton's stump speech has slowly but unmistakably changed since he first took it around the country as chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council. Back then, he was heading a group devoted to pushing the party to what it considers the political center, a group that often feuded with Mr. Harkin's wing of the party.
Mr. Clinton left that post in late summer as he moved toward a presidential campaign. Since then, as he takes his message to the active, more liberal Democrats who participate in primaries and caucuses, he has acquired more and more of a populist tone, railing about the abuses on Wall Street and elsewhere at the top of the economic ladder.
Is a trace of Harkinism creeping into Mr. Clinton's message? Stan Greenberg, one of his advisers, asserts that it is a middle-class populism, "whereas Harkin is much more of a labor-capital kind of populism, and therefore much more of a class message than Bill Clinton's."
This tinkering with message, one of the hallmarks of a party that has lost five out of the last six presidential campaigns, is perhaps the surest sign that the 1992 election is underway.
 
Will Jesse Run?
 The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has not yet closed the door on a third race for the nomination, was also paying attention to the messages offered by his fellow Democrats this weekend. Clearly, he told the committee, the other contenders are environmentalists. "I heard a lot of my speeches recycled," Mr. Jackson said.
But, as he later told reporters, he is often imitated, never duplicated. And indeed, while his fellow candidates reached for their own oratorical heights, Mr. Jackson once again proved his ability to hold and move an audience, even one that includes some Democrats who would prefer he did not run. He provided few hints about whether he will run again, although many continue to believe he will not. He focused his speech on the need for vision and purpose and moral commitment in the Democratic Party.
Mr. Jackson used the recent, devastating fire at a poultry processing plant in Hamlet, N.C., as the heart of his speech, returning, again and again, to the plight of many working women. "We must rescue these women," he told an audience that was utterly hushed. "They must not be abandoned."
And he closed with what is one of his favorite Biblical texts, applied, this time, to 1992: "I know it's dark," he said. "I see the polls. But if we hold on together, as surely as it is dark, the morning cometh." The candidates, potential and declared, are trying once again to dispel the ghosts.

HEADLINE: Kenya Tightening Curbs on Dissident Groups

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Increasingly isolated in Africa as it resists calls for multiparty democracy, Kenya's Government seems to be on a collision course with opposition forces.
A senior minister in the Government of President Daniel arap Moi said on Saturday that a scheduled meeting here in the capital by a newly formed opposition group, the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy, would be "crushed" if it went ahead as scheduled on Oct. 5. The minister, Nicholas Biwott, a close ally of Mr. Moi, has barred opposition leaders from the Rift Valley province where he holds a parliamentary seat. 
 At the same time, Kenyan lawyers who have been at the heart of the push for more democracy urged the Government at a meeting this weekend to hold a referendum that would decide whether Kenya would remain a one-party state. The East African nation officially became a one-party state in 1982.
At the two-day meeting of the Kenya branch of the International Commission of Jurists, the lawyers also urged the repeal of sedition laws that make much political activity a crime. The chairman of the Kenya Law Society, Paul Muite, is currently on trial in Nairobi with 10 other members of the society on contempt-of-court charges for criticizing a series of rulings by the Chief Justice of Kenya and another judge of the High Court. Mr. Muite, who is not in custody, faces jail if the Government wins the case.
The standoff this weekend between the Government and its critics comes as the United States Congress is about to consider whether to cut off all economic and military aid to Kenya. The Senate version of the foreign aid bill calls for an end of aid to Kenya on the ground that not enough progress has been made toward political pluralism. The third largest donor to Kenya after Japan and Britain, the United States gave about $30 million in economic aid and $5 million in military aid to Kenya this year.
Senators seeking the cut-off are particularly incensed that the Moi Government has refused to register a new political party formed by a well-known politician, Oginga Odinga, and has punished those who have urged its legalization. Mr. Odinga's son, Raila Odinga, recently released from jail, where he was held for a year without charges, was fired on by gunmen 10 days ago while he was driving his car.
After Mr. Muite called on the government to register the Odinga party, four lawyers acting on behalf of the Government got an injunction against Mr. Muite that barred him from making statements construed to be political. The contempt charges were called the "capstone of a repressive campaign" against Kenyan lawyers by the New York City Bar Association, which has been monitoring human rights abuses in East Africa.
During his 13 years in office, Mr. Moi has gradually consolidated his political and financial powers. Many members of his tribe, the Kalengin, have attained prominent positions even though the tribe is one of the smallest in Kenya.
 
Democracy Centuries Away?
 In arguing that one-party rule is best for Kenya, Mr. Moi insists that multiple parties would result in a rise of "tribalism," with parties formed along tribal lines. Many educated, younger Kenyans say they find this fear exaggerated. In a new twist, which many Kenyans said they found insulting, Mr. Moi said last month that Kenya was "at least 200 years behind" the West in economic development and therefore should not expect Western-style democracy for another two centuries.
Mr. Moi came under new pressure this month when the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, changed the tone of British diplomacy toward its favored former colony. He said explicitly that "I would like to see multiparty democracy eventually restored to Kenya." During his visit here, Mr. Hurd urged greater freedom of expression and met with two opposition leaders, Martin Shikuku and Masinde Muliro.
Mr. Hurd said: "I would not complain at all if the opposition here, critics of the government here, use my visit to air their criticism." In the past, the British, who have substantial investments here, have given only fulsome praise to Mr. Moi.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid to Israel: $77 Billion Since '67

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The controversy over Israel's request for $10 billion in United States loan guarantees has focused wide attention on a large-scale but little-understood American aid effort that since 1967 has totaled at least $77 billion -- $16,500 for each Israeli citizen -- when adjusted for inflation.
American aid to Israel may actually be larger than that, since it consists not only of the well-known grants and loans that prop up the Israeli economy and bolster its military, but also seldom-noticed indirect assistance. This includes such items as huge transfers of surplus military equipment, subsidies for Israel's foreign aid program and assistance to refugees arriving from the Soviet Union, State Department and Congressional officials say. 
 Moreover, Israel alone among recipients of American aid receives its money at the beginning of each fiscal year, instead of in payments over the course of the year, allowing it to invest in United States Treasury securities and collect interest on the money until it is actually spent.
Nearly three-quarters of Israel's aid consists of grants, according to figures from the Bank of Israel. Israel reduced its annual interest on the remaining $13 billion in loans by $150 million several years ago by refinancing at a lower interest rate, a privilege also made available then to 37 other American allies with weak economies.
 
No Need for U.S. to Pay
 Israel is seeking the $10 billion in loan guarantees now to help resettle up to a million Jewish emigres expected by 1995. With the loan guarantees, banks would lend to Israel at reduced interest rates with the assurance that the United States would be responsible for any principal or interest payments that Israel could not make. Israel's credit rating is fairly good, and its officials say there would be no need for the United States to pay any money.
Israeli officials contend that without the guarantees their country would be unable to provide the housing and jobs needed to use fully the many skills of immigrants from the Soviet Union. The Israeli economy and imports from the United States would suffer, they contend.
But President Bush has insisted that granting the aid now would needlessly upset the Middle East peace process, and he has asked Congress to put off debate on the matter for four months.
The current political uproar has strengthened Congress's interest in examining the financial burden of the American relationship with Israel, which has not been well understood because Israel has tapped many sources outside the main foreign aid programs.
 
List From State Department
 Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East, said he had recently received a list of readily measured aid from the State Department totaling $4 billion for the fiscal year ending this month. The list separately included several programs with costs that are hard to estimate, partly because not all of the money in them had been spent, he said.
"So far as I know it's a comprehensive list, but things keep popping out," Mr. Hamilton said.
An Administration official who insisted on anonymity said "it's really an aid industry," in which no one keeps a full tally of the aid provided.
Mr. Hamilton, Congressional aides and Israeli officials stressed that the United States received much in return for its assistance. Israel has been the nation's main military partner for decades in a region both vital to United States interests and highly unstable.
The $300 million for the stockpiling of American military equipment in Israel, for example, could not be labeled solely as aid to that country, since it is very advantageous to the United States to be able to store its gear there, Mr. Hamilton said.
Economic and military aid programs to Israel, without adjustment for inflation, totaled $47.8 billion from 1967 through last year, according to the figures from the Bank of Israel. But Israeli officials themselves pointed out that it would be more accurate to adjust for inflation. Using the consumer price index in the United States, the aid to Israel would be to $77 billion in 1991 dollars.
 
Some Hard to Estimate
 The programs that are hard to estimate include up to $700 million in surplus military equipment, most of it from American forces being withdrawn from Europe, that is to be turned over to Israel; $400 million in loan guarantees; $150 million in annual interest savings from the refinancing of United States military loans five years ago; $300 million for eventual stockpiles of American equipment in Israel; $60 million in price reductions for military equipment sales and $42 million for a joint air defense development program.
Israel's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees would not involve any immediate outlay for the United States. But under a new law that takes effect on Oct. 1, Congress would have to set aside some money to reflect the risk of potential defaults.
Congress's current budget rules also impose a cap on international spending, including foreign aid. Depending on how different types of aid are categorized, this means that Congress could be confronted with a difficult choice this year on how to divide up limited money among Israel, the Soviet Union and other candidates for American assistance.
The proposed $10 billion in loan guarantees for the resettlement of Soviet Jews in Israel would be much more generous than Mr. Bush's $1.5 billion agricultural loan guarantee program to feed the Soviet Union. The food loan program only guarantees 98 percent of the principal and the first 4.5 percentage points of interest.
 
Banks Are Reluctant
 Commercial banks have been reluctant to take part in this program for fear of losing the unguaranteed part of any loans.
By contrast, Israeli officials want their guarantees to cover all of the loans' principal and all of the interest. Because existing American loan guarantee programs do not have such generous terms, a new program would probably have to be created for Israel, Congressional aides said.
American loan guarantees could save Israel as much as $200 million a year in interest payments, said John F. H. Purcell, the director of the sovereign research group at Salomon Brothers Inc. This is because Israel has a BBB credit rating, forcing it to borrow at an interest rate that is 2 percentage points higher than the rate for United States Government-guaranteed debt, he said.
Such a calculation assumes that Israel would be able to borrow the money at all without the guarantees and without lowering its credit rating, which would result in higher interest rates. "Anybody but the very large countries would have trouble borrowing $10 billion," Mr. Purcell agreed.
Israeli officials estimate that with the guarantees they could borrow as much as $2 billion a year for five years, while without them they would be limited to $500 million a year.

HEADLINE: Gunmen Kill Grocery Owner in Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
For 14 years Luisa Caban ran her grocery on Gildersleeve Avenue in the Bronx like a small-town general store, chatting with neighbors, dispensing friendly advice to anxious young mothers, and quietly extending credit to those facing lean times.
But this weekend the slow and easy rhythms that usually prevail in the Clasons Point section, a secluded community of tidy one-family homes nestled onto a peninsula jutting into the East River, were jolted when robbers shot and killed Mrs. Caban during a failed robbery attempt. 
 Two or three youths brandishing automatic weapons entered the store, Roberta's Grocery, shortly after 7:30 P.M. on Saturday, said Detective Frank Corsillo of the 43d Precinct Detective Squad. They demanded that Mrs. Caban open the cash register, and when she did not react fast enough, she was shot twice, in the chest and the left arm.
Her assailants pistol-whipped an employee, but fled empty-handed when he failed to open the cash register, Detective Corsillo said. The suspects, possibly as many three Hispanic males in their late teens or early 20', are still at large, he said.
 
Coping With Grief
 A leafy green wreath hung on the store's rolled-down shutters yesterday, while friends, neighbors and relatives made their way around the corner, to the apartment where Mrs. Caban lived with her mother, three daughters and a grandson. They grappled with the unfamiliar rituals of grief, in a community that many said had been free until recently of the wanton violence that has marred life in other neighborhoods.
In a neighborhood where people still look out for one another, Mrs. Caban looked out for everybody.
"She was one hell of a fighter," said Zoraida Marquez, a friend of Mrs. Caban who has lived in the neighborhood for 22 years. "She would never close her door to anyone in need. I don't know why this would happen."
Mrs. Caban, 43 years old, came to the United States from Ecuador 17 years ago and was an American citizen. She and her husband Roberto, from whom she separated recently, bought the store 14 years ago, naming it after their youngest daughter Roberta, who is now 16.
"She was so proud of her kids," Ms. Marquez recalled. "She wanted them to go to school so they could make something of themselves. Roberta had everything a kid could want -- Barbizon, karate lessons, tap dancing."
She was also a soft touch for those who were short on cash or luck.
"I had my situations when I've been economically down and she always extended credit to me and offered herself to me in many ways," Ms. Marquez said. "We would talk and discuss our teen-age kids' problems, like one mother to another."
Outside the cramped hallway to the family's apartment, children astride bicycles stood quietly watching as neighbors went to express their condolences to the family. Clementina Lopez, Mrs. Caban's mother, tearfully hugged neighbors.
 
'Don't Wait for Death'
 Mrs. Lopez and her great-grandson Jaime were in the store during the robbery. She had often told her daughter that a bodega was no business for a single mother to be involved with.
"Don't wait for death there," she recalled telling her. "But she would say 'What can I do? If something is going to happen it will happen wherever I work.' "
Orville Barnes lived upstairs from Mrs. Caban -- she helped him get the apartment, he said. He was was walking back to his apartment after visiting his son Saturday evening when he saw a police car outside the store. Rushing inside, he saw Mrs. Caban slumped on the floor behind the register, bleeding and twitching.
"Whenever you needed something, she was there for the calling," he said. "She was a nice person, never hurt anybody."
Lillian Santiago recalled how Mrs. Caban concocted a home remedy that cured her daughter's cold last year. "She mixed honey, onions and lemon in a jar," she said. "It worked, my daughter spit everything up."
To many in the neighborhood, Mrs. Caban's death marks the undeniable realization that the violence that has shaken many other communities has forced itself upon their out-of-the-way haven of narrow tree-lined side streets where until recently the only disturbance was the regular roar of low-flying jets making their landing approach at La Guardia Airport.
"You see more people, more kids running around in the traffic," said Norma Duran. "It's just not the same as before."
Nelson Malave grew up in a house a few doors from the store, and although his family moved from the neighborhood, he returned often to talk with friends outside and help Mrs. Caban unload groceries and other odd jobs.
"I know who the strangers are around here," he said. "I just throw them off the block."
A migraine kept him home Saturday night.
"I should have been here," he said. "I either would have been killed or wounded, but I know I definitely would have gotten one of them."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
One Man's Rx For an Economy That's Still Ailing

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In 1984, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo galvanized Democrats by challenging President Reagan's vision that economic recovery had transformed America into a "shining city on the hill."
Now, less than a year before another Democratic national convention, New Yorkers are anxiously awaiting another overdue recovery. The Governor, meanwhile, is grappling with the consequences of Washington's inattention and local inertia, which have transformed New York into a pining city in a slump. 
 Even before he delivers it, Mr. Cuomo's two-pronged prescription for recovery is being billed as an equally visionary if more pragmatic version of his defining 1984 speech. To distinguish the soaring oratory for which the Governor is best known from the unusually specific programs he is about to advance, Mr. Cuomo's private preview at the Equitable Center tonight for opinion-makers and his public appearance tomorrow before the Association for a Better New York are being promoted not as a speech at all but as a "presentation."
What will he present? A potentially fundamental change in how New York pays for Medicaid. And an infusion of state public works projects to jump-start the local economy by generating jobs and spurring investment.
Albany would assume responsibility for administering Medicaid. In return, the city would agree to curb certain costs. It would also cede to the state a portion of the city income tax, which has been growing more slowly than the local share of Medicaid. Over seven years or so, the state would complete the assumption of local Medicaid costs that the Governor had begun modestly years ago.
Coupled with phased budget relief, Mr. Cuomo will unveil an ambitious economic revitalization agenda with options that include building mass transit "people movers," possibly on the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway medians, to carry travelers to and from Kennedy and La Guardia Airports and to be paid for through a new tax on airline passengers; advancing two large residential and commercial deveopments, Riverside South in Manhattan and Hunter's Point in Queens; further renovating Grand Central Terminal and Pennyslvania Station and spurring a proposed rail freight operation.
Why now? For fully a year, since the Governor invited business and labor leaders to a gripe session, he has been grappling to balance demands that he intervene to save the city from itself and equally emotional appeals that he do nothing that might be perceived as undermining Mayor David N. Dinkins.
In June, the Governor struggled to devise a vehicle that would temporarily allow the city to stretch out its debt while it restructured services, but without the stigma of ceding control to the Financial Control Board, whose oversight role would be triggered by a deficit.
His good intentions exceeded the grasp of his imagination, though.
In July, he lured the city into a joint project to overhaul government -- only to be rebuffed by the Dinkins administration once it became clear that the government he hoped to overhaul was the city's, and without the Medicaid relief that might let defenders of the status quo off the hook. Since then, the Dinkins administration's negotiations with its unions in search of concessions have not progressed much. The Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force won Mr. Dinkins's approval last week to gauge support for its bold proposal to impose tolls on the three East River bridges, but that suggestion has generated skepticism, Mr. Cuomo's included.
Under Mr. Cuomo, the state has spent about $50 billion on building or re-building the subways, roads and the State University, although he may be remembered more for expanding the prison system and for his ringing but abstract oratory than for concrete solutions.
The Governor believes that as the Mayor drafts a revised four-year financial plan, even a still elusive budgetary solution alone won't be enough to revive the city when private investment and confidence has evaporated.
Immigration is helping to replenish New York's depleted middle class. The Columbus quincentenary next year may raise morale. So might the Democratic national convention, which, as it was in 1976, will be held in New York next year. But spirit alone, even the heights to which Mr. Cuomo's words can raise it, will not substitute for some heavy lifting.
Nearly 60 years ago, on the eve of another national convention, Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed for an overhaul of unaffordable government and for an infusion of public works.
That Mr. Cuomo is now pursuing a similar course does not necessarily imply that the two share the same political ambitions. What it does mean, though, is that an accomplished builder of coalitions and public spirit is again raising expectations that he can deliver on his promise as well as he can deliver a speech.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Medicaid Plan Stirs Cautious Reaction

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 22

 BODY:
New York City officials and the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation reacted cautiously today to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal for a state Medicaid takeover, warning that the financial help might not come soon enough for the city and that the Legislature could prove a serious obstacle.
But state officials responded that the Medicaid plan was only feasible as a long-term strategy. And they expressed frustration, as they have in the past, that the city was continuing to look to the state for a bailout when the state has severe fiscal problems of its own.
 
Taxing Authority
 As part of a plan for state aid to the city, Mr. Cuomo has suggested that the state assume the share of Medicaid costs currently paid by New York City and other local governments. In exchange, local governments would cede existing taxing authority to the state. 
 Cuomo administration officials believe the plan could save nearly $2 billion for local governments by the turn of the century, including about $1 billion for New York City. Mr. Cuomo is scheduled to outline the Medicaid proposal and a variety of economic development proposals in a pair of speeches in New York City on Monday night and Tuesday morning.
Senior city officials said today that they were pleased that Mr. Cuomo was pressing ahead with plans for a Medicaid takeover, a possibility he had relegated to the "removed future" only three months ago. But they expressed concern about Mr. Cuomo's timetable for concluding the takeover by the year 2000, particularly since the whole idea of a takeover, from the city's view, was to relieve budgetary pressures in the next four years.
"At this point, the state seems to be back-loading, rather than front-ending," said Mayor David N. Dinkins's press secretary, Leland T. Jones. "If it's in the year 2000, gee, we might all be old and gray by then."
Mr. Dinkins, who has presided over severe budget cuts, is expected to face a difficult re-election campaign in 1993.
 
Concern Shared by Rohatyn
 Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, shared Mr. Jones's concern. "Certainly in the early years, it isn't going to be a big boon to the city's expense budget," Mr. Rohatyn said.
Mr. Rohatyn's views are significant because he will determine whether the city will reap a four-year windfall of $1 billion from a proposed refinancing of M.A.C. bonds. But Mr. Rohatyn has said repeatedly that such help is conditional on a long-term plan by the city and the state to cut costs and restructure government.
But Andrew J. Zambelli, the Governor's chief of staff, said political and fiscal realities dictated that a Medicaid takeover be stretched over the course of the decade.
"If you were going to do a takeover that was totally front-loaded, you would guarantee that it would never occur," he said. "The Legislature doesn't have $1 billion to give out to local governments next year. You would doom it to failure."
That, Mr. Zambelli said, is why Mr. Cuomo will propose a comprehensive plan of aid for the city that "will save the city hundreds of millions of dollars" in the next four years. Mr. Zambelli said the Medicaid takeover, which would be carried out in phases, could save the city up to $300 million in the third year of the plan.
"It's designed to assist the city in the last three years of its four-year plan, not to bail them out of the other actions they need to take," he said.
Mr. Zambelli and his counterpart at City Hall, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, made clear that the political battle to come would concern the structure and timetable for a Medicaid takeover, with the city pressing for relief in a hurry and the state resisting that pressure.
"There are a number of different scenarios that are being talked about and until we have a chance to put together a single package, I don't want to prejudge it," Mr. Steisel said. "Our concern is to put together a program that puts that city on the road to structural balance but also recognizes the state's fiscal circumstances."
One Dinkins administration official, however, was less delicate. "If the Governor wants to be perceived as helping, the help can't be hollow," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The second political fight will be in Albany, where Mr. Cuomo and local government leaders must convince a skeptical Legislature that they can trim the cost of the state's $12 billion Medicaid program.
Only then would the Republicans who control the State Senate be willing to approve a state takeover of the Medicaid program, which provides health coverage for the poor. Currently, the Federal government pays for about half of all Medicaid costs, with the state and local governments splitting the rest.
 
'A Bit Skeptical'
 "We have to somehow save $1 billion in real money," said Senator John B. Daly of Lewiston, one of three Republican Senators on a state Medicaid task force. "Until then we have to be a bit skeptical."
In recent years, the Legislature has balked at serious efforts to contain Medicaid costs, which have been growing at about 15 percent a year statewide. But Patrick G. Halpin, the Suffolk County Executive, said the strain that Medicaid was placing on local budgets, and thus on real property taxes, could no longer be ignored.
"It is literally bankrupting counties and the city of New York and forcing us to make very difficult choices," said Mr. Halpin, who has watched his county's share of Medicaid costs rise to $109 million this year from $80 million two years ago. "I'll gladly give up a portion of our sales tax revenue knowing that Medicaid costs are going to continue to be growing into the future."

HEADLINE: South's New Blacks Find Comfort Laced With Strain

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALUDA, S.C.

 BODY:
Two and a half years ago, when life in Los Angeles became too stressful, Delores Watson moved back to her hometown more than 2,000 miles away to go into business and start a new life.
Over the years her family had operated the small town's only black funeral home, a restaurant and a barber shop, but she and her husband, Rodney, had two teen-age children to raise as well. And raising them here in Saluda, even against a backdrop of racial prejudice, seemed a bargain when compared with the gang problem and the drugs that had begun to penetrate the black upper-middle-class enclave where they lived. 
 The Watsons are among a steady flow of blacks who have been returning to the South over the last decade, reversing a nearly 50-year-long exodus. Their return is not new, but recent figures from the current population survey of the Census Bureau show the stream surging as black retirees and Northern-born blacks seeking greater economic opportunities appear to be swelling their ranks.
 
Like Those Who Moved North
 The reasons given for the moves are on one level as varied as the people citing them: personal considerations, improved economic opportunities, easier life styles and vastly improved race relations. After a time, though, the stories of the migrants and their lives in the South grow remarkably similar in tone, if not content, to those told a generation or two ago by blacks lured from the rural, agricultural economy of the South to the urban and industrial economy of the North in one of the nation's more significant migrations.
But there are constant reminders of both the positives and negatives that such a move can hold for a black person, and both can appear in a single, complex event. For Mrs. Watson, a stark example occurred just recently.
The 45-year-old owner of a health care and supply company, Mrs. Watson was at the post office in this town of 3,000 people when she saw an elderly white woman who had been a patient of one of her home health care aides. There was brief eye contact, Mrs. Watson said, but her greeting went ignored. She said she let the slight pass because she was used to being "invisible" to some whites in town.
A minute later, though, that same woman, unable to get her grandson to mind, threatened him by openly pointing to Mrs. Watson and saying, "That girl's gonna get you."
It was one thing to be ignored, Mrs. Watson said, but it was something altogether different to be demonized.
"I had to confront her," she said. "I told her that she had to understand that she was creating a negative image of black people for this young child by suggesting that a black woman who had no real interest in him might harm him.
"She apologized and left."
It was a defining moment of sorts for Mrs. Watson, a former personnel officer in Los Angeles city government. There had been racial incidents in Los Angeles that had tried her patience and angered her, she said, but they had been more subtle, more a glancing blow than a direct hit, and her responses were therefore more diffuse.
 
More Effort but More Reward
 "Life in general requires a lot of psychic energy for black people on racial things," she said, "and on balance the things I run into here are more demanding because I am more engaged in this small town and its small-town atmosphere. In Los Angeles I was just sort of an anonymous one of many, but here I feel that the energy I expend gets a one-to-one response, and that is more gratifying."
For Mrs. Watson and her family the move has on balance been a positive one that has fed the soul's yearnings, simplified life and its pitfalls and opened up economic opportunities. It is a much-changed South that she and others blacks have returned to, and there are indications as well, said Isaac Robinson, a sociologist at North Carolina Central University, that many of them were actually born in the North and have little concept of the Old South.
"There is a whole generation out there whose idea of the South has very little to do with lynchings of blacks, segregation or the Ku Klux Klan," he said. "They know that there is some racism, but it is not the predominant thing in their minds."
This flow of blacks to the South was first noticed as a trickle in the late 1970's, but grew to be a good-sized stream in the 80's. From 1985 to 1990, the surveys found, a net of 355,000 black Americans moved to the South, compared with 89,000 the five years before and 193,000 from 1975 to 1980.
A significant factor for the increase, the researchers said, was a reversal of the decades-long black exodus from the South. By 1988, Federal data showed the proportion of blacks in the South rising for first time, reaching 56 percent.
 
Spreading the Word
 The migrants, many of them black retirees returning to the areas where they were born, have spread the word about a host of tangible and intangible advantages of living in the South. Among the tangibles, said George Gaymon, a 52-year-old health services administrator in South Carolina government, is the fact that his Columbia home has triple the square footage that his Montclair, N.J., home had at half the cost.
Mr. Gaymon, who was born in Panola, 50 miles south of Columbia, said the intangibles included friendliness and an excitement at being part of a growing region.
Others talked about the comfort they felt from familiar surroundings and familiar patterns of life. Their return promoted a sense of safety for some, said Phoebe Benson, a single parent in her 30's, who grew up in Columbia and moved back six months ago after a 10-year absence. It also contributed to a sense of being plugged into African-American roots and family roots.
"There are patterns that are very comforting here," said Ms. Benson. "It's like the smell of fresh-washed sheets and bacon frying in the morning. These are verities and they are reassuring for me."
 
Fleeing Specter of the Gangs Scene
 Delores Watson was looking for reassurances as well in her life and in the lives of her children when she decided to return to Saluda and small-town life after 20 years in sprawling Los Angeles. There, she said, she had felt an ever present fear of random violence. But most worrisome was the specter of the corrosive effect the city's gang scene could have on her two children, Akintunde, 17, and Monifa, 15.
"I have two bright children, and I did not want them pressured into participating in a gang or ostracized for being bright," she said.
The family also had a practical reason to return to Saluda: the opportunity to run a business in an economic atmosphere that was less pressured and more forgiving than Los Angeles's.
After years of working in government, Mrs. Watson said that she felt she had reached "the glass ceiling" that so many other highly trained, black professionals reach. Starting her own home health services and health supply business, American Sein Pro, seemed a path to greater satisfaction.
"My family has an entrepreneurial tradition here," said Mrs. Watson, adding, "In a way I came back to an incubator for small businesses that I didn't have in California."
Not everything has been rosy, she said. For one, she and Mr. Watson recently decided to buy a home 48 miles away from Saluda in Columbia, the state capital. With a population of 106,000 and a metropolitan area population of nearly a half million, Columbia offered more housing options, "a better social atmosphere" for her two teen-agers, more amenities and expansion opportunities for her business.
"I will keep the business based here and keep the kind of closeness and community life it offers," she said. "But I really just got tired of driving 48 miles to go to a movie theater."
 
A 'Less Global' Life
 While the small world of Saluda insulated her children from the pressures they had faced in Los Angeles, she said, it also meant moving in a much narrower band of the social spectrum. No Asians or Latinos live in Saluda, she said, and so her children's exposure was "less global" than she wished.
Blacks as well as whites returning to or migrating to the South are overwhelmingly choosing cities and metropolitan areas, said John Kasarda, a sociologist and director of the Kenan Institute of Private Enterprise at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, often for precisely the reasons cited by Mrs. Watson.
Many may have been born elsewhere and are simply going where the jobs are, Mr. Kasarda said. Cities like Atlanta, Columbia and North Carolina's Chapel Hill, Raleigh and Durham in the so-called Research Triangle have in the last decade gained technical, white-collar and manufacturing jobs.
Marshal Logan and his wife, Barbara, chose to retire to the Asheville, N.C., area where Mr. Logan was born and raised. But the small city of 61,000 is not the place they would recommend for their five grown children, who continue to live in the Trenton, N.J., area that the Logans left two years ago.
"With their educational background, their exposure, this is not the place for them," said Mrs. Logan, who was born in Princeton, N.J., and has never lived in the South. "There still aren't great opportunities for young black people in small southern cities like this. They would be better off in an Atlanta or even a Columbia, S.C."
Mr. Logan, a 59-year-old retired school administrator, said he returned to Asheville because the lower cost of living allowed him, on his retirement pay, to maintain the style of living he had had in the Northeast. Safety was also a major factor, he said, and he had heard those same concerns expressed among many other returnees recently when he attended a reunion of his class from Asheville's once-segregated, black high school.
Mr. Logan said he had left Asheville reluctantly in 1958 to go "up east," but added: "That was where the jobs were. I thought I might stay just a few years but with family and a career, that just didn't happen. Now I feel that I have returned to my roots. I go to the church that I grew up in and I have restored an old home next door to my 93-year-old uncle. I feel really at home."

HEADLINE: For the 'Bessie' Festivities, Awards and a Little Music

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON

 BODY:
Dance Theater Workshop presented its eighth annual New York Dance and Performance Awards on Friday night at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center. The awards honored achievements in dance and performance art for the 1990-91 season, and the recipients were chosen by a panel of dancers, producers and dance writers who attended 1,200 performances by approximately 900 artists and companies.
Familiarly known as the Bessies, the awards are named after Bessie Schonberg, a highly regarded teacher of dance composition. Award-winning choreographers and performance-art creators received cash gifts of $1,000. Winners in other categories received $500. 
 Presenting one of the event's three special citations, Miss Schonberg acknowledged that these are economic hard times. Then she said: "Cheer up. We'll all be poor together." The citation went to Nancy Duncan, artistic director of Codanceco, a repertory company that has commissioned more than 50 new works representing many choreographic styles.
 
Special Citations
 Other special citations were presented by Larry Greene, an arts administrator, and Francis Mason, editor of Ballet Review and dance critic for WQXR. They went to Carlos Gutierrez-Solana, director of the visual arts program of the New York State Council on the Arts, and Yuriko, a dancer who has been associated with the Martha Graham Dance Company for 48 years and is now the group's associate artistic director.
Choreographers and creators of performance arts pieces who received awards were Paul Clay, Lora Nelson, Cydney Wilkes, Richard Elovich, Alice Farley, Dan Froot, David Gordon, David Hammons, James Luna, Paul Zaloom, and Gusmiati Suid, Syekh Lah Genta and Atif Usman, directors of the troupes that participated in "Music and Dance of Sumatra: Aceh and Minangkabau," an attraction of last season's Festival of Indonesia.
Winners in other categories included:
Performers: Kyle de Camp, Paula Gifford, Chris Komar, Jeremy Nelson, David Neumann and Desmond Richardson.
Visual design: Anthony Chase, Mimi Gross, Sue Rees and Huck Snyder.
Composers: Tom Cora, Julius Hemphill and Pauline Oliveros.
Liz Prince, Mimi Goese, Sean Curran, Norwood Pennewell, Ann Carlson and Garth Fagan served as awards presenters. The evening's hosts were John Killacky, curator of the performing arts at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, and Reno, a performance artist.
 
A Bit of Satire
 Musical interludes during the program, which lasted almost 3 hours and 15 minutes, were provided by the Feetwarmers, a seven-piece swing combo, and Nana Vasconcelos, a Brazilian singer and percussionist who performed in a collaboration with Scott Lehrer, a sound designer. Jason Wilcox, a female impersonator, portrayed a leather-jacketed Medea modeled upon the pop singer Cher in a scene from a satirical update of Greek mythology.
After a moment of silence that paid tribute to people in the arts who have died of AIDS, the evening came to a joyous conclusion with songs by Lavender Light: The Black and People of All Colors Lesbian and Gay Gospel Choir.
Established with the aid of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which continues to provide support, the Bessies this year were also made possible by grants from The Village Voice, the Candy Jernigan Memorial Fund and an anonymous donor. In addition, the presentation was aided by the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, the Harkness Foundation for Dance and individual donors.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Questions Abound In the Case Of Noriega

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
CNN's busy special assignment branch has come up with a report on America's dealings with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that is not likely to add to the foreign policy luster of the Reagan-Bush Administration. "The General's Price: The Full Story," which was first shown about a week ago, can be seen beginning tonight in four installments of about 15 minutes each on the cable channel's 6 P.M. news program. It is more solid than the fare usually provided by the competing local news shows.
Timed to coincide with the Miami drug trial of the former Panamanian strongman, the program goes back to the years when, as the evening's reporter, John Camp, recalls, General Noriega was considered "Washington's man in Panama." He was courted by American intelligence services despite suspicions that he was chronically corrupt. Richard M. Helms, a former Director of Central Intelligence, puts it pithily: "He's a bum." The pictures of General Noriega, which serve as a backdrop to much of the report, make him look like the heavy in a B movie. 
 By tonight's account, even while ostensibly cooperating with the United States Drug Enforcement Agency, General Noriega was on the take from Colombian drug dealers who used Panama as a transshipment point for cocaine bound for Miami. By the mid-1980's, however, says Elliott Abrams, an Assistant Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration, Washington was warning its sometime ally to clean up his act. But the act only got worse. In February 1988 he was indicted in Miami on drug charges, and in December 1989 American forces invaded Panama in what was called Operation Just Cause, and he was brought back to face trial.
The prosecution case, Mr. Camp notes, has certain problems. There is the question of whether the United States violated international law by arresting a country's leader on his own soil. The prosecution's taping of hundreds of telephone calls, including many involving the Noriega defense team, has already been challenged. And jurors will find most of the evidence against the defendant coming from convicted drug dealers who have been offered generous reductions of their own sentences for their testimony.
In Panama, meanwhile, Mr. Camp reports that despite the praise President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney are heard delivering for the accomplishments of the invasion, drug smuggling seems to have increased. And as Operation Just Cause approaches its second anniversary, political and economic disarray persists. Few viewers are likely to come away from this incisive program feeling sorry for General Noriega; but some are bound to wonder about what Washington thought it was up to in this corner of Central America.
