HEADLINE: U.S. Agencies Use Negotiations To Pre-empt Lawsuits Over Rules

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Washington, a city of lawsuits, is embracing a new way of doing business. At stake are rules that govern everything from who may sit in the exit rows on airliners to how much a power plant can pollute.
More and more, Federal agencies are collaring industries and interest groups and getting them together to decide what the new rules will say. 
 So far the reviews are glowing. And one of the most popular elements of these negotiations is that all parties promise not to use lawsuits to upset any settlements that they reach.
 
The Lawsuit System
 Lawsuits to overturn regulations have become commonplace under the system that has been used for 45 years: an agency studies an issue, writes a rule, takes comments, issues a final version and then defends it in court against attacks by industry associations or citizens' groups. That system still predominates, but agencies are seeking negotiated settlements wherever they can.
The Environmental Protection Agency used the new system recently to develop rules to put into effect provisions of the Clean Air Act.
"We had people at the table who probably wouldn't have returned each other's telephone calls," said William Rosenberg, deputy administrator for air and radiation. The environmental agency cannot hope to write all the regulations needed under the new law without similar negotiations in other fields, he said.
One of those at the table was Urvan R. Sternfels, president of the National Petroleum Refiners Association, who said he was an advocate of the new system. "It's a better situation," he said, "when people who are adversaries can sit down at the table and talk about it rather than throwing bricks at each other in courtrooms and the press."
Environmental groups like the new system, too. "We'd love to see it used again and again," said Fred Krupp, president of the Environmental Defense Fund, which recently concluded a negotiation over air pollution from a power plant near the Grand Canyon. "The E.P.A. brought the environmentalists and the industry together to hammer out a creative, strong solution."
One such agreement was celebrated Wednesday, when President Bush and William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, spoke at the Grand Canyon about an agreement to reduce the emissions of a coal-fired generating station that has been blamed for producing haze in the area.
In coming months, the E.P.A. hopes to conclude negotiations on rules governing everything from how to dispose of lead-acid batteries, which can contaminate underground water, to how to glue down wall-to-wall carpeting, which can poison indoor air.
 
Airplane Seating Rules
 Recently the Federal Aviation Administration conducted negotiations among airlines and advocacy groups for people with disabilities, setting rules on who can sit in the rows next to exits over wings on airplanes.
This process was formalized by Congress last year, in the Negotiated Rulemaking Act of 1990, but it has been in sporadic use on the state and Federal level for most of the last 10 years. It is being used so much by the environmental agency that it seems as if the battle lines of environmentalism are now in a conference room.
This is a major advance, Mr. Reilly said, because in recent years the main battleground has been the courts.
"Four of every five decisions I make are contested in court," he said in a recent telephone interview. "We spend as much time designing our rules to withstand court attack as we do getting the rules right and out in the first place."
Mr. Reilly is not the only one who wants to keep the environmental agency out of court. In the just-concluded agreement for clean fuels, oil refiners were expecting to spend billions of dollars, and wanted assurance that they would not be racing to comply with requirements that would be overturned later by a judge. As part of that negotiation, environmental groups and the oil industry promised that neither would sue to overturn the provisions of what they had agreed to.
 
Discouraging Defectors
 They even agreed that if a defector emerged from one side or the other -- for example, an oil company that broke ranks and decided to challenge the rules, or an environmental group that took legal action to block one portion of the rules -- the other oil companies or environmental groups would go to court to support the consensus.
In the negotiations over clean fuels, other participants were the states, which have the authority to issue their own rules within their borders and were believed ready to do so if they thought the Federal regulations were not strong enough. The threat that they would do so, creating a patchwork system of gasoline regulations, was another incentive for the industry to reach an agreement.
The negotiations do not set policy; that is supposed to be done by Congress. But often the law is a bare-bones structure, and the affected parties sometimes disagree over exactly what the language means.
In the agreement on clean fuels, the law set certain standards for the content of gasoline, but the petroleum industry won a provision in the regulations so that the standards had to be met on average, rather than in every case. The industry believes that this interpretation will reduce its cost.
Environmentalists gained in resolving an apparent ambiguity in the legislative language. At one point, Congress appears to set an absolute limit on a parameter of gasoline called Reid vapor pressure, which measures the tendency of the fuel to evaporate. But in another section, the law appears to require a percentage reduction in Reid vapor pressure, leaving unclear whether the percentage was to be applied to the absolute limit or to the existing level.
 
Grand Canyon Compromise
 In the Grand Canyon case, industry and environmentalists compromised on how reliable the anti-pollution equipment on the power plant would have to be, settling on a rule that requires a 90 percent reduction in emissions on an annual basis, rather than the original proposal of 70 percent in any given month. The change eliminated the need for a backup unit for reducing emissions.
According to Mr. Rosenberg, the E.P.A. air and radiation official, settling for 90 percent a year instead of 70 percent each month resulted in a 40 percent greater improvement in visibility at a 20 percent lower cost.
Experts say both those settlements are "win-win" solutions, in which both parties gain from being flexible.
Finding such compromises, reducing costs and staying out of court are also goals for environmentalists, said Mr. Krupp of the Environmental Defense Fund, which had sued over the air at the Grand Canyon. If the job is done more economically, he said, that leaves more money to use elsewhere, and keeping the case out of court "can foreclose the industry from appealing the regulations and bringing the process to a stall."
While negotiations are more frequent now, they are not new. Philip J. Harter, a lawyer in Washington and professor of administrative law at American University Law School, who drafted the 1990 law, traced the origin of the technique to Washington State, where it was used in the mid-1970's to plan a route for Interstate 5 across a scenic lake near Seattle.
But negotiation is far from universally successful. Chris Kirtz, chief of the consensus and dispute resolution staff at the E.P.A., said his agency had tried over the years to steer 60 disputes into negotiation, but only 12 succeeded.
Sometimes, he said, the dispute was too politicized, or the potential participants thought they faced a backlash. For example, he said, environmental groups declined to enter negotiations on radioactive waste regulations, fearing that whatever they agreed to would anger their constituents.
The new system will also fail in cases where the decision is "bipolar," said Mr. Harter, such as, "Are we going to locate a nuclear plant in your back yard, yes or no?"
But it can settle disputes that have persisted for years. Mr. Harter cited the first Federal use of the new system, by the F.A.A., to revise 30-year-old rules on when pilots are required to take rest breaks.
The revision was needed because the industry had gone from DC-3's to 747's, he said, but "every time the F.A.A. tried to revise the rules some political group had the horsepower to knock it down." As a result, Mr. Harter said, the agency kept issuing interpretations of its rule, until they had reached a total of 1,000 pages. The negotiated settlement, he said, was two pages.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Leahy's Compromise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
George Bush is on the verge of a Pyrrhic victory. He picked a fight with Israel just before a peace conference, demanding that loan guarantees to Soviet refugees be again delayed, giving him a lever to force Israel to freeze settlements and in effect hand over the West Bank.
He knows his veto would be sustained in Congress, as all others have. He has Washington Post and New York Times editorialists behind him. In a test of strength, he would humiliate Israel and its American supporters, delighting Arab despots. 
 But at what cost? By inflicting unforgettable punishment, Mr. Bush would boost superhawk Ariel Sharon in Israel, win unwanted backing here from gleeful neo-isolationists, hearten the lunatic fringe, harm his party and earn a place in history as domestic polarizer rather than global peacemaker.
Cool heads in Congress are looking for a way to avert this political Armageddon. The key player, according to senators on both sides of the aisle, is Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat whose Senate committee controls all foreign-aid appropriations.
Pat Leahy is a maverick establishmentarian, a parsimonious liberal, an Italian-Irish Yankee. His Agriculture Committee failed in its oversight of commodity credits to Iraq through the Bank of Lavoro, and he has been an implacable foe of the Stealth bomber. He is his own man, however, and was the Democrat that George Bush counted on, after a private meeting excluding John Sununu, to delay Senate consideration of the loan guarantee to house Soviet immigrants to Israel.
Senator Leahy delivered; the Senate version of the House-passed bill will not be taken up until Congress returns from its post-Thanksgiving recess, probably at the end of January. Nobody knows what assurances Mr. Leahy received from Mr. Bush about support of the bill in return, but bipartisan deals are rarely one-way.
According to Senate colleagues who have been approached by Senator Leahy over the weekend, here are the elements of the Leahy Compromise:
1. The $10 billion guarantee spread over the coming five years will be part of a "must pass" bill, tied to all other foreign aid including Egypt's; it will not be stand-alone legislation that can be singled out for veto; nor will it be subject to further delay.
2. For every dollar Israel spends on settlements in the West Bank, the loan guarantee will be reduced by one dollar. This answers the "fungibility" argument, which holds that guarantees for housing within pre-1967 Israel would free up money that could then be used to settle the West Bank. It enables Mr. Bush to assure Arabs that no American aid is directed to Israeli West Bank settlement.
How much of an economic disincentive would the dollar-for-dollar proviso be? Last year, Israeli spending on new settlements was about $85 million; if Israel spends, say, $100 million next year, that much in loan guarantees would be deducted from the year's $2 billion.
Whose figures would be used? The Leahy compromise envisages a Government Accounting Office continuing on-site review, not dependent on Israeli, Arab or State Department estimates.
3. The guarantee will be tied to Israeli economic reforms. This will be met with cheers from conservatives who wish Israel well and wish it to abandon old socialist economics; in Jerusalem, it will make necessary habit-breaking palatable.
According to a jowly O.M.B. official in a baseball cap, such reforms would affect the amount needed for U.S. budgetary set-aside, which could be brought down to 5 percent of the guarantee, or $100 million a year, as credit ratings improve; Israelis say it could go as low as 1 percent.
Would the Israelis accept the Leahy approach, which permits the President to hold a million Soviet Jews hostage for four months as a negotiations whip, forces settlement spending to come out of Israeli defense dollars and dictates systemic changes? They don't have much choice.
Will Mr. Bush buy into the compromise? He could send Secretary Baker to the Congress with a different plan, or double-cross Senator Leahy by vetoing all foreign aid if Israel does not follow orders at the peace table. He might still win, but as Plutarch reported King Pyrrhus to have said, "another such victory and we are ruined."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The Mosaic and the Melting Pot

BYLINE: By Hugh B. Price; Hugh B. Price is vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

 BODY:
"Was Cleopatra black?" That question, posed recently on the cover of Newsweek, encapsulates the raging debate over multicultural education in America. Mainstream academicians say the movement mangles history. Aggrieved minorities and women claim that history texts are full of glaring omissions, cultural stereotypes and misrepresentations of their histories.
These accusations ring true to me as an African-American. I grew up in the District of Columbia and am old enough to have attended segregated schools and witnessed the onset of integration. In the newly integrated schools of the 1950's, we were taught one version of the Civil War -- the Southern version. Of course, there was another version of the war that we weren't taught. And those contrasting versions clearly were the product of conscious decisions by historians, textbook publishers and school teachers. 
 I was an adult before I learned that Aleksandr Pushkin and Alexandre Dumas were partly black. No literary anthologies in my high school or college courses mentioned those facts. This pattern of denial and duplicity helps explain the deep-rooted suspicions among minorities and women about the accuracy of history taught in schools.
Is it even necessary to present all history as settled truth? Where there is sharp disagreement, for example, between traditionalists and Afrocentrists over the ethnicity and contributions of Egypt, why not pose the contrasting positions to students as propositions to be studied? Teach them how to use primary sources, weigh evidence, critique arguments and form their own views.
Those aspects of my early education that did pay homage to African Americans made a huge impression. We were taught that Ralph Bunche, the American statesman, won the Nobel Prize for bringing peace to the Middle East in the late 1940's; that Dr. Charles Drew discovered blood plasma and saved the lives of many American soldiers in World War II; and, yes, that Jackie Robinson had integrated major-league baseball.
In other words, we learned that blacks were of value to society, whether others thought so or not. It's impossible to overstate the impact of this individual and collective self-confidence on our will to succeed in school and beyond.
We may argue that instilling self-esteem isn't the province of schools, but we delude ourselves if we think there isn't a link between self-esteem and achievement. Or that the nexus between schools and well-functioning families hasn't done this all along for white children. If schools are to succeed for the millions of minority children who lack support at home and in the community, then educators must fill this void.
Multiculturalists also challenge the melting pot metaphor. It is said that most people who have emigrated to the U.S. over the years have arrived expecting to become unhyphenated Americans. The trouble is that the melting pot still excludes many minorities and women. It took decades of marches and lawsuits to eradicate official segregation. Yet housing and employment discrimination persist.
Growing economic hardship may lie at the heart of today's ethnic tensions. How can we expect millions of Americans, a disproportionate number of them minority, to embrace, much less treasure, Western history and values when they're under economic siege?
I wonder whether those who worry that multiculturalism will ruin the melting pot haven't misread American history. Isn't it the opportunity to breathe politically and advance economically that has lured millions of immigrants to our shores? That is the attribute that defines our society, bonds us together and sets our nation apart from others. Were those who preach inclusiveness truly to practice it, then perhaps our collective anxiety about the growing intolerance and insularity in America would, shall we say, melt away.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Fall; Data on Economy Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday, continuing a weak performance as market participants awaited new details on the economy's future.
The dollar lacked a sense of direction throughout the session, and moved lower mostly in technical dealing, traders said. 
 The market was largely unmoved by reports of tension between Iraqi guards and a United Nations peace-keeping force.
Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, said the incident caused a brief rise in dollar prices.
"That was the thrill of the day, but you had to be quick to catch it," Mr. Lawrie said.
Two reports scheduled for release later this week -- durable goods orders for August and the second quarter gross national product -- may provide guidance on the economy's health and a direction for the dollar, Mr. Lawrie said.
Other traders said the United States currency fell through a significant technical level against the Japanese yen in New York trading, closing at 132.84 yen, down from 134.15 late Friday.
Markets were closed in Japan today because of Autumnal Equinox Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar traded at 133.00 Japanese yen, lower than the 134.72 yen quoted in Tokyo late Friday.
The British pound closed at $1.7445 in London, up from $1.7290 late Friday. In New York, sterling cost $1.7425, more expensive than $1.7315 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6735 German marks, down from 1.6845; 1.4580 Swiss francs, down from 1.46985; 5.7035 French francs, down from 5.7395; 1,252.25 Italian lire, down from 1,260.00, and 1.13415 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13445.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mortgage Lender Is Back for More

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
FOR most companies, one public stock offering a year is plenty. But rapid growth and a sharp rise in its stock price have led Countrywide Credit Industries, a Pasadena, Calif., concern that specializes in home mortgage financing, to ask for a second helping.
The second stock offering -- 6 million shares offered today by Merrill Lynch & Company at a price of $27.375 for a total of $164.3 million -- will be much more rewarding to the company than the offering in March of 3.7 million shares at $12.25 each. The company's stock price has more than doubled since March, and demand for the new offering was strong enough that the size was increased from 4 million shares. 
 At Monday's closing price of $27.375 a share, down 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, Countrywide stock is only a shade below its high of 28.125 on Friday and has more than doubled in value since the March sale.
In an interview with American Banker, a trade newspaper, Angelo R. Mozilo, vice chairman of Countrywide, said the company expected to handle a record $1 billion of new mortgages this month, up sharply from the $1.8 billion total for the three months that ended on May 31.
The difficulties of others in real estate, where housing starts are running at a low annual rate of about a million units a year, seem to have opened the door for Countrywide to grow faster.
"With all the pressure on savings and loans and banks, there has been an opportunity for Countrywide to gain market share," said G. Kenneth Heebner, president of Capital Growth Management, an investment advisory firm in Boston. Even Citicorp, the most active new-mortgage lender in recent years and the largest servicer of existing mortgages, has been pulling back, he noted.
The strategic opportunity, plus the strong growth in mortgage lending that Mr. Heebner expects as interest rates fall, led him to accumulate 2.24 million shares, or 9.6 percent of the company as of June 30, making Capital Growth the largest single investor.
While demand for Countrywide stock has been strong, a few company insiders have been sellers. Mr. Mozilo, for example, has sold 78,500 shares this year at prices ranging from $14.50 to $21.125, reducing his holdings to 238,866 shares.
One reason Countrywide earns high marks is its use of computers and communications technology. In a business that is largely paper shuffling, as mortgages are issued and then sold to investors, Countrywide has become a low-cost operator able to handle rapid growth.
"They use technology in ways that give them a competitive advantage and set them apart," said Brian F. Hershkowitz, an associate director of the Mortgage Bankers Associaton. "They were operating with excess capacity, and now they are putting it to use."
In the servicing business, where Countrywide collects monthly payments for more than $19 billion of mortgages, the company has told securities analysts that it uses one employee for each 760 loans, compared with an industry average of 650 loans per employee. With this cost advantage, Countrywide has told analysts that it plans to more than double its servicing business to $46 billion of mortgages by 1996.
All mortgage services are computerized, but few have gone so far as Countrywide. Mr. Mozilo, a founder of the company in 1968, was an early convert to computer power. The company's network of 112 offices includes about 90 that are staffed by three people who act as a sales force, rather than clerks, because the company years ago developed a computer that can handle local chores at the same time it disgorges data to the central office.
In place of the blank forms for the more than 80 different documents a branch office might need, Countrywide uses its computers and laser printers to produce printed versions of completed forms, thus saving on inventory, storage space and clerical time. When a homeowner calls Countrywide, telephone operators retrieve the customer's account history on a computer screen rather than fetch paper documents.
More technological applications are coming. Countrywide is working with I.B.M. to develop computer software to make mortgage lending more uniform and, it hopes, less risky. Mr. Mozilo said earlier this year that he still wanted a process in which a branch manager "can see the look in your eyes" when he asks if an applicant can make the payments.
"The company is perceived by some as a growth stock," said David Hochstim, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. "I think it's a fine company with excellent management, but it's a finance company whose stock right now seems expensive relative to other financial companies I follow."
For example, at its current price, Countrywide's stock sells at about 16 times Mr. Hochstim's earnings estimate of $1.60 a share for 1992, while stocks of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, sell at only 9 or 10 times next year's earnings.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Up a Bit in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities improved slightly in slow trading yesterday, as dealers continued to adjust portfolios in advance of two-year and five-year note auctions to be held today and tomorrow.
Market participants said demand for the new notes should be good. 
 "Over the past couple of weeks, demand has improved for intermediate-term securities," one government bond trader said. "A lot of that stems from money that is moving out of money market accounts and bank certificates of deposit and into higher-yielding intermediate bond funds."
Late yesterday the new two-year notes, were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.16 percent. The five-year securities to be sold tomorrow were offered in when-issued trading late yesterday at a price to yield 7.06 percent.
"With rates on C.D.s and other items for individuals at unattractive levels relative to market rates, money is pouring into mutual funds and the market directly," said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
 
Treasury's Weekly Auction
 Activity at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills was fairly brisk, but yields on the new short-term securities were little changed from a week ago.
The new three-month bills sold yesterday were auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.18 percent, little changed from the 5.19 percent average rate at last week's sale.
Bids on new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.23 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.22 percent at the auction a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 102 29/32, up 5/ 32, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.88 percent late Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 10/32, up 6/32, to yield 7.53 percent. And the outstanding 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 14/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.12 percent.
 
Reserve Bank Resignation
 An announcement that F. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, had submitted his resignation prompted much comment but had little impact on prices of Treasury securities.
Mr. Hoskins, an ardent inflation-fighter, was scheduled to become a voting member of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee next year.
"His departure should add to a more dovish F.O.M.C. next year," analysts at MMS International noted in their daily market commentary.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, a financing subsidiary of the Household Finance Corporation, offered a total of $714 million worth of securities backed by credit-card receivables through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The bulk of the issue consisted of $614 million worth of 7 3/8 percent notes with an average expected life of four years.
The securities were priced at $99.48, to yield 7.56 percent, 83 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
These securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The remaining $100 million of the issue consisted of 8 1/8 percent notes with an average life of 4.6 years. These securities were priced at $99.63, to yield 8.28 percent, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
This part of the issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
American Airlines offered a total of approximately $210 million of pass-through certificates through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The issue consisted of $140 million of securities with an average life of 11.8 years.
These 8.97 percent certificates were priced at $100, or par, 1.42 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $70 million worth of securities have an average life of 20.7 years. These securities have a coupon of 9.73 percent and were also priced at $100, or par, 1.85 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
Both parts of this issue are rated A-2 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Arizona Transportation Board offered $170 million worth of serial bonds in a negotitated sale through Dean Witter Reynolds.
Interest rates on the serial bonds range from 6.30 percent on securities maturing in 2003 to 6.65 percent on bonds maturing in 2011.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues dipped by about 1/4 point in sluggish trading.
Participants in the secondary market for municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Hits a 2-Month High; Economic Confidence Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of silver futures charged to a two-month high yesterday the Commodity Exchange in New York on technical buying stemming from perceptions that the economy is climbing out of recession.
Silver for September delivery settled 8.1 cents higher, at $4.168 an ounce, the highest settlement of a near-term contract since July 23. Gold for October delivery rose $2.20, to $351.10 an ounce. 
 Analysts said most of the silver buying was inspired by optimistic technical signals after a stronger opening.
Many buyers were thought to be metal dealers and users, which suggested that confidence in an economic recovery was growing. Silver prices have been depressed by slack industrial demand for much of the year.
News of a drawdown of four million ounces in the Commodity Exchange's warehouse stocks of silver last Friday bolstered ideas that industrial demand is growing, said Tom Griffo, an analyst at Cargill Investor Services Inc.
The exchange's warehouse stocks rose by about 1.5 million ounces yesterday, to 268.7 million.
Precious metals also drew support from a weaker dollar and ideas the United States was leaning toward more financial assistance for the Soviet Union, said Peter Cardillo, the research director for Westfalia Investments Inc.
Increased Western aid would reduce the Soviets' need to sell precious metals for hard currency.
Mr. Cardillo said silver prices could rise 10 cents or 12 cents more before facing heavy resistance.
But Bernard Savaiko, the senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said dealer demand could dry up at $4.20 to $4.25 an ounce.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil prices rose, as traders stocked up on crude while keeping an eye on increased tensions surrounding Iraq and waiting for OPEC's meeting today.
Crude oil for November delivery settled at $22.07 a barrel, up 28 cents; October home heating oil rose 1.21 cents, to 63.80 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline rose 0.45 cent, to 61.35 cents a gallon; October natural gas rose 5.8 cents, to $1.80 for 1,000 cubic feet, but November deliveries fell 6.1 cents, to $1.919.
On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee futures fell sharply after coffee-producing countries failed to agree over the weekend on a plan to raise prices.
December coffee fell 1.6 cents, to 89.2 cents a pound.
Cotton futures collapsed on the New York Cotton Exchange on ideas that last week's gains, tied to cool, wet weather in Texas, were exaggerated. October cotton plunged 1.99 cents, to 64.08 cents a pound.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean futures prices settled mostly lower, amid forecasts for good harvest weather in the Middle West with little chance of frost.
December wheat ended 3 3/4 cents lower, at $3.26 3/4 a bushel; December corn was 1 1/4 cents lower, at $2.48 3/4 a bushel; December oats ended 1/2 cent higher, at $1.30 a bushel, and November soybeans fell 7 cents, to $5.92 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CAREERS;
Improving Technology In Services

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
DR. DANIEL BERG of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute suggests that this is the decade for stressing technological improvements in industries that provide services to customers, just as in the last decade companies concentrated on lowering costs and improving quality in manufacturing operations to compete better with European and Japanese rivals.
Dr. Berg points out that service companies account for more than 70 percent of the gross national product, and they employ 75 percent of American workers. Yet, he says, technological development and innovation lag in the service sectors. 
 Furthermore, few engineers or scientists have been trained to apply their expertise directly to service companies, and as a result few have been interested in working for these companies.
"The wave of the future involves getting students, especially engineering and science students, to understand this," he said last week in an interview in New York. Students must learn more about service industries and how they can work in a service economy, he contends, and service companies must realize the importance of using these students.
For example, for about a decade a few Wall Street firms have been hiring engineers. Some work in technological areas to improve the delivery of services to customers, but quite a few have become stock and bond experts, doing research and analyzing manufacturing companies.
Accounting and consulting firms like Arthur Andersen & Company have hired many engineers to help both in the technological aspects of their operations and in auditing and surveillance activities.
Dr. Berg pointed out that companies that made nuclear reactors and equipment for nuclear energy found their nuclear business in a slump some years ago. The General Electric Company set up a unit to service nuclear equipment and offers the service to its customers.
Similarly, G.E.'s unit that makes diesel engines for railroads also went into the business of supplying maintenance help. And GE Capital provides financing worldwide for tankers and other heavy equipment owned by others. G.E., once primarily a manufacturer, has become an important service company, with financial services accounting for 24 percent of revenues in 1990.
Dr. Berg wants more companies and more young engineering students to understand the importance of jobs in the service sector. There will be a growing need, he insists, for corporate chief technological officers. "They will report directly to the chief executive officer," he said, and will head departments of engineers and scientists who can keep the company up to date on equipment.
In a recent survey, he found that 11 of 14 major banks had a designated chief technological officer, with titles like chief technologist and executive vice president for technology strategic planning.
"While C.T.O.'s already are common in banks," he said, "research organizations similar to corporate research and development labs in the manufacturing sector are not."
For these reasons, Dr. Berg and some colleagues a few weeks ago began a multidisciplinary Center for Services Research and Education at Rensselaer, in Troy, N.Y. Dr. Berg is a former president of the institute and is now a professor there.
He says there is nothing like the center elsewhere in the country, although some work along similar lines is being done at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
Professors for the new center will come not only from engineering and science programs and from the graduate management school, but also from the humanities, including experts in psychology, sociology, economics and government.
On a trip to New York last week to spur interest in the center, Dr. Berg, who is its acting director, said a half-dozen major companies had been asked to join a workshop this fall: Citibank, Arthur Andersen, Duquesne Light, American Telephone and Telegraph and Aetna Insurance, as well as the G.A.O, the Congressional watchdog agency.
"There are no textbooks on the subject," he said, and not even any courses, but they will be introduced.
"We need courses to teach students about this," he added. "An intellectual challenge is to see how far the manufacturing paradigm overlaps that of services." He visualizes the center as offering workshops for corporations and regular courses for Rensselaer students, and publishing results of professors' research on technology and the service companies.
In addition, the institute's curriculum for Master of Business Administration candidates has been changed in several ways. One is that all courses in disciplines like marketing, finance, economics and even human resources will "emphasize the impact of technology," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Fox Network Producer Named TV Guide Editor

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Anthea Disney, executive producer of the Fox television show "A Current Affair" and a former editor of US and Self magazines, was named yesterday to be editor in chief of TV Guide.
Effective immediately, she replaces Joe Robinowitz, who moved to the newly created position of executive vice president of News America Publishing Inc., the subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation that operates his vastly reduced American magazine business. 
 Leslie Hinton, News America's president and chief executive, said the moves did not presage a big shift in the editorial direction of TV Guide, which has the highest circulation -- just over 15 million -- of any weekly magazine in the United States.
But Ms. Disney suggested that both she and Mr. Murdoch had a rather different TV Guide in mind.
"It's really important not to tear apart something that 40 million people read and like," Ms. Disney said in a telephone interview. But she added, "I would like it to be more controversial."
"I think people are ready for some strong opinions," she continued. "It shouldn't just be a program guide with some fluffy articles next to it. It should have some real content."
Mr. Hinton said Mr. Robinowitz would turn his attention to the development of new products that can be spun off from the magazine, such as the recently hatched monthly, "The Best of TV Guide Crosswords."
"It's been a success from the get-go," Mr. Robinowitz said of the puzzle compendium. "You can expect to see much more of that kind of project from us. Publishing projects, video projects, television projects, book projects -- you name it."
Ms. Disney, 46, gained unwelcome attention two years ago, after S.I. Newhouse, Jr., the chairman of Conde Nast Publications Inc., stopped by her Connecticut home while she was on vacation to tell her she was being removed as the editor of Self. In her yearlong tenure, Ms. Disney marshaled what was at the time thought to be a successful redesign of the magazine. But she clashed with the magazine company's powerful editorial director, Alexander Liberman, she and executives at Conde Nast said.
Ms. Disney, who had previously redesigned US magazine, went to work for Mr. Murdoch on the prototype of a new news magazine, only to have the project succumb to an unwelcoming economy. Still struggling with his company's huge debt, Mr. Murdoch sold nine of his magazines earlier this year for $600 million, keeping only TV Guide and Mirabella.
Next, Ms. Disney went to Mr. Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting Company, to join "A Current Affair" and quickly became the show's executive producer.
Mr. Robinowitz, 40, had spent two years as a senior editor at TV Guide, the second of them as editor in chief. He has worked for Mr. Murdoch since the Australian-born publisher bought his first American property, The San Antonio Express-News, where Mr. Robinowitz was a cub reporter.
In keeping with the slashing executive manner for which Mr. Murdoch is known, Ms. Disney said she first learned that she might be moved last Wednesday. The change was made final the next day, Mr. Robinowitz said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Cleveland Fed Leaves to Run Bank

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The most vocal and effective advocate of zero inflation among the Federal Reserve's regional bank presidents has resigned to run a $9.5 billion Midwestern commercial bank.
W. Lee Hoskins, who heads the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, will take over in mid-November as president and chief executive of Huntington National Bank, a solid if not spectacular regional bank based in Columbus, Ohio. In the meantime, Mr. Hoskins will no longer participate in making monetary policy or bank supervision. 
 An ardent monetarist and admirer of free markets, Mr. Hoskins made quite a mark within the Federal Reserve System since he came to the Cleveland Fed in 1987 with his tireless advocacy of zero inflation. He gave an average of 50 speeches a year, mostly on that topic. He said he had achieved one of his objectives. "I've been very comfortable with the Greenspan monetary policy, which has produced a lower rate of inflation and should continue to do so," he said.
Mr. Hoskin's clean-cut looks, quick mind and sly sense of humor -- along with his doctorate in economics and solid grasp of economic data -- made him more effective than many of Milton Friedman's disciples in advancing his views. "By focusing as much as he did on price stability, he helped us focus on that as a long-term goal, " said Robert Forestall, president of the Atlanta Fed and one who has often disagreed with Mr. Hoskins.
The impact of Mr. Hoskins's departure is less likely immediately and directly to affect the course of monetary policy than subtly to shift the tenor of debate within the Federal Reserve. "Now even dyed-in-the-wool hawks agree that inflation is coming down, money growth is on the low side and the Fed might have to ease," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a securities firm.
Mr. Hoskins, who recently has not been a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, was due to resume a voting role on Jan. 1. Despite the fact that he cast more dissenting votes than virtually any other member, often in favor of tighter money, his influence was based on his view that the central bank's No. 1, 2, and 3 jobs were to wring inflation out of the economy. "The difference between Lee and most of the others is that he was so consistently on the anti-inflation side that when he argued for easier money, it didn't rattle the bond market," said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp.
Running a bank has long been on the personal agenda of Mr. Hoskins, who from 1980 to 1987 was the chief economist at PNC National Bank in Pittsburgh. "When Lee came to the job at the Fed he viewed himself as a private sector person who was doing an interim stretch in the public sector," said Karen Horn, chairman and chief executive of Bank One, Cleveland.
Mr. Hoskins takes over a bank that does not face the kind of wrenching restructuring of many in the industry. The main challenge, Mr. Hoskins said, will be "to increase shareholder value." Mr. Hoskins has a track record as a manager. "The Cleveland Fed is one of the best-managed Reserve banks," said Frank Wobst, chairman of the holding company of the Huntington bank and a member of the Cleveland Fed's board.
"I had a terrific job," Mr. Hoskins said, "but I turned 50 in February and I started to think about what I wanted to do with my next 15 years." One thing that won't change, however, is Mr. Hoskins's outspokenness, though he will mostly be speaking out on another, if less well-known, topic: bank reform. "I will not discourage him from speaking out at all," Mr. Wobst said.

HEADLINE: Economists Say Recession Ended in Spring

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Despite scant evidence so far of consumer participation, an overwhelming majority of economists insist that the recession ended at least three months ago. And two members of the committee charged officially with dating it said today that the bottom most likely occurred in May.
Still, Michael J. Boskin, chief economic adviser to President Bush, persisted in expressing concern about possibly overly restrictive monetary policy by the Federal Reserve that could threaten recovery. 
 "If money growth doesn't pick up soon, the Fed will have to accommodate further," Mr. Boskin said after an appearance before the National Association of Business Economists at the Biltmore Hotel here.
Mr. Boskin, who has long contended that the upturn has begun, said the economy "turned the corner some time in the spring," but declined to specify a month.
According to a poll of group members who regularly forecast the economy, 79 percent believe the recession ended during the April-June quarter and 9 percent believe it will end in the three-month period that ends next week.
And only 11 percent considered it likely that the economy will slip back into recession in the next 12 months.
The survey was conducted in late August, before the Federal Reserve's latest round of interest rate cuts.
Geoffrey H. Moore, director of the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University, declared at a panel discussion this morning that recovery is "under way." He added, "At the moment, I would pick May as the most likely date of the bottom of the recession."
But Mr. Moore said it was "not entirely clear" that the recession had ended and that it would probably be months before the seven-member dating committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private group of which he is a member, would convene to make a formal determination.
Victor Zarnowitz, professor of economics at the University of Chicago and another committee member, agreed that recovery began during the second quarter -- "maybe May, and maybe later" -- but cautioned that the National Bureau "would be well advised to wait a bit" before making an official call. The recession started in July 1990.
As is typical at such turns in the business cycle, manufacturing has set the pace, particularly in the Midwest and South, but consumers have been slow to join in, a reluctance reflected in a sizable decline in retail sales during August that, at least in the case of automobiles, appears to have continued this month.
 
A Wobbly Service Sector
 And unlike previous recessions, the service sector has been battered, another reason for lack of confidence that the rebound will be vigorous. The survey predicts that gross national product, adjusted for inflation, will grow 2.5 to 3 percent over the next 12 months, slightly less than half the 6 percent historic average for the economy coming out of recession.
Mr. Boskin said that while the economy could do better than that, it also "could do worse," citing, in addition to the Federal Reserve, the drag of state and local government cutbacks, overzealous regulators who discourage bank lenders or foreign slumps that depress demand for American exports.
Mr. Moore also offered an optimistic view of the length of the fledgling recovery. Examining the behavior of the prime interest rate after the postwar recessions since 1954, Mr. Moore found that the longer it takes for the prime rate to rise once recovery has begun, the longer the expansion will be. Thus, if May was the trough of the recession and four months have already gone by without a rise -- the latest change, in fact, was a cut earlier this month -- history suggests the expansion is already likely to last 21 months, or until February 1993, Mr. Moore said.
This correlation of the lag in the prime rate with the length of the upturn is one of the strongest he has ever seen in any of his research, Mr. Moore said.

HEADLINE: Hotels Await the Wake-Up Call

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The nation's economy may be sputtering toward a recovery, but the hotel industry remains mired in its worst morass in decades, headed for its 10th consecutive year of losses.
"Sixty percent of the hotels in the U.S. are experiencing a net operating loss," said Bjorn Hanson, a partner in Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. "And this year that loss will reach a little more than $1,000 per room." 
 The hotels' losses have been the travelers' gains, with business executives and vacationers alike clearly benefiting from comparatively low rates and a wide choice of accommodations. Newspaper and magazines have been full of ads from Marriott, Hyatt, Omni and other big chains, all offering such incentives as free meals, additional nights at no charge, rooms discounted as much as 60 percent and suites for the price of regular rooms.
And no quick recovery is in sight, industry executives and analysts say.
 
Plenty of Rooms Available
 The recession and the fallout from the Persian Gulf war, which dragged business travel almost to a halt, held the average occupancy rate to 60 percent for the first half of this year. That is the lowest figure in more than a decade and far below the 65 percent the typical hotel or motel requires to break even.
Among the full-service hotels, which offer room service, restaurants, swimming pools and other amenities, the occupancy rate is slightly lower -- 59.2 percent in the first sixth months of the year, down from 62 percent a year earlier, according to Smith Travel Research, which compiles the statistics used by the United States Department of Commerce and the American Hotel and Motel Association.
In response, full-service hotels like Hilton and Sheraton and even some luxury chains like the Four Seasons Hotels, have been among the most agressive in offering a variety of inducements that include cash rebates, free airline tickets and frequent-flier mileage credits. Whether these incentives have helped will not be known until Smith Research data become available at the end of October. But early indications are only mildly encouraging.
"So many travelers who used to stay in the full-service hotels discovered they didn't need a lounge, or a pool or a restaurant if they were staying just a night or two," said Jackson B. Reynolds, general manager of the Golden Lamb Inn, a small full-service establishment in Lebanon, Ohio. "So they traded down to the newer economy hotels."
As might be expected, economy hotels, the fastest-growing segment of the industry, have fared somewhat better. In the first six months of 1991, the average occupancy rate at economy hotels was 62.4 percent. That was down from 63.7 percent in the corresponding period last year, but still above the industry average.
"A major reason for the shift from full-service to limited-service hotels is that corporate travel budgets have been reduced," said David A. Dittman, dean of the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell University.
But whether travelers have been frugal or profligate, the national glut of hotel rooms -- created by the hotel construction boom in the easy-financing days of the 1980's -- has helped keep increases in room rates well below the rate of inflation for the last four years.
So while travelers are finding bargains, investors are taking a drubbing: the hotel industry lost an estimated $350 million last year. And an estimated $2.1 billion in hotel loans were delinquent or in the process of foreclosure as of September 1990, according to the most recent figures available from Coopers & Lybrand, representing a 4.2 percent increase over 1989.
 
The Nation's Innkeeper Indeed
 Not surprisingly, perhaps, one of the fastest-growing hotel owners in the nation is the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency charged with selling the real estate loans that the Government acquired from failed savings and loan associations. The R.T.C. now operates more than 150 financially distressed hotels, including the 605-room Phoenician Resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., a $250 million complex that had been 55 percent owned by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, formerly headed by Chares H. Keating Jr.
"We just completed a study on the profitability of 2,200 hotels, and in general they lost buckets of money," said Mark Lomanno, research manager at Smith Travel Research of Gallatin, Tenn. With the real estate market depressed, Mr. Lomanno said, the appraised values of many hotels are "dropping like a rock."
The proliferation of the economy hotels, the fastest-growing segment of the industry, reflects not just the budget consciousness of travelers, but also the segmentation of the hotel market into many niches, ranging from luxury to bare-bones.
Some hotel operators have begun creating their own niches. The Marriott Corporation, for example, now offers its Residence Inn chain for out-of-towners who need a place to stay for an extended period, and its mid-priced Courtyard hotels for thrifty travelers.
Some analysts say the industry segmentation has been overdone and more than a little cynical, because it has enabled the major hotel companies in some cases simply to cluster more franchises in popular locations.
But Dan Daniele, a consultant, said that like it or not, "segmentation is here to stay because, just like the automobile industry, you have to have different lines."
And yet, predicted Mr. Daniele, who directs hospitality industry consulting for Ernst & Young in Chicago, hotel companies will not do as well as they expected with segmentation. The discounting by the full-service hotels, he said, has greatly narrowed the gap between the market's high and low ends.
Mr. Dittman of Cornell also sees the operating margins continuing to narrow. "The hotel manager of the future will have to be able not only to provide fine wines and cuisine, but in a cost-effective way," Mr. Dittman said. "He or she will have a firm understanding of quality-cost trade-offs."
Despite the industry's current woes, analysts do expect the lodging business eventually to recover, albeit at a slow pace.
"The industry normally lags behind the general economy by one or two quarters," said Dan Lee, hotel analyst for the First Boston. "This time it was hit so hard it will probably take longer," he added. "But occupancy will eventually increase, rates will rise and the industry will return to profitability."
Analysts expect increases in room rates to pass the rate of inflation by the third or fourth quarter of 1993, but they warn it will probably be another couple of years beyond that before the industry returns to health.
One trend that could stoke the industry's recovery is the current reluctance of lenders to finance hotel construction. Tight credit may enable demand for hotel rooms to finally catch up with supply.
"From 1980 to 1987 we had a 40 percent increase in the number of hotel rooms in the U.S.," Mr. Hanson said. "In 1985 alone, there were almost 160,000 new room starts." This year, he said, new starts will be around 24,000, but about 20,000 existing rooms will be removed from the inventory as hotels retire aging properties.
 
Outlook for Full-Service Hotels
 Once occupancy rates start to rise, even full-service chains are expected to make a comeback, and those like the Hilton Hotels Corporation, the ITT Sheraton Corporation and Loews Hotels, which have been renovating their properties during the recession, are expected to do especially well. Marriott will also return to health, analysts predict, but only after it sells the bulk of nearly $1.5 billion worth of mortgages on hotels and other properties it no longer wants.
"About three years ago, Marriott accounted for one of every three new hotels being built in the U.S.," said Mr. Lee of First Boston. "This year it didn't break ground on a single new hotel."
An industry rule of thumb is that every $1,000 spent in building a room translates into one dollar in the room rate charged to lodgers. By this reckoning, a room that cost $50,000 to build, for instance, should carry a rate of $50. But the high cost of building some hotels, like the quarter-billion dollars poured into the troubled Phoenician Resort, virtually guaranteed they would lose money.
So why were such hotels built? "Because the investors thought some Japanese or Martians would bail them out at higher prices," said Robert Hazard Jr., the chairman of Choice Hotels International, whose seven chains (including Comfort, Quality, Rodeway and Econo Lodge) represent more than 2,700 motels, hotels, suites and resorts.
 
High Debt
 The indebted investors elicit scant sympathy from Mr. Hanson of Coopers & Lybrand. "Because a lender was willing to lend 100 percent," he said, "doesn't mean you had to take it." But many did, with predictable results. In 1977, interest expense on the industry's long-term debt averaged about 6 1/4 percent of revenue, Mr. Hanson said. In 1990, it was about 14 percent.
Smith Travel Research has found that the biggest financial problem for most hotels is not their operating efficiency but debt service. "Interest is eating them alive," Mr. Lomanno said.
Those problems will ease when rates and occupancies rise, analysts say. But by then many hotel properties are likely to be in other hands, as creditors become equity holders.
"Very seldom does a hotel close," Mr. Lee said. "They keep operating, but their ownership structure changes."

HEADLINE: Baby Boomers Fail as Born-Again Savers

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
For years, optimists have been counting on the middle-aging of the baby-boom generation to lift the nation's sagging savings rate. As members of that generation abandoned late nights at discos for early dinners at home with the children, they were supposed to start saving for retirement or college the way June and Ward Cleaver did.
If only "Leave It to Beaver" were true today. Personal saving habits peaked in the early 1970's, when the average citizen stashed away more than 9 percent of take-home pay, and declined through the late 80's when saving reached a nadir of less than 3 percent.
 
Maturing Is Not Enough
 A few years ago it seemed that thrift was getting trendy again, but lately saving has slumped anew. Worse, economists have concluded that there is little reason to believe that younger Americans, merely by maturing, will turn sufficiently thrifty to lift the nation's savings rate much. 
One reason is that as the baby-boom generation moves into middle age and saves more than it has, it is still saving less than earlier generations. What's more, older Americans spend more than they earn in retirement, and the ranks of seniors are growing rapidly -- so much so that younger people would have to save a substantial part of their income to offset the spending pattern of retirees and raise the nation's modest savings rate.
Such a shift is unlikely, economists say, for several reasons, including the fact that average incomes are modest for households headed by those moving into middle age.
 
Bad News for Investment
 That finding is bad news for investment and, hence, for te economy's long-term ability to generate higher productivity growth and living standards. A smaller amount saved by the nation's households, businesses and governments puts a ceiling on new investment -- even if some of it can be financed by foreigners. There is already a broad consensus that the nation is investing too little.
The decline of personal thrift is particularly worrisome because Washington is likely to keep racking up huge deficits, and corporate saving, which may well strengthen in the 90's, is not likely to offset the decline in household saving.
But the maturing of a generation will not rescue the nation from its spendthrift ways, many economists say. "The baby boom had nothing to do with the long-term decline in saving, so I see no reason for expecting saving to rebound now," said Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was the co-author of a recent savings study.
Edward F. McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, dismisses as a "cruel hoax" the notion that shifting demographics will cause a savings surge.
In July, the most commonly cited measure of saving, the personal savings rate -- after-tax personal income minus consumer expenditures -- was 3.7 percent. That was down from 5.2 percent last May.
Economists expect saving to edge up with real income in the recovery, but fewer and fewer expect it to reach its 6.5 percent post-World War II average, much less the double digits that some Wall Street economists have predicted. Forecasters at DRI/ McGraw-Hill project that the savings rate will hover around 4 percent in the 90's.
 
A Seductive Theory
 It is easy to see why the prospect of a spontaneous revival of thrift has seemed so seductive. For Wall Street, more saving is the tide that could keep the stock and bond markets afloat. For people who fret about declining United States competitiveness, more saving would encourage investment. And for the baby boomers themselves, lacking faith in Social Security, more saving would improve the prospect of a more secure retirement.
More than anything, though, the demographic landscape seemed set for increased saving. Households headed by people 40 to 50 years old historically squirrel away a bigger slice of their income -- as much as 16 percent of it, which is more than any other age group does. Now that the leading edge of the generation born between 1946 and 1961 is moving into that age bracket, it would seem to follow that the overall rate would rise.
Actually, it does not follow, several economists say. Members of this generation are saving more than they did when they were younger -- for college education, first homes and retirement -- but not as much as their parents did nor enough to affect the overall rate much.
"The pace of migration of baby boomers into the high-saving age bracket is much too glacial to deliver the promised increase in saving on its own," Mr. McKelvey of Goldman, Sachs said.
 
Job for Middle-Aged
 According to a projection by the Bureau of the Census, the proportion of all households headed by people 45 to 54 years old should swell by less than five percentage points, to about 20 percent, by 2000.
To raise the savings rate even one percentage point, say to 5 percent from 4, the middle-aged would have to set aside an unlikely 20 percent of after-tax income, Mr. McKelvey said. To reach 10 percent, he added, this group would have to save practically its entire income.
A second problem is that while one generation is moving into the high-saving years, the population of Americans 75 and over will also be growing. Like very young Americans, the very old generally spend far more than their current income. "That produces a substantial offset to the small contribution of the aging of the baby-boom generation," Mr. McKelvey said.
Mr. McKelvey also shoots holes in a variant of the aging baby-boomer theme, that of the repentant yuppie. These born-again savers supposedly shopped until they dropped in the 80's and are all shopped out. Besides, they are supposedly tired of materialism and plan to spend the 90's rediscovering traditional values.
But the overwhelming majority of households in the 35-to-44-year-old bracket do not have high incomes to begin with, Mr. McKelvey said. Their average income, $40,000 before taxes in 1989, was "hardly enough to pay for BMW's and trips to the Bahamas on top of basic household expenses."
Besides, contrary to what one might expect if everybody had been splurging on luxuries instead of saving, the fraction of income Americans spent on cars, electronic gizmos and travel did not budge in the 80's. What did take a bigger bite out of budgets, though, was medical care, whose share jumped 4.5 percentage points. That is enough, Mr. McKelvey said, to account for the decline in the savings rate.
There is new historical evidence that casts more doubt on the idea that one generation is to blame for the savings slump -- an idea advanced by the President's chief economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, in an influential paper a few years ago. Much of that evidence is given in a recent study by three Brookings Institution economists, Mr. Bosworth, Gary Burtless and John Sabelhaus. The study examines data from household surveys in the United States, Japan and Canada.
 
Slipped in All Groups
 As it turns out, savings rates slipped in all age groups -- and in Japan as well as in the United States and Canada -- from the early 60's through the mid-80's. Contrary to what most economists have thought, the rates fell furthest among older households. Finally, demographic shifts between high savers and low savers explained virtually none of the slide in saving in the last decade.
One clue to why older households cut back on saving proportionately more than younger households: Saving by homeowners fell much more than that by renters. Prices of houses, which the middle-aged are much more likely to own, were appreciating rapidly in the late 70's and early 80's.
If neither a preponderance of youth nor yuppie excesses caused the decline in saving during the 70's and 80's, middle age and newfound sobriety are not likely to raise it. Mr. McKelvey detects a number of trends that could discourage saving even more, among them the rising birth rate among women in their 30's and the leveling out of the percentage of women in the work force.
 
Spending on Diapers
 "The very generation that is supposed to stop buying too many BMW's may find itself spending money on diapers and day care instead of T-bills," he said.
The true culprit in the savings slump, Mr. Bosworth suggested, may be psychological. People operate with rules of thumb that are formed by critical experiences, like the Depression, he said. As the Depression has receded in memory, he added, the rule of frugality has gradually broken down.
Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist at the World Bank, said he believed that people might have less to worry about than they used to. Twenty years ago the rate of poverty among the elderly was twice that of younger Americans. Today it is lower. "My guess," he added, "is that many more people form a view about retirement by looking at whether their parents seem rich or poor than by looking at the report of the Social Security actuaries."

HEADLINE: Shift in Industrial Aid Is Urged

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
New York City would benefit by concentrating less on trying to retain existing manufacturing jobs, and instead focusing more support on emerging businesses, a report released yesterday by the office of Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero recommended.
The report's conclusions indicate that the city is considering recasting its economic development strategy. 
 It is not clear whether Ms. Hernandez-Pinero will accept all the recommendations. "We wanted this to serve as the factual underpinning for whatever we do in the future," said the Deputy Mayor, who heads the Office for Economic Development.
The report said that manufacturers benefit less than other companies from being in New York, making it harder to justify a general effort to retain them. Moreover, the report concluded, "None of the manufacturing industries forecast to grow rapidly at the national level in the 1990's have any meaningful presence in New York City."
 
'We Shouldn't Pull Our Hair Out'
 Instead of supporting companies and industries that have been around for decades and are struggling, the report suggests that the city focus on those that are new and emerging.
"The message is that we shouldn't pull our hair out of our heads whenever somebody leaves, because that's not necessarily the most important thing for the economy," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said. She cited figures in the report showing that between 1976 and 1986, new businesses generated nearly 464,000 jobs. By contrast, companies that moved to New York City from elsewhere produced only 37,000 new jobs.

HEADLINE: Shifting the Risk;
Under Cuomo's Medicaid Plan, Albany Assumes the Burden of Curbing Costs

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
By proposing state assumption of Medicaid expenses, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is recommending not only a shift in costs, but, perhaps even more important, a shift in risk.
As outlined by the Governor, local governments would have to give up some of their tax revenues in a swap with the state. That is a trade that, under most circumstances they would greet with outrage. 
 But the rapidly escalating cost of Medicaid, compared with the slow growth in most tax revenues, makes the Governor's offer attractive to most municipalities these days. The state, in assuming the local share of Medicaid, would be assuming the full risk of future growth in Medicaid -- and the full responsibility for trying to restrain that growth.
Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said local officials want to pass along the cost of Medicaid for the same reason the state has resisted such a move. "In addition to being so expensive," he said, "it has this horrendous growth to it."
The Governor's Medicaid proposal is the centerpiece of a larger plan to help stimulate the New York City economy with bold construction projects and new jobs. To many politicians, the most significant aspect of the proposal is that it offers proof that someone is grappling with the city's problems at a time when they seem to be slipping out of control.
The proposed state assumption of Medicaid costs is certainly not an idea original to the Cuomo administration. But Mr. Cuomo is the first Governor to open a debate in Albany on the issue by formally proposing it. "This is something that every Governor knew needed to be done," said Meyer S. Frucher, a longtime adviser to Mr. Cuomo.
The high price of Medicaid in New York -- one of the few states in the country to require local governments to pay for part of the program -- has placed an enormous strain on municipal governments, most notably in New York City. But it is the tremendous escalation in Medicaid costs, even more than the cost itself, that has wreaked havoc on local budgets, prompting precipitous tax increases.
Over the last five years, Medicaid spending has grown 60 percent in New York. Last year, New York's program cost almost $12 billion, more than any other state's. Almost half this cost was picked up by the Federal Government; the rest was split between the state and local governments, with the state paying roughly 30 percent and the localities 20 percent.
 
Some of the Sales Tax
 Governor Cuomo has not revealed many details of the proposed shift, but he has made it clear that in return for the state's assuming the full cost of Medicaid it would expect local governments to hand over a portion of their tax revenues. In the case of counties like Nassau and Westchester, this would mean giving the state a portion of the county sales tax. In New York City, it would mean handing over either some of the city income tax or part of the sales tax.
Certainly it would be possible to arrange the swap so that when it took place -- most likely over the course of several years -- the additional taxes the state was taking in would equal the increased Medicaid costs it had assumed. But given the historic growth rate in Medicaid costs and the weakness of the state's income and sales taxes, the state's new costs would, over time, almost inevitably outstrip its new revenues.
In his address to business and civic leaders yesterday, the Governor portrayed the Medicaid swap as a measure intended to help New York City, something he has faced rising pressure to do. But the swap is more politically viable than most proposals to aid the city precisely because the city is not the only local government that it would help.
"It's hard to find a county that does not have significant cost growth in relation to their budget," said Assemblyman James Tallon, a Binghamton Democrat. "I think it is important that this is viewed as something that does not just benefit New York City."
 
Their Immediate Plight
 The benefits of the proposed swap for the city, which consumed almost 70 percent of the Medicaid dollars in the state last year, are clear. City officials have complained that the swap would not take place quickly enough to ease their immediate plight, but over time, the Governor has estimated that it would save the city $1 billion a year.
For counties with smaller Medicaid budgets, the advantages of the swap are less striking, but they are present nevertheless. In many rural counties, the growth rate for Medicaid costs rivals that of New York City, and the strain this growth places on small local budgets is proportionately grave.
If most local governments would benefit from a swap, then it follows that the state would lose. Indeed, Governor Cuomo estimates that the swap would leave the state with almost $2 billion a year in added Medicaid bills -- and that is if it is successful in containing the growth in Medicaid. These additional costs would inevitably translate into state tax increases or cuts in other programs.
Given these unpleasant inevitabilities, why should the Governor and the State Legislature be interested in a swap?
Those who advocate it, like Mr. Cuomo, argue that eliminating local governments from the Medicaid program will streamline its administration, making it easier and cheaper to run.
Advocates also argue that only by concentrating the responsibility for Medicaid with the state will it be possible to take the politically tricky steps necessary to cut costs. "It may be that a state-run system is something you need to really control costs," Mr. Tallon said.
