HEADLINE: MIDEAST DIPLOMACY;
Excerpts From Bush's Address to General Assembly: For a 'Pax Universalis'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's address today to the General Assembly:
My speech today will not sound like any you've heard from a President of the United States. I'm not going to dwell on the superpower competition that defined international politics for half a century. 
 Instead I will discuss the challenges of building peace and prosperity in a world leavened by the cold war's end and the resumption of history.
Communism held history captive for years, and it suspended ancient disputes and it suppressed ethnic rivalries, nationalist aspirations and old prejudices.
As it has dissolved, suspended hatreds have sprung to life. People who for years had been denied their pasts have begun searching for their own identities, often through peaceful and constructive means, occasionally through factionalism and bloodshed.
This revival of history ushers in a new era teeming with opportunities and perils. And let's begin by discussing the opportunities. First, history's renewal enables people to pursue their natural instincts for enterprise. Communism froze that progress until its failures became too much for even its defenders to bear.
And now citizens throughout the world have chosen enterprise over envy, personal responsibility over the enticements of the state, prosperity over the poverty of central planning.
 
Free Markets and Ideas
 The U.N. Charter encourages this adventure by pledging to employ international machinery for the promotion of the economic and social advancement of all peoples. And I can think of no better way to fulfill this mission than to promote the free flow of goods and ideas.

 	 	 		. . .	 	By the same token, the world has learned that free markets provide levels of prosperity, growth and happiness that centrally planned economies can never offer. Even the most charitable estimates indicate that in recent years, the free world's economies have grown at twice the rate of the former Communist world. Growth does more than fill shelves. It permits every person to gain, not at the expense of others, but to the benefit of others. Prosperity encourages people to live as neighbors, not as predators. Economic growth can aid international relations in exactly the same way.
Many nations represented here are parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Uruguay Round, the latest in the postwar series of trade negotiations, offers hope to developing nations, many of which have been cruelly divided, cruelly deceived by the false promises of totalitarianism.
Here in this chamber, we hear about North-South problems. But free and open trade, including unfettered access to markets and credit, offer developing countries means of self-sufficiency and economic dignity. If the Uruguay Round should fail, a new wave of protectionism could destroy our hopes for a better future.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I cannot stress this enough. Economic progress will play a vital role in the new world. It supplies the soil in which democracy grows best. People everywhere seek government of and by the people, and they want to enjoy their inalienable rights to freedom and property and person.
Challenges to democracy have failed. Just last month, coup plotters in the Soviet Union tried to derail the forces of liberty and reform, but Soviet citizens refused to follow. Most of the actions in this chamber stood with the forces of reform led by Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin and against the coup plotters.
 
Democracy Flourishes
 The challenge facing the Soviet peoples now, that of building political systems based upon individual liberty, minority rights, democracy and free markets, mirrors every nation's responsibility for encouraging peaceful democratic reform.
But it also testifies to the extraordinary power of the democratic ideal. As democracy flourishes, so does the opportunity for a third historical breakthrough: international cooperation.
A year ago, the Soviet Union joined the United States and a host of other nations in defending a tiny country against aggression and opposing Saddam Hussein. For the very first time, on a matter of major importance, superpower competition was replaced with international cooperation.
The United Nations, in one of its finest moments, constructed a measured, principled, deliberate and courageous response to Saddam Hussein. It stood up to an outlaw who invaded Kuwait, who threatened many states within the region, who sought to set a menacing precedent for the post-cold-war world.
The coalition effort established a model for the collective settlement of disputes. Members set the goal -- the liberation of Kuwait -- and devised a courageous unified means of achieving that goal.
And now, for the first time, we have a real chance to fulfill the U.N. Charter's ambition of working to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war, to reaffirm faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person, in the equal rights of men and women and nations large and small to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom. Those are the words from the Charter.
 
Nationalist Passions Flare
 We will not revive these ideals if we fail to acknowledge the challenge that the renewal of history presents. In Europe and Asia, nationalist passions have flared anew, challenging borders, training the fabric of international society.
At the same time, around the world many age-old conflicts still fester. You see signs of this, of this tumult right here. The United Nations has mounted more peacekeeping missions in the last 36 months than during its first 43 years.
And although we now seem mercifully liberated from the fear of nuclear holocaust, these smaller virulent conflicts should trouble us all. We must face this challenge squarely, first by pursuing the peaceful resolution of disputes now in progress.
Second, and more importantly, by trying to prevent others from erupting. No one here can promise that today's borders will remain fixed for all time, but we must strive to insure the peaceful negotiated settlement of border disputes.
We also must promote the cause of international harmony by addressing old feuds. We should take seriously the Charter's pledge to practice tolerance and live together in peace with one another as good neighbors.
 
Repeal Racism Resolution
 U.N.G.A Resolution 3379, the so-called "Zionism is racism" resolution, mocks this pledge, and the principles upon which the United Nations was founded, and I call now for its repeal. Zionism is not a policy. It is the idea that led to the creation of a home for the Jewish people, to the state of Israel. And to equate Zionism with the intolerable sin of racism is to twist history and forget the terrible plight of Jews in World War II and indeed throughout history.
To equate Zionism with racism is to reject Israel itself, a member of good standing of the United Nations. This body cannot claim to seek peace and at the same time challenge Israel's right to exist. By repealing this resolution unconditionally, the United Nations will enhance its credibility and serve the cause of peace.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Some nations still deny their basic rights to the people, and too many voices cry out for freedom. For example, the people of Cuba suffer oppression at the hands of a dictator who hasn't gotten the word, the lone holdout in an otherwise democratic hemisphere, a man who hasn't adapted to a world that has no use for totalitarian tyranny.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In a world defined by change, we must be as firm in principle as we are flexible in our response to changing international conditions. That's especially true today of Iraq.
Six months after the passage of U.N. Security Council Resolution 687 and 688, Saddam continues to rebuild his weapons of mass destruction and subject the Iraqi people to brutal repression. Saddam's contempt for U.N. resolutions was first demonstrated back in August of 1990, and it continues even as I am speaking. His Government refuses to permit unconditional helicopter inspections and right now is refusing to allow U.N. inspectors to leave inspected premises with documents relating to an Iraqi nuclear weapons program.
 
Keep Sanctions in Place
 And it is the United States view that we must keep the United Nations sanctions in place as long as he remains in power, and this also shows that we cannot compromise for a moment in seeing that Iraq destroys all of its weapons of mass destruction and the means to deliver them, and we will not compromise.
This is not to say -- and let me be clear on this one -- that we should punish the Iraqi people. Let me repeat: Our argument has never been with the people of Iraq. It was and is with a brutal dictator whose arrogance dishonors the Iraqi people.
Security Council Resolution 706 created a responsible mechanism for sending humanitarian relief to innocent Iraqi citizens. We must put that mechanism to work. We must not abandon our principled stand against Saddam's aggression.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The resumption of history also permits the United Nations to resume the important business of promoting the values that I've discussed today. This body can serve as a vehicle through which willing parties can settle old disputes.
In the months to come, I look forward to working with Secretary General Perez de Cuellar and his successor as we pursue peace in such diverse and troubled lands as Afghanistan, Cambodia, Cyprus, El Salvador and the Western Sahara. The United Nations can encourage free-market development through its international lending and aid institutions. However, the United Nations should not dictate the particular forms of government that nations should adopt, but it can and should encourage the values upon which this organization was founded.
Together we should insist that nations seeking our acceptance meet standards of human decency. Where institutions of freedom have lain dormant, the United Nations can offer them new life. These institutions play a crucial role in our quest for a new world order, an order in which no nation must surrender one iota of its own sovereignty, an order characterized by the rule of law rather than the resort to force, the cooperative settlement of disputes rather than anarchy and bloodshed, and an unstinting belief in human rights.
And finally, you may wonder about America's role in the new world that I have described. Let me assure you, the United States has no intention of striving for a Pax Americana. However, we will remain engaged. We will not retreat and pull back into isolationism. We will offer friendship and leadership. And in short, we seek a Pax Universalis, built upon shared responsibilities and aspirations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 911 words

HEADLINE: After 2 Killings on L.I., a Search for Answers

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARLE PLACE, L.I., Sept. 23

 BODY:
A day after an apparent argument between a security guard and five young men at the high school here ended with two of the men dead and three others injured, the people closest to the tragedy cannot agree on how things escalated the way they did.
To the distraught father of the 20-year-old security guard, who was charged with murder, his son's action was the inevitable response to an unbearable barrage of taunts and racial slurs. To the shocked parents of the victims, it was an eruption of violence beyond comprehension. 
 Here in this close-knit hamlet, where young people buy houses within blocks of their grandparents' homes and where no one remembers the last time someone was shot, or even mugged, residents are struggling to piece all the events together.
Some heard the shots, about 15 of them, fired at 2:30 A.M. Sunday in the parking lot of the high school, on a quiet suburban street in this mile-square community. Five men in their early 20's, who had graduated from school years earlier but continued to gather on weekend nights at the high school, had driven up in a 1982 yellow Cadillac, as they often did.
 
'There Was Some Involvement'
 By most accounts, the men, and others who frequented the school on weekends, had had a testy relationship with the security guard, John Padilla, ever since Mr. Padilla had begun working there two Saturdays earlier. While other guards had apparently allowed the men to congregate on school property after hours, Mr. Padilla had a strict policy of ordering them to leave. This made the men angry, said Detective Sgt. Robert Edwards of the Nassau County Police Department Homicide Squad.
"There was some involvement with these kids in the past," he said. "There may have been some eggs thrown on the defendant's car. There may have been some name-calling back and forth."
Two weeks before the incident, Sergeant Edwards said, the security guard had called the police to report that he was being harassed. But Albert Inserra, the superintendent of the Carle Place School District, said Mr. Padilla had never reported any trouble to him, as he was supposed to do. His log sheets for the first two Saturdays he worked, Mr. Inserra, said "all secure."
It is not certain what exactly happened between the guard and the men. But Mr. Padilla's father, who is also named John and is a 42-year-old electrician, said the young men had made the job miserable for his son, who had left New York City to make a new start for himself in the suburbs. When he was hired this summer by the H.S.C. Security Corporation, which patrols the schools here, the younger Mr. Padilla was on five years' probation for drug and weapons-possession convictions in New York City.
Mr. Padilla's father said that his son was hoping to put that behind him. With his wife, Nanny, and 6-month-old daughter, Christine, he had moved into a house in Brentwood. His father paid the rent and loaned him a black Audi, promising to buy him a car if he did well at work. "He wanted to prove to me he could hold on to a job," the elder Mr. Padilla said.
Speaking in an interview at Nassau County Police Headquarters, the elder Mr. Padilla said that on the two prior Saturdays, the men had thrown rocks and eggs at his son's car and had followed him home in their Cadillac, calling him names all the while. He had had to replace his son's windshield and car window, he said.
The men had used an ethnic epithet, he said, and added, " 'Puerto Rican, get out of here,' and he retaliated," the father said. "He was forced to do what he had to do out of desperation and fear."
But Robert Connor Sr., whose son, 23-year-old Robert Jr., was one of those killed, said it was the security guard who caused the trouble. Sitting in his small house not far from the school, surrounded by his grieving family, he said the guard had been harassing the men ever since he began working for the school district.
Mr. Connor said his son, who worked driving a coffee truck, had gone with his four friends to Little Italy on Saturday night before returning to Carle Place. The five, all of whom still lived with their parents, had grown up together and still spent much of their free time together, he said.
Sam Scotti, 23, who was wounded in the attack, lived across the street from the high school, and that was where he and others from the neighborhood gathered on weekends. "This is their home," said a neighbor, Samuel P. Caliendo. "The kids have been hanging out there since they were 12, 13 years old, and we've never had a problem."
Mr. Connor and Frank Scotti, Sam Scotti's father, both contended that on Sunday morning, Mr. Padilla had gotten into his car and chased the men, also in their car, into the high school parking lot. It was there that he pulled a 9-millimeter semiautomatic weapon out of his car, the police said, and opened fire.
The barrage killed Robert Connor Jr. and Dean Rose, 21, who was unemployed and lived in nearby Westbury. It wounded Sam Scotti, a landscaper; Peter Pinto, 21, a part-time roofer and carpenter, and Michael Russo, 22, a weightlifter and housepainter. Mr. Pinto was listed in critical condition at Nassau County Medical Center today, while Mr. Scotti and Mr. Russo were listed in critical condition at Winthrop-University Hospital.
The security guard pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and attempted murder in First District Court in Hempstead today and was held without bail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "There's no reason for it, no reason to be shot," said Robert Connor Sr., with his wife Maria and photo of his son, Robert Jr., who was one of two young men slain, reportedly by school security officer in Carle Place, L.I. (Kevin Coughlin for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1991

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Runs Against Florio, Who's Not Running

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
With control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature at stake in November, Republicans are running hard against a man who is not on the ballot -- Gov. Jim Florio. Democrats, if not openly running away from the Governor, do not want to run with him.
"Our strategy is quite simply to focus voter attention on the disastrous record of the Democrats and of Jim Florio," said Jeffrey Michaels, executive director of the Republican State Committee. "What we are doing in targeted districts is educating voters for the first time that the incumbent Democrats are responsible, telling them that Jim Florio could not have done it alone. They did it together." 
 Democrats concede that they have an unpopular Governor to contend with but question the impact that will have in November.
"Saying all Democrats are bums because Florio is will have only limited success," said Steven DeMicco, executive director of the Democratic State Committee.
 
Established Political Jargon
 Nonetheless, "the Florio factor" is already established political jargon in New Jersey, an integral part of discussions about races like the one in the 13th Legislative District in Monmouth and Middlesex Counties. Joseph Kyrillos, the Republican Assemblyman who is trying to take away the Senate seat of Jim Phillips, mentions the Governor and "the Florio tax plan" no fewer than four times in a 60-second radio commercial, and Mr. Phillips not once.
Mr. Phillips has countered by posing with a life-size cutout of Mr. Florio, which he dramatically shoves away, calling on his opponent to also "push aside Governor Florio as an issue in this race for State Senate."
The Governor's popularity plummeted when the Legislature adopted a budget that included a record $2.8 billion tax increase in June 1990, six months after Mr. Florio took office after a campaign in which he repeatedly assured voters that he did not think a tax increase would be necessary.
The extent of his decline in popularity was underscored in the latest Star-Ledger/Eagleton poll, which was released on Sunday. In that poll, 23 percent of the respondents gave the Governor an "excellent" (3 percent) or "good" (20 percent) rating, while 73 percent rated him "only fair" (39 percent) or "poor" (34 percent). The telephone survey of 800 New Jerseyans was conducted from Sept. 11 to 19 and has a sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
The poll suggested that about 2 million property tax rebate checks ranging up to $500 apparently did little to ease resentment over the tax increase. Neither did two other Florio programs: increased aid to local governments and school districts intended to halt or reverse soaring property taxes and an automobile insurance restructuring law intended to reduce premiums for most drivers.
Altogether, the polls could bode ill for Democratic legislators if the Republicans succeed in tying them to the Governor and his policies.
 
Setting Stage for Challenge
 The state and national Republican Party hopes to take advantage of Mr. Florio's poor showing to capture the Legislature, which would help offset the loss of the governorship, held by Thomas H. Kean for eight years. They also hope to embarrass Mr. Florio in the process, setting the stage for a strong Republican challenge in 1993.
To help in that effort, President Bush will be host at a fund-raiser on Tuesday at the Ramada Renaissance in East Brunswick to benefit Republican legislative candidates. A central theme at the event, which is expected to raise $800,000, will be "the Florio-Democrat tax and spend agenda." said Chuck Haytaian, the Assembly Republican minority leader.
Several other prominent Republicans, including Vice President Dan Quayle, John H. Sununu, the White House Chief of Staff, and Clayton K. Yeutter, the Republican National Committee chairman, have already visited the state in the last several months to help bolster Republican chances.
In the 19th Legislative District, including the Middlesex County municipalities of Perth Amboy, Sayreville and Woodbridge, the Republican challenger, Randall Corman, a Sayreville Council member, and the Republican committee are trying to portray Senator Laurence S. Weiss of Woodbridge, a four-term Democrat, as a leading architect of the Florio tax program.
Similarly, in the 10th District in Ocean County, Republicans are using the Florio issue against two Democrats, the incumbent Assemblywoman, Marlene Lynch Ford, and John Paul Doyle, an Assemblyman trying to step up to the Senate. Both voted for the tax package, but Ms. Ford was also the architect of the Homestead Tax Relief Act in 1985, which led to the largest property tax reduction in state history.
 
Another Problem
 The situation in the 10th District underscores another problem faced by Democrats: the retirement of several senior officeholders.
In the 10th, the former Senate President, John F. Russo of Dover Township, is not seeking re-election. Mr. Russo, who served five terms and rivaled governors in power, is one of four leading Democratic Senators whose departure will strip the party of incumbency power in their districts and, to an extent, reduce the party's fund-raising ability.
The others are Richard Van Wagner of Monmouth, who served five terms in the Assembly and two in the Senate; Daniel J. Dalton of Camden, the Democratic majority leader, and Carmen A. Orechio of Nutley, who served five terms and was a Democratic leader. Mr. Nutley lost his seat in redistricting. Another Democratic incumbent Senator, Thomas Paterniti of Edison, lost a primary race in which he spent $200,000, in part because he raised property taxes while Mayor of Edison.
Retirements also hurt Democrats in the Assembly, where five incumbents chose not to run. They are Edward H. Salmon of Ocean City, Joseph D. Patero of Manville, David C. Schwartz of New Brunswick, Frank M. Pelly of North Brunswick and James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge.
Only one Republican, former Assembly Speaker Chuck Hardwick of Westfield, decided not to run again.
 
More Level Playing Field
 The retirements, along with a stagnant economy, have created a more level playing field in several races.
All 40 seats in the Senate and all 80 Assembly seats are at stake in the November election.
If they gain control, the Republicans pledge to roll back the one-cent increase in the state sales tax that was imposed last year and to review increases in the income tax.
Assembly Speaker Joseph V. Doria Jr., who initiated the Florio legislative program, said the Republican call for a rollback of the sales tax increase "fails to provide a satisfactory answer to how the revenue will be made up."
"The Republicans seem to believe relief from 1 percent worth of sales tax will send residents into a spending frenzy," Mr. Doria said. "Don't Republican leaders understand that people would have to spend nearly $11 billion to make the sales tax revenue whole? Do the Republicans actually believe New Jerseyans have $11 billion in disposable income?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Senator Jim Phillips with a life-size cutout of Gov. Jim Florio, that he has used in his campaign for re-election. Mr. Phillips, a Democrat, dramatically shoves the cutout away, urging his Republican opponent, who is citing Mr. Florio's record as a campaign issue, to "push aside Governor Florio as an issue in this race for State Senate." (Chet Gordon for The New York Times)
